reviews.review: Worth a visit. Well-organised museum that has a clear purpose and executes upon it: History of Hong Kong up until 1997. Some visitors may be disappointed by the number of 'replica' items on display, but it doesn't really detract from the purpose of a chronological history. Nicely laid out and perspectives are balanced enough that it doesn't feel like propaganda.

Worth a few hours ..... Wandered in here and was very pleasantly surprised and educated. Knew little of Hong Kong history, geography, fauna, flora etc. up until we visited this free venue.
Lots to learn for all ages. Probably do with a little less static display but that's no big issue.
Overall, recommended.
Great visit. Our family of 4 spent around 2 hours here getting a good understanding of the HK history. The great thing about this is that it's free!! Didn't expect that so it was a bonus!

Great way to spend some time! . Recently while on a business trip to Hong Kong I had a few hours to fill before a flight out. Visited the Museum because the weather outside was awfully wet - it was a bit of a trek to get from the Tsim Sha Tsui MTR, but once in the Museum I easily spent 2 hours wandering! Entry on the Wednesday day was free and the exhibits are very interesting and I was glad I made the effort! A lack of time prevented me from viewing the Science Museum as well!
A must see. Went on a Wednesday which is free, so much culture to learn about and see. Planning on at least 3 hours to go thru.

Free entry to a very interesting exhibit. Over 3 floors of exhibits retelling the history of Hong Kong, where the people came from and traditional customs. Some amazing items especially in the traditional customs section. All in a large airconditioned space. If you are sick of shops, try the museum of history - worth a look in

If You Want to Understand How Hong Kong Evolved. If you are willing to invest an entire day, this well-designed museum will explain everything you need to know from the beginning to British colonization to Japanese occupation to the return of Hong Kong to the PRC.

Good place to visit, and you can take a break from the heat too. Went to the HK Museum of History on a recent visit to HK, my intentions were to go for a walk and get out of the heat and humidity of the day. I ended up really enjoying the museum as it has excellent displays of HK's both natural and cultural history. I also happened to go there on a day when the admission was free, so an added bonus. Exhibits, short films and overviews are in English as well as Chinese (Mandarin and Cantonese) character.

Wonderful !. My Wife's never visited anything like this before and she was simply AMAZED ! Thoughtfully laid out your tour allows you to travel through Hong Kong history, some great displays, short movies, and street layouts its really an interesting place to visit, and left her buzzing with excitement !

Interesting & informative. This must be the 3rd time I visited this museum, which for a small town like Hong Kong is a good testament to a will to demonstrate the island city's determination to maintain a place of its unique history in modern China, as well as its special position as an ex-British colony.Upon entering the museum, one would be firstly given a glimpse of the pre-historic world when the earth was young. An introduction to basic geology & specifically how this tiny piece of land came into being, including variety of rocks & special geological formations found over the years since the British took over this piece of barren land from a declining Qing Empire in late 19th century and turned it into s crown jewel of it's own.With the background stage set, more detail lessons are presented in chronological order of how the small British enclave developed itself into one of the so-called "4 small dragons" in Asia (economically speaking), especially so after the 2nd World War which brought in capitals, merchants & skills like no other times in Chinese history.While the more recent history may be more subdued or even plain, especially so after the return of Hong Kong to China, this museum is still a good place to start if one is interested to know how such a tiny place could have such a big impact on China's history, if not the world.

Wow - great place to visit on a Wednesday. Why Wednesday? Because all museums are free on Wednesdays. The history museum takes you on a multi-level, multimedia tour of Hong Kong through the centuries. Life sized exhibits, walk through areas and lifelike monuments abound. We loved the festival displays.
Nice, interesting museum. Free to visit on Wednesdays, plenty to see and do, we spent approximately 2.5 hours here, interesting for all ages.

Well presented History Museum. This modern Museum in Kowloon, chronicles the history of the Hong Kong area, beginning in prehistoric times all the way up to 1997. Well lit and designed displays are on two floors plus a mezzanine, with excellent didactics in Chinese and English. Several short films are shown in small theaters throughout the exhibits. They alternate in narration languages, but are always sub-titled in the other language. A nice facility, and worth a visit.

A place to know about Hong Kong history !!. Visited this museum in year 2011.It's really huge and informative, where you come to know about Hong Kong from past to present. Nice video presentations, sketches, statues, which gives you a real/lively feel. It's worth visit, if you are in HK. Suitable for all age group.

Excellent :). Comprehensive showcase of the history of Hong Kong starting from 400 million years ago. Many wonderful, lively displays, covering the many facets of the island's history. How the British came and bullied the Qing government into the cessation of HK for over 150 years. Pre and post-war depictions of her people, the handover back to the Chinese in 1997, and much more. Great way to spend the day. Oh, and it's free :)Definitely recommend.

A fantastic way to learn about Hong Kong's history. This is one of the best museums of its type that I have visited - and I've visited many! - covering the history of Hong Kong from prehistoric times through to the handback from Britain to China.There was no admission charge on the Thursday that I visited and although I paid the HKD 10 for an audio guide it wasn't really necessary as the English descriptions were so good. There are numerous short films to watch which are extremely informative - the showings in Cantonese have English sub-titles and vice versa, so no need to wait for the English versions.I learned so much, and the museum is thoughtfully laid out and easy to follow - and comparatively empty on the day I visited. I'd intended to pop in for an hour and ended up spending 3.5 hours there - I think this says it all!
so interesting learning about the british influence. great place to visit! definitely wouldn't miss this one. i'd say one of the best things to do in Hong Kong.
Make this your first stop. Great museum you can do within about an hour and a half. It will give you a great base of knowledge for the rest of your trip.

Learn a lot about HK. Seems like every wednesday the museum is free. auditory guide costs 10 hk dollar but wasn't necessary in my opinion. it gives a great overview about hong kong's diversity and culture and is must see for anyone who wants to know hong kong's background. since there are different exhibitions (history from stone age to current history, dynasties, opium war, japanese occupation) better plan to spend a couple of hours and take your time, there is a lot of input in there
Enlightening. We spent and afternoon at the Museum and it was well spent. The layout was good and the exhibits were clearly explained. I learnt a lot about Hong Kong's history.

Get a perspective of the HK Culture!. Lovely museum - they have built a story around the HK history - starting from the pre-historic time - to as recent as Britain handing over HK to China - everything in terms of culture gets covered - from the different traditional festivals to how pop culture evolved with cinema. The impact of the Japanese invasion demands special mention - don't miss all the small screenings - all shows available in English. Entry is free on Sundays.

Simple, educational, and clearly well loved by locals. Visited this museum as part of a short first trip to HK. Loved the simple explanations with artifacts. Learned lots of Interesting facts about history with different tribes eventually forming a nation. Great transition from Ancient to current history and events with lots of connections to understand impact on culture. Interesting description of events since 1997 and transition from Britain to ChinaI loved seeing a great number of families with kids here and the fact museum is free--which to me shows value system placed at making museums accessible to all. Great experience overall

Great showcase of history of HongKong. Amazingly done up place. Shows the evolution of HongKong using real exhibits and mock ups. Has video shows, audio guides and very very beautiful.Must see. I give this place number 1 in my to do list of things in HK.

Amazing. I love history museums and this is one of the best I've been to. Just stunning. I learned a lot about the British influence on Hong Kong. There was so much to see that I didn't get to finish before it was time to leave. Be sure to plan enough time if you like to savor every detail in museums.

Hong Kong History Specktacle. I spent a weekend at Hong Kong last September after a business trip. After attending Sunday mass at Rosary Church (Chatham Road), I decided to cross the street and visit the HK Museum of History.At exactly 10AM, the museum opened and there were already several people lining up. Inside the museum, there are several sections starting from how the Hong Kong Island were formed, the earlier settlers, dynasties,trade and commerce, culture, wars and revolution, etc. I've visited Hong Kong several times and this museum visit gave me a better perspective about the country.The admission is free, and it's best to allocate at least 3 hours to go through the museum. It can become confusing as you go through the different sections, but just follow the numbers and you should be good. They also allow free picture taking (which is what I did), and there are small cinemas per section which shows video documentaries.The museum is air conditioned, well maintained and there are even time slots where you can have a tour guide to go through the entire museum. It's absolutely a must visit place when travelling to Hong Kong. It's also beside the science museum, which I'm going to visit next time.

Interesting and informative . Starting with the geology of the region and bringing you swiftly to the opium wars and colonial rule. Interesting exhibit about the Japanese invasion in ww2 and also more recent culture. This museum is worth an afternoon. Displays are engaging and it's not too stuffy.

High Quality Museum for Free!. A very well presented museum, covering everything from Hong Kong's pre-history to modern times. Wonderful mixture of genuine objets, videos, interactive VDUs and high-quality convincing models. This gave it something for visitors of ALL ages. The building itself was very functional. It's just the right size for a family to cover in its entirety within a day, with an easy and natural route around. There are plenty of rest areas and toilets conveniently placed - even the cafe is positioned for a timely break halfway through the exhibits. My only criticism, if I had to find one, was that the final exhibits covering the transition of HK from GB to China seemed a bit too 2-dimensional for young children to notice or appreciate (especially compared to the rest of the museum).

Not to be missed. This is a large museum divided into sections from pre-history up to modern times. The earlier periods are interesting if you have that specific interest, but the joy of the visit comes in the more recent sections. Exhibits are super (a complete boat-dweller's boat - back- and font-stage of a Cantonese opera - a recostructed village house) and will appeal to older children as much as to parents. The whole visit needs at least two hours, but as it is free I recommend shorter visits on consecutive days. A really great experience.
A great few hours . What a win as this was free to visit and if it did cost I would pay as it was so well presented and detailed the history of HK brilliantly. Well done to the Museum people of HK.

A nice museum for a rainy day . This is worth an hour of your time, it takes you from prehistoric times right to modern times and Chinese folklore and it is free! Don't miss out on the Coffee shop which is nice priced.

Well curated and presented. Great museum that gives a holistic and in-depth look at Hong Kong's history from prehistoric to modern day. All exhibits are in English as well as Cantonese. I really enjoyed the Opium Wars sections as well as the different ethnic cultures exhibits which were very well presented. Go on a Wednesday for free admission!

Some interesting stuff. A good way to see how hong kong has changed accross the ages. Some amazing old artifacts and photos of hong kong in times past. A great way to see how much this part of the world has changed and get some historical context.

The exhibits are free!. I only had a little bit of time, and the museums open at 10am. There were school kids and others waiting with him for the opening. You enter and then take stairs down to the exhibit and then leave on the ground floor, you don't have to go back up.In Honk Kong cars drive on the left side, so people walk on the left side and so entrances to exhibits are on the left side. I ended up going into them on the right hand side and worked my way backwards. I did not have orientation problem on the first exhibit, but once you get arrows pointing you to the different exhibits, don't go the wrong way!There is an exhibit covering the various Chinese dynasties, but of course I was disoriented about the narrative Nonetheless what I did absorb was pretty cool.

Amazing!. I loved this museum. It got details and wonderful pictures on how the Brits made it to HK. I learnt a lot about HK's history by visiting this place rather than reading articles online. Museum is free, and the staffs are helpful.

a cool colourful exhibition of Hong Kong Heritage. we went on Saturday morning after 10 am, it was free entrance and uou , when you enter youare deepen inside some minerals and neolothic life but then , then you start the real journey through the local Chineeze culture and the city diferent community traditions and it was worth evey minute spent there , colourful pictures, it is open to mobiles - try it with your friends with your children please

Excellent. The museum offers an excellent and very vivid history of Hong Kong. It is really informative, and provides a lot of details about the history of Hong Kong and life there in earlier times. But it's not just 'dry' tidbits of information on panels, the execution is masterful - the museum has lots of items and the rooms are designed to put you in the right atmosphere. Me and my friend spent 3 hours here, and it was just fascinating.

Good snapshot of culture and history.. A great well thought out museum. Short movies play throughout the day outlining cultural events.There is a good cafe and conveniences available, it is easy to reach by MTR. Nice souvenir shop.

Really good history museum and free!. The weather forecast was for rain so we went to the museum ( however there was no rain at all today!). We came straight from the airport on the Airport Express train MTR to Kowloon then caught free T3 airport shuttle bus alighting at Hotel Icon. It is a short walk up Glanville street then R to arrive at museum. Next door is the Science Museum, but it is closed on Thursdays. There were several school groups there lining up, but this did not spoil our visit. I really learned a lot about the history of Hong Kong, especially in regards to trade and politics and war. There are short movies all around the museum which bring the history to life, and even if the English version is not running straight away you can read subtitles on the Chinese version if you don't want to wait.We ran out of steam to do justice to downstairs with its prehistory and folk culture- jjust whizzed through.We had lunch at the cafe of wonton soup, Chinese greens in hoisin sauce and drink for 45 HKD each. Good value, although I did not enjoy the flavour of the soup much.Really informative museum.

Well curated and good guide. We were only able to see the Hong Kong Story but I must say it was worth the afternoon trip. It was well curated, seeing artifacts from prehistoric time, through the British administration and up to modern times. There are lots of pictures, videos and memorabilia from each era so you learn a lot about how Hong Kong came to be. I would suggest joining the free museum guided tour (in diff. languages every hour or so) because you get valuable inputs from locals themselves.
MUST SEE. This is the best place for an overview of Hong Kong. It's an easy museum to get to and has a lot to see and it's free.

Great Museum and Free Admission too!. Very well maintained museum with 8 sections of exhibits that include pre-historic through to modern Hong Kong. Culture and religious practices also explained clearly. Many items of nostalgia on display. Lots of seats within for tired legs. Excellent and worthwhile visit.

Unbelievable good. To be honest I didn't have the world's highest expectations for this museum but my opinion after my visit is nothing but favorable. Everything about this museum is beautiful, smart, and genuinely interesting. The free permanent exhibition commences with natural history and moves into archaeological finds and area culture such as fishing and opera. The second floor is devoted to the British side of history and after, which eventually leads to a wonderful exhibition about later 20th century HK. The museum is laid out perfectly, and signs are everywhere suggesting the best route to take to see everything. The artifacts/settings/pieces throughout the museum were thoughtfully picked out and beautifully displayed. They have entire settings on old British post offices, houses, tea shops, etc. which bring an abundance of life to this museum. Did I mention it was free? Gosh, I'm picky about my museums but this one really knocked my socks off. What a fantastic learning experience and time spent.

Well curated museum. on this trip, I only did Hong Kong Story but I have visited other parts in the past which are informative and interesting. Hong Kong Story is an easy way into its geological and historical progress through the ages. It is a good museum for children with large models of animals and imaginative prehistoric scenes as well as colonial shops and some excellent films. Avoid eating in the restaurant which is more of a canteen than a place for a light lunch and the food is very greasy.

Down the memory lane. So glad we set aside time to visit this museum in the morning first. We planned to stay for a couple of hours. We ended up staying far longer and had lunch in the restaurant on site half way through our visit. We spent at least 4 hours and could have stayed even longer. Given this was our last day in HK, we traded our intended trip to Soho with longer stay here.We breezed through section 1 and 2, and focused our time on the Hong Kong history. Section 3 and 4 were wonderful, displaying the past HK culture. Section 5 to 8 mostly depicts the political evolutions from the past to the recent events. There were not many visitors, it was a change of pace from the crowd in TST and central. The information was presented in a chronological order, very easy to navigate and connecting the dots. We really appreciate having the opportunity to visit such a wonderful museum.

Hong Kong history at its best!. Extensive prefabricated structures of historical artefacts can be found here ranging from figurines to big structures to give a very nice and accurate representation of the history. A very interesting place to visit.

An Absolute Must!. What an amazing museum. We intended to just pop in but ended up staying several hours and wished we could have stayed longer.If you want to get to grips with the history of the place in a lively, colourful and interesting way, this has to be for you.
Learn about the history of HK!. One of my favorite museums in Hong Kong. Their permanent exhibit covers Hong Kong's history since the beginning of time

Highly Recommend. A very thorough history of Hong Kong with a starting point 400 million years ago. A very insightful mix of culture, different people of the region, dynasties, politics, economic development and historic milestones (including WW II and 1997).

GOOD for Rainy days , cold weather or escape the heat. BARGAIN AT 10 Hong Kong Dollars.......$1.30 USDMuch to see and learn .....check website for exhibit info or just go for such low cost ...Much variety in exhibits !

Roman Navy and Pompeii. Caught the last day they had the ancient Roman Navy and Pompeii Exhibit. Got in just about an hour before closing. The exhibit was only $10 which was a real surprise. They did not, however, allow photos to be taken....which I found quite odd.
Start your Hong Kong visit here. Very interesting and informative displays and short films in English or with subtitles. Was also free entry today (Saturday).

do it. found this place on a rainy day by chance....it is very very good....the day we went it was free.....the whole layout was extremely well done with reconstruction of streets with shops and houses.....interesting history with full size Sanpan ....amazing displays and diaramas....you will love it......

Free. Air-conditioned. Great for kids (and adults). We caught the MRT to Tsim Sha Tsui Station (or you can go to Jordan and walk back) - it's about 800 m (10 min walk).Depending on the children's ages, you could spend hours here. We (two adults, no children) spent an hour checking out different historical sections - watching some short films (6 - 8 mins long) and generally enjoying a vastly different 'museum' to what we are used to.There were plenty - lots - of children, but all under control, and not a distraction.People say that it should be your first stop - and perhaps that's true with children - but either way, if you are on the Kowloon side of town, absolutely stop for an hour or two and enjoy the Hong Kong history.

Very informative . Been to HK many times and never been here it's definitely worth going if you want to know the history of HK and how the British came to occupied it for 100+ years and how it developed from a basic farming village. Very easy walking through it with multiple levels. They have many mini theaters with short movie clips in English, Cantonese and Mandarin. I was only able to spend about 1.5 hours here but honestly you could easily spend 3 hours here. You should come if you want to kill some time and gain some knowledge of Hong Kong

Encapsulates & conveys the broad span of History of the 'Pearl of the Orient'. This museum in the TST part of Kowloon is very comprehensive in the way it covers many different areas of history - HK prehistory, local history, coastal defence, the Opium Wars, British colonial history, Japanese Occupation, cultural history, natural history, & so on. I first visited HKMH in 2002 & it was first-rate then & it has only gotten better! I especially like the part in one section of the exhibition where you find yourself walking across a Chinese junk which functions as a bridge (I have seen this feature copied by other, newer museums). Entry to the museum's permanent exhibition, "The Hong Kong Story" is free of charge.

Outstanding museum. Can't believe this was free! Great, ENORMOUS museum. Do yourself a favor and skip through the geological and neolithic galleries to get to the awesome main feature areas - cultural history of HK and history of the opium wars & British colonial era. We came at the end of the day and spent about 2 hours, wish we had twice that time. Really an outstanding museum.
Well done and very interesting. Large well organised and very interesting museum. A wide range of exhibits about history, culture, theatre, disasters. When we visited it was free entry.

Really interesting ....and free. For anyone who wish to have some historic knowledge about Hong Kong , this is a great place. The presentation is really fun , easy going but complete at the same time. Our teenagers without a fluent English enjoyed this visit and learnt a lot about HK.Worth a visit for sure !

Mixed opinion. Clearly a lot of money has been put into this but got bored rather quickly, also they seem to have ignored the British occupation of HK so not much about that apart from the withdrawal in 1997 (fair enough to them really but I would have been interested to know more about it)
Well worth visiting.. They've done a great job here, taking you through several periods of the history of HK from prehistoric to present day.
wheelie great day out. This was a very interesting place well worth a visit, the whole place is wheelchair friendly and has some great exhibitions

A museum as it should be, fun, informative and free!. This museum about the history of Hongkong has divided the history in 8 stages, visualized (and recreated) in 8 exhibitions. In enjoyed it very much because you can see the attention thas was put into the exhibitions, the texts are concised but clear, and there are lots of photo's, paintings and objects (there is a tram, an old grocer shop, a boat from the boat people among other things). I especially like the part about the diverse ethnic groups, the English period and the historic clothes.So if you have a saturdau or sunday off, take the mtr to Kowloon. Admission is free

A Must see!. Anyone interested in knowing Hong Kong natural and human history should go here! Absolutely outstanding exhibits on Hong Kong culture. Air conditioned and great way to spend a hot afternoon.

Really interesting . Really interesting and gave us a chance to learn more about Hong Kong. Everyone enjoyed a different part - my advise would be to make sure you don't miss a bit going into an area and going out another exit. Plus there was clean flush toilets.

Good overview of Hong Kong history. Nice facility with history of Hong Kong in displays, pictures and short films. Free of charge. Takes 2 or 3 hours to see all exhibits. Young children would be bored because there is no hands-on exhibits.

Comprehensive, interesting museum - must see!. Tucked away from the tourist hubbub is this excellent museum, just beside the Science Museum. It has eight galleries on two levels, staring with the geological history of the city and working up to the present day. There is much to see, and there's a good balance of text (in Chinese and English) and displays, many of them quiet colourful. There are also numerous film theatres one can sit in for short films. If you want to learn about the city's origins and history, this is THE place to do it. Highly recommended - and it's free! I took about two hours to go through the whole museum.

Second half is brilliant. We visited the museum and it was free entry to the permanent exhibition - The Hong Kong story. The exhibition is split into 8 sections but we were rather underwhelmed by the first half as most items on display were just replicas and the displays were pretty dated.The last 4 sections were super impressive, both context and exhibits - especially the exhibition on WWII. We spent 3.5 hours here but watched all the films. The science museum was closed when we visited the history museum but as it is next door, I would recommend doing both on the same day.

Good idea!. I came here just because the Science museum was packed, and it was the best idea ever. Perfect place to know more about Hong Kong (it really makes you see the city with different eyes after the visit), run away from the heat, and have a nice afternoon. Good explanations, exact amount of information, a lot of visual contents, and it´s free!
Worth the time spend there understanding the history. A great museum! With so many informations about Hong Kong that can spend up to 3 hours there. Admission was free and good food around that area.

Fascinating View of Hong Kong's Birth and Existence. I walked to the Museum of History from my hotel and was pleased with the exhibits showing the birth of Hong Kong, and as a bonus, saw the exhibit on the fall of Pompei. Cost for senior was only 5 HK$. Was worth the journey here.
excellent cultural and historical of Hong Kong. World class museum, much to learn and absorb--then going out into modern day Hong Kong to make your own memories and personal history. Excellent

A good way to start your visit to Hong Kong. Admission was free when we visited the museum one Saturday afternoon. We thought it would help set the scene for a week's holiday and that is exactly what it did. Impressive displays that detailed Hong Kong's history and culture. A short walk from Hung Hom MTR Station.

Well worth the trip. This museum is amazing. You will need to plan on spending at least 3 hours if you really want to immerse yourself into the history of Hong Kong. You will first start millions of years ago and they will tell you how the island was formed. Its very fascinating especially if you are into geology. I love the other exhibits as well. All of them are very well organized.

A must for any HK visitor. I was wrong to think this museum has not much to offer. It has 8 halls with the history, starting from a geological, anthropological and historical development of the city. And the best is that it was FREE! Only the special exhibit is not.

History of Hong Kong. A very nice museum for local or tourist to visit as you can walk through the development of Hong Kong. From a small village, colonial, industrial and now metropolitan. I found my childhood village house and felt very familiar. Lot of great fond memories recovered. Located at Tsim sha Tsui east station very convenience to visit. A highly recommended museum for tourist.

A must for a visitor!. I spent a morning at The Story of Hong Kong - most worthwhile and highly recommended for anyone to appreciate the city and the history. The exhibitions are very well done, the short movie interactions were great too.

Fascinating, informative exhibition. Really educational and informative set of exhibition halls covering HK history from prehistoric times through to the Chinese regaining the territory in 1997. Everything you need to know is presented in a spacious air conditioned environment, there are many exhibits and numerous short film presentations in dual languages that summarise and illustrate key parts of the History. The World War 2 section is particularly memorable with the Japanese occupation well detailed. Free entry to the main exhibition, and a must do.

A great place to visit.. This is an amazing find. It tries to cover a lot from Stone Age through to modern day. It is well laid out, you can skip things that are not of interest to you but linger in others. We thoroughly enjoyed the experience, particularly the modern history for Hong Kong. The videos were also very informative. Well worth the visit and there is a very small entry price of HKD $10 pp.

Great museum to visit . It's not a very big museum but it covers most aspects of Hong Kong - nature, history, old festivals and life styles. the admission is not expensive and it's free on Wednesdays!!
FOR HISTORY LOVERS !!!. Good location in Kowloon...well connected ..friendly staff...Don't miss the hong kong story movie...enjoyable
The history of Hong Kong for a rainy day. The history of Hong Kong exhibit is really well done. This is a highly recommended rainy day activity. Follow up with high tea and the day is complete!

The Hong Kong Story is a highlight of every trip to hkg for us.. Great museum, currently free admission (August 2016) love the room sets of old hong kong and information on folklore etc. My children always enjoy a trip here. they have been several times over the last 15 years and each time they have enjoyed it and learnt a little more.
Fantastic Museum!. A really well maintained, informative museum detailing Hong Kong's fascinating history. Don't miss it!

Outstanding attraction. This museum must rate as one of the main attractions in Hong Kong with eight themed sections from prehistoric to modern day. Well presented artefacts displayed in a modern, air-conditioned building with a reasonably priced cafeteria. Admission to the permanent display is free - temporary exhibitions have a small entrance fee. You should plan to spend at least half a day here, and can combine with a visit to the science museum next door.
Interesting. The Hong Kong Story was very interesting. I recommend visiting the museum while in Hong Kong, preferably as the first destination on your visit!

Not as I expected. Honestly I expected more from my visit to hong kong museum of historyIn my final day in hong kong I thought it would be a great idea to visit it.I can see that the place is little old. There is lack of creativity in it. Perhaps new ideas So it is fine to know about the country but expect much

One of the best museums I've visited . The main and free permanent exhibition of this museum is a full history of Hong Kong, starting from prehistoric times right through to 1997 and the handover from British rule back to China.There is so much to take in, it will take a good few hours to see and take in everything - maybe even needing to return for a second viewing.It is a very impressive and engaging exhibition with mock replicas ranging from boats to Chinese opera staging and a 19th century tea house which really brought everything to life. My personal favourite was a mock up of an old street, complete with a variety of period appropriate shops and buildings. Be warned that the exhibition space can, at times, be so vast that you can get slightly lost and miss out entire sections of the exhibition.There is another temporary exhibition space, when we visited it was hosting an exhibition on Pompeii. These are not free entry unless otherwise stated.There is a reasonably priced restaurant within the museum, or you can easily find food along the main road outside.Finally - if history doesn't interest you so much, the science museum is conveniently located just opposite!

Great insight into 20-21st century Hong Kong . The museum is great. The layout takes you through the history chronologically and there is a great mix of artefacts, films and sets. I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in the complex history of Hong Kong!

Break from the Heat! Free Entry/Good History . This is a small museum focused on the history of Hong Kong that has a free entrance to its permanent halls. I am a history fan, but I will admit I mostly recommend coming here to escape the summer heat of Hong Kong! Apparently everyone else had that same idea. Nevertheless, it's a great place to learn the history of Hong Kong. I specifically liked The Opium Wars hall and the Japanese Occupation hall (I knew very little about this before coming to the museum and found the information interesting and well presented). The layout of the museum could be better and there are significant gaps in the time periods/storyline, but it still gives you a general idea of the era. I'd recommend a visit even if there would be an entry fee. It's a nice way to get a better understanding for Hong Kong and it's people.

Free and excrllent. 2 adults and 2 teens. Our first visit to HK. This museum took us 4 hours to work around - so much to learn. It really set us up with a basic knowledge of the place. I'd skip the cafe on the ground floor - naf and nasty

So much history to be educate on. Great museum. Ancient history comes to life with the life size exhibits. Modern history portrayed with multimedia and movies. Loved it. I could go several times to cover it all if time permitted.

Great place to escape the heat of the day. A really interesting museum. We enjoyed the cultural exhibits on the lower floor, a good cup of tea in the cafe and then some fascinating exhibits upstairs about the Opium Wars, British control, Japanese occupation, post war years and the handover. The video presentations are well worth watching and very informative. The geological history at the start was interesting but for us the best bits came later. We only had two hours bit could easily have spent longer.

So and so. Hong Kong as a big city has its museums, but you don't go to places like Hong Kong and Singapore for museums? It is not Louvre or Hermitage, and even without a high expectation, you are not recommanded to spend your time in it.

Hong Kong: Year BC to 1997. This was a great little museum and, despite what the website said, admission was free. Provides a great overview of the geography, history, culture, and politics of Hong Kong. Some of the exhibits are a little lacking in details (for example, on the Opium Wars - I ended up having to give my husband a history lesson to fill in the blanks here), but others are extremely detailed and informative (life during the Japanese occupation, for example). Somewhat inexplicably, history seems to end with the handover to China in 1997. On the whole, I'd recommend it to visitors looking to learn more about HK's history, or looking for an indoor activity/way to beat the heat. Given the price, I have no complaints!

Recommended to better understand HK culture. We took the visit on the day with free entrance, but I believe we would have appreciated differently the places we visited if done upfront. The museum starts humbly, but as you go deeper things become more and more interesting so don't get discouraged after a few steps. Reserve about 2h to see it at a quick pace, but if sufficient time on your hands about 4h would do the trick. Make sure to stop and see the "shows" -- small cinemas with videos depicting the section you are in as they will very well summarize the section.

Go here if you have time for just 1 museum!. Beautifully laid out museum that covers everything about the history of Hong Kong, from prehistory to the present. Lots of videos being shown where you can rest your feet and learn more about the history and culture. It's a must-see. Admission is free on Wednesdays!

The Story of Hong Kong. A history buff with time on my hands I decided to visit this museum without any real agenda. While I had a difficult time getting there, a nearly walked around the entire building before finding the entrance I ended up spending a full day there. There was a traveling exhibit about Pompeii 's 79 AD eruption that was stunning. Well presented it was worth the exhibit cost. As to the history of Hong Kong we start 400 million years in the past and follow an amazing history of flora, fauna, land and ultimately man. It was great fun, and left all questions about Hong Kong's place in history. Considering its relationship to China, the western traders, English ultimate sovereignty, the Japanese capture, back to England and its unique existence in China again today, I left finally understanding Hong Kong and its place in history. Yes, it's worth a visit. There's a great gift store and restaurants so you won't starve or be able to leave empty handed!

Explore the Hong Kong's history and Being a british colony.. Explore the history behind of a place where the East meets West. It is a special place to discover more about the Hong Kong's History and being Asia's number one. Proper nice place to chill and teach your little kids more about Hong Kong.The museum has kept a lot of things that belongs to the 1940, 50, 60s.Everytime my family goes in there it reminds them of their childhood and how Hong Kongers used to live in this place.

A story telling museum, worth a visit!. A must visit place in Hong Kong, It is good for both residents and tourists. Everything is presented in a very attractive way, not a boring museum, more like a story teller. My favorite part is the old Hong Kong culture and tradition, from a fisherman village to a modern city. You could definitely get to know more about Hong Kong after the visit.Nevertheless, the permanent exhibitions are opened to all free of charge starting from 1 Aug 2016. Please note that the museum is closed on Tuesdays.
Interesting place !. Learning about HK with interesting exhibit items. Visited with my grandmother and kids, lots of talk after the trip! Good family time!

10 HKDs for a morning exploring Hong Kong's history.. Very informative, interesting and I felt honest outlook on Hong Kong's history. The entrance fee was 10 HKD which for the city is a phenomenal price for a morning/ afternoon activity. The museum was very clean, well laid-out, and enjoyable. Plenty to see/ watch and I particularly enjoyed the gallery about Japanese occupation. A must if visiting Hong Kong.

Good summary of Hong Kong's history. It's a good and cheap way to have a brief idea of Hong Kong's history: the historical attractions are very well reconstructed (except the one from paleolitic era) with really cool models and not too much people around, even during weekends.It doesn't make you feel in need of going back after your first visit, but it's a nice walk for a relaxing cultural morning/evening.

Very interactive museum! . For $10 (skip the current Pompeii exhibit if you've already been to one) you get to spend around two hours walking through Hong Kong's history from prehistoric to present. The exhibition follows a very clear path which sees you wind your way through lots of recreated scenes from Hong Kong's past - there's an old fishing boat to climb aboard, houses from the 1600s to peak into, and a particularly good recreation of a Hong Kong street in the 1800s under the British Empire. The information is there if you want to read it, but really it's fun to just see and experience.There is a café and toilets at the halfway point should you need them, and the shop offers an interesting range of items for potential souvenirs. If you're interested, there are tours in English at various points throughout the day - check for times.

A fantastic bargain, a fantastic museum: informative, engaging, but still authentic. From the outside, the building doesn't look like much. We made a huge circle around the whole building just trying to find the rather unassuming entrance. The lobby looks rather dreary, though it's bustling with activity. The ticket is a great deal, just HK$10 per person, including the temporary exhibition, which was about Pompeii. The permanent exhibition "Story of Hong Kong" was excellent. Though Hong Kong has perhaps not the most glamorous history in the world, they present their story very nicely, but at the same time not "dumbing it down", like some museums do. They began with talking about Hong Kong's geology and the natural environment. Especially impressive were large dioramas showing you the various plants and animals in Hong Kong: educational, yet engaging for all ages. Then they move on to the first prehistoric settlers, and then Hong Kong during Imperial Chinese rule. After that, you go up two floors on the escalator for more galleries, beginning with the Opium Wars and the start of British rule, and ending with a film of the 1997 handover ceremony. The museum is very well organized, with a numerical sequence to each of the galleries and clearly marked signs. While some places were very crowded (with school groups), towards the end of the exhibition there was hardly anyone to be seen, and was quite peaceful.The actual historic artifacts are not very impressive (just some pottery, weapons, functional items, etc.). But their reproduction displays immerse you in every time period, from inside an ancient tomb discovered in Hong Kong, to a reproduction merchant boat from early British rule, to nostalgic replicas of 1960s-era homes and businesses in Hong Kong. Rather than being a display area for historical items, everything's presented very much like a narrative. It's not the "Gallery of Hong Kong", but the "Story of Hong Kong". And while some "living history museums" may end up oversimplifying things or making things way too corny, this museum does it unpretentiously, with informative description placards and actual films from each time period playing in the galleries to retain authenticity.After going out for lunch, we returned to visit the special exhibit, which was about Pompeii and the Roman navy. Once again, the actual items on display were rather unimpressive, but it makes up for it through engaging films and reproduction displays to create an immersive atmosphere. An 8-minute 3D film showed a computer simulation of Pompeii's demise, hour by hour. There was no narration, which somehow just made it all the more frightening. We didn't expect to spend very long, but we stayed well into the afternoon. This museum is easily a whole day activity, and for just HK$10 per person, extremely worth it! A trip to Hong Kong is not worth it without visiting this museum.

HK Museum of History. I recommend visiting this first or as soon as possible. Gives one a solid background for this unique city's history that is no longer evident in it's modern state. Can be toured in 1.5 hours or less, if you move quickly.

History Never Dies. It is a very lovely museum in Hong KongI.If you have a second thought to go there,it is a big mistake .Dig the culture or History of Hong Kong in there. You don't need to pay entrance fees for all museums on Wednesday.

Great museum. This is a fascinating museum documenting the story of HongKong from 400 million years ago how the environment developed and changed, through prehistoric times, the dynasties, culture, opium wars and British control, Japanese occupation during the war and modern growth of the city until the time when it returned to China. Interesting information panels in English and Chinese, about 10 audiovisual presentations ranging from 5 to 10 mins alternating English with Chinese subtitles and Chinese with English subtitles. Many models and recreation scenes, especially in the later galleries. It is well laid out and you are lead through the 8 galleries over 2 plus split floors. There is an audio guide available too. I spent over 2 hours.

Lots to learn in a well-thought out venue. A week later I still remember the fascinating history of Hong Kong. The exhibit combined artifacts, videos, and clear explanations, making it one of the better history museums I have been to (frame of reference: The Smithsonian)

Go here first.. Before you attempt to explore Hong Kong make this place your first visit and the rest of it will make so much more sense and your trip will have much more point to it. You'll leave with a better understanding of the culture.

Free on Wednesdays. The Museum shares the history of Hong Kong in an organised manner..From how it came about to the handover..Various timelines with various stories depicted. Museum of History is free on Wed but not free for other exhibits..

A must visit. One of the best history museums in the world. The display takes you from beginning of Hong Kong till present day. Its so well put together that at times you feel you are walking through a time tunnel. The displays are created as towns that you wander through. Throughout are archive movies in black and white of the era you are visiting. Good clean rest rooms and cafe. All exlpanations both in English and Chinese. Tickets are discounted for seniors over 65. Great way of visually learning about the history of the place you are touring. Also perfect for children.

Nice insight into the city.. Presents Hong Kong's history in a direct, insightful way. I had read up on the city before I came, so this place was a nice way to reinforce that knowledge. Of course it glances over some recent developments, but oh well.

Informative and entertaining.. So much information, so nicely presented. i particularly liked the street reproduction, complete with the Ding Ding. The hall with the festivals showcased was excellent too. The history of this city is fascinating, and sensitive topics like the war and handover, were presented openly and (in what seemed to me) a balanced way. My only suggestion would be to add more post 1997 content, as the city continues to have a great story to tell. I highly recommend a visit to this museum for locals and tourists alike.

A great introduction to Hong Kong. Although there is an entrance fee it is not expensive - currently 20HK$. Worth every penny. This contemporary museum is engaging. The exhibits are well presented. It is easy to spend many hours here so ideal if raining.

Insight into Hong Kong . My husband & I visited the museum on a Wednesday and to our surprise entry was free that day. This was the part of the trip tailored tony husband as he's a real history buff. I thoroughly enjoyed the massive museum that takes you through prehistoric times right through the dynasties to culture and even has mock ups of old ships and ancient dwellings. It gives great insight into the History of HK and transports you back to how the people lived before. That is the part I really enjoyed getting to go into the houses, shops etc. there were also short clips on the history esp the Japanese invasion etc that I enjoyed watching. If you are looking to understand modern HK culture a stop here will give you insight into it. A must see on your next visit!

a Must Go and See. The exhibits are fun - and nicely replicated. Recommended for youngsters 10 and over who can read a lot of the plaques to get the flavor of Hong Kong history. If you have little ones, unless they are in a stroller - would be hard for you to go through the exhibit. I grew up in Hong Kong and there are a lot of things I did not know about my own history. It is very educational and an eye opening. There are permanent and rotating exhibits. The permanent one is the MUST if you are short of time - be prepare to spend 3-4 hours there if you are going through it to capture details.

A Holiday Highlight.. The Hong Kong Museum of History is an amazing spot to visit! Great for all ages, the site features many historical artifacts and is a learner's paradise. I learnt a lot from visiting the museum and was surprised by its size. There is a lot to see and I appreciated the explanations available. The entrance cost was only 10 HKD (Cheap!). I would definitely recommend this site to travellers!

Not Boring at all. This Museum is totally worth visitThis is one of the museum that won't make you feel boredThe entrance ticket is 10HKD ( For Student 5HKD)Audio Guide 10 HKDIt will take you at least 1-2 hours to finish walking inside, of course faster if you skip all the audio visual cinema, the audio visual cinema provided in 3 languages ( Cantonese, Chinese and English )They even have English subtitle in the Chinese session one

Interesting and learned a bunch!. At first we just walked through the exhibits but caught up with a tour guide. Definitely get a tour guide!! He went into details and taught so much about the history that we wouldn't have known otherwise. Nothing compares to the experience of a local in our opinion.

Great museum (skip the audio guide though). I thoroughly enjoyed this museum. I'm not big on prehistoric history so I skipped that part but the opium wars and japanese occupation were extremely interesting. I'd skip the audio guide as it doesn't add a lot to the texts that are on display. They also have excellent video showings at each exhibition. I would recommend sticking around to see all of those. Don't bother waiting for the English version either the chinese version is subtitled so just pop in as soon as a showing is starting.

Very well-made history museum that takes you through prehistory to the 1997 release of Hong Kong to China by England.. After being disappointed by a number of subpar museums in Hong Kong, I was impressed by how great the musuem of history was!The Hong Kong Museum of History is one of my favorite places to go in Hong Kong! For a low admission price of $10 ($5 for seniors), you can easily kill a few hours seeing displays and reading the rich history of Hong Kong. You start off the museum by seeing the geological side of Hong Kong. Including animals that used to live here and how prehistoric people used to live. As you go through the museum, you pass by the eras such as the Kowloon Walled City, Hakka villages, wedding traditions, Cheung Chau bun festival, through when the British took over, as well as when the Japanese took over during World War 2. Finishing up with when China took back Hong Kong and how people used to live in the 70s, 80s and to date. I'm greatly impressed by how detailed this museum was. Not only do they have displays, but they actually have a replica old street you can walk through to live like the old days. Personally I think the most interesting part was when the Japanese took over. It's something you don't hear much of. Seeing how Hong Kong looked like back when the British was in charge was pretty cool too.Overall this is easily the best museum in Hong Kong locals and visitors can both enjoy! It's also conveniently located by east Tsim Sha Tsui. If heading there by MTR, the closest way is to Jordan station Austin road exit.

Lots to see . There are multiple floors to this museum, when we went last week it's was free entry in Wednesday, only 10HKD usually so inexpensive, the higher floors were really interesting, lots of different exhibits and interesting mini documentaries to watch. Worth a visit!
Great. Interesting place, a lot to see. Takes you through the history of china in a Great way. Free entrance on wednesdays!

The Best Museum you must see in Hong Kong. Displays here cover everything from the geology of HK, Neolithic human settlement & subsequent waves of mainland settlers arriving from other areas of China. The Han burial tomb is reconstructed, plus traditional villages, fisher people houseboats, colonial architecture, Japanese occupation & more. The best cultural display we saw in Hong Kong. Drop over to the bar at Ikon hotel for a drink afterwards.

Very informative and expressive. Such a detailed history tour along with audio visual displays. The collections are detailed and vibrant covering every aspect of the HK history. Especially liked the festivals and culture section and the Pompei area. It's a must visit

Well worth a visit . Looking for a complete overview of HK history ? do not miss this 'museum'. It presents the story of HK from prehistoric times thru to reunification in an interesting and engaging way, coupled with an introduction to various cultural insights - it is unfortunate that it is not given a higher profile in the various 'to do lists'. Allow 2-3 hours to view.

A must visit if you want to know the history of HK. I've been to Hong Kong many times and this was the first time I'd ever gone to the museum. It's really cheap to get in, but don't think that it's a bad museum. It covers everything from how the Hong Kong islands were formed all the way to present day. You are able to walk into and around re-creations of different businesses and streets from different time periods, which was really cool to see.

Free on Wednesday . The HK Museum of History is an excellent choice of wet weather activity. The informative and well curated exhibitions tell the story of the city right from 400 Billion years ago to 1997. The logical sequence is easy to follow and its interactive nature makes it suitable for children and adults alike. As the title says, like almost all museums in HK, the museum is free on Wednesday, although I wouldn't begrudge paying the usual entry fee at any other time. Would highly ute commend.
Very Informative. This is quite a gem in Kowloon. Very informative and offers a good overview of the history (natural, socio-cultural, political) of Hong Kong. Very well put together.

Excellent overview of HK history; a must to experience. A very comprehensive look at HK's history from prehistoric times to the 1997 handover to China. Exhaustive exhibits and film features including the Opium war, the first Clan settlement, role during various dynasties, the World War II Japanese occupation, the revival and current times. Plan to spend half a day here to experience all the exhibits. Definitely a must-see for first time HK visitor or even those who grew up in HK!

Perfect rainy day activity. I love this place, been to HK 3 times in 10 years and always keep coming back to this museum. I highly recommend the audio tour, it is only $2 australian dollars and offers way more value for that over during 3 hour visit. We went on wednesday which is free admission, saving only few dollars but since it was pouring with rain it was convenient. FYI, a lot of school children around because of the free admission on wednesdays.

I lovely afternoon visit . We went on a rainy Wednesday afternoon it was free to get in on a Wednesday which was good lots of informative information about the history of Hong Kong and also the Japanese invasion staff very helpful lots of school parties there however it wasn't too busy most of the younger families were in the science museum , all in all a good way to spend an afternoon

Very educational from both exhibition and video show. We spent about 4 hours to go through all 10 exhibitions and video shows. It was not boring at all and by the time I felt I learnt a lot about HK history. Especially video shows are good that you can get either summery of certain topic or further details. Overall quite impressive.

Must visit! Free entry on Weds. Went there on Wednesday and it was free entrance for all (Story of Hong Kong). Otherwise the entrance fee would also be reasonable given the quality of the exhibitions. Exhibition started by telling stories (with videos) about how HK is formed geologically. and then the people, the culture and the festivals, modern history etc. Nicely choreographed and informative bilingual display. I went at 4pm and didn't have enough time to view all galleries before the museum closes at 6!Definitely a must visit before exploring other parts of HK. Access: get down by MTR at 尖東 East TST and walk around 10minutes

Recently Extended Hours. As mentioned before, this is a very well done display of Hong Kong's history with a nice rotating special exhibit (separate admission fee) but what i did not see anywhere online is the change in hours. It used to always be open until 6 pm but now it seems to sometimes be open to 7 pm, at least on weekends and holidays. There are numerous short multi-media shows throughout the day in several languages but often if the dialogue is not english, there are still english subtitles. Foreign seniors do get a half price discount--bring your passport.

Excellent . This was an easy to follow and educational visit. The info is broken into various eras and you can dig into each with as much detail as you wish. The entry fee is only $10HK which is about $1.80USD!! Recommended! Easy to find and get too as well.

Amazing museum. I had read the glowing reviews before hand but I was still blown away by this museum. It's interesting and fun and frankly it wore me out! Almost all of the exhibits are immersive--they've re-created environments and buildings and festival scenes and periods in history, and you really feel like you're getting a sense of what those things are or would have been like. I highly recommend it.

Very interesting and beautiful museum!. The museum is very nice, teaching about the history of Hong Kong in an interactive and visual way. We really felt that we learned a lot about the history of the place, while having fun. I think the museum would also be interesting for kids.
Informative and entertaining. A wonderful activity especially in the rain. I learned much, especially on the Japanese occupation of Hong Kong during WW11.
In depth History. This museum is a great way to spend a few hours in air conditioning. The level of detail was amazing and we really felt that we learned a lot about the overall history of Hong Kong.

wonderfully Curated. This museum is well sign-posted from Tsim Sha Tsui MTR. Cross the overhead bridge at Granville Road and follow the pink signs. Admission on Wed is free. There is no need for the audio guide which costs HKD10 as the displays have clear information. The dioramas are beautifully executed and tell the story of HK from prehistoric times to early settlers to the Opium War and cession to UK through to the Japanese Occupation and return to China. In between are the folk traditions and shops and enterprises that constitute what is quintessentially HK. 8 galleries over 2 floors. Cafe is open with reasonably priced food.

An interesting lesson on Hong Kong. I went here for the afternoon and was glad I made the trip. It's about a 10 minute walk from the TST metro station.The museum is nice and seems well maintained. I got the audio guide since someone here recommended it, but honestly I think you're better off with just the signs. The audio guide basically says the same thing as them, along with some other mundane information about what you're looking at (this is a terracotta pot, 25 cm tall and 15 cm wide). Boring.I wish I'd left more time for the areas on the regions tribal ancestry and ceremonies, and WWII stuff upstairs.I learned a lot, which is the point of the museum so I would recommend this to others!

Great introduction to Hong Kong. Some parts of the museum were a little slow, but there are lots of colorful exhibits on Hong Kong history and culture. Admission was only 12 HKD, half price for seniors. And the cafe had a delicious inexpensive lunch.

Pretty Not Great. Entrance into this museum is very cheap, only 10 HKD per person. Unfortunately the entrance fee is an indication of how extensive the exhibition is. Compared to my favorite museum, the New York Natural History Museum, it just doesn't compare in any way. For an international city as affluent as Hong Kong, I expected much better. Expect to spend no more than an hour here. Still worth checking out if you are in the area. It gets 4 stars because I am a supporter of public educational projects.
Great place to spend an afternoon!. This is a must for first-time visitors to Hong Kong -- really good way to learn about the history of the city!
Informative. This is a very informative museum that's worth a visit. All you want to know about history in the area.
Great visiting exhibit right now. Pompei visiting exhibit at the Museum of History.Always wanted to go there, now a little bit of it has come here. Good short film of the day Vesuvius buried Pompei.
Best museum in Hong Kong. Excellent look at the history of the territory, the culture and more. Well organized, clean, esay to get through.
Amazing!. The museum was planned. It was organize and it will really bring you back to those era that you have no idea what & why it happened. Kudos!

Great museum to enjoy, get over jet lag or just soak in the history. I went with a business colleague from Hong Kong the day after I arrived from Boston. Plenty of history, very detailed and interesting exhibits. English, Cantonese and Mandarin on almost all exhibits. I didn't observe other language options but there may be. I highly recommend for business travelers, tourists and families. Great to see the history of this great global city.

Well worth a visit. What a great museum. Definitely an interesting way to spend a few hours. I thought the displays were excellent. I was particularly interested in the sections on the Opium Wars as well as the local cultural groups. Would definitely recommend this museum.

Very informational! . The museum is well divided in chronological sections and each section has a short movie that summarizes the information. It starts with the geological birth of Honk Kong and ends with the British handover of Hong Kong to China.For someone unfamiliar with the history of Hong Kong, this museum can be very informational. It's not too large as to overwhelm, it can be covered in about 1.5 to 2 hours. Entrance fees are HK$10, ~USD$1.3.

Beautiful. If visiting with family, this is a must see place. Located in the heart of the city, this museum is well laid out with a lot of information wrt the history o0f the region. You need a full day here to do justice to the place.
Enjoyable and very interesting. Was surprised by how fun and exciting this place was . A truly hidden gem. Very educational and entertaining!

Lovely museum. Enjoyed the visit at this museum tremendously. Its housed in a rather in descript building so my expectations were kept low but really enjoyed the exhibits and how the History of Hong Kong was told through the ages with some strong content, story telling and exhibits design. If you have a free afternoon and would like to learn more about this amazing city do visit the museum!
Worth the detour on a rainy day. Excellent look into Hong Kong history, complete with short films in English and maquettes. Worth the detour on a rainy day.
Nice. Good place to visit to know about the history of Hong Kong.. Make sure to take the audio tour guide available from the ticket window itself..

Free on Wednesdays!. It's easy to access to buy foot, bus or taxi. However, the MTR is not quite so close. As the title says, head over to this on a Wednesday as it is free. This applies to the general museum but not special exhibits.

Well Executed Museum. You can easily spend an entire afternoon here. This museum has done such a great job creating a very interactive and visually pleasing space. Make sure to leave plenty of time for the upper levels because these levels have such vibrant displays representing various ethnic groups to colorful festivals like the Cheung Chau Bun Festival. There is also an area set up as a street from the past with various stores to look into. This museum is well put together and is definitely worth a visit.

I would definitely go again.. Arrived around 4:30. The museum closed at 6, so I had about 90 minutes of wondering around, which was fun, but not enough time. I plan to visit this joint another time, for the facility is not only well designed and informative, but also quite enjoyable and fun to experience.

great review of the natural, geographic and historic story that is Hong Kong. A server at our hotel recommended we go here on a rainy day and we are so glad we did. Very well put together and excellent flow. We took 3 hours exploring and loved every minute, I of course love history !

Brings back memory. We spent a good few hours in the museum after walking across from Nathan Road. It had another exhibition on the Chinese Dynasties coupled with the evolution of Hong Kong over the years. It was very interesting to see how Hong Kong develops and evolves into today's skyscraper city. The Museum also brought exhibits of the three main groups of indigineus people , their cultures etc. Sometimes the younger generation should learn rather than glued to their smart phones or tablets. Although you have to pay to get in, it was well worth it to bring back memories of my childhood.

Loved it!. great experience for everyone, especially if you are a history fan. The admission fee was HK$10 which was extremely cheap for this multi-floor museum. They had guided tours in English only on Weekends so we settled for the cantonese guide. i believe the tour guide made the difference. he was enthusiastic with a good pace. he was clearly very knowledgeable and provided a lot of trivial facts of HK. without him, I imagine it would be quite difficult to read through every exhibit. I highly recommend joining this 90 min tour. the entire place is well air-conditioned. can serve as a nice break if the day is hot and humid.

A Great Rainy Day Activity. If you're ever in Hong Kong looking for something to do when it's raining or for when the heat outside gets to be just too much, visit the Museum of History. Entrance is only $10 HKD and the museum has a lot of interesting exhibits. The pre-history was alright, but where the museum really shows its worth is in the folk arts and traditions of Hong Kong. It also covers the modern history of the city very well.

Interesting for both visitors and residents. I regularly go and visit this museum as a lot of temporary exhibitions worth the discovery.Also highly recommanded for visitors or newcomers : The LG presents prehistory/climate but above all models of daily life objects or buildings such as temple, theatre, farm house, boat,... Movies also punctuate your visit and make it easier & funnier for those who don't like to read too much. The 2/F is dedicated to English occupation (since 1840's, till 1997) with also a lot of model, movies, pictures and objects. Highly recommanded visit!

Great for people on a budget.. At just 10 HKD to enter, this was a bargain if you have an hour or two to walk around and understand a bit more about the history of Hong Kong.The Science museum is also just across from this.

A good place to go to understand the history of Hong Kong Island. It takes several hours to see al the displays in this very good museum It is free on Wednesdays and is a good place to visit if weather is poor. Information is provided in English and Chinese and audio tours are available. It looks at the early clans who settled on the island and also looks at recent political events that have impacted Hong Kong.

Great exhibits and mock up's. Open 10am - 6pm Monday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. 10am - 7pm on weekends and public holidays. Closed on Tuesday's. It's free entry on a Wednesday, otherwise it's only 10HKD for adults or 5HKD for children over 4, persons over 60 years and the disabled. The museum is split into 8 permanent galleries:1 - The natural environment2 - Prehistoric HK3 - The Dynasties, from The Han to Qing4 - Folk culture in HK5 - The Opium Wars and cessation of HK6 - Birth and early growth of the city7 - The Japanese occupation8 - Modern metropolis There's free guided tours in English at 14:30 hours on weekends and public holidays. These start at the entrance to Gallery 1 and last for an hour and a half. I went round pretty quick as it was my last day in HK, but I was still there for over two hours. There's also a good quality shop and a decent and reasonably priced cafe to the right of the main entrance. I particularly liked the mock up streets and shops in Gallery 6 and would definitely visit the museum again.

Good for School Trips. My colleagues and I brought our 11 yr old students there. We enjoyed learning more about Hong Kong. We saw the first inhabitants of Hong Kong and their art. We took photos in a Ding Ding and in a medical hall that reminded me of Wong Fei Hong, a famous character of China. There was a section on how the Chinese celebrated the religious festivals. And of course, how the World War affected them. Truly interesting.

Great place for people who are interested in Chinese history. History museum exhibits the history of Hong Kong and China, starting from the pre-historic period to contemoprary times. In the museum you can learn about ethnic minorities of the Guangdong region, see their traditional clothes, learn about their way of life, customs, beliefs and religious festivals. There are also great short documentary sessions in Mandarin, Cantonese and English. You can also see replicas of shops, homes, pharmacy stores (etc.) from more recent times. Even if you are not interested in history, history museum is a great indoor activity for rainy weathers.

Wow. I am normally not a big fan of museums, so wasn't too excited when my travel companions decided to visit the museum. The first 3 exhibitions about rock formation and past animals of Hong Kong could honestly be taken out. But the following exhibitions of the museum were all worth it! We ended up tagging along to the Cantonese speaking tour offered by the museum halfway through the tour. The guide was just so enthusiastic, we were kind of sucked in! I highly recommend joining the museum offered tours, she was talking for over 3 hours, and everything she was saying was so interesting and not necessarily on the information cards! Would definitely recommend this museum, even for people who don't like museums! Also, for only HKD10, what's the worse that could go wrong!

One of the best museums in all of Hong Kong. This museum tells the story of Hong Kong from prehistoric times to the cessation to China. Most impressive to me were the houses, store fronts, scenes replicated throughout the museum. Aside from the visual displays, there were also audio recordings as well as video. It really gave you a sense of being in that place at that time. Put this on your list of to-dos and go in the morning when it opens at 10:00am to avoid the crowds.

Excellent museum. I don't love museums, so when our tour guide wanted to take us there, I was not overly excited. This is an excellent museum! It is a very large, well organized museum. The exhibits were very interesting with english descriptions. They offer an audio guide, which we did not use since we were there with our own guide. When it was time to leave, I actually wished we could have spent more time. Be aware that admission is free on Wednesdays and it will be very crowded. Definitely worth a visit!

Interesting and well set-up with a lot of staff to advise you.. Interesting and well set-up with a lot of staff to advise you. The museum is nicely organised and signage is clear. Admission fees are very low for the good quality the museum represents. Recommend this museum for any visitor!

very good for children. we went with a large group from school and parents and were entertained the enitre day by all showcases and presentations. museum did some extra effort with the group which was nice, but without the place is one to visit for the rainy days in Hong KOng

Excellent, be prepared for a long visit!. When you need a break from the heat, the Hong Kong Museum of History is excellent. However, it is deceptively large, so make sure to give yourself enough time to adequately absorb the vast amount of information. The permanent exhibition of the Hong Kong Story begins with the history of the region 400 million years ago and takes you all the way to the reunification of Hong Kong with China in 1997. They say it takes about two hours if you just walk through the eight galleries, but I would give it at least three so as not to feel rushed.

Good history lesson with my nephew. I took my nephew to visit a museum for the first time. Very informative displays some with theatre displays. Especially the opium war and Japanese invasions. I will recommend everyone to pay a visit when you come to Hong Kong. You will be amaze how a little place with so much history.

Great Museum, Not Toddler Friendly. We visited with the intent to learn more about Hong Kong's history and culture and we certainly achieved this. The exhibits were great and the artifacts and displays were awesome to look at, photograph, and experience. I do think this is one of the best museums I have been to in terms of content.That being said, our experience was ruined by multiple workers harassing us about our baby. Maybe we were wrong for bringing a child with us to a history museum; but for the most part I thought she was well-behaved. The one time she started crying, I quickly removed myself from a video we were all watching. In the process, I was "shooshed" excessively by some of the workers even after we had retreated to the bathroom and stairway area. They actually followed me out there to continue reminding me that I had to quiet her down. Yes, yes, I am doing what I can to get my 19 month old to stop crying... But I can't exactly reason with her, can I? We were also reprimanded for putting her on my shoulders to carry her and told we had to take her down immediately, so heads up if you engage in this form of "horseplay".At the end of the day, the museum information was good, the AC was cold, and the communications network between the museum workers was on point. I would still recommend this place to any of my friends coming for a visit.

Glimpse of Hong Kong's History. It is an amazing gallery of Hong Kong's History. The gallery consists of artifacts and stories from the Stone Age or something of HK, down to what is Hong Kong to date. Tip: Museum is free on Wednesdays!

Really good museum, worth going to visit. I went to the museum by myself while my other half was working (we went for a week and he was working for a couple of days there). It took a good 2 hours at least to go around but I found it all very interesting. I was particularly interested in the part of history / display all about when the UK handed over HK back to China (because I was too young to know what it was about when watching it on TV). There was another exhibition there but I didn't go into it due to lack of time but this was just as busy as the main museum. I didn't eat or drink there so can't comment on these facilities. Overall, I think this is worth going to, plenty for kids and adults.
Great place to learn about the history of Hong Kong. One of the best museums I've been to. The short documentaries about folk culture and the Opium War are really well-made and informative.

Nice displays. The first 2 exibitions were a bit boring, but the rest was very beautifull. It was very nice displayed and I loved the part with all the different inhabitants of Hong Kong. You literaly walk trough the history of Hong Kong. Litlle downside, the walking order isn't always clear. For a merely 10 HK dollar, you really get your moneys worth

Very decent musuem. Give yourself plenty of time to get round as the displays are very good and it is an enormous museum which you can see a lot of effort went into. I really enjoyed it but needed more than 2 hours sadly.

ONe of the best museums I have ever visited. This provides an excellent geological, cultural, political, and historical view of Hong Kong and the surrounding area. Several theater presentations, reproduced shops, fascinating cultural displays and all in a modern, attractive, and well designed building (in warm or damp weather, you will appreciate the climate control!) GREAT for rainy days!!!

History in Detail. For those going to HK for the first time, this museum gives a good perspective on the inhabitants of the islands and their progress over the years ... its also a good place to escape the afternoon summer heat

Excellent!. There is so much to see in the Museum of History and through many different exhibitions, including replica streets and shops, it takes you on a journey from Hong Kong's beginnings to the present day. Allow several hours to visit if you want to see it all. Facilities such as café, shop and toilets are good; there are plenty of staff around to give more information and on a Wednesday admission is free!

A brilliant museum if you skip the first bit. Allow 3 hours.. This is a great museum at HKD10 especially on a rainy day and you can combine with the excellent interactive science museum next door. You start at basement level in the prehistoric age and there are lots of bits of pottery and displays on fauna and flora which are interesting but I spent far too long here and therefore missed out on the upper floors of the museum which are far more interesting and include a reproduction of an old HK street with the shops you would expect to find plus a tea house on 2 storeys as well as lots about the Chinese Theatre and huge colourful procession floats.
