The flow of the museum allows for you to travel through time in Hong Kong. I personally didn't find the first half of the museum very interesting, although it was very informative. Once it got to British colonization and Japanese control, it got very interesting to me. Nonetheless, the museum is worth the price of admission. Also- the museum has a GREAT gift shop... If nothing else, stop by the museum to shop.

Worth the visit, especially on a rainy day. We went during a recent visit to Hong Kong. We had one rainy day, so decided to visit this museum. So glad we did. Especially enjoyed the Dynasty's display.

Great Introduction to the History of Hong Kong. The museum provides a great introduction to Hong Kong. The displays include English panels and there are also several video shows in English. I really enjoyed the modern history and explanations of the Opium Wars. We were also lucky in that we visited on a Wednesday when it is free to the public.

Very interest & great for a rainy day. We went on a Wednesday and it was free entry. Seems to be every Wednesday, but that may change. Found the very early part, about the land formation and soil structure a bit boring, but once you got into the history of HK it was very interesting. Some of the exhibits are a little dimly lit and could do with a dust, but generally good. With lunch, which is not expensive, we spend over 4 hours in there. Which was great as it was raining all day.
A must go place touring Hong Kong. My family enjoyed the museum very much. It was both informative and entertaining. The displays were well executed. The museum attendants were helpful and friendly.

Educational and insight to Hong Kong history . This is a great museum to see and understand the of Hong Kong. The museum is very well planned with layouts that brings you from the start of Hong Kong history to present time. The entire trail is like a journey and is filled with intricate designs of exhibits and artifacts. An attraction not to be missed.

Interesting overview of Hong Kong History. If you have some time to spare in Hong Kong, be sure to visit the Hong Kong Museum of History. The museum shows an overview of how Hong Kong came to be the amazing city that it is now, and is never dull (or you know, if you think parts of it are dull, you can skip those parts if you'd like).

Really worth a visit. We were recommended to visit this museum before all others in Hong Kong. I'm glad we listened. Entrance at a mere 10 HK dollars was very cheap. Our ages brought that down to 5 HK dollars which made it a real bargain. Visit on a Wednesday and entrance is free.  The main display here is "The Hong Kong Story" which covers the emergence of Hong Kong, through natural environment, folk culture and historical development. The display is executed with aplomb. Theatres have shows covering everything from how the land became as it is, to the deprivations suffered during the Japanese occupation. We relived the British departure from the area, but also see displays on tradition opera, puppetry, processions and bun-towers (you need to see the display to understand). A life-sized street of shops complete with tram further told the story. We learnt a lot across a three-hour visit and then retired to the cafe for a meal. Here, too, was a surprise: it is run by an organisation offering jobs to the disadvantaged. Highly recommended.

Don't be fooled by the building exterior! . I didn't have a good first impression the moment we arrived. The exterior looked dated and uninspiring. When I stepped into the first section I was telling myself this would be over within an hour. But the more we explored, the more we were wowed! I was particularly impressed by the details they put in to tell the life and culture of the people of HK in the past. What was supposed to be a 2 hours max trip (we had other things planned in our itinerary) ended up with us spending more than 4 hours. There were just so much interesting stuffs on display! We learned so much about Hong Kong. One of the best, if not the best museum I've ever visited. Tip: We went on a Wednesday, and to our surprise the entrance is free of charge every Wednesday!

Spacious museum interestingly presenting Hong Kong history from the "beginning". A very nice museum to visit. For adults and maybe also for kids. During the day of visit, kids were a small minority among the visitors.Museum is closed on Tuesdays unless Tuesday falls into public holiday. Opening hours 10am - 6pm. A nice surprise was the opening hours of 10am to 7pm on Sunday (Also Saturdays and public holidays).Take subway to Tsim Sha Tsui and exit subway fromExit P2. When outside, turn right, walk to the next crossing and again turn right. You are then on Chatham road South. Five minute walk straight ahead and the Museum is on the right side of the street. There are signs on the pedestrian street once or twice whilst walking towards the museum. We visited the museum on Sunday and it was not packed; surprisingly. On the other hand, the museum is very spacious and designed in a way that maybe you don't feel very packed even if the people flow is big.There is a small nominal entrance fee.Explains a wide variety of Honk Kong history starting from 400 millions years ago all the way up to transfer of Hong Kong from The UK to China.

Excellent. Always go here when I am in Hong Kong. The layout is excellent and the displays so informative.
This is all what a museum should be
Excellent. Great displays. The folk culture exhibits are very interesting and illuminating. Need more than 2 hours to really go round.

Best $10HKD you will spend. We crammed a visit to the museum in on the day we were leaving HKG - and we wished we had done it on the first day and had more time to take it all in. This museum is an experience, its not all about artefacts in glass cases (although there are some). This is a place you walk through and take in history. We only had two hours and could have spent half a day or more there. We loved learning about the dynasties and the history it provides would set you up well to understand and explore modern day hong kong. We missed having our 9 year old daughter there and decided on the spit we would return to visit hong kong and mainland China, and we will start that trip at this museum. Solo, couples (like us) and families will all enjoy!
HK museum of history. It costs 10 HKD to enter the museum and it shows the history from the very beginning of the world intil now.

Awesome!. Central location and free admission on Wednesdays are a bonus. But would be worth travelling to and paying for. One of the best Museums (maybe the very best) that I have ever been to. Wonderful, superbly displayed exhibits. Nice gift shop too. And accessible for wheelchair users.

Nice for kids. Very interesting place to go when its rains .... Just went there for' my kids because i have no choice , it was raining and we have nowhere to go ... it was a nice Visit.... Nothing else to say ....

A historical summary of the last couple of thousands of years of Hong Kong. If you are interested in the history of Hong Kong you definitely have to visit that place, lots and lots of beautiful displays and explanations, very entertaining, visiting this museum is a trip in itself, easily a whole day can be spent here, also interesting for children, Wednesdays free admission!

Huge. Plan to spend a day here.. We spent the whole day here. It tells of prehistoric days till how Hong Kong was modernised. If you love history, come to this place. It was interesting how they tried to depict those early Hong Kong streets - as though you are living in it.

Free on wednesdays, very informative.. A short 10mins walk from Hung Hom MTR (cut through the university). If you don't intend to stay for long, I would recommend that you skip the first section on prehistoric stuff. I enjoyed understanding more about HK history and I thought it did provide me with enough information.

Visit this museum!. This attraction seems to be a bit underrated, maybe because it is a bit out of the way on the Kowloon side. However, it gives a riveting panorama of the history of Hong Kong and southern China from earliest times until the present day. There are dioramas of costume and landscape for Hong Kong's 4 main ethnic groups and sections on cityscapes with actual buildings and shops as well as on WWII and the colonial period. Fascinating. You need about 2 hours at least.

Great visuals and well written . Planned to only be here for an hour but stayed for about 3 as it was so good!Takes you from millions of years ago right up the present day.Loads of visual stuff to see. Very well written and well explained.They have a tram inside and a Chinese theatre show and an old street. I would really recommend coming here and it's so cheap! There's also a cafe on site.

Very interesting museum. Very informative and well-done museum that informs you about the entire history of Hong Kong, from prehistoric times to today. Most interesting were the exhibits tracing the period from the Opium Wars to the return of Kong Kong to China.

Wish I had more time!. The permanent exhibit, the Hong Kong Story, includes so much that I ran out of time. If you only have an hour or two, skip past Galleries 1 & 2 that cover the Natural Environment & Prehistoric Hong Kong. The really interesting exhibits start in Gallery 3.The audio guide was interesting, but not necessary since the exhibits are well marked & described in English & Chinese. At the same time, but guide was quite inexpensive as was admission to the museum.I definitely recommend a visit if you're interested in understanding how Hong Kong has changed over the centuries and even millennia.

Hong Kong's best museum, currently. The section reproducing life-size streets and traditional shops is excellent, and so is the one explaining the successive waves of settlers, their houses, customs and costumes.

Rethink your idea of a museum!. This was my second visit after an absence of 4 years, and the spaciousness and clearly labelled exhibits of this museum are second to none. The old newsreels of typhoons, Japanese occupation, etc., give you chance for a welcome seat, especially when you can timetable your visits to the different theatres, and the museum is so spacious that groups and people taking selfies are not a problem. If time is limited, it is probably worth skipping most of the ground floor and going up to the second, more recent, section.

Rainy day tour. I had already planned to go to the museum, but it was a good day to be indoors as it rained most of the day. The museum tells the history of Hong Kong from prehistoric times to the present. I especially liked the cultural exhibit. I was in HK for a wedding, and this exhibit explained many of the origins of the rituals I had seen at the wedding. I rented the audio tour. It was helpful, but sometimes too much information. Fortunately, you can move onto the next exhibit easily or skip those not requiring an explanation with the push bottom controls. You are able to pay for the fees with your octopus card.
what an experience!. one hot, humid day in HKG and I have read somewhere about the museum. Giving it a try, I can say, it was/is worth a visit!

An amazing museum. Forget your ideas of a museum! This museum is absolutely different and absolutely stunning! Dioramas offering images of early Hong Kong, life size reproductions of temples, processions, festivities; you walk from a religious monument to a colonial post office, a bank, or a powerful evocation f Hong Kong during the war. It should not be missed.

Best museum in Hong Kong. I have been to Hong Kong many times but still find time to visit this museum. It depicts the history of the former English colony in an excellent exhibition with many films on show. There is also an excellent bookstore in the museum which also illustrates the history of Hong Kong. And if you go on a Wednesday, the entry is free as is with most museums on that day. Give it a try.
Good. We enjoyed this Museum, although some of the early exhibits are very stock standard. Once you get into the recreated old Hong Kong city things change.

Rainy Day Trip. It's interesting to see the more rural aspects of Hong Kong life, but I would still save this museum for a rainy day. I think that there are better attractions to be seen if you're only here for a short trip, but the majority tend to be in the outdoors. It's a good option for when the bad weather hits.

Well worth a visit. If you want to understand Hong Kong's history, this museum is the place to go. Beginning with pre-history to the present day it is well laid out and so informative. Very impressive. We caught a train from Tsim Sha Tsui station to Jordan (1 stop) then walked down Austin Road to Chatham Road South, where it is located. We spent at least 3 hours here. We managed to get a bus back to the Harbour front along Chatham Road rather than walk up Austin Road in the heat to the train station.
Getting to know hong kong. Amazing exhibit and many informations provided throughout the trip.learnt a lot tru some videos and pic.

Really good museum . Well planned out n structured museum. Cheap entry n very informative. Definitely a must go to relive tvb moments and many Hong Kong movies as you would finally learn the real facts surrounding the stories of ur fave shows. Very pleasant trip down memory lane. A lot of effort went into the museum. Just a tad disappointed not much info and chronology of the Chinese dynasties.

Great Historical Museum. This is a fabulous museum that covers the full history of Hong Kong as to culture, environmental evolution and colonialism and wars. You will have a much better understaqnding of Hong Kong after this visit. Very close to restauarnats and main shopping area in Kowloon and accessible by 2 lines of the MTR.

Great experience. A great way to learn about the history of Hong Kong. Suitable for every age and massively entertaining. It's not just text, pictures and fragments of some stone pots. Take your time (at least three hours) and explore the different epoques of Hong Kong. Visit on Wednesday because it's free (like most museums in HK).

Eh. The Museum has a lot of information that seems scattered and more about geology than actually about Hong Kong. It seems it doesn't know what it's purpose is and it's trying to cover too much info. Fortunately, it is not expensive and the audio tour is worth the extra. You can get through it rather quickly and feel like you've gained a little more knowledge about China/Hong Kong than you came with.

Very Informative. I really enjoyed my visit to the Hong Kong Museum of History. I had visited the museum on a Wednesday which is free admission for everyone. The museum is very informative and well-laid out. The museum covered the history of Hong Kong from prehistoric times to 1997.There weren’t too many hands-on displays for children but there were many life-sized models of various items. All the displays had signs in English. The museum is definitely worth a visit to learn about the history of Hong Kong.It’s best to combine the visit to the Hong Kong Museum of History with the nearby Hong Kong Science Museum. It’s also free admission on Wednesdays to the Hong Kong Science Museum.

not a bad idea to drop by. there are interesting places around the area and if you like history, this is not a bad choice.... would recommend you also visit the neighborhood... there are other museums, parks, and shopping areas in the vincinity
Good museum. Nice to visit.. You can learn about the history and culture of Hong Kong here. We took about 2-3 hours in this museum. Lots of things to see. Free entry on Wednesday.

Comprehensive presentation of Hong Kong history. The Museum is, if anything, a little too comprehensive. I could have done without the first two galleries on The Natural Environment and Prehistoric Hong Kong ; but the later galleries covering Chinese history, British occupation, WWII and Reunification were very interesting.
Nice museum of local history. We spend a couple of hours there before our flight home. Very good geological history as well as modern history of the city..
Great museum. This is a really good museum. If you take the time to reach at the exhibits, you will learn quite a bit about Hong Kong history.
A great museum. The museum teaches you basically the entire history of Hong Kong, from long before humans inhabitated the earth. Well worth a visit, a great activity on a rainy day.
Good Museum. We go there in Wednesday and it is admision free on Wednesday. The collection is quite interested. We can see Hong Kong culture there.

One of the best museums we have been to. What a great museum. Split into different zones for the different periods throughout the history of the island. It was really fascinating and you could spend hours in there. It was also free - always a bonus. Would recommend to anyone visiting Hong Kong as a must-do place

Meaningful visit. Many interesting exhibits - one gets to learn about the history of the city. Exhibits are carefully displayed. Worthwhile spending a couple of hours here. Free admission on Wednesdays.

well known HK history. I love this museum, it has different exhibition halls which show different age of HK. I love the second floor which mentions the Sino Japanese War and of course the time under the rule of UK. It sets up different scenery of HK people place and shop which we can take photos there. I pretended I was visiting the Chinese doctor! It's so funny!

Holiday. IT WAS EXCITING TO BE AT THE HONG KONG MUSEUM .The Chinese were very friendly and they asked me to have photos with them.I also went to see Chinese doing Tai chi and I took a photo of myself at the Hong Kong Museum

Don't miss it.. Its free on wednesdays, but don't miss it anyway. It is a brilliantly devised history of Hong Kong starting with the geological ages and all the way to the Handover in 1997, when the whole story seems to rather bizarrely to stop. The displays are great and there are some audio-visual presentations in the theatres scattered over the 8 exhibition halls.Why only a 4 and not a 5! Well if you wanted some refreshment in the way of a tea or coffee and a snack, you would be hard pushed to find anything quite as bad in the whole of Hong Kong than in the museum's cafes.

Interesting presentation of Hong Kong's history. A great rainy-day activity or for those that have extra time available when visiting, the museum charts the history of Hong Kong from prehistoric times, looking at the geology the city is built on, to the Handover Period (1997).Lots of large and colourful display items. Some media (interactive and passive) spread evenly throughout the different time periods exhibitions. While the lack of genuine artefacts (lots of replica items are kept behind the glass) may cause some disappointment, there is enough information presented and stimulation provided to keep all ages entertained.Open 10am - 6pm weekdays (closed on Tuesdays), and open 10am - 7pm weekends. HK$10 adults, HK$5 concessions.

Do this if you have time.. We spent about 2 hours here. The museum is very interesting. There is obvious propaganda by the Chinese government regarding it's relationship with the people of Hong Kong. However, this museum will help you understand the complex history that Hong Kong has with China, the UK and the west.

A well set out and interesting Museum. We have been visiting Hong Kong for 20 years - and it was only on our last trip that it was suggested we should visit the Museum - how silly we were not to have gone sooner!The Museum is a little off the beaten track and so has to be sought out rather than come across - but it is well worth the effort. is it extremely well set out, has much of interest and a lot is to be learned from it. We visited, planning to spend an hour or so there, but were there for an entire afternoon. Staff are unobtrusive - but there to answer any questions - and are obviously interested themselves in what that have to tell. we left feeling that we had learned a,lot about Hong Kong - and with definite plans to visit places that we passed often but hadn't known the history of. A musty museum this most definitely is not - a pleasant journey through time it certainly is!

You could spend all day here. We only had a few hours to spare but you could have spent all day here! Some things were less interesting to us but we loved the folk culture sections . Everything was well laid out and there were short films available in several languages . Upstairs there were mock ups of pre war shops and more recent history such as the opium wars.Wednesday is free entry; consequently it is full of school trips. We didn't find this a problem as the children were impeccably behaved, but less peaceful than it would have been otherwise.
museum near tsim sha tsui. If we come to tsim sha tsui and have some time, better if we visit this museum. Frankly, visiting museum is kinda boring. But if u hv time , why not

very cool museum. its really the best place to visit specially for those who wanna discover the history of hong kong & the show way there is very creative,its really cool interesting place to visit there .

Fantastic Layout. I have been to a few museums and this one is one that keeps you interested the whole way round. We visited ob a wednesday so the entrance was free and i was suprised at how empty the place was! The exhibits are very well arranged and lots of details clearly labelled. I would recommend in a visit to HK

Pretty poor collection. You would expect from a city like Hong Kong - cool, trendy, developed, fun - you would think the museum of history will be at the same level. No, not even close. Very few pieces here and there, lots of closed areas, nothing memorable, really. They tried to make something out of nothing. And because it's Hong Kong, it's still a little cool. But the content, the substance - very limited.

Excellent job of telling their story. By the time I finished the tour of this facility I knew the history of Hong Kong intimately. The movies, the displays, the educational booths, the newspapers!! It all adds up to a very thorough retelling of their story and other museums could benefit from copying them

What a wonderful museum!. The Museum of Hong Kong History is easy to find and the tickets are cheap. I find the history of Hong Kong fascinating and the museun presents it with wonderful photos and artifacts. You can easily spend 2/3 hours there. It is a spacious place where you can roam, while getting pulled into the local people's stories. It is a fun place for children as well. I especially enjoyed the folklore part, but all of it was interesting. Everything is very aesthetically displayed. I highly recommended!

Historically magical . A very nice way to learn and understand the history of Hong Kong and China. Beautifully arranged and displays of different facets of the rich cultural heritage, economic and social development. Certainly worth a visit

Take a peek into HongKong history. Hong Kong Museum of History is one museum where i didnt get bored for a second. The museum boasts live models and media rooms which depicts the geographical, ancient n modern history of HongKong. Personally I liked the exhibits about the ethinic groups of HongKong. If you have time to spare in HongKong, it is a "must see".. Will take around 2-2.5 hours to finish the entire tour.

Worth a visit. This was excellent, a little slow to start with the geology section but once past that it blossomed, with the 19-20th centary section facsinating. Not expensive to enter, not though near tube, but very walkable.

Answered a lot of questions I had about Hong Kong's history. This museum is really interesting. There's a big section on prehistory going back 400 million years that you might choose to ignore, but once you get into the more recent period (early Chinese imperial history; also, more recent colonial history, the Opium Wars, and Hong Kong's 20th century development), the material becomes very interesting.
Excellent museum (free on Wednesdays!). The exhibits are really comprehensive on HK history and people/culture and we went on a Wednesday where admission is free. Worth going.

Worth a visit. The Museum of History is a nice way to spend time in HK to observe the development of culture, politics and the demography of HK. The entrance tickets are cheap. There is also the museum of science in the same complex.

A very informative guided tour. If you are interested in Hong Kong History. This Museum tells you a lot. I joined a Cantonese speaking guided tour in the afternoon. The tour guide did a very wonderful job. She is very knowledgeable & delivered in a very interesting way. The tour is suppose around 1.5 hours but she had so much information to deliver. The tour was over run. I enjoyed the tour very much. And I will go back to look around the exhibits.
Vista Early. Did not have enough time to visit this museum. It is wonderfully setup but it closes early. Be prepared to spent a lot of time exploring and learning.

This is a must-see!. You can take the Star Ferry over to the Kowloon side to visit this terrific Museum. It's very well laid-out, and simply following thru the galleries will take you from the Paleolithic on thru the turn over back to the Chinese in 1997. Exhibits and dioramas cover everything from ecology to industry. There are lots of dioramas, many featuring real artifacts. There are interesting exhibit re: salt making and drying/preserving of fish, life on the water, the Opium Wars, and a couple of exhibits about unique festivals, like that of the "Bun Tower." This is definitely not a place full of dry display cases and lengthy descriptions and notes. There are lots of (mostly English-speaking) staff around if you have questions. To me, Kowloon also seemed a less crowded and commercial place than Hong Kong itself, on the other side of the harbor. Do plan on spending the entire day.

Must see museum in HK. Must see musuem in Hong Kong. Good signage to location by MTR railway. This musuem is suited for kids and also adults for a day tour. You can spend about 2 to 3 hours easily at this musuem.Price:heavily subsided by government $10 HKD which is equal to about 2 bucks NZD or 1USD.Multi-lanuage audio system suited for adults and young adults.

A must see stop on any visit to Hong Kong. This is without doubt one of the places that should be on any tourist visit to Hong Kong.It's situated in a vast specially built building and all the displays are laid out in a very sympathetic manner. The entrance fee is less than £1 which is tremendous value considering it takes around two hours to take in most of what's on offer. (You could happily spend longer if reading everything in detail and watching the many video displays, which are also in English.There is a whole area set out as old trading shops etc which is both informative and world class in it's presentation. There is so much to take in I would happily return the same week if time permitted.Without doubt highly recommended.
Great museum. The museum provides a lot of knowledge about the country, its history and people. I spent 3 hours in there and have not covered the entire exhibition.

Make time to visit this museum!. We were in the area, it was raining and it was featured in the Lonely Planet. We only had 2 hours but it required much more time to get through this great museum, the exhibits are well curated and history of Hong Kong is very interesting.

Great museum. This is a very well done museum which chronicles the history of Hong Kong from early prehistory through the present. One of the better museums I have visited. I highly recommend making this an early stop in your trip to get a good overview of Hong Kong's history.

Captivating Storytelling. An excellent museum. Only 10hk (1.5 USA) for a wonderful educational experience. Progresses from geological history, to ecological history, to prehistory, to ancient history, and finally ends with contemporary modern world. Great exhibits and captivating videos at each stage that help the story of Hong Kong come to life. One of the best museums I have visited (and I love museums). Highly recommended.

Two hours or more for very low price. Museum had galleries for all aspects from rock formation and how Hong Kong was formed geologically, flora and fauna, early man, primitive life, and development through to the present day.There seemed to be something for everyone. As well as exhibits, there were short films in various languages, including English.This was a great way to understand how Hong Kong had developed into what it is today, as well as entertaining for 2 or 3 hours.Went on a Saturday morning, not very crowded, helpful staff.

Get to know more about Hong Kong. It has permanent exhibition about Hong Kong history starting from being a fishing village to how it becomes a vibrant and cosmopolitan city of the present day. Special exhibition changes every 6 months or so can be interesting too. Good environment to spend a few hours there.

Really good afternoon out!. I visited Hong Kong Museum of History a couple of times while I was over in HK and it does give you a really good appreciation for what makes Hong Kong unique from an historical perspective. The exhibits are well presented and there is a wide variety of information available. I think this would be a particularly good museum for older children, there's a lot of exploring which can be done- and lots to look at and interact with, rather than just being a hall of dusty cabinets. It's a big museum too, so make sure you're prepared for a fair bit of walking around! Really easy to get to though, and super cheap entry fees.
Very informative. Good lesson on history of Hong Kong.very well presented. Good displays that made it interesting. Tip:closed in Tuesday but free entry on Wednesday
Informative activity. The price was very reasonable and the presentations informative. You could spend as much time as you wanted touring the displays.
Expand your knowledge!!. This is great way to spend a couple hours getting the history of Hong Kong. I learnt a lot on how the city came to be. Only cost 10 HKD, which is ridiculously cheap!!

Very interesting. If you're into museums, this is the first place to visit. Entry ticket only HKD10. The permanent exhibition goes through all the history of Hong Kong from prehistory to the present. Good restaurant as well with good selection of lunch specials! By the way don't forget to drop by the gift shop to get some excellent Hong Kong souvenirs, a lot better than the junk you can find elsewhere, oh and good prices too!

Great Museum. The History Museum is an excellent museum with thought provoking displays and excellent exhibitions. The permanent collection looks at Hong Kong from pre history, to China, the Colonial period and the wartime occupation to its return to China. It looks at multiple aspects of life - culture, employment, the post office, banking and finance, transportation, housing, children . Religion and customs, institutions and defence. There are various films on show with some with English soundtrack - on a rotational basis.There is a good display very nicely presented that will appeal to the younger and older generation of visitor. Bilingual labelling is helpful. There is something here for the whole family and one could stay there all day.The special exhibition that was on last week focussed on the Han Dynasty and had a wonderful array of artefacts including the original gold seal of Emperor Wen. Jade pendants and jewellery together with statues and even dice and money from the same period. The development of the Silk Road and it's importance was well illustrated. As with all government museums there is good wifi connectivity. This museum is closed on Thursday. Great facility that gives you the urge to go out and find some more of the history of Hong Kong.
great museum!. Loved this museum and so did our eight year old. Easy to get to and reasonably priced. It takes you through the various eras and the information provided is interesting.

Fine Museum. It is located in Tsim Shaw sue . Museum provides very good information about the Hong Kong history. All the displays were very informative in providing the history. There is so much to see inside and a good souvenir shop. We learned many things here and it is worth visiting if you have time.
The Rise of the Celestial Empire. An excellent Museum, I very much enjoyed this temporary exhibition - a must see. Easy place to find on Chatham Road in Kowloon.

One of the nicest museums I've seen!. Was planning on spending 2 hours but spent more than that--so much to see and well done. Great to learn about the heritage. There is a café in the museum if you need a break. I highly recommend it. It's very inexpensive for admission. Senior and student discounts available.

Awesome!...and It's all about the Hong Kong Story!. We dropped into this place while we were walking on the Jordan path toward Hong Kong cultural center and the Avenue of Stars. On that day the museum offered free entry to every visitor. It took us few hours to explore thee floors of rich and intersting stories of Hong Kong from ancient to modern times. This is the place worth to explore before visiting other places, to appreciate Hong Kong people's culture, custom and ways of life. Staff are welcoming and all exhibitions are well organise. You will be amaze and surprise of your discovery and it may help your stay in Hong kong more enjoyable. There are many significant historical items on display and most of them include English narratives. If you are tired of browsing and moving around, drop into the well set up theatres which show a wide range of interesting short films. Must watch at least one of colourful traditional shows! After this visit you may want to refresh yourself by trying local famous snacks, noodle and drinks at 'Sam Gor Mixian' restaurant, located in front of the museum around 300m on the right. If you stay in Kowloon this place is easy access by subway and/or walking.

Three hours well spent.. Well laid out modern museum. Air conditioned throughout - a must in Hong Kongs sultry climate. Museum traces history of HK from its earliest days to the present. Walk in displays of the Japanese occupation, traditional Chinese weddings and the HK of the 60's well worth the visit.

organized and huge. im not into history but i love the museum of history because it is huge and there is so much to see... not free but when we visited it, it was free of entrance. not sure when was it free but 20$ not too much.

Not only history but also .... A bit ashamed that we didn't visit this place earlier, while already living here for couple of years. In fact, it exceeded our expections. The museum is big (2-3 floors), modern and very interesting. It covers the obvious Hong Kong history, but also other topics like nature, traditions, cultures, villages, etc. We spent there nearly two hours. If you have time to spare and/or looking for shelter against the rain, sun or humidity, it's worth the visit.
Absorbing informative and fascinating. We chanced on this wonderful Museum which told us graphically so much about the history of HK from prehistoric times. Lots of interaction and exhibition.
Well worth a visit. Puts HK in context, Especially interesting if you grew up in the UK. Liked the recreations of shops and other facilities.

Skip the audio tour. They do a good job with limited space and material but there is a lack of particularly impressive artefacts. Skip the audio tour: it isn't desperately interesting and the narrators, while native speakers, seem to have trouble pronouncing many words which are technical, Chinese, or just long. You sometimes have to guess what they were trying to say.

The Story of Hong Kong. Really fantastic museum! I absolutely loved the organised layout of exhibits, taking you from prehistoric times right up to present day, all of which were extremely well designed. Most sections had small cinema screens with short (8 mins) documentaries relating to the exhibit, playing constantly, with English language versions available (all of the Chinese showings were English subtitled). Best of all the entrance fee is incredibly cheap, just 10HKD, definitely worth a visit if you enjoy history or have a spare afternoon!
Must visit. My favourite is the geological history of Hong Kong. I have not seen such an excellent presentation anywhere.

I absolutely love this museum. Last time I visited this museum was a few years back. It seem like they've only made slight updates to the exhibitions. A great intro to Hong Kong over the years and hand over from the British to the Chinese. I highly recommend spending at least 2 hours at the museum (I can spend a full day there)!

A Facinating Place. We anticipated spending a couple of hours in this museum, but we're there for the entire day. Fortunately, there is a cafeteria for lunch. The museum is on several levels and features displays covering the natural environment, pre historic Hong Kong, the dynasties, folk culture, the opium wars, birth and early growth of the city, the Japanese occupation and return of Hong Kong to China. The displays are excellent and all information is in English as well as Chinese.This museum is more than a respite from the heat or rain; iit will appeal to adults and.children alike and is well worth a visit.

Great Museum - Very Interesting. This is a great museum. We found it very interesting.We spent two to three hours and it did not seem that long.The museum covers a lot of subjects all related to Hong Kong. It has many small theaters showing short films that alternate between showing the film in English with Chinese subtitles, then in Chinese with English subtitles. Interesting films, not too long, that give you a chance to set a little.It is probably one of the best rainy day choices you could make. We went during good weather and it still felt like time well spent.
Great Overview. Excellent museum providing a realistic overview of the history of Hong Kong. The entry is free on Wed however the cost is cheap. The various scenes are very realistic.
Hong Kong museum. I had a few hours open on a business trip. I thought they did a great job with the displays. The beginning is not as interesting, but it turns interesting quickly!

Great place to find out more about Hong Kong. If shopping is not high on your list, make this a must-see. It literally introduces you to Hong Kong from the ground up to the lives of the Chinese who came before all of the high-rise you see.

Learn the history of Hong Kong within a day. If you love history, the heritage museum is an idea place to go and get to know better the history of this city. There are many videos shown in different languages.
Free entrace every Wed; for senior citizens, the entrance is HKD 5 only.

Wonderful and cheap!. I got a tip from a couchsurfer to go visit the museum.
And it was wonderful. Cheap for a student 5 HD and it was fun and informative. And for a scandinavian it was a reliefe to escape the Hong Kong humid summer in the aircondition :D
Very informative musuem. This place is a must visit if it is ur first time to HK! Very gd place to know more abt the history of HK!
A must-do in Hong Kong. It is something that you shouldn't miss!A very interesting museum that offers all you have to know about Hong Kong in a very modrn building and in a very low price

History. Beside shopping in Tsim Sha Tsui, a good place to visit here in Hong Kong. The entrance fee is cheap and you can spend an afternoon here. Lots of different historic items you can find there like boats, trains, clothes, houses...etc. a peaceful place!

great way to spend a rainy morning. Had plans of visiting the museum anyway but chose to go when the weather was abit drizzly. Spent 2-3hrs walking around and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. The special exhibit featuring old relics from around china was particularly interesting. Very well laid out museum with many interactive areas.
Go on Wednesday. excellent information and free on Wednesday, but not too bad either way. Interesting exhibits. Close to the MTR station and please to see in the surrounding area
Hidden Treasure in TST East. I especially enjoy the permanent exhibit, HK Stories. I came just in time for the exhibit on Han Dynasty.
Beautiful and Informative. A very informative museum that houses a lot of beautiful displays that showcases the beautiful history of Hong Kong.

Great place to go when raining. What an interesting place to visit. The museum is well set out with lots of information. We spent 4 hours there and enjoyed every moment. Great place to go when it rains

Excellent, A must visit!. I love visiting museums. And by far Hong Kong museum is one of the best. The entrance fee is cheap, cheaper for students (even international). It was designed perfectly, and was so interactive that those who did not lie museums will even enjoy exploring this museum. With movie played about the past times was the great addition so the visitors wont get bored. I spend more than 3 hours inside the museum, bauce its just so good that I didnt want to missed out any part of this

Colorful and Stimulating. This will definitely be a museum that I will return to many times. It is arranged in chronological sections, beginning with land formation and prehistoric man in the region. The Han and Qing Dynasties are explored and section 4, Folk Culture, was especially interesting to me - religion, the 4 main tribes of people in the region, festivals, opera and puppetry, wedding traditions, and customs and beliefs. The Silk Road and Opium Wars were well-explained, then the growth of the city, the Japanese occupation and finally the return of Hong Kong to China.

Excellent museum. Great story told through well through designed sections. It took my wife and I 3 and half hours, even though we ARE NOT usually museum attenders. The clips in each section were good summaries of the displays. We had to stop at the museum cafe for a break before going to the temporary exhibition - Rise of the Celestial Emperor.
Interesting and worth a visit. Found the museum interesting and not too overwhelmigly big. Free admissions on Wednesday, although it's not very expensive normally either. Nice cafe in there too.

Great to spend an hour. My first trip to Hong Kong, I wanted to get some insights into the history. - The Hong Kong Museum of History is the place to go to. I spent about an hour and enjoyed the life-size displays that give an excellent impression about the past and the development of HK.

Nice historic place. A good historic place to visit, there are lots of different historic items, including the old boats, trains, and clothes, houses, jobs, etc. There are lots of theatres inside the museum, people can sit down, rest and watch the movie documentary clips presented inside the cinemas. You won't feel boring, and also there are very few people visiting the museum, even on Sundays. Not much children inside the museum, very silent, and is suitable for a visit.

Nice design . The interesting interior design made you feel like you were walking through the streets of Hong Kong rather than a museum. There are several life size homes, shrines, and even a small city block. Nice break from the heat.

An extremely interesting museum, with a very low entry fee.. It must be an interesting challenge to be a museum curator in a Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, but the challenge has been surmounted here. About the only sign of any 'corporate' issue was that the same information board can be seen in more than one museum.The museum covers several millenia; with only limited time at my disposal I jumped the pre-historic section and the Dynasties (I had been in the PRC earlier this year). What I was particularly interested in was the history of the development of Hong Kong and the last 170 years or so.This was well recounted, although to be honest not quite as comprehensively as the museum in the base of the Television Tower in Shanghai (but to be fair, that does have the advantage of only covering Shanghai's recent history and not trying to cover as much as this museum).Various rooms were re-created and political, commercial and social history explained, usually accurately. (That said, I do hope that they have taken note of my comments and replaced the Union Flag at the stern of a model harbour vessel with the red ensign shown in the picture on the wall behind the vessel).The potentially sensitive area of the creation of the SAR was well handled.With an entry fee of only $HK10 I thought this cheap enough, but the price is halved for anyone over the age of 60, so amounting to about 50 pence in UK money.A lot of 'buses run past the museum, although I was within walking distance from the United Services Recreation Club (which regrettably TripAdvisor declines to list).
Don't miss it.. A must-see for first time visitors to HK. Great backgrounder for geology, geography, social and recent history of this great city.

This is a museum trip like in the movie Night At The Museum, amazing 1nce in a lifetime experience.. Now this was something really special. I knew I was going to a museum. I wasn't expecting to be taken through a trip of Hong Kong's history and I was both surprised and excited to enjoy such an experience. The history is brought to life through the most amazing museum exibits you will ever see. Walk through an ancient Chinese city, explore the open port of Hong Kong. This was a wonderful museum and a wonderful show of national and cultural pride. I was proud to have spent the day learning about Hong Kong's bright and wonderful history. The noddle bar was sweet but the food wasn't great. Everybody was very kind.
Gorgeous - Must See Museum. This is one of the most beautifully designed museums I have visited. It is a must see for anyone interested in a visually stunning trip through HK history.
Great culture experience. Very well display and very interesting museum.Interactive enough if you want and definitively not boring.Well done

Excellent museum with things we had not known about. This is a fine medium sized museum, a short walk from the waterfront promenade. We were glad we went and learned many interesting things about Hong Kong in WWIi, the rebuilding of a high rise Hong Kong, as well as earlier history and folk culture. It is well worth watching the video presentations. There are also hsnds on activities for children.

Good . very easy to reach this place by bus also. The architecture is very interesting. This museum does a great job covering the very early beginnings of Hong Kong thru present day. Well worth a look round with some beautiful displays.

Enthralled by it ! Must visit for History lovers ;-). I visited Museum of History on a nice sunny day in Hong Kong ! Well, I had a spledid time there. I had read in a TripAdvisor review, that if you want to know Hong Kong, you need to underestand Hong Kong first ! And the best way to "know" & "understand" this beautiful place is by visiting this museum of history !This is very well-organized place...and it takes you the old era...and different life-styles in those era. If you just walk through a particular era...you literally live the life-style of that period, so finely and minutely are the things placed and described....Well, the museum starts from very basics of Natural Environment & then Prehistric Hong Kong,. It has sections on various dynasties & Japanese Occupation as well. Ends with a lovely view of Modern, Post-British Hong Kong ! Was amazed to know what all this beautiful country has been through !!

Great Museum Indeed!!. Great content for those interested in History. The stories, exhibits, descriptions are world class. It may not be the Chicago History Museum but it surely is very very good !! The entry fare is so resonable @10HKD. Loved the experience overall.

Great rainy day out. Great way to take in the history of Hong Kong on a rainy day. Some interesting perspectives and introduction to the ancient and modern history of China and Hong Kong. Great for kids to explore and run around too - not at all stuffy.

Well worth a visit. I managed to leave the familly shopping and visited the Hong Kong Museum on my own. I was in a rush and only had an hour or so, which didn't do it justice. However, the whole layout and exhibits are second to none. they have gone to extraordinary lengths to make the exhibits interesting to children and adults alike. Strongly Recommend a visit.

Give it a miss . The ticket price is HKD 7 but it is still not worth it. Not even worth the time. The closest MTR is Tsim Sha Sui and its a 15 minutes walk to the museum. The museum doesn't say any entertaining things about HK. I love visiting museums. But this one was a bore.

Good Museum with lots to see.. From a full size Junk to a walk through old fashioned street with a good overview of village life the museum has a lot to offer. There are several AV presentations as well. Kept 2 six year olds and 2 three year olds interested for 3 hours. Didn't see it all so will be back. Well maintained and good information available,

Interesting facts about Hong Kong. Very interesting museum. Got there 2 hours before closing but ran out of time for the latter part of the exhibit. Spent too much time at the beginning sections 1-4. Almost missed the fact that you had to go up 2 sets of escalators to the second half of the exhibit - which featured the more recent history of Hong Kong. Was unable to watch the various videos as closing time was approaching. Definitely worth a visit!

Superbly maintained with lots of interesting exhibits and shows. This museum can be a good respite from the hustle and bustle of the TsimShaTsui area that surrounds it, and it has some very interesting exhibits too. Hong Kong history would not be vast compared to many other civilisations, but it surely is fascinating, and the museum does a great job in bringing the visitor from jurassic times right up to the handover of Hong Kong from British to Chinese rule.Having spent a period of my early childhood in Hong Kong, many of the mid to latter 1900s exhibits and shows are quite amazing. Particularly good for me are the replicas of the 1970s-style tea house and convenience stores. The attention to detail is very nice to see.Very much worth a look, you won't be disappointed.

History museum. Free, very well done, spectacular and instructive. The films are good and the museum staff is amiable which is not always the case in Hong Kong where a certain abruptness may be encountered
A Great Overview.. This Museum has an extensive range of exhibits covering all aspects of the history of Hong Kong.Very interesting to see how things have developed.

Very Interesting. Easy to go by bus or walking ,the museum is next to others on a parge plaza. The architecture is very interesting. Inside we walk across the wooden bridge above the 19th century lanes . It strats with the historical geography/geology of the area ,explaining through interactive display in several langages ...so it goes from the early human settlement to nowadays .houses,trades,fashions,documents....Worth a visit !

Not to be missed!. A fabulous museum very carefully planned. There are eight galleries displaying the history of Hong Kong from the beginning of time to the present day. We spent hours here, working our way numerically through the galleries. The variety of material and its presentation ensured that we never became bored.

For history lovers. I like the permanent display of how Hong Kong looked like decades ago. The exhibits of the traditional Chinese drug store, tea shop and the 7-storey public housing unit are fabulous. Theme displays such as the Russian joint exhibition of the Tsar dynasty are really eye-opening.
World-class museum. The Story of Hong Kong is amazing. Its history is relatively short, but it packs a lot of fascinating events into it. This museum depicts it with panache.

Trip Through the Ages. We spent 2 hours in this Museum which was a little too short - at least another hour could have been spent. The museum tells a very interesting story which is really interesting. The exhibits are first rate and they even have sections with tea rooms, shops and a bank showing what these were like. The usual video-film sections educate and the layout takes you through the years.We liked it - two teenage kids in tow also enjoyed it. The entry ticket was cheap (£5.00) for the four of us.
Visitor. Very enlightening to the children to see so many of the historical views in HK. Very colourful and educational

Great way to learn about the history of the city. Fantastic journey from prehistoric times up to the hand back to China in 1997 and beyond. Great way to spend the one rainy day on our visit. The map showing the expansion of the coastline due to reclamation was astounding.

Very Good for learning more about Hong Kong. We meant to go to the science museum but that was shut (as it was a Thursday) so we went to the History museum which is just next door. It was a really thorough museum of a period of time so short. Would definitely go there again and as a bonus there were short documentaries where you could sit down at regular intervals. Just take note that it is shot on a Wednesday and is shut for refurbishment currently.
Informative and interesting. Lots of exhibits, well written and explained.It gives you a complete history of Hong Kong, its culture and heritage.

Brilliant and Interactive Journey through Hong Kong's Rich History. This is one of my top recommendations for travelers coming to Hong Kong. This museums details all of Hong Kong's extensive history in an extremely fascinating and interactive way. Visitors are able to walk around in mock houses and even go on a boat in order to really experience the history being discussed and shown. The flow of the museum is natural and easy. Not to mention, on Wednesdays, any visit to the Museum of History is free! I would highly highly recommend visiting during your trip here if not only for a few hours.
Good way to spend a few hours. Pick a hot or rainy day and go for a visit, only $10 entry and informative, do it as a first thing on your holiday to set the tone of the area

Great Museum covering City History. This museum does a great job covering the very early beginnings of Hong Kong thru present day. Captions are in Cantonese and English for most displays. Definitely grab a map to see which exhibit areas are around you. Not much in the way of hands-on activities, so not a good museum for kids under 12 (there is a kids' science museum not even 50 meters away in the building just across from the front lobby, best to take them there). Once you exit the exhibits at the end, there are bathrooms and a small restaurant along with the gift shop closeby. Excellent museum overall, covers the history very well. Of note, usually on Wednesdays admission is free of charge. Check ahead to confirm. A perfect outing for rainy days.
Could have stayed all day!. A must do for a visit to HK. Fabulous exhibits covering prehistoric HK up to the modern period . A bargain at $10! Definitely recommend!
worth visit. Interesting place just when you are tired of shopping. Worth visit, allow for a couple of hours. Nice souvenir shop downstairs.

Excellent explanation of Hong Kong History. This was a way of cooling off in mid day for 3 hours - though we could have easily stayed longer if they had not been closing. Excellent presentation of Hong Kong - super video presentations too. Interestingly enough the eras of Hong Kong difficulties with China were ignored which was a shame but otherwise don't miss it.

Rainy Day at Hong Kong Museum of History. I headed here on a rainy day and learned an amazing amount about Hong Kong. The floor plan is excellent and takes you through the exhibits chronologically to the modern day. It is huge and there is a lot to see, so if you like history and want to take everything in (including all the video installations) along the way leave LOTS of time. If you just want a snapshot you can do it more quickly but I would say you would need at least 2 hours to make it worthwhile.

Good museum with beautiful displays. This museum was near our hotel and ad it was a Wednesday we got free admission (many museums are free on Wednesdays). Well worth a look round with some beautiful displays.

One of the BEST history museums EVER!. This was an amazing museum! It was set up by period and had extensive displays that showed the culture of the time, the way people lived and also dealt with the art and music of the times..one of the best history museums I have seen. It actually had mock streets with stores, banks etc set up. It touched on the education system and even showed more recent items from the 50-60's. I would offer a suggestion....start at the top floor and work your way down. We started at the bottom which was nice and informative but the top floors have more to see and we had to push to get through everything before they closed. The museum is extensive.Be prepared to spend 2-3 hours of time..it will pass quickly. It has clean restrooms and places to rest along the way and a wonderful store filled with great things about the history of the area.

If you want to really learn about HK history, you must visit this.. I lived in Hong Kong for ten years but never visited this museum until March 2014 when I came back to visit. I really enjoyed looking at pictures and detailed descriptions of Hong Kong's history, before and after becoming a British colony, during the Japanese occupation in WWII and its handover to China in 1997. The whole exhibition even starts from the ancient times before Hong Kong even existed. There were many exhibitions depicting the daily lives of Hong Kongers in the 1950s and 60s. Looking at images from history did not always feel distant--there were pictures that showed people lining up to fetch water during a water crisis （制水） in the 1960s--and my dad went through that phase in his childhood when he was asked by his mother to go get water. So going through these exhibitions felt really personal to me.There were also a lot of replica old ships, cars, trams, Chinese medicine shops, post offices and etc on display. There was also one section about the time when Hong Kong was opened up as a port after the Opium Wars. I even saw a copy (or original) of the Nanjing Treaty that was signed between China and the UK which conceded Hong Kong to the UK. It felt quite emotional to see these artifacts because I learned about the history during high school and finally got to see things related to this humiliating chapter of Chinese/Hong Kong history. There was also a part about the Japanese occupation and a board that indicated "Japanese occupation of Hong Kong headquarters" which was placed in front of a Japanese military office in Hong Kong during the occupation. Looking at these artifacts and descriptions of the hardships Hong Kong citizens suffered during the occupation was quite emotional as well. The most significant thing that I've always remembered about the war was that local citizens were confiscated all of their HK money and were forced to convert them into Japanese military money--which became useless after Japan's surrender in 1945. To this day, people in Hong Kong who held these military bank notes still have not gotten their money back. It's been 70 years since WWII and the Japanese have still not completely apologized for their wartime aggressions towards victims in Asia. One must not forget history if one does not want history repeated.

Complete history of Hong Kong. I took advantage of a rainy afternoon and paid a visit to this museum. It's very well laid out, spacious and informative. It gives an interesting and complete background the the fascinating history of Hong Kong.
PERFECT SUNDAY!!. I had such a lovely time exploring this museum for hours on end. It is clean and hygienic as well as interesting. Definitely worth the visit. The entrance is extremely cheap too.

Packed with information!. At only 25HKD, this is the best value for money in the whole of Hong Kong. The permanent Story of Hong Kong exhibition is a detailed and exhaustive journey from prehistoric times to modern day. I went with the main purpose of finding out more about how HK became a British colony and what instigated the handover back to China in 1997. I wasn't disappointed!Showcasing a dazzling range of photographs, films, models, storyboards, recreated streets and some amazing old newsreel footage, the museum excels in educating and engaging you.

Well thought through in its layouts and exhibits!. Maybe not as fancy and expansive as the other big museums but clearly a gem in its own distinction. There is a sense of linearity in its exhibits, which is brilliant if you are a history buff or prefer a linear timeline. If not, there are places for you to 'skip' certain periods, which works great if you are in a rush or not into certain historical periods. I make it a point to visit a nation's museum everytime and this one was educational and excellent.
Stunning exhibition!. Excellent exhibit about the history of Hong Kong from pre human settlement to modern day. Everything you need to know about Hong Kong.

A small museum packed with a lot of History. For a relatively small state, Hong Kong's Museum of History contains quite a great deal. Going around the museum's various floors makes it quite fun for someone like me who is into history to just absorb and explore everything. I'd give it around a 3-4 hour walkaround the whole place just to really see everything about Hong Kong's history that's displayed. It's located in TST, so when you're done, you can just take a 10-15 minute walk back to the shopping areas.

Not to be missed! . Wonderful exibits! History of Hong Kong from the very beginning. The bottom floor is about the early settlers while the upper level documents European settlers. Can spend two days exploring this museum. Free admission on Wednesday.
Very intersting. Really interesting and well presented exhibitions. We only intended to spend 90 mins here but stayed for 3 hours! It's a good way to learn about how HK has developed.

Very enjoyable with special exhibit on Han Dymasty a must see. Well organized museum adjacent to Science Museum. I learned lots in an unhurried pace. Beautiful exhibits with sculptures, statues, clay and other artifacts. The jade suit is awe-inspiring. The rest of museum is also interesting giving facts about geologic aspects, nature in Hong Kong, a brief tour of dynasties, the Japanese occupation and Traditions in Hong Kong.

Worth a visit. Great display of the history of Hong Kong. Skip the beginning prehistoric section and head right to the cultural exhibitions. There is just so much to take in and the best parts begin with section number 4. Also do not invest in the headsets. They do not work well and don't follow the displays.

intersting way to spend an afternoon away from the heat. took my wife and daughter and we all enjoyed it vey much.learnt quite a lot on Hong Kongs history , culture and people. canteen was a bit naff though ( although to be honest thats not what we went there for)

Interesting museum. I'm not usually a fan of museums but the Hong Kong museum of History was really interesting and I thoroughly enjoyed my visit with my family. Inexpensive entry fee and a lovely few hours break from the summer heat. Would definitely recommend for a family visit.

Interesting history. I'm not a huge museum person, but this museum was great! It was a wonderful of the history of HK and it was very creatively put together. It was a great escape from the summer heat for a couple hours. don't bother getting the english audio guide....you definitely don't need it. All of the exhibits and multimedia are in english.

Very interesting and easy to find. We found the history museum to be a great place to visit. They have a special exhibit now called the Rise of the Celestial Empire about the Han Dynasty. It is the 60th anniversary of the discovery of the Cheng Uk Han Tomb and many relics from the tomb are on exhibit and are very fascinating. The history museum exhibits are on two floors and are very well done as well. There are many video presentations and the history of Hong Kong is very interesting...many subject areas are covered including the Opium wars, Japanese Occupation, folk culture and more. We took the MTR there and found the museum without any trouble. A friend recommended we visit the museum and we were glad we did.

Great overview about the history of HK. We have been visiting the museum with our kids at least 7 times over the last 5 years and enjoyed it each time since there was always something new the experience. Some of the exhibitions were really interesting and well curated. Can recommend it to each tourist who is interested in the history of the city in particular with kids.
Fascinating insights.. Spent a long time here - so much to see. Very imaginatively laid out. Needs more than one visit if you have the time.

to know Hong Kong better.. after visiting the museum, then you know Hong Kong is CHINA. PRC is not CHINA. PRC is thief who steal from HKer: baby formula, study, housing, selling lead contaminated and poisoned produces. PRC is about to destroy Hong Kong, so go to HK museum of history soon, before PRCers changed the history saying PRC is the savor of HKer.“He who controls the past controls the future. He who controls the present controls the past.”― George Orwell, 1984

Outstanding and enormous!. The museum's permanent exhibition the history of Hong Kong is outstanding and enormous! It has 7 sections covering from when the area was formed to the handing back of HK from Britain to China. It is amazing whoever has curated this exhibition with interactive parts, films and plenty of 3D displays.We enjoyed the few hours we spent in this museum and believe everyone living in and visiting HK should visit. It also happens to be a bargain museum at only HKD25!

Time for only one museum ?, this is it.. It was fantastic, educational and cultural immersion for an introduction to HK. With it, you will see why HK is what you see and experience during your trip. To me, I try to visit a museum in every country/city. This one is a must see for Hong Kong.

Historical insight into Hong Kong in an immersive permanent exhibition. Hong Kong Museum of History's permanent exhibition gives an exciting and immersive walkthrough of Hong Kong through the ages, from when it was a patch of land inhabited by early ancestors up until today. The museum put a lot of work into the exhibition and as you walk through the museum, your surroundings will change as you walk through the ages. You don't just read about the British occupation of Hong Kong - you walk through the streets as they looked back then. Would definitely recommend this permanent exhibit to anyone who's wondering about Hong Kong's history, e.g. tourists with limited prior knowledge like myself.All descriptions and signage is in English, and the museum appeared to me to be wheelchair friendly. At 10 HKD for entry, it's basically free to enter. Expect to spend a good 2-4 hours in here, all depending on how much you decide to delve into or skim through. Also expect a somewhat onesided take on some historical events, but as long as you are aware that you are mainly hearing one side of the story, you will still learn a lot about those parts of the story.

...and I am impressed!. I would rate this the best museum in Hong Kong - great displays, spacious, entertaining and educational - the Hong Kong Museum of History is one not to be missed! It took us almost half a day to skim through one floor.. can't wait to be back to check out the remaining floors! From pre-historic landscape formation to present day culture and heritage of Hong Kong, a visit only costs 1USD. There's also an excellent exhibition going on about the Han Dynasty till Oct at the museum. I can't recommend this place more
Wonderful. It's a wonderful museum! Didnt got much time to explore but it's sure a nice one. It's a comfortable place and you can even try on the traditional clothes for free!!

Suprising. A very good museum with many interesting exhibits.Visited on a national holiday so entrance was free, but isn't to expensive anyway. It told the full story of HK from thousands of years up to Britain's colonial rule, returned to China. All factualy told

Opium Wars & Japanese Occupation. Very interesting museum that kept me fascinating for close to 3 hours. I skipped through the first two sections (natural environment and prehistoric Hong Kong) and didn't spend too much time on the Dynasties (Han to Qing) section. However, from the folk culture, Opium Wars and the Japanese Occupation sections, this is where I was most interested and spent the bulk of my time. Extremely informative and the various video/theatre shows are a great way to soak in the information whilst sitting down (they have English, Cantonese and Mandarin screenings but if you can't wait for the English one, there are subtitles for the other shows). Modern Hong Kong (postwar) section was quite amusing seeing the various plastic products Hong Kong use to make.There was a separate special section which was at an additional cost - not sure how much but I was more than happy just to get the standard ticket for the bargain price of HKD 10 (around GBP 0.80!)Recommend to come early: I came on a Sunday morning around 11am and it was pretty empty (15-20 people max) - when I had finished which was almost 2pm, the queues were building up and tour groups were coming in (which I'm sure would have made for a noisy, crowded and unpleasant experience).
Good canter through HK's past.... ...with a very straight bat played on the past -- very informative, good exhibits and well set out. Definitely worth a visit for those interested in HK's past

Brush up on the past. The Hong Kong Museum was very easy to reach on foot from the Ikon Hotel where we stayed.
It gives you a very comprehensive background to HK and is well worth spending 2 or 3 hours - particularly good for a rainy day
Spend Some Time. We kind of happened upon this treasure and wished we had more time to spend as we had to rush it in the end. Great displays, and an excellent account of Hong Kong history.

A must-see for all HK Visitors. Hong Kong has always been known for its shopping and food. But first-time visitors should find time to visit this museum. A half-day tour is okay and there are not so many tourists especially during weekdays. It's a 10 minute walk from TST MTR station and is very close to a nearby HK Science Museum (you can actually visit both museums in 1 whole afternoon).The museum admission is a negligible HK$10 so that is just a little more than US$1. One gets to see HK's history from prehistoric to modern times. They even have small replica of HK's famous junk and complete with the backdrop of the old HK in the 50s. The kids will enjoy all the collections of artifacts, dioramas, dinosaur bones, painting, replica of old chinese stores, opera, and many others. The place is clean and the rest rooms are immaculately maintained. You may want to bring thin jacket as the place is really cold. This is one place first-time or many-times visitors should go when they visit HK.
Small. very small compared to major museum in Paris or UK. HK is stil far away from historical preservation.
Proud of Hong Kong. A museum should not be missed! Especially the kids in Hong Kong, they know nothing about the past history of Hong Kong. ^0^
Very organized. It is easy to get around and you can easily choose what to see depending on your tastes. They have audio recordings giving more information which I thought was awesome.

Great Place to Catch Up on the Story of Hong Kong. I am a history teacher so I obviously love things like this, but even my wife (who is not a history fan to say the least) enjoyed this place. It does a good job giving some background knowledge on the story of Hong Kong. It was a perfect place to spend a rainy morning out of the wet humid air!

Good option on a wet day. Visited on our last day in Hong Kong prior to a late flight. Better than expected, spent several hours exploring and had lunch in the cafe. Short videos often shown in English or at least with subtitles.

A fascinating and detailed look at HK history. I don’t know how the other reviewers got through this museum in two hours; I spent six hours there and had to go back the next day! (A week-long museum pass is only HK$30 and covers "all museums of the Leisure and Cultural Services Department." Totally worth it.) If you like museums, allot plenty of time for this one. It starts 400 million years ago and charts Hong Kong’s development to the present. There are videos to watch; interactive multimedia screens that allow users to learn more; rooms set up to simulate traditional festivals and homes or even towns, so you can poke your head into everything from the traditional home of the boat people to a turn-of-the-century grocery store, dressmaker’s shop, post office, and more; dioramas of natural environments and animals native to Hong Kong, along with interesting notes about how the animals have adapted to these environments and whether the animals can be found in HK today; and helpful explanations and fascinating tidbits throughout, in English. The museum also has a nice cafe that’s perfect for an afternoon tea break or reasonably priced lunch, and the gift shop offers an excellent selection of English-language books as well as classier souvenirs than you’ll find at the average market. My only complaints about the museum are that sometimes the intended order of exhibits isn’t clear, and occasionally the museum presumes knowledge of Chinese history. For example, from the Bronze Age it suddenly jumps into the dynasties, with references to people and events that haven’t previously been referenced in the museum. There were also a few places where I wasn’t sure where I was supposed to go next, or where the chronology was muddled. The First and Second Opium Wars are mixed together, for example, and the events are displayed willy-nilly around the room, with references to people and events that might not be explained elsewhere. The introductory video in this room gives a good overview; but even so, it’s difficult to figure out what happened in what order. (I think the outstanding Maritime Museum gives a better explanation of how the Opium Wars came about and what their impact was.) Overall, a great way to spend a day! Highly recommended.

Go here FIRST!!!. Poor planning on my part, we went to this museum on our last day. I wish I had gone here FIRST because it was an excellent overview of the history of Hong Kong (from pre-historic to present day). This is a great museum and we were able to see the special exhibit on the Tang Dynasty, which was amazing. This is a great place - do not miss it.

Worth a visit!. This is probably not a museum that you would want to take your children to, it could be a little bit boring, but it is an excellent museum to learn all about the history of Hong Kong. The museum is well laid out with plenty to see and learn about. The first part of the museum (downstairs) was a little bit dull but for around £1 per ticket you really cannot complain. This is a great way to spend a couple of hours!

A Must to Learn about Hong Kong!. If you want to learn about Hong Kong, a half-day tour of this place is enough. Lots of dioramas and full scale models to appreciate the culture that Hong Kong is. There are also some docus to watch and plenty of interesting trivias to learn. Nice place to shoot a lot too! Plus there is a gift shop at the exit for you to buy some cool souvenir items.

Pretty good. The permanent exhibition gives a good overview of Hong Kong's history. Two quick comments:(1) Don't bother getting an audio guide. It's easier to just read the info and watch the videos, than to search for audio tracks that correspond with exhibits.(2) I'd like to have seen some physical models of Hong Kong to retrace it's spatial development over time.
Worth a visit!. It is very nice and complete museum. It is a good opportunity to spend a couple of hours learning more about the Chinese culture and history.

Great place for Hong Kong history. Inside the museum, there are a lot of traditional and cultural setup for phototaking. You will understand all old stuff of Hong Kong. All models are in real size. In addition, there will be different seasonal exhibition. Once you finish this museum, you can just go to the opposite science museum to enjoy another half day.

Thoroughly enjoyed. They've done a wonderful job in putting this all together. Huge, to scale constructions inside the building. Short documentaries done in English in the theatres, all translations on exhibits made sense, and a good intro to HK history. Entry is only $10 HK- well worth it.

Tell-tale of Hong Kong - free visit on Wednesday. Museum is a tell-tale of Hong Kong, from how it was ceded to Britain in the 19th century to its handover back to China. Displays many aspects of local culture. Its a collection for shutterbugs.Unlike other museums of the world, this one doesn't have a welcoming entrance or a helpful staff but don't fret, its still worth a visit.

Get to know Hong Kong's history!. A walk through Hong Kong's story, well explained . Everything in Chinese/English. Up till today's time, get to see images and lot's of lively shows and movies (timed for Chinese and English). You need min. 2 hours to visit.

A useful stop for history buffs, but not a great museum.. If you can even find the poorly-marked entrance, you will find yourself wondering if the museumis actually open.For museum fans, this might be a disappointment. Although there are many interesting individual exhibits in the museum, it feels like a museum with inadequate funding. Go anywayfor an educational overview of HK history, but don't expect the staff to be responsive or even helpful. You have to leave the museum for a coffee or snack break, which is unfortunate given the sizeand number of the exhibits. It misses the opportunity to bea perfect indoor oasis on a hot day of travelling with family, so it falls short of being user-friendly.The museum shop might be the best part of the visit. The book section is great.

Great and eye-opening experience! Must try!!!. I am not really a history buff, but this place really piqued my interest. The dioramas/displays are very extensive, it really shows how Hong Kong has started, yes even how the land formations were showed clearly and accurately.I can say that this is one of the few museums that I've really enjoyed visiting. By visiting this place you can already have a clear picture of how Hong Kong came to be. One suggestion though, make sure to visit this place with a full stomach, seeing all the exhibits would take a couple of hours. And there aren't really any interesting cafe/restaurant in the museum building.

Not-to-be-missed. None of the S.E.A. State-owned museums that I have visited can beat this one . This is my second time here, i last visited was June 2014, and I still very much enjoyed 2nd time here. The displays & exhibits were details and very impressive, entertaining and educational.
