Many of the exhibits were of life-like manner (eg herbal tea shop, grocery shop, barber shop, old street scene, there is even a double-decker tram) You get too see, feel and touch the daily life of the Chinese during the olden days. The exhibitions showcase the natural environment, cultural heritage and historical development of hong kong. There are also small theatres that run short videos. You can easily spend 3 hours or more in here. Highly recommended to visit this museum, specially to the younger generation. Take note museum close on Tuesdays (except public holidays) . Free admission on Wednesdays to the history museum, space museum & Art museum. . Space Museum it's just opposite history museum.One of the way to get to History & Space museum take MTR to Tsim Sha Tsui station, before exiting the station look for the exit point to the history museum. About 10 mins easy walk.

Getting to know HKG within 2-3 hours. Reading travel guides? Browsing websites? How can they be compared to seeing it for yourself! With vivid display of exhibits, the Story of Hong Kong in the History Museum tells you a lot about the evolution of this city in 2-3 hours - from how it was ceded to Britain in the 19th century to its handover back to China. It has displays about many aspects of the traditional Chinese culture, and it also has presentation about how ordinary people lived in this mostly densely populated city in the world. Displays are in life-size models so that you may feel returning to the 60's. (Remember to bring your camera) It is not only for history lovers. It in fact offers a good introduction about the city to any tourist. It should be a good place to start your exploration in Hong Kong. A tip for those with little time - skip the first two galleries. If you are interested in history, start at the 3rd, otherwise, start from the 4th. Here is a link to the official website:http://www.lcsd.gov.hk/CE/Museum/History/en_US/web/mh/index.htmlThe museum is located in Tsim Sha Tsui, within walking distance from the MTR stations. A similar display in UK can easily cost you 10 pounds but here the normal entrance is only HK$10. And it is free on Wednesdays!

I will come back again and again. If my friends visiting us from abroud, I show this museum first, when they aren't so tired, becaouse there are a lot of things to see.Highly recommended for everyone.
A must for history lovers. a place of heritage. a must for those interested in knowing the history as well as the special festivals of hong kong.

Highly recommended. Highly recommended for history of China and HK. Divided in different eras presented very well in life size models. Could easily spend half day here. The little movies and temporary exhibitions were also great. Definitely go if you'd like to know about chinese culture and various demographics of the region

Even better than I remembered. We were here maybe 12 years ago, and remembered being impressed with the exhibitions. Went again, and got even more out of it the second time around. This time spent more time in the section about the first peoples(aboriginals?) who occupied the Hong Kong area. Very interesting!
History of Hong Kong. A very well presented museum, with a lto of interesting points I didn't know about Hong Kong and its relationship with its neighbors.
Awesome History. Has Hong Kong history for everyone, and well placed alongside other museums. Wednesday's are free and well attended. Amazing permanent exhibit telling Hong Kong's story. A MUST !

A cultural experience in a modern city. I come to HK for the cosmopolitan indulgence but it is wonderful to trace its history and culture in this museum. It offers depth and is very well done, you will come away with a better understanding of HK, besides shopping and eating!

Good Overview. A nice overview on HK's history. Even for a local, there could be some aspects that are new. Overall nice space, with clean bathrooms and courteous staff, I would say around 1.5 - 2 hours for the whole museum if you want to take a good look around and actually read about the history.
Well maintained museum. Good collection and well maintained. Even though the main Gallery was closed on the day of my visit enjoyed got a good overview of the Chinese history.

Nice overview of Hong Kong entire past. It was a very nice and interesting museum. The experience started some 400 million before now and went through how the area had developed up to now and how man had moved in and lived 5-10000 years ago. The main part covered the last 400 years. Highly recommended for anyone that wants a comprehensive overview of Hong Kong history in 4-5 hours.

Wonderful Museum. Wonderful museum. From early geologic to Post WWII and 1997, museum is just beautiful and informative. I didn't have nearly enough time but it was well worth it to learn more about Hong Kong history.

Great Museum. Spent half a day at the Hong Kong Museum of History and found it most interesting and enjoyable. The displays were first class,well presented and informative. Anyone interested in general history will enjoy.
a taste of the past. Its great that someone has made the effort to keep a bit of hong kong's history. Well worth a visit as it is a shame to miss the history of Hong Kong among the modern skyscapers
A must see. This museum is amazing! It can be difficult to navigate given it's size and the number of exhibits. Do not leave Hong King without seeing it.

Learning Hong Kong history. HK Museum is a place for visitors to learn about the history of Hong Kong. The exhibits are built 1 to 1 ratio and very informative for the old Hong Kong. The history from China, then opium war, Bristish colony and back to China. Each decade, unique culture and commodities are displayed. A good place to experience old Hong Kong.
Very interesting Museum. A very interesting museumEverything is well explainTo now the history of Hong Kong, Opium war, Japanese occupation, etc.

Fantastic Museum - though not ideal for young kids. I generally avoid History Museums, but after reading the great Trip Adviser reviews for this museum, decided to visit during our recent one-month stay in Hong Kong, and we are so glad that we did. We took our two children with us (5yo and 2yo), and here are our thoughts based on our experiences:* It is a really informative, interesting and unique museum. We had set aside three hours to see the museum, but after two hours we had only seen half of the museum, and the kids were feral, so we decided to cut our loses and leave, which we were very disappointed about, as we (hubby and I) would have loved to have spent much more time there.* The tickets are so incredibly cheap! We went on a Sunday, and there was hardly anyone there. Apparently the Museum is free on Wednesday (please don't quote me on that though!), and gets extremely busy on that day ... I would rather pay such a relatively small amount and have the place to myself!* The Museum itself is very easy to get around with a pram, and all of the employees that we encountered spoke good English, and were incredibly friendly and helpful.* Our kids were too young for this Museum ... which is the case with almost all museums and young kids! The Melbourne Museum that we go to quite frequently has lots of things to engage young children (buttons to press, things to touch, etc), which the Hong Kong Museum doesn't have (not in the first half of the Museum anyway - which is the half that we visited), which meant that our kiddies weren't engaged on any level, hence our hasty departure. If you are travelling without young kids, please make the time to go - it would be particularly great on a rainy / super hot day. If you are travelling with young children, perhaps take some toys to keep them occupied while you take it all in and buy yourself some more time (which we unfortunately didn't think to do).

Brilliant!. A definite must for all visitors into HK. I found the displays and exhibits very informative. It gave one an insight into the early settlers, living through the Japanese invasion, experiencing the never ending land reclamation, nervously awaiting post handover etc. The cultural displays were very good as well - full of history and colour.
Well worth a visit!. An excellent trip through Hong Kong from prehistoric times to the present day. Displays were well done with lots of accompanying information.

A must see. My husband and I decided to have a easy day and go to the Museum of History. Wednesday is free so we arrived at 10.00 and left at 4.00 it was a full day but very very interesting a lot of thought and work has gone into setting up of all the exhibits it all just flows through the history of Hong Kong. A must don't miss it.

Interesting place. Kids love the museum with all real-size models. Full history of Hongkong land. Very good place to go if you have half day free. We bought combo tickets for some museums: science, history, art...

Don't Miss This. This museum was a highlight of our 5-day stop-over in Hong Kong and perfect for a wet day.The design, layout and quality of exhibits was impressive. It is also very reasonably priced at HK$10 with 50% discount for seniors.

A multimedia history of HK & China. The exhibit wanders around the enormous building as you follow the path of history. It go really interesting in the early 1800s when the British entered the region.Go on Wednesday, its free.

Excellent museum. This is set up very well. Very well created exhibits and displays. The area is built up in different areas to give you a walk through history. The displays are life sized and very interesting. This is like walking back in time. My two young boys loved there visit here. We will go back next time we are in HK

Interesting and worth a visit.. We visited this museum mostly to get out of the heat and avoid spending more time and money shopping. Admission was only $20HK and an extra $20HK for the special exhibition about the Han dynasties so we did that as well. If you visit on a Wednesday admission is free. We found the museum to be interesting and well set out, with video presentations adding interesting extra information and insights. There were many fascinating exhibits and they were presented well. It was particularly heartening to see so many local families visiting with their children, demonstrating the Chinese value of history and education.

A stunning place to visit and learn the history of HK. We were very much surprised by this museum, and enjoyed our visit there very much. To learn so much that we did not know before, made our stay in HK memorable. Beautifully laid out, and for visitors to be able to be close to things was great.

Best Place to go in HK. Nice place to go when you are in hong Kong . it reveals the past and present times of the country very informative and enjoyable. I will visit this place next time I go to Hong Kong .
Interesting and informative. Informative, easy to locate and not too big, can easily cover the exhibits within 2 hours, worth visiting once
Good place to see. Good and quiet place to visit. You can view tradiational Hong Kong in a comfortable envirnoment with low entrance fees.

Interesting Museum to learn more about HK. Interesting Museum to learn more about HK.
The most interesting part is the last one (20h century) because before that it's not that interesting
Han exhibition. excellent exhibits, especially the Han exhibition currently on! A definite must see destination in HK.

interesting . this was a very interesting place to visit. as a teacher, I've brought 5 year olds and they loved it. they learned a lot from this field trip, and especially loved the status starring the terra-cotta warriors.

Good showcase of the history and development of Hong Kong. The exhibits are very life like and well done. The exhibition starts from the Devonian period 400 million years ago and concludes with the return of sovereignty of the territory to China in 1997. Well set out over several floors, a good way to promote and preserve the history and cultural heritage of Hong Kong.

very enjoyable. We spent a hot humid afternoon inside the pleasant surroundings of the museum and felt refreshed both physically and mentally. All the display are informative and we learned a lot about this ex-British colony. Highly recommend if you have some evtra time, took us about 2 hours!

The best museum we've seen on 6 continents. The Hong Kong Museum of History is a big museum...not the biggest (the Louvre fills that bill) but the best at telling a compelling, cohesive story that takes one through history. The art, crafts, and cultural artifacts are well-chosen and displayed with care and for impact upon the viewer. The museum is divided into four sections that are seamlessly linked – prehistoric times, Neolithic times, Dynastic times, and recent times. A mixture of individual items, very well-done dioramas, videos, and articulate and in-depth descriptions does the job. We saw objects from Dynastic times, for example, that are unique among the museums we visited in China. The descriptions are in excellent English (and, I presume, excellent Chinese, be it Cantonese or Mandarin). The presentations on recent times include some impressively large displays from Chinese celebrations, such as the 10-meter-high bun mountain, 3-meter-high effigies of guardian figures, a traditional wedding ceremony, and lion dances. I have never spent as much time continuously marveling in a museum. In China, the Luoyang and Guangzhou museums are larger and interesting in their own right, but the Hong Kong Museum of History provided the most gratifying experience.
Worth a Visit. Worth a visit, a great place too see the history of HK. Easy too get around and very intresting and it has air conditioning a must this time of the year.
Must visit. This is suitable for visitors who are interested in Hong Kong history. It suitable for family as well, especially for children. It is worth spending at least 1 day at this museum.
Interesting and worthwhile. Good way to kill a couple hours in Hong Kong. Very interesting history of Hong Kong and unlike everywhere else, wasn't too over crowded.

Nearby museum worth visiting. One can see the historical development of Hong Kong. An appreciation of the local races and their culture and living environment. For instance how people migrated from Mainland China have helped to transform a fishing village to a regional finance centre and air/maritime logistics hub. How old style lowrise buildings were changed into skyscrapers.

Place to understand Hong Kong. Entrance ticket cost HKG 10. Children half price. Good source to know more on Hong Kong. Very informative and good experience. Need at least half a day to complete this place.

Great History lesson. Wanted to get an uderstnding of Hong Kongs people and history. This is the place to do it. Starts with a geological exhibit on how the islands of Hong Kong were formed, finishes with the British hand over and everything in between. It is spread over three floors and has many interactive touch screens and a few small theatres that run short videos. Worth the time.Was a little chilly after a couple of hours so maybe bring something warm to wear while inside if planning on staying a few hours.

Good place to understand the history of this distinctive city. This museum is small, but worth a visit to understand the distinctive. Hong Kong is a very different place from the rest of China and people dont even speak the same language. Have a look and gain a perspective to the unique side of the city.

There are some free days - eeee free museum entrance!. The free entrance is valid only for the HK History section, not for any temporary exhibition they may have at that moment.I just visited the free part, the main floor is about the natural history, fauna and flora of HK, and leads to the ancient populations of the area. Upstairs is more about the modern human history, ending with the retro-cession to China.All in all, I would have liked to stay longer, I really enjoyed my visit.
HK. Absolutely basic, essential & fun, to understand Hong Kong from it's beginnings ; complemented by videos, commentary & even a little cinema for the afternoon feature!

Gives ample information on HongKong History. Visit on Wednesdays for Free Entrance. This was me and my friend's first visit during our HK escapade. It did not disappoint us as the place offered everything; from ancient HK to modern HK. They have mini theatres with different shows, depending on which part of history you are in. I was glad they had english shows. Hand held cameras are allowed inside. eating and drinking not allowed.Visit on Wednesdays for Free Entrance.

So Much to See!. The museum presents the history of Hong Kong from Neolithic times to the modern era. Its expositions vary from cavemen to traditional Chinese theatre, from antique junk models to old books, from 19th century house and market models to exhibits on Japanese occupation and various social issues. Very interesting museum where you can easily spend half a day or more. Well worth a visit!

the history or Hong Kong from prehistoric times until now. The museum is located in the Kowloon Park. It has 8 thematic rooms over 17 500 m2. You can also watch a lot videos about various topics.Hong Kong's natural environment is a major theme. There are 2 800 specimens of roches and minerals and more than 750 types of shells found in the Hong Kong territories.But the other themes include Hong Kong's prehistory, the imperial densities (from the Han to the Qing), popular culture in Hong Kong, the opium wars, the sales of Hong Kong, the birth of the city and the beginning of its growth, the Japanese occupation and finally the modern metropolis and the retrocession to China.Hong Kong being such an extraordinary place, learning about its history in such details is really interesting.

Great way to learn how HK become what it is. We took advantage of the free Wednesday admission and visited the museum. I grew up in HK and it was great to get a refresher on the history and a new appreciation for the resiliency of the HK residence.

History museum which is not boring. History museum may not attract everyone. This one is big and need 2 good hours if you read and take time to appreciate the varoius info boards.However, if you just want to stroll around, it is enough to get a good glimpse of what HKG was and went through. Very high ceilings allows big mock and fake shops, fishing boats to be exhibited; Many short movies, around 10 minutes, are screened along the rooms (mandarin, english) for variety and also a good way to have a short rest.the ticket is not expensive (HK$10). if you are in the TST area and need a break from shopping, it is a good stop.for those who likes to know the background of HKG, it is worth your time.if you come from HKG side, you can take the bus 111, which stops you just at the toll, near HK Polytechnics. it is 8 minutes walk to the museum.

A must visit for history buffs. This is very well set out with many different areas of interest . There is no need to visit every gallery, just choose those of interest. The galleries are set out in logical sequence. There is a lot to see so allow at least half a day. Have a look at the early photos of Hong Kong and the harbour.

Good oversight of the territory. The museum is modern and well designed. It provides an excellent overview of the area from prehistoric primeval times (not so interesting) to the handover in 1997. Well worth spending a few hours, especially if it's raining!

Old Hong Kong easily accessible. Like much of Asia the old Hong Kong is hard to find. So great credit goes to the Museum for capturing the history of Hong Kong from the earliest times to today.Any one who knew Hong Kong of the 60's and 70's will love the recreated Hakka villages and other clan housing. Also they have a great selection of the articles of the time including an original HK Tram !! Well worth the visit to Kowloon

Excellent for a rainy day. A very good history of the sometimes forgotten parts of the cities fascinating history. Dating back from pre historic times to the present. Not to be missed by anyone interested in these things

Informative displays and videos about HK history. The Hong Kong Museum of History is spacious and has interesting exhibits. Areas have been designated for different periods within its history. Great displays and rooms you can walk into and become a part of (pawn shop, post office, etc.). The videos are very informative and a wonderful resource for 20th century HK history.

The best museum I have ever been to. Museums don't usually interest me, but this was well worth the HK$10. There are very interactive displays and have recreated an ancient village. Excellent for understanding the history of Hong Kong and the social changes.

Good way to get an overview of Hong Kong history. We were a bit unlucky as we coincided with school visits: there were hundreds of wonderfully ebullient primary school children with us. Even looking over these tiny heads we could still appreciate the detail and care taken in the research preparation and display. Of particular interest were the sections on the different ethnic groups which initially settled in the Hong Kong area. The museum does not shy away from a nasty past such as the role played by English and French colonials during the opium wars. There is also a very impressive research centre available to the interested public.

Best museum I have been to. I have been to many museums both in the UK and when overseas, the Hong Kong Museum of History Is the best of them all! It is very evident from the moment you step inside that there has been a lot of investment. The museum is well laid out and easy to navigate, with signposts to different periods of time. I guess the thing that most shocked me was some of the innovative ways in which the information was presented. This is truly a museum for the whole family. With detailed statues and recreations from all the key periods of HK history and theatres dotted around the museum that brings it all together. The videos go on a rotation between Mandarin, Canton and English languages.I have to say, that unlike a lot of museums in the Mainland, it is evident that the curator have utilised a native English speaker to write the descriptions, which makes a massive difference to the overall experience and quality. This is a must see, for anyone interested in more than just selfies of corporate buildings in Central.
Worth a visit. This museum takes you through the 8 phases of the history of Hong Kong. I spent more than 2 hours walking through looking at the exhibits and viewing the old documentaries.
Really interesting. Learnt so much about the history of Hong Kong and the surrounding area, really worth a visit. It's free on Wednesdays.
Good place. Interesting - worth speeding past some of the ancient stuff to get to the later more interesting bits IMHO. Lots to see

History museum visit turned into nightmare. I went to see the Treasures from Tsarskoye exhibition at the HK Museum of History in TST in 2014. I really enjoyed the displays but my tour presenter did not speak good English. Not only did she have a difficult accent, she did not pronounce many words correctly. So I decided to leave the group to wander on my own. The lighting was dim in some areas and the description of the pieces is placed far from the white borders on the floor, as I tried to lean over in order to read the writing (not stepping over the borders yet), a security guard was quick to tell me off, "Stand Back!" This happened 3 times during my 1 hour on my own. I am a frequent museum visitor and know the ettiquetts that one should respect the rules and I do. But these guards apparently they are out sourced to a private security company. These staff are not well trained and they don't even look like a security guard in their uniform. Anyway, I went to Customer Service at the end to lodge a written complain about the bad treatment.It's really too bad because HK needs more cultural activities and exhibitions. We need the people involved to be more friendly and professional without being condescending.
Best museum in Asia. Yes. worth taking the kids and an education museum and worth every penny a visit if you and kids are into museum this is a must see!!!

Very interesting. Been here twice now and find the museum extremely informative and very well presented. It is ideal for tourists as well as local residents who want to learn a lot more about Hong Kong's history.

Fantastic museum telling the story of Hong Kong in a very visual way. This museum charts the full history of Hong Kong. It does this in stages and in chronological order. Lots to look at which aids the story telling.Going here really helps you fully understand what Hong Kong is all about

Learn the history. The museum is situated in Tsim Sha Tsui which is very convenience for travelers to visit. Inside the museum, it separate in different sections which show you the living of Hong Kong in different stages. You can easily understand how the changing of Hong Kong from a fish village in the early stage to a modern city. Learn the history, gain the knowledge.

A superb museum covering the history of Hong Kong across the ages.. Whilst on business in Hong Kong I had several hours to kill before my flight home to London and so I decided to visit the HK Museum of History and I'm glad that I did as it was very informative and very nicely laid out. It covers:(1) The Natural Environment(2) Prehistoric Hong Kong(3) The Dynasties from The Han to The Qing(4) Folk Culture in HK(5) The Opium Wars(6) Birth and Early Growth of the City(7) The Japanese Occupation(8) Modern Metropolis and the return to ChinaYou really need a whole day in the museum to really do it justice (or several visits) but while I was there I really enjoyed sections (2), (3), (4) and (5) where I learned some interesting facts about the development of HK and its people that I'd not known previously. The Museum is spread over 3 floors with escalator and lift access. The exhibits are superbly done, especially the junk and the different living conditions in the Folk Culture Section, bringing history to life and making it easy to understand and enjoyable for all age groups from school kids to pensioners. There are also theatres on the G/F & 2/F Levels which regularly show educational audio visual presentations.I visited on a Wednesday which happened to be Free Entry day, but even on a paid entry day entrance cost is a very cheap HK$10 (that's less than GB£1)!! Refreshments, rest areas and toilet facilities are available and are well maintained. There is also a good sized shop selling gifts and reference books, etc. All in all this is a great Museum and one that I highly recommend anyone to visit.

For history buffs.. A great museum if your in to history. Covers the time from the formation on Singapore in geological terms to the handover by the British to Chinese. Also has some displays with local fauna.

Very good or excellent. The weather in HK is often an incentive to find things to do indoors! But whatever the weather if you have any interest in HK, this museum is a must. It is very well presented, suitable for different ages, some of the exhibits are spectacular and all are well explained, the various films available as one progresses through the museum are informative and the right length, and the explanations are based - where relevant - on the Chinese (and not, for example, the British) point of view. Set aside 2 - 3 hours at least ...you will not be disappointed. The entry cost is approximately the equivalent of £1.00 - free on Wednesdays (but closed on Tuesdays).

Modern China and Hong Kong's role. A must see if you are interested in how modern China - from 1900 till present is shaped. How Hong Kong became a revolutionary hide out for Dr Sun - the founder of modern China. You can visit places close to the museum where Dr Sun was educated, lived and practiced as a Doctor.

As interesting as ever. The museum never ceases to interest as it tells the story of Hong Kong from before Neolithic times to the present. Particularly interesting are the accounts of the Japanese occupation and the post Second World War period.

Worth a visit, rain or shine.. This was one of the best museums we've been to... as many have already commented, it really is more than a museum. They did a really good job recreating things and making it really interactive. You're not just looking at photos or things or artifacts behind glass; you're physically walking through a cultural adventure. This history museum is no joke - they start you at pretty much the beginning of time where on one end the Earth's crust is cooling, and then on the other end the British are handing Hong Kong over to China. We went on a rainy day and it was an excellent day for that, but if you have the time it's worth a visit in any weather. You can fly through there and get a gist in about 1.5 hrs like we did (dim sum reservations awaited) or you can probably spend upwards of 3 hours really getting into it.

Good one. This is museum has lot of space related stuff from China. Nice to go with children once.Most of the items are related to China and US only. Space related History of other countries are not covered in this mesuem

Great insight, excellent displays. The Museum is located in lower Kowloon and is a great activity if you need to escape some heat, or even better on a rainy day. It offers a great insight into the History of Hong Kong, starting with pre-human times and animals and plants, and slowly winding its way (literally) through major periods of social and political history in Hong Kong, the various Opium Wars, up to the Handover back to China. Dioramas and displays are excellent, with lots of large 3D interactive displays, recreated cityscapes and houses, even a recreated port area. Definitely recommended if you enjoy museums
Great way to spend an afternoon. the museum presents a chronological history of HK from pre-history to present. The displays are interesting, particularly 20th century. t
Qite informative. We easily caught the ferry across bay and walked the 20 min to museum. The price is reasonable and the layout was easy to follow

We didn't give this enough time!. The Hong Kong Museum of History is an exceptionally well put together museum which covers the full range of geology, culture, natural history, modern history etc.There are two huge floors and we were running out of time when we made it to the second floor so didnt have enough to time to see the excellent displays of life in Hong Kong in the last centrury through British rule. The section on the Opium Wars, the Second World War and Japanese occupation.are also excellent. Give your self at least three hours here. It's modern, well set out for English speakers and very interesting.

Find out a bit more about Hong Kong. A very good museum. Honestly I believe if you are going to visit a place you owe it to yourself to find out a bit more about it than the shops and nightclubs.This is a wonderful place to learn more about Hong Kong - its distant past, recent past, and where it is going in the future.There is a lot of fascinating history connected with Hong Kong and this museum does a great job of presenting that.Worth a decent half-day trip.

Visit here twice, it holds its charm. Its unbelievable that in the middle of a very premium city, there's a space for museum with such an extensive displayThe museum experience is rich and immersive.It describe HongKong "ages" with extensive display in terms of size and detail.Should go here if you have more than 2 days at HongKong.I think, truth be told, the shopping malls present things you can get in your hometown. This museum presents something that is unique to the city.
More than a museum. It`s really great!!! Its not a common museum, its a exhibition, gallery, cinema in 1 place. Must visit!!!
History museum in Kowloon. Excellent museum our family went and enjoyed every minute even though we are not usually museum visitors as sutch. Good for a rainy day as well

A REAL EXPERIENCE. Spent a whole afternoon here and thoroughly enjoyed it. First two sections not so interesting but remainder excellent with good displays and video presentations (all with English subtitles). Reconstruction of shops and businesses very well done and plenty of information for all displays. Loved the Chinese culture gallery with its explanation of Chinese opera and festivals.

Entertaining but lots to see. Give yourself at least 2 hours to properly enjoy. Very reasonable pricing, 20hkd inc. audio guide and maps.
If on time limit, skip the first section which is exclusively about rocks. Whilst the geology is fairly interesting it doesn't deal in too much of the cultural history.
Low lighting for most exhibits so some may struggle with photos.

Worth the Time. Great museum. Would recommend allocating 2 hours in the museum. Watch most of the videos in each area as they give a great overview of the different sections of the museum. Don't wait for English version, the other versions have English subtitles.
Highlights: Different ethnic communities of Hong Kong, festivals/celebrations and Japanese occupation

Interesting Few Hours. The museum is great - filled with valuable information on the history of HK. The beginning section (geology/etc) is a bit dry but the second half is very engaging. Starting with the opium war background through WWII and into the transition back to China's rule, the museum does a great job illustrating the history of the city and its role in Chinese history.

Great for History Lovers. If you go to Hong Kong not knowing much about the area's history, like I did, this a great stop for you. The museum starts back in the prehistoric era and comes all the way through into the modern history of Hong Kong. I learned so much about the city and it made me appreciate Hong Kong a lot more than I did before.

Great crash course of Hong Kong. I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of exhibits and how well this place was laid out. The full scale exhibits like the Bun Festival, Chinese Opera Stage, etc. were especially delightful. Expect to spend about three hours here, in order to do it justice. The entry fee of HKD10 was reasonable and worth it.

Awesome Museum. I loved this museum. It was fun and realistic. The amazing exhibits - historical events and culture - brought HK's history to life for me. I feel so informed now about how and why HK is such a fantastic city. Don't miss this opportunity. And, easy to get to by bus from Star Ferry.

Surprise Special Exhibit. We were fortunate to visit while the"Treasures from Tsarskoye Selo" - Residences of the Russian Monarchs - was exhibited. Evidently this was many years in the making. As well, the museum was very well done definitely worth visiting.

Amazing.... We visited the history museum ...it was opposite the science museum... I must say I was quite amazed... It was a real treat for the eyes especially for me as I am very interested in it...they have an elaborate display of all their culture ..they had made displays of old Hong kong...like banks...shops ...fishing ...clothes ...etc so good...a must visit...my little one was a bit troublesome and the security was following us :) but we just had to see place ...it might be tiresome for less than 3 yrs old kids..
The best museum of Hong Kong. A large museum provides very wroth information of Hong Kong.You will feel like you are walking on a street in the past.วันพุธเข้าฟรีครับ

if you crave for culture and a bit of history, this is the place. As a travel, this place is a well managed compact venue, and a popular sightseeing attraction. Due to its limited space, only a few exhibits are displayed at one time. Elaborated presentation may warrant more spectators.

Every object tells a story. The Hong Kong Story comprises 8 galleries located on two floors. The display has over 4,000 exhibits, life-size exhibits and short documentaries. This museum is set up in a way that makes you feel as though you are going back in time, because they do a great job with settings and costumes. It has an easy to walk through. Free entry on Wednesdays. Well worth the visit.

Interesting, Comprehensive Primer on Hong Kong. Well curated and wonderfully displayed, this is my favorite museum in Hong Kong. Especially for the first time visitor, excellent way to be introduced to the history and rich Cantonese culture.

An incredibly informative and detailed museum. WOW. The Hong Kong Museum of History exceeded our expectations. Our only regret is not being able to spend more time there.With 8 exhibits, flowing throughout HK's fascinating history, we thoroughly enjoyed the whole thing. It provides a very detailed, colourful account of how HK became the place it is today.There are many staff members about, making us feel like they take their museum business pretty seriously :)We did a little interactive quiz upon entering and even though I failed terribly I was given a fantastic little notebook as a prize. A NOTEBOOK! Woo! (#highlight) :)

One of the best museums we have visited. Visit on a Wednesday if you can free admission to all museums. Certainly worth paying for if Wednesdays aren't an option.Well designed exhibits and displays. Films giving explanations of the history of the island also very good. Britain had a lot to answer for with it's treatment of the locals during their imperial reign,If you only have time to visit one museum in Hong Kong this is the one!

Very interesting Museum!. An excellent museum! With interesting artefacts.Go early so you can view the exhibits in relative peace. I went at 10am (it opens at 10am).look at how Hong Kong was born. from the really prehistoric to the modern city it is now!Especially great are the life-sized housing in the museum! If you only have time for 1 museum in Hong Kong, make this the one!

A very interesting place of learning. Most museums I tend to just wander through, but I actually enjoyed this one and spent more time in it than I thought I would. The museum has designed the walkthrough following the timeline of Hong Kong. I enjoyed the way the museum has built streetscapes and rooms using original features. There are different films using historical footage in the small cinemas along the way to reinforce the things happening in the timelines. This is my 4th trip to Hong Kong so I thought I knew the place but I learnt many things here. I believe that is a reflection of a great museum. Good gift shop too.

Great Excellent. Fantastic. In fact this place should be a must on Family Traveler's list. This place gives you a complete picture right from the Evolution of Hong Kong in the primitive days up to the Modern Financial Business Hub - Hong Kong. Completely enthral lung and educative experience.
Interesting place. Free entry on wednesday's and well worth a visit, lots to see - we spent a happy couple of hours wandering around.

Get to know more about Hong Kong. If you want to experience the life of old Hong Kong and have a look at the things that were all so common to every Hong Kong households in the 50s and 60s, you got to come here. You probably won't have a chance to uncover this part of Hong Kong if you do not visit this museum. Interesting and fruitful. You can come with your kids for a relaxing afternoon.

From fishing village to a busy city. Spending 3 hours in the H.K. Museum of History can be extended to a full day's activity. This Museum is interesting in its own right. Next to the Museum of History is the Science Museum. Entrance fare is also as low as HK$10. Location of this museum is in Tsimshatsui East, good shopping area with easy transport.
nice place. nice place for warst the time during raining day, intersting for learning about hong kong history. Free acces in wenesday..

A Mixture of Good and Disappointing. Overall an OK visit. I was really impressed with the beginning of the museum. Some of the details are outstanding with the houses and clothing on display. The level of detail for the WW2 piece was very good indeed.However I was really disappointed with the lack of content that was provided for the period 1945 - 1996 and made me wonder why?! It appeared that the growth of HK during this period was glossed over with only two or three panels detailing the modern history and development of HK into a major financial center. Then after the handover the level of detail was again very good. Reminds me that the "owners" write the history books.
Its a museum. Some history of HK! but only go if you have no other options. HK anyway have a lot of other attractions.

An interesting look at Hong Kong's history; particularly the British Colonisation period. A very interesting visit. Good value at 10HKD entry fee. Covers Hong Kong's ecological development, settlement of various groups of people, its relationship with Mainland China, British Colonisation, Japanese invasion, and finally the handover to the PRC in 1997. Although there were disappointingly few artifacts and a lot of photos generally, it was clean, well organised, quiet and good value for the price. However, a lot of the information there could have easily been accessed from the internet, such as the photos and details. Nothing too exciting in terms of seeing too many artifacts from the period's of time. If you are a beginner to Hong Kong's history then you should find this museum of great interest, but for advanced knowledge visitors, it may not be for you.
Nice way to spend a few hours. Covers from prehistoric times (a bit boring) through the Opium Wars (which I now understand), through British and Japanese rule to modern day status

Excellent Museum. The museum is well laid out and contains a number of interesting displays. It provides information about: - the geologic, geographic and biological history of HK - the influence of the various groups of Asian arrivals and the various Chinese dynasties on HK - the reasons for the arrival of and the impact of the British - the Japanese occupation during WWII - the period 1945 to the present dayEntry fee is very reasonably priced at $HK10

Definitely worth the visit. We visited early in our Hong Kong stay we we might brush up on our history before we started seeing other sights. The museum did not disappoint. It is very well done with lots of different ways to present the information. Short films...large visual exhibits...displays with all different kids of artifacts. best part was we were practically the only people there on a Tuesday...except for some adorable school children. You can get through the whole thing in 90 minutes so definitely go if you want an overview of Hong Kong/China from a historical perspective.

dont miss it. need 2 hours, dont go with a tour, there is a very good explanation of the history of hong kong.
it very close to the science museum and also the harbour.
Good visit. A concise historic record of Hong Kong. Well presented building and usually quiet. Wednesday's is free admission but be prepared to share with school children!

We love this place. We love this museum. Went last year, and we again found it fascinating. With all the articles in the press about China’s sense of historic humiliation, this museum gives excellent presentations of part of that history, naturally focused on HK. The exhibits depicting and describing the four main groups of people who came to settle HK was well done and gave a good explanation of the population’s diversity present from its beginning. The displays of religious traditional elements was wonderful, and the material about World War II and the aftermath were very informative. This is definitely worth your time and the little money it costs, especially for seniors.

Ok. Only went in as was opposite the the science museum which we loved. Not very enticing this museum so only the half hour there. I would give it a miss if you are on a tight time limit see other things
Exploring Hong Kong. Every Wednesday will have free admission for the public. We can explore and enjoy the interesting feature of Hong Kong History.

Explains a lot about Hong Kong's fascinating History. Our visit to this museum proved to be a very enjoyable way for us to learn about Hong Kong's fascinating history. If you visit make sure to see more than just the first floor. We were there for more than 2 hours and enjoyed room after room. There's so much to see. Hong Kong is a great city to visit on holiday and this museum is definitely worth a visit!

Informative Background on Hong Kong. Museum provides a comprehensive background on how Hong Kong developed to present day. Multi-level facility with multiple informative periods and exhibits. Went on a Wednesday with free admission.
A better way to explore Hong Kong. Is all about Hong Kong and is a nice place to explore if you wanna get to know more about Hong Kong. Free admission during Wednesday.
Informative. This is a very interesting museum. You get a better understanding of Hong Kong after going through all the exhibits. A visit of 1 to 2 hours is recommended.

Informative and interesting !. We are not typical museum person. But it is a good place to spend some time here if you are not keen on shopping areas. Our guide , Helen, from China Odyssey Tours, offer to bring us there after our tour ends early in the afternoon. The exhibits are all well presented and there are several short film which help us better understand the past and present of the city. Interesting place to visit!BTW, the museum is free on Wednesdays and only HKD$10 per person.Closed on Tuesdays.

An excellent, almost un-censored history of this fascinating city. We were in HKG for a couple days to visit family & checkout the sights, but it was quite rainy/cloudy & cool, so we decided to checkout the museum, which was a bit of a walk from our place for the night: YMCA at The Salsbury. We were educated on many of the things that we should've studied up on prior to travelling, but were too lazy to. The One Country - Two Systems was an interesting concept to me, although it continues to be a struggle since The British "gave back" HKG.This was a very well done museum & should be a required stop for all visitors. Mainland China has had some major issues with the truth that you will find here.
Very Interesting. Brilliant History Museum with plenty of History and artifects. Interesting to visit this place. The entrance is free along with your Hop on Hop off Tictects

Learned a lot in a fun way. This museum is set up in a way that makes you feel as though you are going back in time, because they do a great job with settings and costumes. It has an easy to walk through layout from the prehistoric times all the way to modern Hong Kong, and is great if you're a visitor looking to learn more about the city, or simply there to learn more about your own heritage.

Can spend half day and have fun. With human history at the very beginning and Hong Kong history in the last section, this museum is worth for both local and outsiders to visit. I brought my parents there and triggered them to share their childhood to me which is also very meaningful! I think the last part of "re-unification with China" is not worth to visit, it is a nightmare indeed!
Beautiful. We were amazed by this museum. Well done, you can walk it on your own or take the self tour. Beautifully done. Great place to go.

On your own or as a family group, do visit - a big, and rather unexpected surprise. I grew up in Hong Kong and have visited a number of times over the years, never visiting any museum. Rain, however, drove us in here and oh my goodness was I surprised by the place, as was my husband as he would have brought his UK pupils here if he could have done, there was so much to see. I would disagree with a previous reviewer that they were constrained on budget, they have actually spent a lot of money on this place and the exhibits are excellent and particularly in the cultural part of the museum, they are very colourful and lively which kids will enjoy. I had expected to spend an hour here and spent nearly 3 which I think says it all.

Big but clearly budget constrained.... Nice sections about old Hong Kong including some very cool ones from the 20th century. The museum feels like it came from 1975 - for better or worse. Convenience is a big plus, you should go to Taiwan or China to see the real thing...

A fantastic history of Hong Kong. I am not a museum person, usually only last an hour or so, I have been to this one several times, it has great exhibits and a mocked up city, allow plenty of time when you visit.

a must do in HK. in between going to the Peak or checking out the markets, this museum is a must do in HK - HK's history is well presented and gives context to everything you see and do and experience in present day HK. take the Star Ferry to TST or the MTR to TST station and take a short walk to the museum. you won't regret it.
Good museum. Good place to see. Have many historical things there in Hong Kong Museum of History. You can spent 2 to 3 hrs there.

Very interesting indeed. Well-laid out and covers HK history very well.
The striking thing is that only a couple of posters and half a room are devoted to post-British 'Chinese' Hong Kong and the 'future'. Maybe this will change?

The best museum in HK. Well-presented, spacious and educational, this museum outperforms the others in town. Whereas the art museum and science museum nearby both feel completely stale and outdated, the Museum of History's exhibits have been carefully and thoroughly thought-out. Great for a visit with kids or visitors from out of town to gain quick insight into the region's complex and rich history.
Place of quietness. Surrounded by skycrapers, this beautiful nonnery is a place of quietness and power. You can relax in the wonderful park and forget about the hectic of the City.
Great for history buffs. Excellent displays, shows history timeline in accessible manner, visited several times, my HK favorite

Well curated, interesting for the whole family. Well laid out museum that tells Hong Kong's story logically and in an appealing way. Background on the colonial era is especially good, but the natural history, ethnic exhibits appeal to kids also.

Well worth a visit. We took the Metro to this modern and well presented Museum.From start to finish the rooms and the exhibits were very well lit and the air conditioning excellent. We liked the way the Hong Kong story was told from the earliest of times, through the Opium Wars, the early trading settlements, the development through to WW2, the occupation, liberation and hand over in 1997. All was presented professionally and was most informative.

Good way to spend a few hours. Although I previously lived in HK for more than 4 years, this was my first visit here with my girls whose Dad is from HK. the exhibits were interesting, colourful (in parts) and provided a good overview of the history of HK. Of interest was the video showing HK during WW2 and during the water rationing period in the 1950s. Its easy to get to (like most places in HK) on the MTR. The special exhibit (for which there is a separate charge) in December 2014 when we were there were the treasures of the Czars. It was a beautiful display of an ostentatious lifestyle and they even brought a real golden carriage there. All in all, if you have a few hours and can tear yourself away from shopping, its worth a visit. There is also an excellent cafe which is charitable in nature (cant remember the name but there are clear signs around the museum) where you can have snacks as well as a full meal.
A walk through The history of Hong Kong. We spent several hours here and it was amazing .Several short movies,wonderful exhibits made the outing very informative .Admission cost was $10

Fascinating museum. A fascinating view into literally thousands of years of Hong Kong history. The displays are incredible and have bilingual displays. The dioramas are really good. Great fun for young and old. Go on Wednesday when it is free!
Free on Wednesday. + Free on Wednesday+ Near from science Museum+ Friendly Staff+ Knowledge about Hong Kong+ Not so hard to find the place

Very dissapointed. We walked quite a way through busy streets, too much traffic!!, especially to this museum in the heat in order to gain some knowledge of the history of the area. We walked all around it to find the door! Not easy ! It was closed!! Oa Tuesday!!!

Great museum with free admission on Wednesdays.. We visited the Museum on Wednesday which was free. The staff was friendly and helpful. We arrived late and had 40 minutes to visit. It is a good museum. I wish I had more time to explore the museum.
Go here. This is a great museum. Everybody in the family loved it. Good balance of stuff and interaction. Gives some great context to the city as you walk around.

A very good museum. The museum gives the history of Hong Kong. It has many divisions. Shows are run at many theatres. A place where one can get information about the history, culture, trade, rise and fall of Hong Kong, natural disasters, etc. A must visit place.

Fun Day. If you would like to know more about Hong Kong,
I would suggest you come to visit Hong Kong Museum of History
The location in TST, easy to go, even you are a Hong Kong people, you must come and know more about your country
Definitely worth a visit. The complete history of Hong Kong, presented in great, easy-to-understand manner. Would highly recommend it.

History is fun.. After The Peak, this is the place my wife and I visit. We actually hadn't plan to get here, but when we saw the building, we just had to come in. It is as fun as it is educative, especially if you like history and want to educate your child on the history of Hong Kong.
Nice musuem. The musuem was very nice and for only 10HKD it was worth it, for walking around and learning about the history of hong kong for the 2 and half hours that I was there.
Well worth a visit, and a break from the bustle. Only $10HK and excellent and informative history of Hong Kong from the pre-historic times to the present.

Visit only if you have time. Hong Kong does not have great museums as well as much illustrious history, so you should not expect much of this museum. Only if you have much time, or real interest in the history o Hong Kong that the museum is worth of a visit.

Visit this musuem for some valuable context. It will enhance your experience in Hong Kong.. If you love history and want to learn as much as you can about Hong Kong, don't miss this museum. Do this at the beginning of your trip. It will help give you some context for what you will experience while in Hong Kong. I loved the stores that they have installed in a recreation of a typical old Hong Kong street. There is audio playing in the background of the last descendent telling the history of that store.

Very informative. The museum is great way to learn the history of Hong Kong. We enjoyed a rainy afternoon indoors. Every aspect of Hong Kong life dated back thousands of years ago is documented and displayed. The short films gives you good visuals.
Free on Wednesdays. A great way to pass a few hours if the weather is a bit unkind and you want to be inside.Very interesting and the information in English as well as the video presentations.
A must to learn Hong Kong History. Excellent museum on the history of Hong Kong, obviously Chinese biased towards the British.Free on Wednesday.Visit also the adjacent Museum of Science.

Set Aside Time for This. A trip to this museum should take about half a day if you plan to go through most of the exhibits and areas. It is a fountain of information about Hong Kong and a feast for the eyes with its attention to detail. The coverage of this museum is massive. There's even a Chinese junk boat and tram (ding ding) replica you can actually stand in. Free entrance on Wednesdays, except to the special exhibits.

Loved the great color and larger than life exhibits. We spend an entire afternoon in this newish museum, following the chronological history of Hong Kong. The exhibits were most colorful and we brought home great photo memories of them. We also learned about the bombing of Hong Kong the day after Pearl Harbor, about which we had never read and the horrible 3+ year occupation by the Japanese that followed. A very moving part of the museum.

Well worth the visit!. This is a wonderful museum - I learnt so much about Hong Kong during my visit here. The experience was made all the better by the docents, in particular Wang Fei Cheung, who spent over 2 hours with us, giving us a tour of the museum and a concise history of Hong Kong as well as giving us an insight into his personal perspectives. Nothing he said was boring which can be the case when you take a tour of a museum! Everything he said was genuinely interesting. I would definitely come back here on my next visit to Hong Kong and maybe try out the Science Museum next door next time.

Fantastic museum. We decided to take our two kids (5 and 8) there for a late afternoon visit to kill time. It was such a fantastic experience and wished we discovered this museum sooner. There is so much to learn and to explore there that it is worth it to get a pass and visit over a few days. The museum was spacious and the exhibits are fantastic - with a good mix of interactive and informative displays. Our kids were fascinated by this place. The best part is that general admission is so cheap that you don't feel bad just going in to see one section and leave.

Excellent History Museum, Great for Curious Children. I wouldn't bring hyper kids here, but if you have children that are interested in or engaged by learning, or even if you just want to know more about the natural and cultural history of the region yourself, this is a great stop.Among the best parts was the "The Hong Kong Story" which had a great series of recreated shops and scenes from the history of the city. A better history museum than I was expecting.

A whole day's event for the family, or the curious.. This is a wonderful museum for the whole family to go through,to learn and enjoy. Lots of exhibits which are not like you would find in the US. I wish I had had more time to read every label and story of the various displays. I plan to go back our next time we visit HK.
All about history starts from here. Do you interested in Hongkong's real history? come and see the details in Hongkong Historical Museum. You'll find unforgetable experience about hongkong history

A must see when you visit Hong Kong. This is a fabulous museum with so much information for all ages, Adult and Children, and should be a must of places to visit in Hong Kong. Every aspect of HK life going back thousands of years has been included both in information (written and verbal presentations) and the display of artefact. Give yourself a minimum of a few hours to absorb the incredible amount of information.

Great Museum. Brilliant. I took my 3 children (aged 8, 11 and 18), who were not keen, but they loved it. We were in the museum hours and they want to go back. It was varied and interesting, if you go on a Wednesday it is free. Highly recommend this museum if you want to find out the history of Hong Kong.

Brilliant!. I had so much fun visiting this museum. A lot of work has been put into making this museum interesting and visually stimulating. It's a great attraction, very interesting and easy going and ridiculously cheap AUD$1.50!! Definitely recommend!

Story of Hong Kong . I went to the museum with my 11months son. Very baby friendly place! Strolling around with him was easy. Interesting lay out of exhibits. I enjoyed reading and my son slept through.

A very interesting place. The Hong Kong museum of history is a nice very visual museum. It gives you a very good idea of what Hong Kong was through the centuries. Kids usually love it because of the very visual aspect of it. there is not a lot of artefact but more some reconstitution of streets and local culture.

Donghuan caves on show in Sha Tin. This is a temporary exhibition, but I should say that I've always found the temporary shows at the museum to be well worth the time and trouble of slogging out to Sha Tin. This one featured facsimiles and explanations of the Buddhist caves on the Silk Road in the northwest of China, and you you really need a couple of hours to do justice to it. My advice would be to go and see how much you enjoy, then leave. Entry is only HK$10. Unfortunately our party found the museum to be a bit chilly -- the aircon was pretty fierce on an early March day.

Don't miss if you like history. The museum is really well done. They do a good jo of making it interesting and interactive. There is a wierd part about the natural history of the island at the beginning which we sort of sped through to get more to the cultural, political history - but ended up spending hours here. It's cool, I learned a lot

Great museum . The museum covers Hong Kong's history from the beginning of times to the English handing Hong Kong back to the Chinese. Very interesting and believe it or not fun museum to visit. If you are short on time, I would recommend to just quickly walk through the first two exhibits.

Very interesting. Covers just about everything you would want in a museum of hong kong's history. Some nice displays, though some more background info would have been useful for some displays, particularly relating to Chinese history, which I was not very familiar with before visiting!

A must!. I love museums and feel that it is a must to visit local museums to get a quick glance or in depth understanding of the country. The admission was as low as HKD10 which was very surprising as it costed nearly HKD100M to build. I'd say my preference for the whole museum was starting from the second floor where opium war started till the transfer of sovereignty. The details of everything - buildings and artefacts - made me feel like I was walking through the tunnel of history and living the moment. It was also well equipped with a lot of little theatres, showing short documentary of relevant topics. It was the best HKD10 spend and honestly I am happy to pay more for the value. Be ready to spend a good few hours and probably include it in your last day of itinerary if you take a late flight as we did - check out, take a slow walk and spend some good time there!

Hong Kong history in style, well-kept museum. If you don't know anything about Hong Kong, come here for a stroll! It will perhaps be the cheapest paid museum you'll find in the world - costing HKD10 (like merely a buck!). It's installations are well-kept, and you do get to see a lot of Hong Kong history and culture which is disappearing from mainstream Hong Kong life. There's a section about Hong Kong as a colonial city, donned with beautiful old Hong Kong posters and memorabilia, complete with actual sized shops. In a different section there's some older Hong Kong history pertaining to fishing life and boat people's dwellings. In another section, you'll see life-sized homes and models, displaying Hong Kong village life in the old days. It's especially beautiful with all the red items detailing wedding rituals, Cantonese operas, and small village ceremonies. This museum is a gem and also a favourite even among the locals.

The Hong Kong Story.. Went on Wednesday, admission is free on Wednesdays. It starts slow, but once you get to the folk culture portion of the museum with the bun mountains and the Cantonese opera theater it gets interesting. Following that is the history of Hong Kong from the Opium Wars to the present. Was a nice 2-3 hour afternoon stroll.

Well Worth a Visit. This museum is a little way out of the centre but its worth the effort to get there. The staff are a bit querky in the way they run this place but the whole site is cavernous and has magnificent displays - particularly for the folk displays. Its very child friendly and I strongly recommend this venue.

The Lovely Experience!. Please Scroll Down for English language หากใครคิดว่าพิพิธภัณฑ์คือสถานที่น่าเบื่อ เต็มไปด้วยตัวอักษรและประวัติศาสตร์ แล้วไม่ยอมมาที่นี่ขอบอกเลยว่าพลาดมากค่ะ ภายในจัดแสดงเรื่องราวของฮ่องกงตั้งแต่ยุคก่อนประวัติศาสตร์ ไล่เรียงมาเรื่อยๆ จนถึงยุคอาณานิคม ยุค 50's จนถึงปี 2000 ที่อังกฤษส่งมอบฮ่องกงคืนให้กับประเทศจีน ได้อย่างน่ารัก มีมุมถ่ายรูปเก๋ ๆ มากมาย ส่วนตัวชอบห้องที่จัดแสดงฮ่องกงในยุค 50's ที่สุด น่ารักมากๆ ได้เห็นเฉินหลง โจวเหวินฟะ ดีไซน์ผลิตภัณฑ์แบบย้อนยุคสวยๆ ร้านเต้าฮวยสีพาสเทล ประทีบใจจนต้องกลับไปอีก ใครที่ผ่านไปจิมซาจุ่ย บอกเลยว่าห้ามพลาดนะคะForget about the old style museum that you ever visited before . Here's chic and trendy . the exhibitions has many information about history of Hong Kong but the high light are in the 50's room that will bring you back to the past with oldie songs in the pastel mood.LOVE!!!

I guarantee you'll like it.. Began wondering about this museum as we walked around the first floor. But when we got to the second floor our doubts vanished. There's a lot of maritime history here, along with headdresses, statues, masks, models, costumes and a Chinese junk. Lots of kids from school were here. Go, see it, I guarantee you will like it.

Great introduction to HK history. We really enjoyed the museum, especially the part on modern history. It gave a good impression of how Hong Kong evolved from a swamp to one of the most exciting cities on the planet. The section on the Japanese occupation during the second world war was fascinating, would have liked more details there :) highly recommended

Go upstairs!. The first part of the lower floor covers the natural environment and "pre-history" of Hong Kong. Near the end of the first floor is a nice exhibit on folklore, and early groups and how they lived. After that, one is directed up two floors and can learn more about the British arrival and occupation of Hong Kong, early days of the city, the Japanese invasion during WW II, postwar and modern Hong Kong of the 60s/70s. For us, as foreigners, the last part of the first floor, and the second floor were most interesting. Worth a visit; Wednesdays are free days.

If you are from Asia with Chinese culture knowledge, you may not spend much tme here. . As I am from Malaysia and we have similar Chinese tradition and culture, I find that most of the information that is gained there is nothing exceptionally new. So we spent less time than other visitors here. as many highlighted the place is big and very informative especially if you are not exposed to Chinese culture before. I enjoyed the short documentaries most.make sure you catch the show of the documentaries at each key sections. I was amazed on how rapidly hong kong has changed. The place is huge so make it your first visit of the day before you starts walking more in the city. It can be exhausting if you have walked in and out of the mtr before coming here.Suggestions to have tickets counter at the entrance instead of the level above. Also the arrangements of the exhibition is a bit confusing as it is not numbered (information cards) I was lost few times finding the right flow. Overall a good introduction to Hong Kong definitely!

Fun and educaltional. My wife and myself spent an excellent afternoon in the history museum. The museum is organized wisely and with Proper combination of pictures, exhibits and videos.I highly recommend for all ages.

For $10 HK - A Clean And Fun Museum. We traveled there on Weds (free admissions day), but it was only $10 HK to get in. The museum taught me HK history from prehistoric to the present day. You couldn't tell from the outside, but it was quite large. One could really spend over 2-3 hours (or more if you looked at everything) at this museum. Across the way was the Science Museum. That one was equally good. A family could spend all day there. The only drawback was that there was no "in house" dining. If they offered old 60's HK style dining there, then this would be a place with "6 stars". There was a gift shop at the end of the museum walking tour. It was a well-stocked gift shop with many interesting items. The museums (both the science and this one) were well monitored with staffers to make sure everyone has a good experience. I believe that this museum and the Science Museum across the open space were "must goes" if one was in HK with kids. If you don't have kids, just stick with this museum.

Really interesting. Really good museum. All HK's history is explained pretty well. Even if it's not huge, you can easily spend here at least 3 hours roaming around quickly. There are documentaries projected which are interesting.Right in front of it there's science and technology museum.Ticket fee is 10 HKD.Highly suggested during a rainy day

A must visit!. If you are anywhere near Sha Tin, you must visit this museum. I absolutely love it. You will learn a lot of history from your visit. My friend (he lives there) suggested we visited it and I was reluctant at first, but turned out I had a blast! You even learned about the indigenous people of that area thousands of years ago.

Excellent, excellent, excellent. Going through the exhibitions, it hits the exact memories when I was growing up. Very detailed and very authentic.This was what Hong Kong was like and some would want it to be like again.

One of our favourite museums. This would have to be one of the best museums we have ever visited. The museum is spread over 3 floors and contains 8 separate historical eras. We found the overall setting was fantastic. Each era was complimented with true to scale buildings, streetscapes, boats, temples, effigies and these helped create a truly immersive experience. We did gloss over some of the prehistoric sections as we were more interested in the specific Hong Kong history including the Opium Wars and their folk heritage. Given our limited knowledge on Hong Kong we learnt a great deal about it from this museum.The main entrance is located up a wide stairway behind the Hong Kong Science Museum and not from Chatham Road South where a lower level entrance is for disabled access. To visit the café you have to get a pass from one of the staff members so they can let you back into the museum as the café can be accessed externally.
Know more about history of HK and china. There are many things about old HK and china.For visitors and local people, it should be a good place to know more about HK!

I planned a 1 hour visit and stayed for 4. This is what a history museum should be - a mix of all-encompassing views and little details presented in a way that allows people to see it all or pick and choose details to dwell on. All for 10 HKD. And with a well-stocked museum shop plus cafeteria (which I didn't try). It's a big museum - there are galleries starting from the geological formation of HK beginning 400 million years ago and going right up to 30 June 1997. The museum presents a history of the city in an interesting, varied and entertaining way. There are plenty of well made films (usually rotating between Mandarin, Cantonese and English, occasionally only single language + subtitles). Comfortable seats ! It's not a high-tech museum - but for history that isn't necessary. It's also reasonably objective - in the sense that it doesn't dwell on the excesses of the dynastic era or the British or Japanese or PRC but merely reports on the key occurrences in as much as they affected HK. (Nor does it directly confront visitors with questions about what they would have done if faced with the circumstances of the time - a style modern history museums in Europe are increasingly adopting). Biggest emphasis is on 20th century. The storyline I missed not having more detail shown was on how opium gradually morphed from the cause of a couple of trade wars (mid 19th century) to a product that could only be enjoyed in 'private premises' (1930s) to being illegal (now). When I visited there was also a temporary exhibit on a St Petersburg imperial palace - this is standard museum quality, OK but not exceptional stuff. Only go if you have a particular interest in Russia.
WORTH A VISIT. It takes you through the entire history of Hong Kong.Everything is well presentedI was there 3/26/2014
Take the English guided tour. The museum offers guided tours in English. Take the time for the tour as you will learn so much more! This is a wonderful museum that is often overlooked.

The Great Museum Expedition. I spent a Wednesday visiting museums in Hong Kong (the day itself is important because the museums had free entry that day) and I called it the Great Museum Expedition. I visited the Flagstaff House Museum of Teaware, Hong Kong Science Museum, Hong Kong Museum of History, and the Hong Kong Space Museum.Easily one of my favorite museums in history is the Hong Kong Museum of History. Set up differently from most history museums, HK Museum of History starts pre-humanity. It brings you from the formation of the islands themselves, through the dinosaurs who lived in the area, and into the time of British colonialism. The museum's timeline ends in the 1990s, when England "returned" Hong Kong to China.My favorite part of the museum was the section about the Chinese minorities who lived in the region. Unlike other history museums I have been to in China, it not only highlights the fashion and differences in the way the minorities look(ed), it also talked about their different celebrations and the cultural differences.If you enjoy museums at all, definitely give this one a chance. I've gotten accustomed to the "eh" level of museums in my time in China, but this one definitely hit my Western standards.
Superb. A great afternoon by myself was taken up with this visit , the whole place I found clean and very informative ,I could have spent longer ,but it had to shut ,spent a good two and half hours .

good learning experience. the exhibits have been put up in a very thoughful way and descriptions help to understan the evolution of hong kong. i specially liked the section on hong kong culture - it was vibrant, colurful and interesting. worth spending a couple of hours here.

First Rate Museum. I visited this museum twice. The first time to see the permanent collection about the history of Hong Kong. The second time, I visited a special temporary exhibit of Treasures from Tsarskoye Selo, Residences of the Russian Monarchs. Admission price for temporary exhibits is not included in the general admission fee for the permanent exhibition. Both of my visits were very enjoyable.
interesting to visit. It is interesting to go to this museum to see the big deco of the old HK. Mostly it won't be too crowd. I won't mind to go again.

time well-spent. this was a place I could have spent my entire day at. unfortunately, I reached here just about an hour before closing time and hence could not do justice to it. the museum takes us through the evolution of Hong Kong, right from the movement of tectonic plates, to the world wars, to the times today. the museum is clean & well-maintained, & has a logical flow of exhibits. it is a great way to understand the city and its culture.
Superb. A really impressive museum. Well worth visiting if you have any interest in history. I especially enjoyed galleries 5 to 8. I plan to return soon.

Tasteful exhibits.. The Museum is well laid-out and replete with tasteful exhibits. A very pleasant afternoon was spent here with friends. I particularly liked the 19th century Hong Kong artifacts. As other reviewers have pointed out- it's the Hong Kong History section which is particularly interesting and particularly well done.

One of the best museums I've ever visited.. You don't have to be an academic to love this museum. The exhibit when I visited was the history of Hong Kong; it was so well done and comprehensive, interesting, interactive and totally informative. An amazing visit. Definite must see

Interesting!. You will need a few hours to enjoy this museum. This was advertised on the airport express so we decided to check it out...glad we did, very interesting! We also visited an exhibition from Imperial Russia which is also a must visit. The staff were very helpful and friendly as well.

Must see attraction. We were introduced to this attraction by a friend who was vitiing family in Hong Kong at the same time we were these. The outside building may be unspectacular but the exhibitions inside well and truly make up for this. We only spent about 2 hours here so missed lots. The exhibits are interesting and the written commentary really informative. My husband and I came away with a much better understanding of Hong Kong's journey. Really recommend taking time out to go here.Just a word of advice for parents with children on the autism spectrum - the lighting in some of the exhibit areas can be a bit low (clearly for conservation reasons). Our youngest doesn't deal with low light places very well so we ended up rushing through and avoiding some exhibition areas : (((((

Really Interesting Place to visit. We spent a good few hours in this museum. At the time we visited an exhibition from Imperial Russia was on and was so interesting. We also thought that History of Hong Kong was very well done and was very well done. It was also good to see so many children visiting this museum. Well worth a visit.

Huge and interesting!. We must have spent about 3 hours in the museum and still didn't see everything. We had to leave due to closing time, and we had yet to get to the 'Modern HK' exhibit, so missed everything regarding the takeover etc. We learnt so much during our time here and it's so cheap for a ticket. Definitely worth spending half a day in here if you are interested in how HK came to be how it is today.

Excellent Overview of Hong Kong History. This museum is a great first stop on a trip to Hong Kong and will enrich your experience in the city. The trip through Hong Kong history is first rate, and I found staff to be very helpful despite limited English proficiency. I visited an excellent visiting exhibition on the Russian Czars' Summer Palace; the only problem I had was spending too much time at this exhibit and failing to leave myself enough time to learn about the history of Hong Kong!

A lot to see. Starting millions of years ago up until the last decade, the entire Hong Kong history is told.There is a lot to see, if you really want to see it all, you'll probably need at least a half day.Recommended!

i wish to visit this place again & recommend to other also. The Hong Kong Museum of History is a museum which preserves Hong Kong's historical and cultural heritage. It is located next to the Hong Kong Science Museum, in Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon, Hong Kong, China.
Recreation of China life. Lots of reproductions of Chinese life including costumes, jewelry, festivals, and history of the Japanese invasion. Strongly recommend it (free on Wednesdays)

Nice to "see". Better to "Read". & Don't get lost. It got great information in order. Read the small panels, that's how you'll make the most out of the visit. It's in order from 1 to 8. But make sure you finish each tour before you enter the next. Because I got lost at the second floor (5-8) skipping some. Can be done in 2.5 Hours.

Avoid the Museum Giftshoppe. The Museum is excellent whilst the Giftshoppe is a disgrace. Whilst the Giftshoppe is a contracted vendor, there is no excuse for a staff who desperately requires BASIC customer service lessons. I strongly suggest opening any book with a very careful examination PRIOR to purchase. The quality control for the books is very very poor.
