Kindly review this caution once again.Highest marks for the Museum. There is not a category sufficiently low for an adequate description of the Giftshoppe.

You need a full day to see all. This place is amazing. The amount of information provided is huge, lots of short movies, exhibitions. It gives a clear picture about how Hong Kong evolved during the years. We learnt so much. This is a must and it's a good break from the (bad) shopping.

Great way to get overview. We spent several hours in Hong Kong history exhibit which is permanent. Do not bother with the audio tour - not very good. You will do better reading the blurbs. Nice overview before we did sightseeing

Exactly what you'd expect... ..the history of Hong Kong, which is exactly what we were looking for. We went on Saturday afternoon and it was not busy at all. The only downside is it was COLD in there. I wish I had worn an extra layer!

Very easy to Understqnd. Well designed and on a number of floors. The Russian item was extra but worth it.
We did not really need the spoken hand set as each item was in both English and Chinese.

The Romanov Exhibit was worth the walk. Spent three hours wandering through the new temporary exhibit outlining the history of the Romanov dynasty which was fascinating even though we are constantly swamped by bored and loud tourist groups.
will be back to see the rest on my next trip.

interesting once you get past the first part. I initially thought we were just going to get pictures of the ancient geographical features of the land, but once you got past the first room, the presentations were stunning. It is free on certain days and well worth it. the Chinese Wedding exhibit and puppets were beautiful.

Showpiece museum. Really well organized. Visually engaging exhibits. Huge but not overwhelming. Good use of multimedia. Goes from prehistory (geological formation of the area) all the way to handover to PRC. Worth several hours.

Loved the permanent exhibit. When I visited, there was a special temporary exhibit from Russia. I saw both the Russia exhibit and their main permanent exhibit.I was disappointed in the Russia exhibit. Really not all that much to see...the one highlight is the mosaic with the amber frame. That was *impressive*. But, it wasn't really worth the time and money.The permanent exhibit, on the other hand, was really really well done.This museum provided both the natural history and more recent history of HK. There were a few movies to watch. One on geology was very interesting because later that week I saw some of the reference points of that movie and recognized the structures.There were many rooms depicting everything from Chinese opera, pearl divers, festivals, early peoples. All were well done. All had extensive English text, which as an Anglophone was a major plus.We spent a couple of hours. You could easily spend more if you wished (we would have, but ran out of time...)
very informative. might not be the best choice with kids, however if you are interested about arts and hirstory you will have a good time.

Great Overview of HK history. Really good experience and well worth the 10HK$ entrance price.Well explained exhibits in English and Chinese and short films in each zone giving further information. The recreations are also well done and this place feels authentic.It did get slightly tedious towards the end and I wouldn't recommend bringing children here, but I learnt a lot about Hong Kong on my first day and the rest of my trip was better for it.

Oasis of calm amid the hustle and bustle. Tucked away on TST is the highly enjoyable museum on a quiet and widely spaced entrance plaza. Immediately the atmosphere of the location is calmingly different from the hustle and bustle right across the road. The entrance fee at HK$10 alone is well worth the calm, but it is the story of Hong Kong that it tells that makes this a must-visit. Skip the archaeological bits if short of time and head straight to the colonial and subsequent galleries. It shows the fascinating insight of how HK developed into the frenetic place of commerce and capitalism that it is today. The historical background is, to me at least, fascinating as I often like to appreciate the back-story of the places I visit. The cultural and social anthropological sections captures the colourful nature of the Southern Chinese and their stoic resilience. We followed up with visits, on another day, to two heritage trails that shows the scenes captured in the museum. It was great to see the culture and tradition still alive in the outlying areas of HK away from the incessant shopping districts.

Interesting on the whole. Worth a visit for a general historical overview. Some of the re-creations are well done, eg. Junk boat, medicine store, colonial post office etc. Great museum store with good collection of books on HK history which you don't find elsewhere.

Interactive and informative. The museum covers HK's history from its geological history up to the present day. Each section offers reconstructions of geological features, street scenes, Chinese theatres etc that you can actually walk into and explore. The sections on the 20th century contain a lot of film docementation as well as reconstructed streets. This is one of the most engaging, interactive and entertaining history museums I've visited.

Really nicely done with great exhibits. This is a fairly new museum and its well structured and easy to follow different areas of interest. The exhibits are pretty much replicas of real life houses, boats and scenes, making it a great experience. Great way to learn a bit more about HK and its history.
Getting to know HK. It was very educational. Worthwhile visiting. Did the same in Macaulay too. Visiting museums are becoming rituals when visiting countries.

Taking 1.5 hours from your shopping trip to visit here is worthy... It's right next to The Icon hotel where we stayed, also close to the largest DFS shopping mall in the world. Taking 1.5 hours from your shopping, and strolling in this informative museum will make you understand what makes HK unique and Why HK people are proud of the place they make it call home. It's free entry on Wed, and you still can hardly see many people there.
Well worth doing. Very well laid out, lots of interesting facts without it being dull, very large scale exhibits of HK traditions, under the British, during the war etc. Highly recommended

HK History Museum. The second floor of this Museum does an excellent job summarizing Hong Kong's history from the past two hundred years or so - from the 1840 Opium Wars through the handover to China in 1997. I thought it was much more interesting to visit this museum and read their timelines than try and slug my way through a book.
Great for History Buffs!. This is a great stop if you are planning to be in HK for an extended visit and want to understand the history of the island and chinese/british relations
Excellent value. This museum is definitely worth the small entrance fee ... Kept husband & I and master 15 interested for hours. Very clean, informative & interesting. A must see ....

Museum of History. Great history from all aspects of the region. Especially interesting about the geopolitical history including the pre-British, British, and now reunification. Also as the natural history.
Wednesday Charm. Free entry every Wednesdays! Just when you though you are done - turn a corner, there's sooooo much more to see. Great history of HK. Amazing museum! One of the best I've been!

A Tremendous Exhibit. This is the best HK$10 you can spend in Hong Kong. A large and engaging exhibition that is a lot more engaging than you standard museum. Indeed, I think it might now be called the Heritage Centre but it belies a great series of exhibitions that follow the history of Hong Kong and the region. The pre-history section is a bit slow and tedious but when the human dimension starts it becomes very engaging. The sections prior to and during the British occupation period are the most interesting and colourful. The tour will take at least a couple of hours to complete and do it justice. There is a tremendous gift shop with lots of unique items as well.
WORTH A VISIT. This is a large museum with plenty to keep you interested for 2 to 3 hours. There was an exhibition for which you have to pay extra but I just stuck with the main area. Worth a visit.

Very interesting!. Start your visit to Honk Kong with this museum. You will learn a lot and you will understand much more about this fascinating city. Even if you are not a fan of museum, this one is really worth it as there are many displays about the architecture and the folklore, like giants puppets, an opera stage, a old street, etc.On your first Museum, you can buy the Weekly Museum Pass, priced at HK$30 and enjoy unlimited admission for 7 days to several museum. If you are planning to visit just three museum or less, don't buy it.

Best museum in Hong Kong ... great exhibit + "The Hong Kong Story" walk. Best museum in Hong Kong with great exhibits and especially "The Hong Kong Story." The USD 20MM+ it took to build the exhibit are dollars well spent as it shows the incredible journey from millions of years ago all the way to the handover of Hong Kong from Great Britain to China. There is an audio tour, written descriptions (in Chinese and English) plus videos (in Putonghua, Cantonese and English). An incredible amount of work has also gone into explaining and experiencing Hong Kong from the fishing villages and salt makers of the past to the festivals of today. I would think it is best for older children (who can read and are interested in history), college students and adults but there is the Science Museum right next door which is much more geared to kids so you could do both and have a good mix.

Great way to spend 2-3 hours in Hong Kong. We discovered this museum on a recent trip, and are very glad we went. As other reviewers have written, if time is limited, skip the first couple of rooms and get right to the good stuff: The Opium Wars, the Japanese occupation, and the handover in 1997.This is not some little dusty museum. This is "Disney quality" or better. It's within walking distance of anywhere in the heart of Kowloon. We planned to stay an hour, but stayed almost three.

best that HK can offer. HK isn't known for museums, and visitors looking for bit of culture injection plus trying to get away from the shoppers, would do well by heading straight here. entrance fee is a snip at HKD10 per adult

Skip the first couple of rooms and head straight to the recent stuff. The first couple of rooms are mostly about the ancient and natural history of the island of hong kong. If you're into that then great, but for me I probably should have skipped over those as I found the more recent (last 200 years or so) history much more interesting. There's so much to see that I was pretty pooped by the time we got to the good stuff. The only other thing that's a bit odd is that the museum finishes with the transfer of sovereignty from the UK to China in 1997 and there's nothing more recent. A good way to spend a few hours and to learn a bit more about how Hong Kong came to be the great citiy that it is.

Neat Stop. If you are spending more than 2-3 days in Hong Kong, I would recommend stopping by this Museum. It provides a neat overview of the ancient history of Hong Kong Island as well as perspective on Hong Kong after World War II and during British leadership.

Spend as long or as little as you want here. This enormous museum takes you through the entire history of Hong Kong from prehistoric times through to the handover in '91. If, like me, you think that prehistoric rocks from one region look more or less like prehistoric rocks from another, then you can quickly walk through the exhibits to whichever point you want to begin at - for me it was the ethnic people and fishing villages of the region. Plenty to see, read, watch and occasionally touch, it's a great introduction to a somewhat bizarre history. With a student card it costs around 5 HKD, and I think it was 10 HKD without. I skipped about a third of the museum, and skim read most things, and it took me two hours. If you were really keen it could easily take you 5 hours to go around the whole thing. Very enlightening, and great for a rainy day.

Exhibition. The exhibition was generally good but came out short of expectation. Visited the place 8 years ago and they had built up exhibits of old life style but this time around its almost all in prints or av. They have also skimmed on the time with the old China and Japanese occupation.

Large exhibition, but missing bits and pieces. It starts with the geology 400 million years ago... but you are rapidly lead through the halls, and forwards in time. I think we spent maybe two hours in there but you could easily walk around half a day if you wanted.Everything is well presented and text is easy to understand. I might have been exhausted and missed things in the end but I really wanted more on the last 2-300 years of HK history and the relationship between the Chinese and Brittish heritage. And more information on the kowloon walled city's rise and fall.Recommend a visit if you are on holiday and fed up with shopping.

Fantastic! . We had a few hours to kill in transit, so checked Trip Advisor for an interesting uncomplicated activity. This had great reviews and deservedly so. It was also super-easy (and inexpensive) to take the airport express light rail then associated shuttle practically to the door.We only had a couple of hours, but its an excellent museum that warrants at least half a day.

Excellent Museum. This is an excellent museum that gives you a great sense of Hong Kong's ancient and modern history. It is an absolute must see. The exhibits are very well done and I learned so much about Hong Kong's history.

Always interesting. After navigating the most bizarre entrance imaginable (into the lobby, up an elevator, outside to the ticket booth, down an exterior escalator, around a plaza and finally back into the lobby and on through the door to the museum) the museum itself is spacious, well designed and informative. Lots of the exhibits are actual full scale artifacts: boats, buildings, life-size dioramas, etc. Consequently, there's a lot of space and even though the place was full, it didn't feel crowded. The timeline is thorough: from geologic time to the present, presented chronologically. I believe this museum would be interesting to everyone from those with a casual interest in history to even a serious scholar. Also had one of the better gift shops.

Terrific museum. Went to this museum because it was close to my hotel. Really enjoyed the visit! Saw the nice temporary exhibition on Tsar's Royal Village and then spent couple of hours touring the museum. It contained terrific displays of Hong Kong's history from it's geological creation to the present time ranging from the political life to the every day life. Really enjoyed the many short films that brought the history to life. If you are interested in knowing more about HK, you must visit this museum!

if you like science and history. the museum would take more than 5hours to explore so go early! it shows you in a story format which you can walk through easily. from land formation to rock metamorphosis to landscape of living animals, then early cavemen, early settlers, prawn paste and fishing settlers and then the opium trade, japanese occupation and british influence to shipping... i didnt finish the last few as i had ran out of time. the tschar russia last empire is currently on exhibition for 20hkd till march2015 so do go for it. its a must go for families and friends or solo! even if you're Chinese, you'll be fascinated. if you're not a nature lover, does not appreciate culture or knowing about hongkong origins, you wouldn't enjoy this.

Fantastic for History Museum of History. The Museum of History was recommended by a friend from Hong Kong and it was well worth the visit, although we did not allow enough time, so I would recommend allowing for 4-5 hours or going a couple of times if you do not want to spend that amount of time all at once. For seniors it only cost HK$5.00 and HK$10.00 for everyone else so it is quite cheap. I would recommend not getting the headphones as the written descriptions are in English and are very good. The museum goes through the entire history of Hong Kong including geology, paleontology, and history of the people and developments of Hong Kong industry, etc. We were there for the Treasures from Tsarskoye Selo (Residence of the Russian Tsars) which was better and more informative than our actual trip to Saint Petersburg and area
a must do. A must do. It;s free on Wednesday and really worth a visit - allow half a day and skip through the geology / prehistoric stuff, as there is SO much more.
Building. Nice building design, and a nice place if you curious about the Hong Kong and related history of the past
Great understanding of HK history. What a great place. We spent a good coupe of hours here and came away with a real understanding of the country. We recommend visiting first

Totally worth it to learn about the history of Hong Kong. Visiting the Hong Kong Museum of history was not only interesting, but also very enjoyable to see the extraordinary changes to the city state.While many will prefer to go shopping and eating, a walk around the park, then the visit to the museum is a definite good thing to do; the park itself is huge with birds, trees and lots of running tracks - the museum has functional displays, great images, pictures and video which does an excellent job of summarising where Hong Kong came from.The short videos showing how people lived, and interviews with residents on video, was a highlight.For people with kids, Chinese ancestry or an interest in history, this is a highly worthwhile place to visit!

Fantastic way to spend 2 - 3 hours. For $10HKD per person - this is great value. The Museum of History traces HK's history through a series of separate exhibitions each detailing a different era in HK's history.As someone who doesn't like to read a huge amount of detailed information in one go - the way the information was portrayed - with both visual information and short wall panels was perfect for me and kept me interested throughout the exhibition as a whole.
Very nicely put together exhibits. Entry is super cheap and the exhibits are pretty spectacular. Gives a good impression and introduction to the history of Hong Kong.

Impressive exhibits - free on Wednesday's!. This museum houses eight permanent exhibits, starting with the geology and ecology of Hong Kong through to current social conditions via traditional peoples and the impacts of invasion and war.There are many interactive opportunities as well as actual-sized exhibits modelling the natural ecosystems and living styles of the past. Allow plenty of time to wander through and learn about Hong Kong's history.Clean toilets and comfortable seating is available on each floor as you move through the exhibits. Well worth the effort to visit, you won't be disappointed.
Good for a history of Hong Kong. I struggled with pacing of this museum. Maybe it is just my personal interested, but some areas seemed to have too much depth, while others needed more detail.
Well worth the time. Very very good at filling in the gaps from millions of years ago to the present day - includes section on Japanese occupation.Spent four hours there.

Brilliant!. This is one of the best history museums I have visited anywhere. A fascinating and really comprehensive insight into Hongkong's past up to the current day. You could easily spend a whole day here.

Very interesting. Shows so much about the culture and history of the city. Its is a must see. It also shows the history aboutthe occupation and invasion of the Japanese Army in WW2. A very disturbing kind of exhibit, if this kind of thing bothers you.

Great exhibit, beautifully crafted museum!. We spent and afternoon learning everything about the gorgeous Hong King traditions as well as seeing the hard work and perseverance of the HK people. Very impressive!

waste of time. We have been to this museum before, however the weather was not too kind and decided to return for another visit. We were advised on entry "no Chinese art" which we took to mean paintings/calligraphy, in fact there was no Chinese art whatsoever, two floors were inaccessible, all we had access to was Modern art which was not very exciting. Visiting the shop on our exit was just as disappointing, hardly any items for sale and what was on offer was hugely expensive. Make sure all floors are open for viewing before you enter as the Chinese Art is incredible here.

A very neat museum. I've been to this museum several times and I learn something new everytime. I've never been a huge history buff but this is such a neat perspective on the history of Hong Kong. Something to do if you're in Hong Kong for more than a week. I think it's free on Wednesdays!

Really interesting insight into Hong Kong. We went here not really knowing what to expect, on a Weds there is no entry feeThe initial geological history is a bit bland however we found the social history of HK really interesting. A vast array of exhibits and information about the history of Hong Kong is providedLearned an enormous amount about the history of HK that we knew nothing aboutAllow 2-3 hours there is a lot to get throughEverything is in English as well as chinese

The best museum in Hong Kong. This is worth almost a full day, if there is a good special exhibit. We visited when the Treasures of the Tsars was on--it lasts well into 2015, and would be a destination worthy exhibit in NY or London. The history museum is great for any age group. It starts with the geology, animal life, then "people history". It is a great overview of the habitation of Hong Kong, with enough recreated streets, shops, waterfront, etc. to both inform and entertain. The cafe is charming and the menu is much more extensive than would normally be expected for a museum. We had a very nice dim sum lunch. If you have to choose between this museum and the Hong Kong Heritage Museum (which is also quite good) choose this one.

Great place to learn about Hong Kong. This was our second time here and we enjoyed it just a much. It give a great history of Hong Kong from ancient times to modern. I especially like the excellent presentations on the history between the Europeans and Hong Kong, as well as the Japanese occupation period.
Great Attraction. Learn about the history of this amazing city...combination of exhibits , pictures, films, and audio...

Great Museum. Definitely worth a visit to the HK Museum of History. Very well laid out museum. You can walk around the 'old streets' of HK which was interesting. Very informative and interesting in the way that you walk through in a chronological order from the early stage to now. A lot of interesting history facts and events.

Worth a visit. Easily accessible, very informative and a great experience for families. Extensive range of exhibits to suit your needs. The walk through city was wonderful for kids to get a hands-on feel of Hing Kong life. Not too crowded and very inexpensive.

Good visit.. Overall really enjoyed my visit. Very quiet when I visited and also good value for money. The start of the exhibition was a bit slow and a bit generic rather than being specific to Hong Kong. That said, the rest of the exhibits were really good insight into the history of the city. The special exhibits were really interesting, especially some of the depictions of the villages etc.

Well worth a visit. An interesting museum which will take approx 1 1/2 -2 hours to go round. Lots of information in English, we got the audio. The audio gave a lot of information. However the last 100 years of history has been glossed over. Very little information covering this time, a shame as we feel it would have been interesting.There is a cafe inside for drinks and snacks.

Nice exhibition from Russia. I went to see Treasures from Tsarskoye selo exhibition and really enjoyed it if it wasn't for the big groups of tourists and their loud presenters. I had hard time hearing my audio and had to move away to different rooms for this reason. The museum really needs to book these big groups separately as the exhibition got overcrowded and noisy. Otherwise nice exhibition with a lot of information.Entrance fee is $H 20, 10 for students and they lend you audio for $H10. There's also exhibition of the history of Hong Kong.

Special exhibit: "Treasures from Tsarskoye Selo, Residence of the Russian Monarchs" Exhibition. Our family visited this special exhibit just after Christmas. I loved it. There was a pleasing variety of items to look at, from old pistols and dinnerware to clothing and paintings. A number of slide shows featuring photographs and paintings set the scene; I started to understand where in history each tsar fit. The captions struck the right balance by providing enough information to educate while being short to maintain my interest.The collection of personal items, while not extensive, was a good representation of how they lived. There were some interesting and unusual items such as a matched set of 4 flintlock pistols, in a carrying case with accessories. I'd never before seen the uniform dresses that female royalty wore, so I liked that.I would recommend this exhibit for teens and adults. We brought a 3-year-old and he was bored. I noticed that other families with young children left quickly.

Great overview of Hong Kong. I was fortunate to visit on my first day in Hong Kong. Also, there are guided tours in English on the weekends at 10:30am which was when I just happened to be there. Overall very lucky for me as the 90min tour with our guide, Lilly, was a great way to see the large collection very efficiently. There are 8 galleries on 2 floors comprising the permanent exhibit - "The Hong Kong Story". Starting from 400 million years ago until the transition back to China from the UK, the exhibit was very comprehensive. Personally, I enjoyed the later exhibits on the second floor the most. I felt this was a great overall introduction to Hong Kong and would strongly recommend going here as one of your first activities if you are visiting Hong Kong for the first time.

Worth a visit . Visited the museum on a wed (free entry). Had planned to spend the morning there (2-3 hours) followed by a spot of shopping in the afternoon. However, there were so many things to see and learn. Ended up spending almost 6 hours at the museum! In between, we left the museum for a quick lunch before returning to continue with the rest of the exhibits on the 2nd flr.
Short history. HK's modern history is short, but don't forget about the mainland side of HK. Colourful and informative, but few bells and whistles.
Hong Kong Museum of History. it bring you go to old time ~~lt is very crowded on weekend~~lf monday to friday there are no people to visit

Really Nice to Know Stuff. The Hong Kong Museum of History houses different thematic exhibitions showcasing Hong Kong and South China's rich history. You can choose to follow the suggested path through the museum, or you can go straight to the sections that interest you the most. There were sections in which they depict cultural events such as festivals and rituals. While other sections showcase monumental events and historical pieces in Hong Kong's history.Lots of students can be found inside the museum copying different pieces or exhibitions on their sketch books.At different points in the museum, there are interactive kiosks where one can learn more about what is being depicted on the section by an audio-visual presentation, which can be either in Chinese or English. And at the end of the path of the museum, one can sit down and watch a short clip on Hong Kong's most important historical events in a small theater house.The entrance is free every Wednesday.

Informative. As the name suggest it is the history of Hong Kong which is at display here and anybody who wishes to learn and know about the origin and phases of Hong Kong throughout history, this is the best place and the exhibits and the information are impressive enough to give a good time. The entrance fee is not much too and it free on one of the weekdays.
Special exhibit on Tsarskoye Selo. The special exhibit was impressive and very well presented.We spent about 3.5 hours and unfortunately didn't have time to explore the other part of the museum.

A very thorough history of HK. Eight large rooms that cover everything from the prehistoric origins to the British colonial period through the Japanese occupation and the turnover to China in 1997. I liked the display of the different ethnic and tribal groups.

You learn a lot about Hong Kong here. Nice museum, lots of interesting information about the histroy of Hong Kong, well presented. It is easy to get there and the musuems in Hong Kong is free on Wednesdays, except special exhibitions. Even if you have to pay, it's only HK$10 which is very minimal for what they are offering.

Just a great place to visit and see the history of Hong Kong. This is really an excellent Museum which provides the history of Hong Kong. What you get is excellent set scenes of the ethnic groups, the history of British occupation, recreation of streets and then of course the 50/60s. Expect film shows, great set pieces and really interesting History.On this visit there was also a special exhibition on Tsarkeye Selo - the Tsars village outside of St. Petersburg. This was a brilliant exhibition with sleighs, full size carriages and stunning costumes.Literally jaw dropping in its magnificence.
A must - free on Wednesdays. Check the schedule - but if you are Bruce Lee fan or not - it is worth a visit - lots of ancient pottery and they should be finished with the remodel by 2015.

Take the free tour. While doing this museum in a self-guided natures probably okay it's a lot better to take it with the tour guide provided by the museum.This free service provided in different languages at different times the day is well worth setting aside the time for. You get a real sense of what the locals think about the history that is in this museum and how it's affecting them today you can always go back and look at the exhibits that interest you afterwards
Know HK. Great Place to learn everything about the history and culture of Hong Kong.Free Entrance on Wednesday and to join the guided tour inorder to fully appreciate all the exihibits.

A good way of knowing Hong Kong's history. It's a well-organized history museum. It's huge enough to showcase Hong kong's timeline dating back even before its existence. We went here on a Wednesday hence, we got in for free. It has a fee on other days. It's near other museums hence it's good to museum-hop. It's a walking distance from Promenade and from TST where we stayed.Visited: November 2013

Love to all collection. Love so much for the museum, through the collection you can see the life of Hong Kong from people, culture, to technology and film. One the collection is dinosaurus's egg. Tree wishes and tram also boat fo fishing. Just fyi Hongkong for the first time only small fishing village. The island is part of china and the on war, when China lost at War.

Time well spent. Take the time to visit. I spent hours here. My mother grew up in post WWII Hong Kong and the museum gave me some insight into what life must have been like. I think of HK as a place to shop and eat. This museum highlights its people and history, from its place in Chinese history and also the impact of Europeans. The exhibits was well laid out and the English explanations are well done. I missed the English tour (I think there's one per day) but still feel I got lots of information just on my own. The Hong Kong Museum of History is a must see.
Boring. worst museum I have been too, only my opinion of course, as I am not really into museums anyway.as I find most museums boring
Tsar palaces. The museum is currently showing "Treasures from Tsarskoye Selo". An excellent exhibition. Very informative. A must for any body in the Kowloon area.

Good tour of HK History. Even the museum is a good display of making the most of limited space. In three floors they packed the history of Hongkong and a little bit of culture. Better allot a couple of hours at least to make the most of the visit.

A Glimpse into the Island's Colourful Past. I walked not expecting much but to my surprise you can literally stay the whole afternoon learning so much from various media about Hong Kong. From the prehistoric settlers to its various war-torn eras to its fair share of natural disasters.

Worth the time...really!. The must-do things in HK include the Peak, Ocean Park, TST promenade, eating roast meat and dimsum, etc. I will probably add visiting the HK Museum of History to this. For the HK$25 entry ($30 for weekly pass - highly recommended), one can actually spend at least 2 hours or more here. Stuff to see include the early Chinese history to how the region became a British colony to the Japanese occupation and then the handover.If you are here before Mar 15, 2014, do spend the extra $ for the Tsarskoye Selo where one can learn more of the Russian monarchy before it was taken over by the Communists - interesting stuff.Oh yes, do actually try the food at the museum cafe and visit the bookshop. We purchased some gifts for friends back home, i.e. items that you would probably not find anywhere else.

Great place to understand Hongkong history. I am not specially fond of museums and hence was pleasantly surprised to find a place that makes history vivid with the great exhibits and short explanations that give you an overview without being lengthy. I would definitely recommend this to everyone who has 2-3 hours to spare in Hongkong.

Brilliant but follow the process for getting in. This really is a great museum charting HK's history and turbulent times.- To get in you must initially buy a ticket... go up the outside wide steps to an open piazza area. Keep to the left hand side where you will find ticket sales just before the fur corner- Once you have your ticket - come back down the steps keeping right. About 20m to the right you will find the museum entrance - It is setup in a way that should keep children engaged although reading what is beside each area gives great insight into what has gone on.- There are no eating or drinking locations once you are insideA great place to visit

Loved it! Loved it! Loved it!. This is a MUST visit attraction in everyone's list! Entrance fee is only HK$10 and what you get in return is much more than that! The museum is simply awesome, can't believe they put so much efforts in making the museum so so so interesting! Do plan your time properly, it may be hard to believe but you will most probably spend at least 2 hours there! I bet majority of you will love it!

Worth the trip!. Although it isn't near a MTR subway station, it is worth the trip on foot or taxi to get to this fantastic cultural museum. I wish I had followed the advice of so many to walk quickly through the beginning sections on geology and pre-history and skipped to the fascinating displays that come later. The streetscape recreations are so interesting...wish we had had more time for them. it is a great museum and should be on every traveler's list. Note that many locals don't know about it except as a location for school field trips.

Not the usual boring place..... Fantastic museum. Super cheap, like $US 1.50. Suggest you skip to section 4. The best part are the videos about the short Japanese occupation of Hong Kong, and the mainland propoganda video. Fun experience.

Well Worth a Visit. This museum presented you with a lot of information on Hong Kong, its founding, geology, history, and the various ethnic groups that inhabit the city. I enjoyed the recreations of old city shops, a Chinese junk, and displays on the various Chinese cultures involved in the founding of the city.
An interesting visit - very convenient. I liked the mock up of the different shops -- found the history very interesting - must visit again - there were parts of the story I must have missed!

Nice place to learn about Hong Kong. On a recent trip we spent time at this museum in Kowloon and learned about both the geological and historical foundation of the city. Descriptions and movies were both in Chinese and English so things were easy to follow. I particularly liked the films in theaters that were included in each section as they gave you an opportunity to sit and see the historical events unfold. This is a nice way to spend a morning or afternoon.

There's something missing.... A nicely appointed museum with lots of interesting information on the landforms and early history (and pre-history) of the region and the people who have helped to uncover it. However, the museum bills itself as showing Hong Kong's history from 400,000,000 years ago to it's re-unification with the rest of China... The last 100 years or so of history aren't referenced at all, perhaps understandably so.
very interesting. go on a Wednesday and its free, lots to do and keeps the children engaged. the short movies are very good.

Do not miss this museum. This is such a great place and tells you so much about the history of Hong Kong. We went over two days and it was worth every hour spent. The fee is so cheap and they are free on Wednesday like most museum in Hong Kong. Enjoy this wonderful place.
Wonderful Museum. Excellent well planned museum, gives a sweeping history of Hong Kong, a must visit to understand the region and the culture and history
Desserve a visit. For those who wants to know the history of Hong Kong, it's really a great place! Children will love it thanks to the models .

Magnificent. Absolutely wonderful - the history of Hong Kong from prehistoric days through to today, with so many artefacts, displays and life-size exhibits. If you want to do the job properly, don't reckon on less than 5 hours!The in house cafe was quite special too - try the local dishes rather than the more western ones. You won't be disappointed.

It is free on Wednesday. You may visit The Hong Kong Story in about 2 hours.(The Hong Kong Story comprises 8 galleries located on two floors. The Hong Kong Story outlines the natural environment, folk culture and historical development of Hong Kong vividly) However, if you would like to enjoy the multimedia programmes featured in The Hong Kong Story, including theatre shows and interactive booths, you are advised to spare 3 to 4 hours.

Fantastic trip through history. You are led through the exhibition by signposts and this makes it easy not to miss any of this fascinating exhibition. It takes you from ancient history up to modern day Hong Kong explaining what has formed this fantastic city. We spent a good 3 hours going round and were entertained. It is good for any age and I would thoroughly recommend a visit here to help you understand the city better.

Enter a Real Time time travel. Most of all I loved the last sections, so parcel out your time carefully. There'a lot to see and explore and all very well done. The walk through villages were an unexpected pleasure. Save energy for the second half of the visit.

Pretty nice..... Not a bad museum for a very quick stroll. We have visited on a Wednesday, when all museums in Hong Kong are free, so some of the exhibits were actually closed. What we did get to see, was definitely interesting and worth visiting.
fascinating. was the best time and money spent doing this, we found it better to do this on our own rather than with a tour

Worth a visit +++. I've heard from many people that Hong Kong lacks a lot of serious cultural institutions, so naturally I wasn't expecting much. However, I thoroughly enjoyed my time at the museum and I'd highly recommend it.At times it got a bit difficult to follow the suggested route but it contained interesting and insightful exhibits and artefacts. Be prepared - it is quite big, it took me by surprise and I never got to go to the upper levels which contained modern HK history. Entry is free on Wednesday so I'm planning on returning sometime soon. But if you can't go Wednesday it'll only set you back HKD$10. Cheap!

Crap information. Not really the museums fault but trip advisor has the wrong opening hours information. Travelled 2 hours to get to this museum only to find it is closed on Tuesdays! Sort your information out Trip Advisor!!!!

Really good museum. I really enjoyed this museum although I was pushed for time and we only spent two hours here. You can easily spend the entire day here looking through it all properly. It is definitely worth a visit and I highly recommend it. We went in the late afternoon so it was quiet and there was a few tours going on.I learnt a lot about Hong Kong and all the cultures etc. My parents tried to explain things to me which were very interesting as they are 'hoklo' and 'hakka' descendants. We saw all the old agriculture tools and my parents were able to explain to me how they were used etc as they were growing up as children when all these farming tools were still in use and are still in use in parts of china.It can be quite confusing to get to, from the mtr station, we went around the long way and it took quite a while to find it, there is a much better shortcut that we found coming out of the museum to the station which only took 5-10minutes walk compared to our 30 minute wonder to find the entrance of the museum. Make sure to check where the entrance is, its on the south side of the museum and the museum is HUGE, it takes up the entire block so depending on which path you take, you can go long way around the entire block or short way around. Also we bought tickets upstairs before going downstairs to the museum itself which is also quite confusing, after we got told off by the security lady for not knowing you have to go upstairs to get a ticket before going inside the museum entrance!!!

Check out the colonial history. From geography to the colony and the people, I found the most interesting part towards the end so if geography is not your thing, head towards the 2nd part and learn about the Brits and the opium wars! More to it than just that of course but put things in context for me.

Must see!. Enjoyed three hours here exploring the history of Hong Kong. Started with the rocks and how the landscape was formed over millions of tears with a short film in a theatre that looks like the inside of a volcano. Then it takes you through the flora and fauna and then to the earliest peoples. As you progress through the museum you are taken through the ages, a Victorian street with real shops to a house during Japanese occupation in WWII. Highly recommend this museum and I left feeling I want to revisit Hong Kong.

Where East meets West. The static and ever changing exhibitions are great-from Chinese works on paper to Miro, there is always something to see. It is great just to sit and rest, gazing out at the ships going past.

This is a MUST........ Even our Hong Kong friends had never visited this treasure. Very well done history of the area - we knew things even our hosts were unaware of. Spent probably too long (2 1/2 hours), but the exhibits are excellent.
great museum. loved it ,very interesting ,cheap only $30 hong kong each,helpful staff who took time out to point us in the right direction

Museum director gives it a WOW!. I'm a retired history museum director and make a habit of visiting history museums wherever I travel. This one is huge and good. Plus, for the next five or six months, the museum is hosting a remarkable exhibition of portraits, objets d'art, furnishings, and even an imperial coach from Tsarskoye Selo, the Catherine Palace in St. Petersburg, Russia. I found the portraiture, the gowns, the regalia and menus from coronations, and the military uniforms to be remarkably evocative. Thank to the Hong Kong Jockey Club Foundation, which has supported various exhibitions and it the sole sponsor of this one, the objects are shown in a stunning physical installation that evokes the character of the palace. The checkered history of the Russian tsars and tsarinas is told obliquely and well, too, with riveting portraits and personal items of the last tsar and his family.The permanent installation on the ground level covers the history of Hong Kong and the different ethnicities. I concur with other reviews that found the pre-history and geology a bit dull, but the installations for the various ethnic groups are excellent. The afternoon I was there, the place was full of school groups having a great time. Of special interest to me was the exhibit about the Japanese conquest of Hong Kong, their efforts at "Japonification" (which assumed everlasting control), and the liberation, which came after more than three years of a brutal regime. This exhibit is very, very well done and merits lingering attention and reflection. By contrast, the Singapore National Museum's similar exhibit, is a bit diffuse and doesn't tell the story of liberation as well. All in all, this is a very fine museum that speaks to many different interests, even Chinese opera and folk festivals.
great museum. this museum is very good and nicely located. it shows a good history of the area from prehistoric to modern times. well done.

Excelent background to history of Hong Kong. This museum provides and excellent walk through time on the history of Hong Kong and the surrounding area. Covering the changes in culture and ownership of the territory.

Free on Wednesdays.. The other half and I spent a good four hours walking through the 8 different sections of the history of a Hong Kong.Very well laid out, a combination of video, reading, you can get head sets for extra audio at a small cost.Starts at the geological formation of Hong Kong, Chinese traditions, through to the opium wars, British and Japanese rule, famine, drought, fire. It's all there. Wear comfy shoes, there are places to sit and rest.We loved it. A great learning experience.
Good place. A good place to go with family and friends. It's near shopping mall and convience.
Nice, OK. We went on a Wednesday so it was free admission. It was a cool place to spend 1-2 hours there learning the background of Hong Kong.

Excellent and unusual museum. This was a very informative and interesting museum presented in an unusual and visual way. Great place to spend half a day leading everything about Hong Kong from pre historic to modern times. There's also a lovely little cafe on site staffed by disabled people where we had a nice -and cheap- lunch. Worth a visit!

Very interesting exhibits. This was one of my favorite outings while we were in Hong Kong. I liked how it presented the the island from the geology of prehistoric times up through various historical periods. I loved seeing the cultural artifacts and was thrilled to climb onto a junk and walk through dwellings of yore. I thoroughly enjoyed everything except the cockroach that climbed up my leg under my skirt! A museum guard came running when I screamed and she kindly stomped the nasty thing to smithereens.

Dusty old museum - It is not!. Went here to kill an hour or so whilst waiting for another attraction in Hong Kong. Rookie mistake. This is not some dusty old museum looking tired and lifeless. This is an immersive experience that guides you along Hong Kongs history from the geology to the modern Hong Kong city.I went with my partner and we thoroughly enjoyed our time here, my only regret was not being able to spend more time enjoying the shows dotted throughout the museum. The museum takes a tour through several time periods of the history of Hong Kong. This museum is not done on the cheap and it feels like a celebration of Hong Kong and its diverse history. This is a museum to visit, it is free on a wednesday to, at least it was when we visited. A tip if you visit - allow adequate time and take provisions/food/drink, as other reviewers have noted it takes awhile to get around. There is a cafe on site which we used, had beverages and a snack, very cheap and reasonable.

Very good & interesting museum. I enjoyed spending a few hours in the Museum of History as it's one of the places I haven't visited before. The museum walks you through the geology of Hong Kong, prehistoric times & then moves into more modern history of the city. It's well worth a visit to learn more about this fantastic place & understand it's development and history.Quick budget tip - the museum is free on Wednesdays!

Worth your time while in HK. I spent a few hours in this museum on my first day in HK. Very well designed, very interesting, and informative. I agree with some previous reviews that many might prefer to skip some of the beginning exhibits (geology and primitive history of the area). I went through them but quickly. The rest of the exhibits were very interesting to me and seemed well-organized & presented. You have to go to the side of the museum on an upper level to buy your tickets and then come back around & down to enter. Seemed like the only poorly-planned part of an excellent attraction.

Great collection of HK's past. Enjoyed the HK Museum of HIstory, but found that we were rather worn-out near the end (people who have been to HK know how much walking it entails). A good idea might be to bypass the "prehistory" section with the stone tools and artifacts, in favor of the more modern history, say from the 1800s-on.

Really interesting. The English tour was so good. Learnt heaps from our guide. You do need to spend a couple of hours here. Only negative was the so-called cafe. We couldn't buy any decent coffee or food.
Interesting but hard to follow. I learned a lot at the Museum but found the layout a bit confusing and hard to follow the thread at times. Was glad I went on Wednesday when admission is free.

Nice place. The museum has quite a big exhibition of ancient history (pots, coins, mummies of animals etc). The majority of exhibits are present in a form of a scene. the modern history has a wider exhibition. Tip: they have very interesting movies running every 20-30 minutes in different languages. better plan your visit for a longer time to be able to watch them!
Excellent history of Hong Kong. This museum is well worth a visit. It's informative, interesting and well set out - I stayed far longer than I thought I would do!
Hong Kong Museum... worth a visit. Access is easy and it is well laid out and most informative. You should allow plenty of time for your visit.
Great. Worth of time. One of the world class museum. It is one of the must go in Hong Kong. COOOOOOOOOOOOOl
History of Hong Kong. Excellent history of Hong Kong. Select part you are interested in as you need hours to appreciate the whole exhibit.

Great museum - very interesting. We got the audio headphones (only 5$Hk) and they were well worth it. It's a very interesting museum telling the history of HK way back into pre historic times. Its well laid out with good captions and tells the story well. The cafe is rather disappointing and a bit like going back in time to 1950s.

Well done history. This Museum is modern and well done in covering Hong Kong history (and some of other China as well) in a chronologic order re geologic setting, people, culture, etc.The Museum also had a special exhibit on Russian Tzars at the moment.A government facility aimed at education so the cost is nominal.

Rich, engaging narrative of the HK story.... Given its strategic location, Hong Kong has had a very interesting story (despite it's small size) and thus warrants a museum of this scale...The museum does supreme justice, with beautifully crafted exhibits that bring the story to life. The exhibits have painstakingly recreated the life and times of the bygone era...I wasn't too interested in the initial sections (concerning pre-history, anthropology etc), but the sections starting from the British entry, were fascinating.... Must-visit if you're interested in history, pre-history, anthropology, current affairs, and are in Hong Kong.
Our first trip to Hong Kong. A really good place to visit if you want to learn about the history of Hong Kong, and it's free.Very easy to find and well worth a visit.

Free Admission on Wednesday except for Special Exhibitions. Hong Kong Museum of History close on every Tuesday except Public Holidays. If it is your first time visiting, you would have a feeling of “when east meet west”… from ancient Chinese ceramic,British Colony - (28 Governors of Hong Kong from1843-1997) to 1997 Transfer of Sovereignty... If you have got time and interested in local history, please spare 2 hours and make a visit.

An outstandingly well done History Museum!. Although we have visited Hong Kong several times in the past, we learned of this Museum shortly before our trip last month. What a wonderful treat it was!! Without question, it is by far one of the most interesting history museums that we have visited, regardless of where! And it's scale is definitely "small", however the chosen presentations of various exhibits is so true to life (ie. the old herbal shop which has been set in a space, with an original store front (of beautiful carved wood, very much indicative of what would have been in a certain era)! And so the list goes in. Should we ever have the good fortune to spend time once again in this sophisticated international city, I will definitely want to carve out some time to revisit this museum! A must for anyone wishing to experience by gone era's!

A Compact, yet Concise Museum. A good museum for it's size, compact but well presented. The general exhibits are of a good standard but be prepared for the Hand of Beijing in some of the histories presentation, with very few direct references to the British impact & achievements, evern though it's inferred in so many of the exhibits. The special exhibitions they host are generally of a good standard too, although the bookshop needs seriously stocking, because of your interest is piqued there are very few decent publications to follow up with.

Well done and enjoyable mix of natural and recent history. Very cheap and a little geeky! An excellent spot to go if it is raining. Lots of natural history if that is interesting but also possible to skip to the more modern stuff. Well curated and quite detailed although not always clear the route you take to stick to the chronology! Worth a visit if over in TST though.
Excellent. Learn the history of Hong Kong and about the people. Kids had a great time. Go on Wednesday. Free to get in.
gud. Good if you interested to know the history ofplkaces you visit not a must but since u are vusiting u can go through it tooo

Hong Kong from the Chinese perspective. Toured the exhibit on the history of Hong Kong. Did you know the communists actually saved Hong Kong from the Japanese during WWII? That the British really did not know how to run it afterwards? I found it extremely interesting to see their perspective. Not right or wrong, so I enjoy museums like this to see how others view the world and for that it was an excellent experience especially considering I am here during the Umbrella Revolution which at this point is not going anywhere.

Such a great experience for a small admission!. This is one of the best history museums that I've been to so far! Every time I am in Hong Kong, I bring my tourist friends with me to visit this museum, and I have yet to hear back feedback. We did not think we'd spend as much time as we did at the museum, only because we actually enjoyed the exhibits so much! Sound, color, information, texture - this museum does it all very well. Around each bend you wonder what's next, then you see these huge displays, artifacts, and replica houses; it really makes you feel like you're part of history and in it. Though they may not have enough information in certain areas, it still does a good job at explaining how Hong Kong came to be. I recommend it early in your trip, so you can see the relevance and understand the background of the sites you'll see while you are in Hong Kong.

Interesting. Gave a complete overview of Hong Kong starting with geological periods way up to transfer of power to China. Interesting exhibits. The strange thing is you have to go up a level outside the building to buy your ticket then they send you around to the other side of the building on the ground level to enter. After going through the exhibit you exit near where you bought your ticket

A little superficial. Unlike previous commentators I felt the coverage was rather shallow. I was particularly disappointed by the lack of detail in the Opium Wars section ( which is what lead to the establishment of Hong Kong) only HK$10 for entrance so go and make your own mind up.

One of the best history museums. I'm truly amazed by this place and happy that I decided to dedicate one of my days to visit it. First thing you should know - it takes a long time to visit it properly - give yourself at least 4 hours - 6 or 7 if you are interested in the topic. The museum shows you the history of Hong Kong from the moment of the islands' creation to the modern times. You can see the rocks from which it was formed, the flora, fauna and the first stages of human civilisation. But the later part is the best - you enter the section about Hong Kong's culture and tradition and be ready to stay there for a while - you will see traditional bun towers from the festivals, costumes and items from the traditional opera and wedding ceremonies. But the best are the movies - you can watch all major cultural events - including their annual parades and wedding preparations. Another amazing thing is a replica of the Hong Kong's streets and shops during the British Empire rule, including shops, tea houses and even a healers house - all have props with very interesting descriptions. Sections about WWI and WWII are also very well made. All floors are well presented, information is very detailed and after you finish, you have an impression that you know almost everything about HK. Plus the tickets are dirty cheap. If you like history and museums - this place is a must.

Extravagant full-scale recreations. There is much to like in this museum, which covers Hong Kong from early geological time (it's been a river, a desert, and a sea, among others) to the present day.What I liked best were the models of buildings and streets, which were very close to full-scale, and handsomely executed with plastic resin and other durable materials. There was also a full-size sailing junk, and a bank office.Highly recommended.
Gets better as you go along. Well worth a visit - it gets more interesting as one progresses from primeval swamp to HK post-1997. Very well laid out and well explained.
Very interesting. Once I got through the sections on rock and volcanoes and got to how Hong Kong developed it was really interesting and unlike China, was pretty objective. Free on Wednesdays rocked!

Hong Kong History Museum. The History museum takes you from the prehistoric era to the modern. It is well laid out, all the exhibits and the video presentations are translated to English. Very well done.
Learn about Chinese culture. There are great displays and volunteer tour guides to explain them it was free on Sunday and not busy. We did only the culture part of the museum.

Give it half a day. The museum is divided into stages and most people will save time by skipping to section 4, which is where it starts to get more interesting (not wishing to undervalue pre-history, early man and the natural environment...). From there on it's very well displayed and explained. It's also completely free on Wednesdays! There is usually a revolving exhibit for which you pay extra. The shop is a great place for gift shopping and has some good quality bits and pieces. The restaurant isn't great and perhaps best avoided.

A very nice place to learn about the city's history.. Everything about this museum fits in: centrally located, very reasonable income, spotless interior. Gives a very good overview of Hong Kong's history - well balanced in all aspects: not too little - not too much, not too simple - not too high brow.Take at least half a day or return a few times if you can.If having limited time: skip the very old stuff on the first floor and hop to the second immediately: more about the city as it has become now.Go to the museum shop and check out these great (replica's of) old HongKong toys they sell there!

A Hong Kong Must!. Came to Hong Kong Museum of History towards the end of my visit. Its a little out of the way, and if you are visiting, make sure you look it up on a map first - its not the easiest place to find, even from Tim Sha Shui station.But endure, and find it. Its a must see if you come to Hong Kong.... gives you such a sense of history of the place, spanning 4million years, but particularly about the last 200 years. In one afternoon, I got a sense of the indigenous peoples of the place, their traditions, the British takeover, the opium wars, and the 20th century history. And because Hong Kong is relatively small, i could relate what i was seeing, watching and reading about to the places I've been every day.Informative, interesting and well-presented. You SHOULD come here if you are visiting HK!

Wonderful photographs give you the history. We happened upon the museum by a lark, but are so glad that we did. It was a cool place to rest in the heat of the day, the bathrooms were wonderfully clean, and the displays themselves were terrific. We really got a feel for the many changes that this city has undergone by seeing the still photographs, as well as the slideshow pictures which show the growth of the buildings. This is a place you should certainly check out.

Nice visit. We wanted to get a better sense of the history and development of Hong Kong/Kowloon while visiting the area for the second time. The museum about 15-20 walk from the Tsim Tsa Tsui area, and it was even free being it was a Tuesday. The museum is spotless, well (if not over) staffed at every corner, and pretty interesting. We walked through the entire museum in about 2-3 hours and it was nice to get some better understanding of old Hong Kong and its struggles.

Good and interesting intro to all things Hong Kong. The Museum of History is a good overview of all things Hong Kong, beginning with its pre-human natural environment and working its way to the present. At a cost of 10HKD (half-price for seniors) and a cool place to hang out, this is a great option during the heat of the day. This is an extensive museum that covers a lot of territory and time, so be aware and pace yourself according to your interests and time. There are dioramas with sound effects that bring the settings to life, and tons of artifacts that date through the ages. There are extended sections on various ethnic groups, including the boat dwellers and salt makers, with recreations and replicas of their ways of life, including a walk-on junk. There are recreations of various festivals, marriage and birth celebrations, the Cantonese opera, parades and lion dances. There are many other replicas of Hong Kong life through the decades, including a Chinese herbal medicine shop, grocery store, post office, bank, tram car, peasant houses, and many others. There are numerous (10) short films (running in English about every third running) that provide further detail, and some exhibits have taped interviews appropriate to the scene. The museum covers the opium wars, the cession from China to England, the world wars, the Japanese occupation, and the return to China. The museum is very interesting and quite well-done for the most part. In some cases, there are too many artifacts too strung out when they could be clustered and organized in time more efficiently. It is often difficult to work your way through in a chronological or logical sequence, but there is a lot of material to cover so you do the best you can. In some cases, the explanatory captions were in too small a print, badly placed at the bottom of an exhibit, or suffered from poor lighting – we particularly found this frustrating in the case of the ethnic costumes, which were very interesting. Pace yourself and enjoy this very all-encompassing museum.

Leave plenty of time for this place. This place is well worth a visit to get a real feel for Hong Kong. It starts quite literally at the beginning with the geological formation of Hong Kong and ends up at the modern day region. To see it properly takes a good few hours so leave plenty of time to meander through it.

Go on Wednesdays,free entry!. It's not often you get something for nothing these days, and the museum has free entry on Wednesday's which is great. In saying that, I think it is quite cheap to visit on other days too. Lots of information and so much to see, I'm not really a museum person but this was very well done, and you need a good 2 - 3hrs to really see everything. Very interactive and interesting to learn how Hong Kong came about.

Interesting Peak in the History. *) Take the MTR to Hung Hom Station. Exit via D1. A bit tricky to reach to the main gate though.*) Opening Hours for Galleries:Monday & Wednesday to Friday : 10am - 6pmSaturday, Sunday and public holidays : 10am - 7pmClosed at 5 pm on Christmas Eve and Chinese New Year's EveClosed on Tuesdays (except public holidays) and on the first two days of the Chinese New Year*) Free admission on Wednesday (except for some Special Exhibitions)*) Standard Ticket-$10 . Ticket price is HK$10 per person, discounted price of HK$5 for students, seniors and those with disabilities. Can use Octopus Card to buy this ticket. *) It is located next to the Hong Kong Science Museum.*) Air-conditioned. *) If you want to take an hour out to get some food you can get a stamp from reception and return later in the day.*) The descriptions in English of the different exhibits are quite good; one can also rent an audio guide, but it is really not necessary. There are also a lot of videos, which run continuously in different languages, including English; when the audio portion is not in English there are English subtitles.*) Takes around 3 hrs.For a detailed trip list feel free to visit http://hongkongandmacauitinerary.blogspot.in/2014/10/hong-kong-macau-itinerary.html
awesome museum!. Cheap entrance tcket. Most is explained in English. Very interesting exhibitions. Full sized eg two storyes tree tram etc.Museum shop was woerth a visit.

Great place to learn about Hong Kong history. We spent a whole afternoon here - lots of historical stuff plus some special exhibits. Love the details about traditional Chinese customs, marriage traditions. There was a projection room which is beautifully decorated with lanterns.

Very well set out and presented. A great place to visit with first rate exhibits all life sized and beautiful. Could take photos and an easy place to access with lovely surroundings. Could spend an hour easily and also watch a couple of ten minute films. Very spacious inside.

If you enjoy Museums, you will love it!. Although the HK Museum of History is not that close to the subway, it is definitely worth the walk (can be accessed via TST/ East TST/ or Hung Hom MTR station): http://www.lcsd.gov.hk/CE/Museum/History/en_US/web/mh/plan-your-visit/access.htmlEverything has signage in English and I especially enjoyed the upper floor with the large-scale replica of what the HK streets and shops used to look like--it felt like going back in time. Also, they have a bunch of dioramas! My original plan was to spend several hours to do a quick walk through, but ended up spending almost half a day and didn't really finish seeing everything. Check the official website for descriptions for the permanent (8 areas) and current exhibitions. If you have time to spare, it's definitely worth a visit!

Worth the visit. It was highly recommended by our travel guide and we surely did not regret it. A bite difficult to find from the closed MTR station. The museum describes the creation of Hong Kong from its mineral era to today's situation. Very interactive, English and Chinese video projection, nice decors, good for both adults and kids.

need a whole day. this was great! although SOOOO much information i visited for maybe 3 hours and had to rush the end, don't spend to much time in the beginning of the museum unless rocks are what your into, also they offer small little movies throughout the museum most have English subtitles in case you miss the English video, its a really fun day, not very interactive though so wouldn't recommend it for small children but would recommend for say 10 years or older, lots of fake buildings to explore, if your curious about hong kong and its fascinating history have a visit!!
A step back in time. Definitely worth the visit and glad we gave ourselves 3 hours to do it. So much to see and learn, well set up and easy to follow

Abundance of great exhibits but lacks flow. Went to the old history museum many years ago and thoroughly enjoyed the exhibits as i felt i came away with a good feel of the history of HK. Whilst many of the exhibits are the same and there are an abundance of new ones with explanations in cantonese mandarin and english, i felt the museum lacked flow and it was difficult to keep track of the chronology. Nevertheless still an entertaining visit and was free admission (as it was a wednesday).

Spectacular Museum for all ages..NOT TO Be missed. I have often despised museums as a child but that's because they were so boring.. not this one. Chinese gov't promotes culture in Hong Kong so all the museums are so inexpensive to go in and you can get 1/2 year passes for so little money you can go to all the museums in a 1-2 weeks trip. This one particular is my favorite.. not only because it is conveniently located across from the Science center but because it brings back my youth. Other reviews already mention what you see but no one really mentions how amazing it is to see the reconstruction of old Hong Kong in the 60s. It is stunning. There are activities for kids as well. I have been here a few times already on trips back and I never find it boring.
Enjoyed this museum very much!. I highly recommend this museum. Its design is lovely, the exhibitions are very rich and interesting.Great value for the modest fee of 10 hkd.

So worth it!!!. I took the advice of TA's reviewers and went to the museum with the thought that I will make a short visit. It turned out that I spent there 3 hours, fascinating 3 hours. Don't skip this museum!!!
Brilliant and informative!. We went here as we had a couple of hours to spare. Very cheap entry. Lots of things to see and learn about history of China and Hong Kong. We were very surprised

Just a very, very good museum - simple as that.. Very extensive - covers from geological progression 400mya, the evolution of humanoids in the area, flora and forna, politics, general life of inhabitants, weather among others. I think the only part it didn't cover much of is WW2 but then again I can't say I didn't miss a section of the museum. I think you'd want to give yourself 2 - 3 hours to really get the most of the place. It was HKD $15, so less than AUD $3. Pretty awesome.

Great history lesson. This is a very well planned museum of HK starting from it's formation as a rock island all the way to present day so to speak. We visited on a Wednesday as it and all museums have free admission on Wednesdays. It was also a great stop to cool off on a rather warm/humid day in late September.It was a great way to start our HK vacation and would recommend to visit.

Nice place to kill time. I came here on a Sunday lunch time, and it was nice and quiet. The entrance fee is 10HKD.The museum is nothing spectacular, but if you have a couple of hours to kill, then it is definitely worth checking out.
Very nice. Very nice displays and very well done. I really enjoyed the recreated shops and homes. The shop has some very nice items but is really expensive.

Worth a Visit. Surprisingly informative - covers everything from geological formation to current political situation and everything in between. Very cheap - HK$10 pp and free on Wednesday. Only reason for not rating 5 star is that the layout of the various exhibits is very haphazard - we looked for but couldn't find the Opium Wars. Entry is off the street at ground level but the ticket office is in a plaza two levels up! Keeps a few people employed guiding tourists backward and forward.

Superb Museum--Go Early in Your Visit. Really great museum and tells the story of Hong Kong in well-described detail. Excellent curation, easy to follow, with amazing depth. Superb descriptions of regional cultures, different colonial periods, Japanese occupation, and post-WWII economic expansion as well as the transition from British to Chinese rule. In retrospect, this should've been the first place we visited in Hong Kong just to establish a baselne of knowledge.

Well worth it. I thought I knew the historical highlights of Hong Kong, the museum opened my eyes to facts I was missing. Well worth the $15, it took us half the day, and the content & way it was represented was fascinating.

Wednesday is free entry. We were wandering the streets and found the museum. And to our surprise the museum is free entry on Wednesdays. We spent a good 4 hours here. Great mix of natural history. Politics. Worth a visit to touch base with what Hong Kong is all about

A nice overview of HK. I made my first trip to this museum recently, despite being born in HK and multiple visits to HK over the years. This museum gives a comprehensive overview of HK's history. The displays are well done--beautifully presented and informative. The museum is most interesting with its mock storefronts and displays of the different cultures in the upper level. Towards the end (return to China), it does feel a bit propaganda-ish. I thoroughly enjoyed the visit as a single adult visiting yet can see kids enjoying a few hours here. It can be a nice break from heat or rain. However, it is a bit of a walk from TST metro station (as LP guide suggested as closest metro). Jordan is a bit closer but still about a 15 minute walk. There are buses that pass closer.The museum is reasonably priced most days and free on Wednesdays. It is closed on Tuesdays.

Brilliant museum. This is an extremely interesting museum if you want to know more about Hong Kong's history. We allowed a couple of hours to visit before a flight and this really wasn't enough. I would recommend planning much longer but over several days.
a must visit. one of the best city history museums I have been to. Cost not much to get in to and is in a ok location. Go there

DON'T MISS THIS WONDERFUL MUSEUM. We spent about 3 hours exploring this interesting museum which tells of Hong Kong's development for ancient times to the present ( and I mean all the way back to the Cave Men. It gave a very god presentation of the Opium Wars in the mid 1800's right through to today with many great movies to watch about the various time periods (some with actual footage). Also had some old stores depicted with their original fixtures. Great way to send some time in air conditioned comfort - Oh and seniors get in for half price.

Brilliant day out for the museum buff. I was in the disappointing science museum - just leaving saddened by the dumbing down of science, when I noticed this over the other side of the plaza. When I went in I was politely informed that as an over 60 I got a concession entry, brilliant! Everything the Science Museum was not this museum was, thoughtful, detailed, inticately explained in Chinese and English, beginning 500M years BCE it took you step by step through the history and culture of Hong Kong until modern times after the Japanese invasion ended. I had intended an hour's visit but I was there the entire afternoon and would dearly like a trip back there with my wife. This one is for people who love reading, like looking, are interested in history - it was a great visit.
Great place to spend an hour or two. Very informative displays. A reasonable size to cover in an hour or so. English spoken throughout. Very low admission fee.
Excellent Bruce Lee exhibit. Very good place to spent a rainy afternoon. Exhibits were excellent. The building need some maintenance. English signage was limited.
Not to be missed. Most people may not think of visiting a museum in HK but this one is really worth it. It has lots of interesting Chinese artefacts and a recreation of an old Chinese street.
Neat. It's very comprehensive, so neat. And the staff are all kind and helpful. Even my 3 year old daughter was fascinated. And it's only HKD10.

Worth to visit, especially on Wednesday. Museums in Hong Kong are mostly free admission on Wednesday. The museum is nice decorated and simply amazing. I love to visit museum when visited to a country as it represents the culture of the country and how they carry the country brand.

What a find!. Especially if raining or stifling hot. Air conditioned with escalators and lifts. Terrific exhibits, well laid out with small screening rooms in English and Chinese. We hired an audio recorder but didn't use it much as everything in both languages with excellent explanations. Allow at least 2 hours and afterwards go to the piazza across the road left side about one block down for a drink or meal in outdoor cafés. Not far from train and good bus service. Highly recommend!

Surprisingly Interesting!. Surprisingly interesting. Very comprehensive. Huge place and unfortunately we didn't manage to get round it all before it closed at 6pm. Was tempted to re-visit just to finish but our time in Hong Kong was far too short to make this possible. I'm not normally into this type of tourist attraction but it had me captivated. Within the museum, they have recreated some of the old style Hong Kong villages which still exist to this day in the mountains and explained the traditions and beliefs that still hold true to this modern day. Extremely fascinating!All museums in Hong Kong are free to get in on Wednesdays but unfortunately we were unable to make it, so went on a Monday instead, only 10 HKD to get in! Blown away. Especially considering the fact that it cost 190 million HKD (if I remember correctly) to build and it's only 10 HKD for your entrance fee. How is this possible! Recommended for tourists and locals alike just to see how Hong Kong has been formed over the years into the insanely busy tourist hub it is today! Worth a visit. I think this is the quietest place in Hong Kong I have ever been, so it may be worth a visit just to see that! Albeit it was a weekday at around 3pm we arrived.
excellent ~. good facilities ! bit far to walk from Train station ! lot of attention is paid for even minor details !

Great Museum. You need around 2 hours to visit this museum that explains the history of Hong Kong, very informative and interactive to keep children entertained. Worth a visit. Also the entrance fee is very cheap 10 HKD

Comprehensive and immersive. Starts right at the dawn of time! Tells you everything there is to know about Hong Kong, and with lots of life-size recreations and videos to keep it interesting - not just looking at things in glass boxes. Worth a visit.
