Awesome. What a fun museum - loads of culture, makes you want to explore more. We were only in HK for two days but after learning so much of the culture from this great museum - we really want to return to see more.

Great overview of Hong Kong's history.... Decided to take a break from the heat and check out this museum and we're sure glad we did. It was very cheap to get in and I actually learned a lot about the history of the area. The routing of the exhibits can be a bit confusing (we got mixed up several times) but overall the displays were great, with lots of English written explanations. What a turbulent and exciting history Hong Kong has had...great stuff! A great place to relax when the heat becomes unbearable or the rain is pouring down.

Informative and CHEAP!. The government in Hong Kong supplements the cost of entry and it is SO CHEAP to get in here. Completely worth it. It was $10 HKD per person, which is like $1.25 per person. Exhibits are really well done and informative, but poorly laid out. However, the signs suggest the path you should walk throughout each exhibit. They give a very interesting view of historical events that you may have learned about in US history class, but with a broader perspective since this is the other side of the world. We just loved it and felt like we learned a lot about WWII and the Opium Wars, how Hong Kong came to be, and also other interesting things about Chinese culture and rice cultivating and harvesting.Since this is a government building, it offers free WiFi, which is a nice bonus if you're a tourist and don't have regular phone service here. I loved being able to check my Facebook and get emails.Facilities are nice and clean and overall we had a wonderful experience here. I would highly recommend it for tourists, as it gives you a lot of history and facts about Hong Kong, with beautiful exhibits you can walk through.

Wonderful museum. This museum includes information and elaborate displays on the history, archaeology, culture and traditions of Hong Kong. The museum also includes information on the opium wars and the handover/return to China. If you are interested in the history and culture of Hong Kong, this is a "must-see". I was pleased to see so many school groups visiting on the day I was there.It is very easy to get to from the East Tsim Sha Tsui MTR stop.

Free on wednesday. When on wednesday so free entrance, the science museum next door is also free.If you have been to a few history museum you can skip the first few exhibition since it is just about geography (maybe not generally interested in geography see for yourself there)There are a short video for each exhibition and it kind of summarize the exhibition so watch it before or after going around.

4 floor galleries. the gallery is huge, the art show is great. i enjoyed the wood sculpture art and Chinese antiques that they display.Price is 10 HKD (standard package) if you want to see all galleries it would be 20 HKD
Best Museum in HongKong. I think it is the best museum in HongKong.. I love old Chinase cultuer, best section for me is Chinase Folk Culture. . you can take photos ..

excellent. We arrived at the museum at few hours before closing and weren't able to finish it. The history of Hong Kong begins with the evolution of the earth and its pre-historic times! We used the audio tour which was helpful and fascinating - recommended. Very through and very interesting to say the least. Wish we came in a few hours earlier so we could give adequate time to the rest of the museum.

A CREATION OF THE BRITISH!. There is no doubt that the best Museums have been created by the... Britons! ...and the City of Hong Kong is a British Creation, representing -more or less- the "spirit of Rule Britannia"!The way that the history of this "ROCK" has been presented in this Museum is remarkable; although there are parts of the Museum referring to the "Imperialistic Role" of Britain in this area of the World (...for example the period of the "Opium War"), there is no doubt that Hong Kong remains "British" even under the Chinese Administration!Visit this Museum; it will remind you the "Museum of London" at the Barbican, but on the other hand, you will enjoy the magic of the "Orient World"! .

The exhibits are very life like and well done. A good way to promote and preserve the history and cultural heritage of Hong Kong. The Hong Kong Story is a good showcase of the history and development of Hong Kong. Well set out over several floors and we visited on a Wednesday and the entry was free.
A taste of old Hong Kong. This is one of the best history museum I've ever visited in my life. It is a museum full of interaction which makes it a perfect place to go with younger travelers.
Good introduction to HK history. A good primer for HK history although it did not go into great detail on the Opium Wars or 1997 handover and Basic Law. Some subjects may be a little too sensitive.
Very interesting. It is a treasure trove of things that will allow you a peak at the past glories of Hong Kong. Good exhibits too
History lesson. Loved the history learnt a lot about Hong Kong that I did not know easy to get around beautiful place you need at least 4 hours to see it all

Lots to see. A huge Museum with interesting displays and info on the history of Hong Kong going back to prehistoric times. Upstairs was a Japanese section which we didn't have time to explore but want to next time!

The Story of Hong Kong. I had choice between the HK Museum of History or Science Museum. I took a chance and went for the History Museum.I thought 2 hours be enough but if you love history, you will take your sweet time here. I enjoyed walking and looking at the exhibits so much. it starts from HK in prehistoric times all the way to its modern days. This is the story of HK
Great insight into Hong kong's history. Brilliant. Really enjoyed the history and the fantastic displays especially the street scapes. Well worth a few hours.

Excellent introduction to a complex history. We only visited the walk through timeline section and skipped most of the geological and archaeological sections but the narrative history was very well presented with a fishing junk to walk on, a recreated street of shops, a Chinese opera etc. Excellent way to get the basics of the Hong Kong story in perspective.

Fascinating history lesson. You can spend there many hours and you won't be bored! Modern, amazing museum. I learned a lot about the history and the people who have inhabited Hong Kong for centuries, about their traditions, life, culture and nature. Highly recommended, especially on one of rainy days in Hong Kong. Free on Wednesdays.

Highly recommended. Gave us a great review about the history and the people that have made HK as it is now. I spent 3 hours at the museum. Perhaps because I am a museum buff, but it was far from sufficient to look around the exhibits.

See this on the first day. The organization of this stunning museum is amazing and the information it shares is in English and Chinese. You never have to guess what an exhibit is about. The visit could take 4 or more hours! so plan accordingly. We saw it on our last day, which was unfortunate. Had we seen it early in our trip, we would probably have returned two times, for 2 to 3 hours each, rather than "suffer" through a long standing session.

All informations about Hong Kong in one place. You can spend there a whole day - good for one of Hong Kong's rainy days! We learned a lot about the geology and environment, the people who inhabit Hong Kong, their traditions, about the British in Hong Kong, the Opium War and the time of "One nation, two laws". For food you have to leave the Museum, but there are some nice Chinese restaurants two minutes walk away. On Wednesday is free admission for everyone (August 2014). And it's not crowded like other places in Hong Kong.

Comprehensive (even if they never say 'Tiananmen'). Something for everybody here. Sections on the early geographic formation, early cultures, and more recent history. Big enough you can skip the sections you don't care about and still have a full visit. They do reference the million person march of 1989 but not so much what it was about :-)

Everything you ever wanted to know about Hong Kong. This is a vast repository of information and exhibits about Hong Kong. Geography, history and culture starting 400 million years ago right up to the British handover in 1997. It is vast.Better for grown ups and older kids but even our youngsters enjoyed it for a while.Very highly recommended.

Great for understanding Hong Kong & Mainland China’s complex relationship. In the permanent collection, the museum is laid out in different sections to historically explain what has happened to Hong Kong over the years. “At first, Hong Kong became a British colony in 1841. Then in 1842 the Treaty of Nanking was signed, formally ending the First Opium War. In 1898, Britain was granted an additional 99 years of rule over Hong Kong under the Second Convention of Peking. In September 1984, after years of negotiations, the British and the Chinese signed a formal agreement approving the 1997 turnover of the island in exchange for a Chinese pledge to preserve Hong Kong's capitalist system. On July 1, 1997, Hong Kong was peaceably handed over to China in a ceremony attended by numerous Chinese and British dignitaries. The chief executive under the new Hong Kong government, Tung Chee Hwa, formulated a policy based upon the concept of "one country, two systems," thus preserving Hong Kong's role as a principal capitalist center in Asia” (reference History Channel). Our Hong Kong local guide told us his personally he would always stay in Hong Kong. It was his home though his brothers have moved out of the country. After the 1997 hand over back to China, there have been subtle changes -- a road that has bus transportation going directly to mainland China, b) cars that have dual license plates – Hong Kong & mainland China and c) a shift from Cantonese to Mandarin as being the main language. Personally, I know that before the handover those that had monies left Hong Kong to the United States and Canada. In southern California these wealthy Hong Kong residences purchased homes for cash which drastically drove up housing prices. So if you’re into history or are curious about how Hong Kong has been impacted this museum has documented the various aspects and is well worth visiting.

Good Afternoon activity.. Great chilled afternoon. Cost 10 HKD.The Museum is great place to spend the afternoon. I loved all Video shows and also "Section 8".Overall spent about 2 hours here, learnt a lot and got some great photos too.

Cool place. It's a very neat museum. Lots of exhibits to see and interact with. I wish the media played more often and there were more maps to show the places the media talked about but it was a very interesting place....Gives a good glimpse into the cites past and it's present.

Excellent coverage of the long history of Hong Kong and the region. The museum gives an excellent account of the different periods of rule in South Eastern and Hong Kong in particular. Covers aspects of economic growth, food, trade, .... Great place to visit.

One of the best museum . Surprising good museum and very cheap. The museum tell all the story of HK and all the documentary is well presented.
Highly recommended if you have spare time after shopping and eating! :)
worth visiting. We never thought a museum could be so much interesting. The shows and presentation makes it special.

well worth a visit. Cost HK $10 which is about AUD $1.40 - fantastic museum with so much to see. Particularly great for the kids. I spent two hours there one afternoon and only saw a fraction of the offerings.

Well worth a visit. Extensive building . Very spacious and well laid out. Good use of various media and displays. Particularly good on the last 150 years. A bit of a walk up Kowloon island but worth it. Free on Wednesdays.

Very informative! & not crowded at all !. It's exhibits /videos covers local history from the Devonian period 400 million years ago to Hong Kong’s reunification with China in 1997 & today. Exhibits were well documented in English too!
& what I like about this place, is that unlike many other HK attractions, this museum is very spacious and not crowded at all! : )

Tells the Hong Kong Story. I sure wish we would have visited the HK Museum of Science earlier in our HK trip. It has some wonderful artifacts from old HK, and explains its development under British rule. However, I found the gift shop to be more books than true souvenirs.

Really good museum. Very informative museum with lots of interesting visual displays. I lived in Hong Kong many years ago and yet learned quite a bit of HK history that I had never heard of. It is a large museum and, if you really want to read all the signs, etc., you should plan at least a half day and a full day wouldn't be out of the question. The recreations (and in some cases, the actual stores and their goods) of various periods in HK history were fascinating.

nice museum. This is a good place to start a HK visited. It covers the geological, geographic as well as human history of Hong Kong.There are many exhibits and photos from various periods of time. You can cruise through or take your time.It is close to the science museum as we as shopping.
Not very informative. Pretty dull exhibits spread out over a large area, especially little to see or do for the English-only speaker. We didn't learn much.

Loved every bit. Loved it. Could have spent much more time there. I loved that the décor and theming of the entire space changes as you move through the time periods.Very informative and seemingly unbiased representation of history.

Fantastic HK History. I really enjoyed my visit to the Hong Kong museum. Entrance to the main exhibit is a bargain $10HKD, I spent around 3 hours in total, mostly in the main exhibit. Being British it was particularly interesting for me to understand and learn about the full history of Hong Kong, the museum shows it brilliantly. The history is covered from millions of years ago to present day with a large focus on the British and Japanese occupancies which was my main interest. Large well presented exhibits and some really good movies make it one of the best museums I have been to in Asia. Really worth a visit

Possibly the best museum I've been to. Less impressed by the natural and pre history on the ground floor, although still worth a look around. But the stuff on the political history is hugely interesting and really well curated. Brilliant stuff

Great way to get to know Hong Kong. Love this museum. Been here a few times over my 6 visits to Hong Kong and have enjoyed it every time. The displays are very detailed and well kept. Covers a wide range of topics and events. This is a must for anyone spending a few days in Hong Kong or if you get a rainy day

Extensive displays. This exhibit is extensive with lots of special displays showing models of machinery used in such things as the fishery industry, etc. I particularly liked the Chinese theatre display. It is well worth the visit. Allow at least an hour or more, preferably more.
worth a visit.. 15 minute walk from Sha Tin station. Not well signposted from mall. Worth it to see Bruce Lee exhibition.

Everything from acient to modern in HK. It is a immersion experience to explore the Hong Kong museum of History. People can not only see pictures and words on the wall, but can also walk into old drug store, cable car, or even living rooms dated back to last century. But it seems Hong Kong's history ended by 1997. Because there was almost nothing showed after that.

Great way to learn about Hong Kong (and beat the heat and rain!). We decided to visit this museum in light of the pouring rain and high temps that have characterized this week for us so far (hope springs eternal that tomorrow will be better!). We went for free (Wednesday) but would have been worth the admission any other day. The museum covers the history of the city from literally the dawn of time to the present day. The prehistoric/natural history stuff was a little hokey - but the legends (in that section and throughout) were still quite informative. The best areas were those that covered the local culture (4 very different settlement groups), day to day life during the British period (the pawn shop, post office, and tea trade exhibits were all great), and the japanese occupation. There was a clear effort to paint the reunification with mainland China as a very positive thing - even though this remains quite controversial outside the walls of the museum. Many of the exhibits are colorful and interspersed with movies depicting the various periods (in multiple languages and with subtitles). One negative was the other patrons seemed to have no space boundaries at all (constant bumping) and who took incessant pictures (lots of kids just snapping pics for the hell of it without even really looking at the exhibit or reading the legend). Still very good place to spend a day and get some longitudinal perspective on a city that is so manic in real time that it's easy to forget all that has come before.

learn about Hong Kong. If you think Hong Kong is a charming city, you should go to the museum to learn more about its history and how it becomes the place it is today. It doesn't take you a lot of time. A couple hours will be worthwhile and enough to make you love this city even more.

A wonderful way to understand the History of HK. You could definitely spend a whole day and then some at this museum! We learned so much about HK and it's history during our 1/2 day visit. It is a amazing way to learn about the culture, customs and history. I only wish we had more time to spend!

Nice museum and free on some days. Tells the story of Hong Kong quite well but they seem to forget a large part of colonial influence. But the exhibition is outstanding and if the attendants were a little more welcoming I would rate it higher. Across the square is the HK science museum also worth a look.
Go on Wednesdays. It's free. A brilliant journey through the history of hong kong and cracking shop which has good design-led products.

Fun and Informative. This will take a whole day, the museum starts with Hong Kong's beginning of time to present day. I loved how they organized it!!
Take the family, the kids will love it. Many short films in English, Mandarin, Cantonese, and Korean

Good way to spend a few hours out of the heat.. I enjoyed learning about the history of Hong Kong. It was nice to have videos in English. I liked having the audio guide, but the layout was a bit confusing and I had a hard time finding things or knowing which way to proceed.

Good way to learn about the culture!. We visited the museum on a Thursday afternoon, it was not very crowded, and spent about 3 hours. It is worth the $10 HKD to buy the self-guided tour by earphones (this is in addition to the admission of $10 HKD). One problem with this however, is not all of the exhibits are marked with the number on the guide, so we had to look around for some of the items while listening to the guide. The first two sections on prehistoric and early times were not as interesting as section 4 through the end, when the focus was on folk culture. The exhibits on the culture are excellent, showing how they lived in real size and with great detail. It was interesting and flowed well. Lots of bathrooms along the way and helpful guides, and places to rest, to listen to the guide explain the details. We thoroughly enjoyed the visit, and the admission was very reasonable!

Enjoyed it. We enjoyed our 1.5 hour or so in this museum outlining Hong Kong's history. The content is divided into 1 to 8 sections by time. The sections 4-8 on the 2nd floor have more info and exhibits. If your time is limited, would start w these sections and then spend less time on the 1-5 sections on the ground floor. There are less exhibits from this time which is prehistoric to early dynasties. Wish we had done it this way. In any case, it is well air-conditioned and was a great break from the July heat. Adds to understanding the culture of Hong Kong. You may want to get a broader perspective on events like the Opium War, which are depicted pretty much one-sided here.

One of the good Attraction!. Good for both tourist and resident, interesting to know about Hong Kong's history and geography, also worth to spent time to watch the short movies to more understand this small city.
It's good. Nice museum, some of the content is dry but still worth the visit. You don't need to spend too long in there, would prefer if they made some of the content more interactive.
Superb Museum. If you have time, is worth the time to see the museum. spend at least a couple of hours, but less is doable.

A great museum to see. We have seen many museums in our travels and this one is a good one to visit. Interesting and enough entertainment to keep you there for approx 3 hrs, certainly for adults interest nothing there for young children, but a great insight on the history of honk kong,

I really enjoyed learning about the history of Hong Kong. I was so intrigued with Hong Kong after learning so much about it from a walking tour that I wanted to learn more...so off to the museum! They have a great and thorough exhibit on the history of HK from 400 million years ago to the present day. I was surprised how long I spent walking through the exhibit ( with an audio tour pair of head phones) - about 3 hours!

Good museum to take your children. Around HKG$30 for two adults and two children. Almost all of the display signage is in English as well as Chinese, so it's easy to understand. We were there around 3 hours and only saw about half of the museum. You could easily spend a half-day here if you would like to. We went in July, and the museum Is air conditioned. This alone was worth the price of admission. Nice gift shop, and the restrooms are clean inside as well.

Fascinating. Great museum with enough little gems every now and then to keep everyone going. Vast and complicated in its layout, I kept feeling like we were doing it wrong or missing bits. Got very confused by jumping from prehistory to Han dynasty in the space of a ramp and and an iron bowl. First galleries are a bit ubiquitous - geology flora/ fauna without cutting to the chase of what's distinctive about the archipelago. In fact that's the only and meagre criticism I have of this excellent museum throughout- it's a bit wordy and doesn't give you a succinct storyline. It's great to be in a Museum about Chinese peoples that acknowledges and accepts spiritual and cultulral traditions ( in utter contrast to the museum in Tianneman square Beijing. ), distinct tribal/ ethnic groupings within china. these bits were by far and away the best. Watch the video of the opium wars first before doing the exhibits - it's much better than trying to get the narrative from the exhibits. It's horribly even handed toward the British and Europeans ( I'd say this was one of the darkest deeds the Brits have done) especially when the museum dispenses with objectivity with the Japanese invasion 100 yrs later. So it's fascinating to see who is writing the history and who are the beneficiaries of the peculiar political situation that is Hong Kong. Great museum. More going on within it than it's creators intended.

Best $1.50 USD!. It was as wonderful as others have said. I took 3 sons ( 19, 16, 10) and it appealed to each one on different levels. The 19yo, generally NOT into museums, had to be pulled away & said it was the best one he'd been to. It is like the Lincoln Presidential Museum in Illinois (another not to miss attraction) with the interactive displays, movies and realistic settings. Spring another $1.50 for the audio headset for everyone. Over 100 audio clips will guide you through the exhibits! Movies are educational in an entertaining way. Also noteworthy, the staff is ever-present to guide you in an unobtrusive way. So pleasant and helpful from the moment you walk in. Suggest you go at the start of your trip, especially if weather is inclement or HOT.

Innovate layout, interesting pieces of history . Obviously this is dedicated to history of the region of Hong Kong, starting in the pre-history era when the land was formed and transitioning right up to when the Sino-British joint declaration was signed. It was a wonderful experience, and really opened my eyes.Dedicate at least three hours as it is quite large (we took that long, but we watched almost all of the presentations). If you're considering doing all of the museums in HK, they offer free admission on Wednesdays (but undoubtedly packed as this is common knowledge), so I recommend grabbing a multi-pass from the ticket booth. It was only 30 HKD (about 4 AUD) and allowed us unlimited visits to all the main museums for one week.
Wow!. What a well set out and interesting museum. Took my history mad husband and 15 year old daughter and all three of us enjoyed it immensely!
A really informative museum. I love museums of history of the regions i visit, and this one was no exception. Informative, many maps, photos, objects to see.
Museum of History. This museum was well laid out and had a lot of good exhibits. We went on a Wednesday when admission is free.

Good way to understand HK. Loved this museum,for a start it's cool inside! It traces Hong Kong through the ages with archaeology and natural history. For me the best area was the one with replicas of local tradition. there were old shops and streets from different periods and ceremonial processions. Expect many children if in school time but they are all so well behaved as not to be a bother. All very well signed in both English and Chinese and toilets were available and very clean.

Start your HK trip here. This museum is great for both adults and children. You really feel as if you walk through Hong Kong's fascinating history. Don't miss it, as it will make you understand more when you walk around the city.

A must visit. This is one of the great museums in my opinion. Anyone who has had a connection with Hong Kong in the old days (like me) will find some piece of nostalgia ... sometimes bringing a tear to the eye.For those new to the place there is no better way to find out about the place.

If you visit one museum in HK make it this one. We visited on a Wednesday when it's free (usually only $10 anyway) and it was brilliant. A full journey through the history on Hong Kong. Very hands on and a good mixture of artefacts, videos and reconstructions. Very informative at all levels from children to adults and it was great for us as first time visitors to Hong Kong to learn more.

Fantastic museum. A really lovely museum which is well worth a visit. Fascinating history of the country covering every aspect from prehistoric to present day.Exceptionally well signposted with plenty of information. We visited on a Saturday afternoon and it was quiet and certainly not crowded. Interesting videos shown in English as well as Cantonese.Something to please everyone.
very interesting and worth a visit. we enjoyed learning the history of Hong Kong and the respite from the humidity. Was not busy when we went and staff was friendly.

An excellent introduction of Hong Kong. If you only have time to visit one museum in Hong Kong, make it this one. it gives a vivid introduction of the wonderful history of Hong Kong, and the special exhibitions have a lot of valuable old prints which you can't find via google. If you have kids the science museum adjacent to it is a paradise for the little grown ups.

A good way to spend an afternoon in HongKong. A nice way to introduce yourself to the region, detailing its development and history from prehistoric times to now. Has a huge array of displays but give yourself a lot of time to visit, at least 2-3 hours. Excellent value for entry too.

Great layout - a walk through time. The museum starts with the geology of the area and continues all the way to modern time (and reversion of the area to China). There are lots of dioramas and interactive exhibits and a great museum store. Learned a lot about European involvement and WWII - never knew the Japanese had invaded.

Important historical facts and cultural descriptions. From the outside of the building I was not expecting such a huge factual and cultural overview of Hong Kong and its people. Decades of information is presented on several floors with pictures, artifacts, cultural settings, displays and videos. I thought it was fantastic!
Excellence place for me in hongkong.. Excellence museum , I need my country have museum like this , so attraction place , near TST , easy to go by MTR.Great.

History of Hong Kong. One of the best museums I've ever visited. It is unusual for me to spend more than our hour in any museum or art gallery. I spent four hours in the Hong Kong Museum of History & enjoyed it all.

HK Museum. It was so so good. A complete history of Hong Kong and surrounding areas. We came over on the ferry from HK island, and walked to the museum. It is a bit difficult to find, so take your map with you.

Interesting. If you have sufficient time this place is a good way to see how the locals have enjoyed or suffered the historical development of their homeland. Somewhat kitschy (unavoidable now almost everywhere) but still moving.

Great day at the museum. We had a wonderful time going through the museum. Learned quite a bit of the Chinese culture. There could be better direction for the parking to get to the museum. During the summer months there are a lot of school children

Found it by chance. Only found it as we were going to be picked up to go and see the Elephants , Had time so looked around , then went back another day , Top restraunt there in the complex and money exchange , another place to go , Take the round the city Hop on Hop Off Buss will go back close to many Hotels and not crowded , Great Staff in the museum .

Well worth a visit. The museum was recommended to us and it was well worth the visit. Very well set out with beautiful displays. We ended up spending close to 4 hours here because it was so interesting. A definite visit for anyone interested in history
Very informative. This museum provides you with the total history of Hong Kong. Very interesting for a visitor like myself how Hong Kong has evolved.

Enjoyable way to learn the history of Hong Kong. We thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience from beginning to end. It takes you through the history of Hong Kong from the beginning to the present day. We learned things we were not aware of e.g.The Opium Wars and who was responsible. The Japanese occupation was interesting and eye opening. There are many many exhibits and it will take as long as you want it to. We were there for over 5 hours but it was time well spent. They also do a discount for the over 60's. Everything was well presented and we came away wiser than when we went in. The old shops and Temples were really good and the information on the wedding rituals was interesting. There is something for everyone here. We also visited the Art Museum and the Space Museum and found both of these to be most enjoyable with the latter having many hands on exhibits.

Brilliant, absolutely brilliant. Being a museum curator myself, I know how tricky it can be to present a story with very few original artefacts. HK Museum of History have done an absolutely astounding job nevertheless. Engaging, beautifully presented this museum is really all about the story of this great city. There are a few ancient artefacts - but rather than having rows upon rows of pots and tools and showing things in case after case (which there could undoubtedly be room for somewhere else) they have chosen to tell the story in a large as life manner. Visitors are drawn into dwellings, places of business or worship and using the many photographs of HK as she has changed, has created one of the most enjoyable museum visits i have experience anywhere in the world. Those who complain that there are not enough original artefacts, perhaps have a point, but do not let that deter you - this museum is ABSOLUTELY worth a long visit. Bravo HKMoH - you have done spectacularly well! (and for $10 HKD per person - it is criminal not to make it a part of your visit!)
Good way to spend a few hours. Very well set out and gives a good display of Hong Kong through past times to present days. Displays are very visual takes a good couple of hours to complete
Fantastic. Enjoyed the whole place. Really worthwhile. Very well set up. Great to be able to see the history of the four different groups that came to Hong Kong.

Free on wednesday and worth it. If you are travelling HK on a budget and looking for things to do. Museums are free on wednesdays. I only visited this one because of limited time. But you learn a lot about the history of HK. There are also a lot of quick film screening which you can watch. There a different time for mandarin, cantonese and english but if it is not in english, there are subtitles. Bring cameras as there are a lot of memories to take. There is also a wishing tree where you can hang your wishes.

Helps to understand how Hong Kong became important city.. Very interesting museum although I skipped all the first geological section. Good English signage and well executed exhibits especially the Opium Wars and the Japanese Occupation. Social history well presented throughout so not dry or boring. Fee is 10 HKD for adults and free on Wednesdays. Closes at 6 and takes about 1.5 to 2 hours to see.
Excellent. Well presented. Some locals were causing a raucous in one of the projector rooms so no-one could hear the movie. Security went in straight away and threw them out. Good job!
Very informative. We have spent a whole day here since the place is just so big and interesting. You learn about Hong Kong's geological history, its people etc.

Full of Interest. I spent an interested few hours wandering about the exhibits in the museum and thoroughly enjoyed myself. I got an audioguide and didn't really need it as all of the exhibits are well labelled. I would be inclined to call this a 'Must See' for anyone visiting Hing Kong.

Excellent Exhibition.. The attention to detail is excellent with a sound depiction of Hong Kong's History and Culture from start to modern day. Located on Chatham Road the Museum is simply reached and adjacent to the Science Museum. Many of the exhibits have audio and visual features with captivating old footage. The last theatrette displays the hand back to the Chinese with actual footage. We felt that this attraction was very worthwhile and believe all new visitors to Hong Kong should make it a must see.

Well worth the visit. Would highly recommend a visit to the HK Museum of History - well presented museum with interesting and interactive displays. Definitely worth the HK$10 entry - and if you go on Wednesdays it's free!

Great Museum. Was pleasenly surprised to find that it was free upon arrival (but i think this only applies to Wednesdays).The Museum is very well set out, and the standard of the displays is very good.We found it very informative and a great insight into the history of Hong Kong and its inhabitants.Particuarly liked the Costumes on display.Would recommend that you put a couple of hours aside to do this justice.

worth visiting. We went to this museum on a Sunday afternoon. It is very well-done, and for anyone who is interested in the rich history of this area, it is well worth the time to go. The exhibits are well-maintained and in many differently languages, including English. The entrance fee was nominal and well worth it--plus--it is air conditioned, so you get a break from the heat and humidity outside if you are in Hong Kong during the summer months!
Great overall view of the history of a city. Excellent recreation of Honk Kong from the past. Low admission fee and free on Wed. Near the Kowloon promenade, well work the walk over to it.
3 hours is not enough. well worth a visit - 3 hours is not enough. More interesting than we had expected, and great value for money

Wednesday is free entry to museums. I was delighted to find out that we arrived to this museum on Wednesday and it's free entry . So bare that in mind if you have time up your sleeve . As it's lovely to get something for free every now and then . Museum was interesting with lots of displays . Well thought out over 4 levels . If you are a history buff .,this us for youn

Excellent museum is a must-see to understand Hong Kong. This museum is really well done. Organized in a way that makes a lot of sense, pleasantly laid-out, with great and colorful exhibits. All signs are in English as well as Chinese. All films are offered in English as well as Chinese. I feel like this museum is a "must see" for anyone visiting Hong Kong for the first time - it helps give you insight into the city and understand why it is so westernized and such an eclectic mix of cultures.
Interesting. It's a little old fashioned but endlessly fascinating. Well worth a visit. Only spent an hour there and ran out of time - suggest you schedule at least 2.5 hours to do it justice.
Hong Kong is more than a shopping haven.. very nice display of history of Hong Kong. Only 10 HKD for traveler. If you are bored with all the crowded tourist spots, do visit here.

Informative and Perfectly Presented. The Hong Kong Heritage Museum was not actually a high priority on my itinerary and I went there because it happened to be close to a conference I was attending. It is hard to describe the pleasantness of the surprise.This museum is huge for a city history museum, displaying the history of Hong Kong from prehistoric to the present day. To a Westerner like myself, almost all of the information was new, so it was a pleasure to go around the exhibits and read the plaques. And this is where the museum truly shines: the plaques are highly informative and just the right length, with the exhibits they represent being perfect representations of the subject matter.In the museum you will learn about the early clans of Hong Kong, the Opium Wars period, the immigration to Hong Kong, the city in World War II and the development after it, including the massive projects undertaken to bring water and more land to the city.I ended up spending about 4 hours in the museum, instead of the ~1 hour initially planned. You should visit this place too, it's definitely worth it.

Commendable....!. The museum is an example of excellent planning and innovation.... The articles on the ancient and past HongKong is very nicely depicted, which kindles our concepts and creates interest to read more. The full models of culture of various tribes of HongKong is very tastefully designed. The model of forest with full size trees is something to be remembered forever..Museum is conveniently located, campus is clean and well maintained. One can also enjoy Museum of science in the very next bilding

Immersive exhibits, lots of information. Although my family is from HK, I don't know very much about its history. This offered a great way to see how Hong Kong has evolved over the centuries, from simple fishing village to burgeoning British colony, and everything in between.

Its a great visit. I visited Hong Kong so many times and i have not visited HK Museum of History until the recent trip - which I am SO glad i did.It is a comfortable and easy to navigate museum that only charge HKD10 per person and HKD5 for elderly above 60 yo - it is such a comfortable escapade during hot summer. walking around the museum helped me to understand much more about Hong Kong. everything is well laid out and very elderly-friendlyit is just next to Science Museum - so you can kill 2 birds at the same time

Definitely a worthwhile visit. Easily spend 2 hours here, specially love the show cases of the colourful customs of ethnic groups of Hong Kong. You get to view life-size replica of fishing junk, living condition by the boat dwellers', traditional buildings, 2 storey old European style buildings that housed tea shop, herbal medical hall, tailor's shop and many many more. Some of the scene comes with sound effect too. Very impressive. High recommended to visit this history museum. Visit on Wed it's free admission for history museum, space museum & Art museum. Space Museum it's just next to it and the Art Museum is further down at the waterfront. One of the way to get to History & Space museum take MTR to Tsim Sha Tsui station, before exiting the station look for the exit point to the history museum. About 10 mins easy walk.
Very Informative, Kid friendly. Great information on the history of HK. There were lots of short films to move visitors through the history. The museum has a good flow for kids.

Stunning Exhibition.. There are some 8 galleries that will easily allow you to consume a few hours. The attention to detail is excellent with a sound depiction of Hong Kong's History and Culture from start to modern day. Located on Chatham Road the Museum is simply reached and adjacent to the Science Museum. Many of the exhibits have audio and visual features with captivating old footage. The last theatrette displays the hand back to the Chinese with actual footage. We felt that this attraction was very worthwhile and believe all new visitors to Hong Kong should make it a must see.

Excellent way to learn about HK. As a resident of HK, I have been to this museum twice, once in 2001, and recently in May 2014. You can easily spend a few hours there.There are many floors, and even though this last visit, there were renovations going on, the exhibits were still top quality. There is an area dedicated to the 4 main ethnic groups in HK, which were fascinating. The top floors, with recreations of HK in the 70s and the section about the Japanese Occupation was really well planned and detailed. I will definitely visit again.Entry is free on Wed, which may explain the large groups of school kids there too.

Not bad for the fee. We purchased a museum ticket that covered all of the museums in the district for a week so decided to come into the history museum. There was an exhibit about the history of Hong Kong which was quite short but interesting. We didn't spend more than 30 minutes in here but it wasn't bad for the fee and we learnt a bit about the history of HK.

Exceeded expectations. Having visited many poorly lit mainland Chinese museums complete with incomprehensible English notes, this museum exceeded our expectations.The museum traces both the natural and human history of Hong Kong. It offers a range of display formats with traditional information displays with artefacts, plus other multimedia displays including full size replicas of traditional Hong Kong housing as well as short videos summarising each time period.At times the displays were confusing and did jump from one time period to another but luckily there were videos to tie all the history together. Furthermore, the museum gives you an accessible overview of such a broad time frame.Highly recommend visiting in all weather - it is air conditioned! 10HKD for an adult and you will probably spend a couple of hours there.

Fantastic - even for someone who is not a museum buff!. The exhibitions at this museum were so informative, yet interesting. The displays of mock up stages for the Chinese opera stage, the boat on which certain communities live, the natural environment from thousands years ago , were amazing. I am no museum buff, but I was able to walk through the museum for a good 3 hours and enjoy the stories of the past, and that gave me a much better understanding of Hong Kong's history. Definitely must visit, even if it is not your first trip to Hong Kong (this is my fifth!).

HK Museum of History .. Exceeded my expectations. We visited the HK Museum of History and found it to be a very pleasant experience. You can use your subway/octopus pass to buy your entry ticket. They have headsets you can use as well. It is air conditioned (which is a blessing). The basic history of Hong Kong, the land and it's people is very interesting. We all learned a lot, and took some great photos. FYI: you need a good camera with a flash. Your iPhone won't cut it. Everything will be dark.

An Amazing Exhibit of the Hong Kong Story. The HK story is definitely a worthwhile exhibit to visit, especially if you are from Hong Kong, but was raised overseas. I went with my parents a few years back, and it was definitely a worthwhile trip down memory lane for them. It brought a lot of nostalgia for them. As for me, my recent visit with my husband was a learning experience, as we revisited the HK history from the beginning of time, and especially during the British reign. The exhibits were built extremely well, and it made you feel as if you were traveling back in time. The lessons in tradition certainly shed a lot of light as to why our families had certain requests and expectations on various special occasions and holidays.I would definitely recommend anyone to visit the museum, as it brings perspective to why Hong Kong is shaped the way it is presently.Note: Wednesdays is free! Otherwise, the admission fee is not too pricey.

Impressive and Well Planned Museum. The museum takes you through the history of Hong Kong from the beginning to the present. The exhibits are well done and interesting. The museum is spotless and well laid out. We spent two hours there and we could have spent even more time, but the museum was closing.
A lesson on Hong Kong. A good place to have a good understanding of Hong Kong's past and also some Hong Kong specific cultures. Also some great background to take pictures to remember Hong Kong!

A comprehensive insight into Hong Kong's history and culture.. There are many displays and rooms here. You will need to spend at least a few hours. So much to see from early origins in the Dinosaur era, war time occupation, local customs etc etc etc...

Quick history lesson in a few hours. I was only in Hong Kong for a few days and could not go visit as many places as I would like to. After spending four hours in Hong Kong Museum of History, I was able to see miniatures of quite a few places I wanted to visit and learned about their history. Had a great time!

A very enjoyable walk with the history of HK. It is always good to visit a museum of history when you traveled to a place. You will get a chance to know the past of the place and how it shaped the present.. This is what this Hong Kong Museum of History presents to me. A very detailed and interesting presentation of the past history of Hong Kong, Now I know how a small fishing village can change into a cosmopolitan city.

History repeating. Hong Kong weather is famously unpredictable. If you do draw the curtains back to a rainy, foggy day, a great way to pass a few hours is to visit the Hong Kong Museum of History.There are eight permanent exhibits: on the lower floor, you’ll tour through the natural environment, learn about prehistoric Hong Kong, be introduced to the dynasties and their impact on South China, before arriving at my favourite exhibit dedicated to folk culture. On display are Chinese Opera scenes, a lion dance, paper effigies.. Visit my blog to see the full review, photos, and other Hong Kong attractions to help with your trip planning http://feastplaylove.me/2014/04/26/things-to-do-in-hong-kong/

Superb!. We went to this museum thinking we'd spend about an hour there but we got lost for 3 hours!! It is a fantastic display of Hong Kong's history right back to the creation of the island through humans development up to present day!! The information keeps you interested and wanting more so go with a few hours to spend! Very much worth the HK$10 you pay to get in!

Unbelieveable!. You'd think that a small city like Hong Kong would not have much to offer. You'd be nicely rewarded if you talk with the guides manning different exhibits. One even opened up the display counter to show me the marriage documents. Well, there were no pre-nup agreements to read about....

good to see old items. The Hong Kong Museum of History is a museum which preserves Hong Kong's historical and cultural heritage. It is located next to the Hong Kong Science Museum, in Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon, Hong Kong,

HK Museum of History. Many interesting exhibitions esp those about local tradition and Chinese life It cenral in location with easy traffic access from Kowloon. It is also near other museums such as the Science and Art Museum and the Space Museum which are worth visiting

Musuem with interesting exhibits. This is a museum of history but it will not bore you with history text. Instead, the history is intriodduced through a very wide range of exhbits, ranging from old housewares to a re-built room/buidling which resembled the past. It is like walking into the old history of Hong Kong and witnessing the past. There are also very good audio-visual effects. It is highly recmmended for those who want to know more about Hong Kong history.

World class and very interesting. If you have any interest at all about the history of Hong Kong, I highly recommend this museum. Ranging from pre-historic times through the early history of Chinese clans, then the opening of trade and the British influence, right through to handover. You could easily spend a whole day if you want to see the whole thing. Personally we had a few hours, and skipped quite a bit to get to the more recent history of the past 200 years, which was of more interest to us. Entry is incredibly cheap, just like most of the museums and galleries in HK. We both hired English audio guides as well, although the exhibits were so well presented with an abundance of English explanations that we didn't use the audio guides much at all. This really is a high quality museum, with some impressive and inventive displays. Walk through a life-sized century old village to peek into the tea shop, post office, general store ... walk onto the life-sized Chinese fishing boat and hear about the life of the fisher people, and see three-story towers of buns and carvings of gods and emperors used for local festivals. Highly recommended to anyone who's curiosity has been aroused.

Get some perspective before sightseeing!. The museum is fantastic! It doesn't look like much at first as the renovations on the top level haven't been finished, but as you head to the exhibits downstairs everything looks great. Everything is well labeled and there is a huge variety of media (photos, life size models, real media clips, films, etc.) that walks you through all of Hong Kong's history... starting from its geological formation until now. There are a few interactive exhibits as well. It was very informative and a good way to start a trip to Hong Kong by getting a good overview of its past. AND there is free entry on wednesdays (great AC too if you are visiting in the summer and can't stand anymore heat). Depending on how fast you want to go through the exhibits I recommend around 2 hours (less if you want to skip parts, more if you want to be really thorough).

Excellent attraction. I am a great fan of Hong Kong history. The museum, which boasts a very impressive replica of early colonial era street of Hong Kong, allow one to experience the romance of Old Hong Kong, a unique mixture of Western and Chinese culture. Another interesting exhibition shows the various indigenous groups who lived in Hong Kong in its early years and their own unique culture and customs, many of which still survives today. I am also impressed by the number of 80's and early 90's household items and toys they have on display, which brings me down memory lane. A must go for an in depth understanding of the Hong Kong culture.
nice run down. Hong Kong has a very interesting history. Through the years during war, the hand over etc. Work the very cheap admission.

Excellent Account of Hong Kong. The museum is spread over 3 floors and showcases almost every aspect of Hong Kong from prehistoric times to the 1997 Handover. It was a very intriguing and educational visit which could easily take 3 to 4 hours if you were to meticulously read and visit all the different sections. Best of all, it's free entry to all on Wednesdays!

Interesting exhibits. The history museum was very good. They had great films on the opium war and a 1938 travelogue for Hong Kong. We have been to Hong Kong before and read novels and histories but we still learned quite a bit at the museum.

Great museum, lots to see!. We didn't realize how big this museum was! It took about 3 hours to see everything. You get to really see the entire history of Hong Kong and it's very inexpensive to do. My favorite part was seeing the various costumes and clothing. It's located right on the waterfront so it's easy to get to.

Fascinating glimpse of old Hong Kong. Well worth a visit to get a view of old Hong Kong. I loved all the examples of handcrafts and folk art. Amazing what people could do with so little to create such beautiful embroidery, clothing, drums, housewares, etc. Scenes of life tell the story of how people lived here in villages and eked out their livelihood from the land and sea. Fascinating. Highly recommend a visit.
Place to visit. This museum was fantastic. We spent over 4 hours learning the history of Hong Kong. Make it a point to visit this place on your trip to Hong Kong.
Vast. So much to see and a lot of well presented, interesting and detailed information. Great to go later in your trip to help put into context the things you have been seeing around the city.

Great Museum. Very informative and provides a great amount of detail and understanding of Hong Kong's history in multiple different aspects, from its natural history (rock formations) to ancient history (Chinese dynasties) to modern history (cessation to British rule, Japanese occupation, 1997 etc.), and culture. The museum is very organised and the various exhibits are numbered in a chronological order so it is very easy to follow the development of Hong Kong. There are plenty of things to read and look at and it took me about 3+ hours to finish the whole museum, longer than I expected. By the way, note that the museum is closed on Tuesdays and has free entry on Wednesdays.
Excelent for a Rainy Day. Superbly presented, very informative, much to see and extremely good value for money.Go even if it is not raining.

great details of days gone by. It is a bit difficult to find. Wish they have shown more directions on how to get there. I learned a lot about the history of Hong Kong. They were bi-lingual which made it easier for non-Chinese to understand more about the history of Hong Kong. Well done.

fascinating museum, one of the best I've visited!. It is a well spaced out, very informative, big and interesting museum. If you want to take an hour out to get some food you can get a stamp from reception and return later in the day. It is especially great for people who speak English as a first language as there are plenty of detailed explanations written in English. There are sections such as Hong Kong folk culture, the opium wars, the cession of Hong Kong, the Japanese Occupation during world war two and a lot of information on the return of Hong Kong back to China in 1997 from Great Britain. Fascinating museum with fantastic exhibitions and a must see for anybody visiting Hong Kong but especially for UK citizens as it is very relevant to their history!

Very well done museum. This is a relatively new museum that sets out, in different sections, the history of Hong Kong, with separate areas for pre-history, the cultures of the different people who settled there, the impact of the West, the Japanese/WW2 period, etc. The descriptions in English of the different exhibits are quite good; one can also rent an audio guide, but it is really not necessary. There are also a lot of videos, which run continuously in different languages, including English; when the audio portion is not in English there are English subtitles.The only slight negative is that the museum is limited to the history of Hong Kong, so one learns about the history of the Chinese dynasties only as they had an impact on Hong Kong.
A lovely place to visit. I am an archaeologist and found the hong Kong Museum of History authentic, informative and interesting. Well worth a visit, as is the bookshop!

A passage through time. Impressive. Galleries are well curated. The permanent gallery is appropriately named the Hong Kong Story. Galleries were presented in chronological order - pre-historic through the Chinese dynasties to British colonization to return to China.

Outstanding, More then a typical Museum. Well worth the visit. Presentations and exhibits are top class. Spacious and very well presented in an easy to follow format. Museum is centrally located. One may not usually want to spend extensive time in a museum on vacation, but this one will capture your visit and wish you had allotted more time if you are on a tight schedule. But eve nif you only have a hour or two well worth it.

Far better than expected!. At $10HK this museum is an absolute bargain. The museum was larger and more engaging than we expected. The children enjoyed the many large-scale exhibits, like the tram they could climb on. The section on the opium wars was perhaps the most interesting in the museum, and the movie about the subject gave us a new perspective on the history of HK.

Provided knowledge on various aspect of Hong Kong history . A very comprehensive museum covering Hong Kong history right from the dynasty days. The various key time era was segregated with very good information, short clips that provide valuable information.Worth a go if you are keen to understand the country's history.
Puts it all in perspective. Really enjoyed this museum- spent a couple of hours plus and felt it was very worthwhile. Had done lots of reading about HK but this put all the pieces together.

Much more than history!. This is a great museum to visit with children as there are huge life-size temples, traditional boats, artifacts and colorful effigies of Chinese gods. There are also several interesting films on the geological origins of the island of Hong Kong and on the development of the modern-day city, going back to prehistoric inhabitants of the island. To see everything properly, you would need several hours.
Very Good. If you like museum and learn about Hong Kong, this is your place. The museum has headohones where you can here about history and meaning of what is inside there.

Good to see the history of the city. From the early days of HK to present it was interesting to see the growth of HK and the way it was settled and developed by the British to present day HK. The hustle and bustle has never changed just more cars and transport. HK history museum was an eye opener as there s a lot of stuff about HK that I didn't know. The museum is definitely worth a visit. It takes about 3 hrs to see it all its pretty big and for HK$10 its worth the look. The science museum is right next door if you aren't museum'd out after the first one. Recommended.

Well Worth A Visit. I must be honest and say we aren't normally museum people but, due to wanting to know more about HK (and it being rainy!!), we decided to visit this museum.We are very glad we did too as it was a very interesting experience that gave great insight. It covers from present day right back to prehistoric times; we'd only anticipated spending and hour or so here but we're actually there for half a day. Not sure re the entry cost as we went on a Wednesday when it's free!! (We aren't cheap, just didn't know this!).The post war sections were of most interest but we really enjoyed the whole thing. Worth a visit for sure.

Great display of Hong Kong History. A good way to promote and preserve the history and cultural heritage of Hong Kong. The Hong Kong Story is a good showcase of the history and development of Hong Kong. The exhibits are very life like and well done. The exhibition starts from the Devonian period 400 million years ago and concludes with the return of sovereignty of the territory to China in 1997. Well set out over several floors and we visited on a Wednesday and the entry was free.

One of the best museums I've been too. Wow - what a great experience! HK Museum of History has to be one of the most fascinating museums I've ever visited. The exhibitions were amazing and interactive. There was so much detail and history - I spent half a day in there! It's definitely worth paying for any special exhibits that are on too, they do a great job at curating and maintaining the exhibits.

Fantastic overview of Hong Kong, past and present. This is a great museum. It covers everything from pre-history to re-unification with colonial rule and 20th century development thrown in. The exhibits are well curated and the atmosphere is very easy-going. Definitely worth the very good value entry price.
Great for little people. My daughters spend the whole morning in there. Very hand on. Made with bright colour. Had lots of puzzle game to sort, some of them quite difficult even for grownups
Lots to see. It took us 3 hours to go around and we still did not see everything-very interesting and well laid out

Worth a visit. From geological beginnings (interesting in itself!) through early settlements, and long history right up to the reunification with mainland China, this museum does a wonderful job of bringing Hong Kong's past alive. The hearty may be able to take in all the exhibits in one day, but a better plan is to pick the areas of history which most interest you. The biggest impact for the modern visitor may be learning about the last couple hundred years. A poignant story.

Perfect place to start a visit. Here is not just history, but the flavor and character of Hong Kong. Start your visit here and you will know a lot more about what you are seeing later.The museum is laid out chronologically, beginning with geology and ending yesterday. The exhibits are easy to follow (good for kids 8 and older) and comprehensive.Take the Metro to Tsim Sha Tsui and follow the signs about 5 blocks to a pedestrian overpass. The History museum adjoins the Science museum. A variety of non-rated eateries surround the complex and you can have in-out privileges. Allow 2 hours plus.

Answers all your questions about HK. We spent 3 hours here and usually are through a museum in a much shorter time - loved all the photos and displays and little video clips. I wished that I had skipped over some of the pre-historic stuff to have more energy for the later sections in the museum.
Good. Interesting slice of the history of Hong Kong. They have spent a lot of money here and you can see it in the displays.

a good wet day excursion. The museum was well laid out and told a very good story of Hong Kong from its earliest beginnings to the present day. The walk though theme enhanced the story and the exhibits were well presented.

Much larger than expected. A lot of the exhibits were life size to help you understand what it would've been like. Lots of large colourful and engaging exhibits - even children would find it interesting!

Truly fascinating trip across time. Located centrally in Tsim Sha Tsui, this museum covering the history of one of the world's great cities is an outstanding cultural experience that will be enjoyed by all, and at a minor admission cost. Somewhat overcompensating by starting at (virtually) the dawn of man, the exhibition comes into its own when it begins to cover the religious culture that has helped shape the city before detailing the incredible upheaval caused by the Opium Wars (truly food for thought on what lengths governments will do for power), the invasion of Japan and the post-war boom that made Hong Kong the city it is today. Featuring a great many unearthed treasures from the distant past, the visitor also walks through life-size recreations of various periods of history exhibiting and explaining festivals, maritime events, pre-war streetscapes & shopfronts, the Japanese invasion (including propaganda extolling the virtues of the occupation to locals!) and the dauntingly small spaces that residents were housed in during the 1950s. Short films in local languages (subtitled in English), as well as English language versions, screen on constant rotation further outlining the city's history and evolution. Of great interest is the final section featuring the post-war cultural boom that covers the rise and rise of local cinema, consumerism and manufacturing. The handover of Hong Kong from England to China is covered in detail, however it did feel like this final section had been drafted with the mainland's sensitivities and agenda in-mind.Only disappointment was the lack of a shop. It must be said that the city's souvenir trade has been overtaken by mobile phone covers and cheap sunglasses. What I would have given for a take-home recreation of some of the brilliant pieces displayed from the 50s, 60s or 70s! In fact, we headed straight to HMV music afterwards to find some of the great local pop music playing in the later part of the exhibit. It plays as I write this very review: a great keep-sake after discovering a new found respect for the city in this museum.

The exhibition of statues by Ming was excellent inside and outside if the museum. 20dollars to visit this museum inside is equivalent to £1.50 approximately. Fantastic exhibitions. We actually went around the statues outside again and realised we had walked past some thinking they were real people.
Museum of history. top quality museum with excellent and lucid exhibitions. No visible bias in how the story is presented. Many interesting personal details. Nice café.
Great Museum. Nice Museum and of course it's free on any Wednesday for visitors to Hong Kong, although you will have to pay if there are any special exhibitions going on.

1st rate cultural experience. This was a well-planned and well-executed museum. The facilities are beautiful and the exhibits are top-notch and authentic. Everything is labeled in both Chinese and English. The English translations are impeccable with none of the grammatical errors and typos commonly seen in Asian museum. My one criticism of the museum is it's failure to openly discuss the extreme apprehension many HK residents felt over the 1997 handover to China. It glosses over the Tiananmen protests of June 4 and its subsequent effect on the people of HK as they wondered if they would suffer similar political repression with the approach of 1997.Bottom line, if you have even a remote desire to know a little of HK's colorful history, this is an absolute must-see.

A complete and comprehensible Hong Kong story. We did very much enjoy a couple of hours at this well-kept museum containing a mix of traditional exhibitions, built up environments, and multimedia productions.

Must see. Their permanent exhibition on the history of Hong Kong is magnificently designed - interactive, informative, colourful with attentive staff at every corner! Great attraction to visit prior to beginning your exploration of Hong Kong as it provides the relevant cultural background on how the city has developed.
good experience. It was really a great experience in those places we visited in Hong Kong. The people were all busy doing their stuffs. Riding in the MTR was a great experience also.

The best way to experience the Hong Kong through time. $10 for the main museum and $10 for the exhibition on Old Photo of Hong Kong, 3 hours to truly understand Hong Kong, it's past and present.The main hall walks you through the era from the war to handover in 1997, from the fishing and farming era to industrial evolution on toy, watch, fabric, FMCG...It also include the people, culture and local festivals of Hong Kong through overwhelming illustration and actual size set up.Seriously, for $10? Yes, it's so worth it.

Great museum with cheap admission. Usually one wouldn't expect much from a museum that charges only $2-3 USD (depending on whether or not you pay for the special exhibit), but this museum is extremely well-thought out and offers an entertaining but comprehensive history of Hong Kong. I'm not particularly a history buff but I still found the museum incredibly interesting. They use an immersive form of presentation where the rooms for each of Hong Kong's era are suitably decorated in the form of that time period, all the way from prehistoric to the Opium Wars and later. I walked away with an increased appreciation of HK's heritage and history. Signs and placards are available in English.It is a shame that so many families with children opted to wait 2-3 hrs on the long lines for the natural history museum right next door while overlooking this one. Give it a try - for such a low admission fee it's hard to go wrong.
Wednesday's are free. we stumbled on free entry wednesday's by accident. We walked between the science/astronomy and history museum. Pays to have good walking shoes on
Must see. Such a wonderful insight into the history of Hong Kong. It really gave us an insight into their culture.
Great with Kids. We went here on a rainy day and was pleasantly surprised. It has great interactive displays and the kids loved it!

Decent museum and pretty cheap. This place is pretty cool to check out and really cheap, I want to say it was about $2-3 USD, so it was totally worth the cost. Most of the exhibits and kept up very well, but compared to other large museums I've been to it's pretty average. It's a cool museum, but many museusm are cool so relative to other museums it's average. Still worth checking out though.
Excellent museum. All the presentations are really well thought out. Exhibits are very well planned and made. If you want to understand how Hong Kong became Hong Kong, you got to visit this museum.

Informative and good value at only HKD10. We enjoyed our visit to this museum in April 2014. There was a photo exhibition on at the time with historical photos of HK. The permanent exhibitions were informative and interesting. I especially liked the old "ding ding" (tram). Good value at only HKD10 per adult.
Awesome place wish I could go again tomorrow. This place is so easy to find so interesting and easy to understand all aspects of all the different displays also they show a great short film

Fantastic. Free on wednesays, but usually the entry is only $10HK. You can easily lose a few hours in here. A great place to spend a rainy day. Colorful, vibrant displays and a good mix of multi media exhibits. staff are very friendly and helpful.

Fascinating museum, well presented. This museum gives an excellent overview of Hong Kong, through a fascinating combination of exhibits, videos/documentaries and reconstructions. Other reviewers have described it well.We were intrigued to notice the fairly benign treatment of the British colonisation and the fears for democracy following the communist takeover (although no holds barred for the Japanese).Good tip - free on WednesdaysThe exhibit descriptions are very good. We took the audio guides, but did not feel they helped a great deal.No café.

Great Historical Photo Exhibition. We loved the exhibition of historical photos of Hong Kong currently open (april 2014). It shows marvellous old photos of Hong Kong Island and Kowloon during early settlement from about the 1820s with shots of street life, colonial events and of course the harbour. Well worth a visit

Interesting insight into the history of the city. Great videos to introduce exhibits. Lots to see!. Time just flew as there was so much to see. The curators have done an excellent job. We visited on a Wednesday when there's no entry fee, as did lots of school children! It was busy, but it's a large museum, so it was fairly easy to avoid the crowds. The permanent galleries describe the history of the city and its rise from fishing village to major city. Several excellent videos summarise the various exhibits - bringing them to life. Thanks to one of them, I now know much more about the Opium Wars than I did previously. I think there's something for everyone in this museum, it's well set out, lots to do and quite diverse in interest. It's next door to the Science Museum, so you could easily visit both if you wanted to!

Recommended. Interesting and informative. You can spend 2-3 hours here to see and learn about the history and culture of Hong Kong. There are many collections/exhibits.Just follow the sign "Suggested Route", so you wouldn't be confused to choose which part you should see in the museum.

A must. A pitty that we visited it 1h30 before closing time. We did not see the time passing. If it's raining outside a must. The museum is not dead at all. It's well decorated, and you learn a lot about the culture and history of Hong Kong.
Much to see. Great. Lost the sense of time. Much to see. very interesting and very intereactive exhibits. easy layout to follow
Great place !. Every thing so nice. I went here and know more about culture, traditional about Hk. I took alots photos here
great place for the family. We had a great time there, we chose it because of the rain and had not much else on but even if it is fine outside it is a good option for about 3-4 hrs

Informative and interesting exhibits.. Being a big fan of museums, these are always high on my to-do list when traveling. And the hong kong museum of history didn't dissapoint. Lots of interesting and informative exhibits, making for a pleasant 2-3 hours to see everything.
Very interesting. This museum is well worth a visit. It's informative, interesting and well set out - I stayed far longer than I thought I would do!

Museum Hong Kong. Visited the museum on a rainy holiday day. The museum is so well thought out, presented and has extensive and interesting exhibits. There are numerous movies you can watch and it gives and excellent and easy to follow history of Hong Kong from geological creation to the treaty with the Commonwealth. We had a 6 year old child with us and she was not bored. On the day we attended it was free access but I think usually there is a nominal fee. Recommend for anyone.
must go. What a great way to spend a few hours and learn a bit about HONG KONG. There was a great photo exhibition that I got to see. REally really great and interesting!!!!!
Lots to see. Lucky enough to go when the "old photographs of Hong Kong" exhibition was on. Stayed for several hours for that and the Hong Kong story.With a Museum Pass it was good VFM

A must see in HK - great story and value. This museum was an excellent story of Hong Kong to present day. My girlfriend and I spent hours wandering through the halls, enjoying all of the stories and displays on offer. It was great to see the transition of modern HK and British/Chinese periods and transition.
Wonderful Exhibits. For only HKD$10 there's definitely a lot to see and experience the Hong Kong culture. Close proximity to the science museum also.
An intimate museum. Nice short walk through Hong Kong's past and a pleasant break from the going-on outside on the busy streets. .

Lots to see. Very expansive, lots to see, and affordable. I suggest buying the weekly museum pass if you plan to visit more than one museum. Just be sure to research ahead, it is closed one day per week.

great museum. I made the mistake of going there 2 hours before closing :(. There is too much to see in this museum. The flow and exhibitions take you from the beginning of the big bang theory to present hk. I am a native hk citizen then immigranted to the states. This museum is a great place to reconnect with my root.
What a place to visit. Liked all the large informative exhibits they were very interesting and held our attention for more than 4 hours. So much history regarding Hong Kong and it's people.

Calling This a Museum Does Not Do It Justice. Put this on your must do list if you are at all interested in the story behind modern Hong Kong. Plan on 2-3 hours to wander through the various areas that each bring the history alive through excellent full-size, walk through recreations. You will visit homes, temples, shops and other aspects of daily life as it developed over time. There are also several videos that help tell the story and offer a welcome chance to sit for a few minutes. This museum is truly world-class and should not be missed!

Must See Attraction. I rate this as one of a half dozen or so must see attractions in Hong Kong. The admission price of 10HGK (half or seniors) is unbelievable. You must allow 3-4 hours to see everything. We took a free 90 mniute docent led tour in English one Sunday morning. We were happy to speed through some of the early sections, which dealt with the early geology and pre-history. We especially enjoyed the folk customs, recreation of a street in Old Hong Kong, and later history of the place. There are several short films and other things to watch and listen to. Don't be in a rush as the place is laid out superbly and it's really easy to view most of the exhibits. I'd advise doing this early on your trip but in any event, this is MUST see.

Double Joy & Knowledge. I do not know about you, but my cousin was and is not interested in history. He went along with me because the science museum happened to be closed on Tuesday. Well, it is a statement by itself when I say that he spent good four hours in the museum. It was really a joy to see him enjoying the show.There were two sections; one taking you through the history of Hong Kong and the second was about modern Hong Kong. The joy was doubled as I stated above with my cousin and the shows. The knowledge gained about Hong Kong in every aspect was more than double my expectation.This is a great place to spend half a day with family or friends.

Worthwhile Visit. My wife and I spent a very interesting couple of hours in here. The history of Hong Kong is presented in seven different aspects from pre history until the Chinese take over in 1997. The day we went the museum was not at all crowded and the historical tableaux and items were displayed in a very understandable way. Well worth a visit (particularly on Wednesday when it is free to get in)

A well presented history. For the Brit abroad it's good to see our colonial history presented from a local's perspective. This exhibition-style museum presented it well. From pre-history through early inhabitation through to the opium wars and the growth of the colony to become the flourishing city state it is today, As a one-stop education to the place it's worth a visit.
Travelling back in Time. The Hong Kong exhibit was very insightful and informative. I would reserve at least a day to tour this exhibit thoroughly. I would definitely return to this Museum.

Great for few hours.. We had few hours to kill, and this was opposite our hotel. For a £1 entrance fee thus was just a great place to visit. To see the history of Hong Kong and the setting inside was something special. Don't be put if just cus it's a museum.

great intro to Hong Kong. The museum was really well done with great exhibits and videos. I especially enjoyed the exhibits on the folk life of the early groups of Chinese and the celebrations of various festivals. We thought we'd spend an hour or two but found ourselves still there after three hours watching the videos on the the Opium War and the Japanese Occupation. (YOu might skip the earlier parts on the prehistoric times unless that is of special interest.)
