One of the best museums. This museum and its exhibitions are extremely well executed and interesting for all ages. I'm not even a huge history fan but still found this place very interesting :) Make sure to have at least 3 hours if you're planning on seeing most of it without rushing through!

Gets more interesting as progresses. I can get through the Louvre in under 3 hours, so am not the best person to comment on museums. Having said that, the first part of this museum is early history and probably of interest to many. As it becomes more current, the relationship with the Japanese, with China and many of the local customs and culture are well-explained. English tours are available for free at certain times, and are well worth it. Our tour group was us and the guide, so it was 100% customized for our interests.

Great photo exhibition of old Hong Kong. A great place to while away a few hours while in Kowloon. The exhibition of old photos was fascinating; the rest of the collection and exhibits were less so but worth a quick run through. Nice modern facility on Chatham Rd.

Best museum in Hong Kong. We spent a half a day here, whether you are a museum buff or just want to look beyond the shopping and eating in Hong Kong, this is the place to go. Wednesdays are free. Well-laid out with enough information to give it depth but not so much to be overwhelming. Must see while in HK. Good place to go also in hot or rainy weather, great for first-time visitors as well as those who have been to the city. You will probably learn something you didn't know before. Topics are presented in movies and displays that bring history to life. Displays include geology, the natural environment, animals and birds, history of the opium war and WWII, local culture and people, festivals, pottery.

great photo exhibition!. I saw a great photo exhibition, with photos from 1850s onwards, showing the development of Hong Kong, the first settlements, etc... Very instructive and very beautiful photos too.

Very Interesting. I have worked in museums for several years and visited many across the world (3 continents worth). This one was very unique and very well done. I'd recommend it and I'd also say it is worth the extra fee to see the special exhibitions

Excellent and worth a visit. The museum is excellent and well presented. Not quite all of the displays had English descriptions but not really needed. The displays cover the background of the HK area from prehistory to the modern day including the recent history of the boat people as well as the earliest settlers. A must for all visiting for the first time. It is conveniently situated in Kowloon within walking distance to the Star Ferry terminal as well as other museum and are very cheap.When we visited it, it was the day that it is free entry but here may be a small charge
Boring, tired exhibits. I was quite looking forward to this museum, in my head I expected something else. I found the exhibits to be tired, boring and couldn't wait to get outside.

Good overall information on the history of Hong Kong. This museum is a gem, I think all new visitors to Hong Kong should visit and learn the history of this great city. We did buy a ticket to the special exhibit also and we actually should of just focused on the 4 stories permanent exhibit about the history of Hong Kong since we ended up rushed and breezed through some of the exhibits to see it all before closing time.

Excellent museum to know Hong Kong. This is an excellent museum to know Hong Kong, especially how it evolved from a small fishing village to a world class city.The current exhibit of old pictures taken during late 19 century to early 20th century is very interesting.Come on Wed to enjoy free admission.

Great if you are keen on the history of cities. The museum is well laid out and a great way to learn about HK for 2-3 hours. Really liked the post WWII history onwards, public housing, manufacturing and social unrest areas.

Free entrance fee. I was here few months ago, I was able to see different artifacts from this museum. Every Wednesday there is no entrance. Everywhere I go I make sure to visit museums and this musuems is one of a kind :-)

Very interesting..... Decided to be a tourist in my home town, and visited the Museum of History this past weekend, mostly because of a temporary exhibition of photos depicting Hong Kong since the mid 1800s. It costs HK$10 to visit the permanent exhibition (Story of Hong Kong), and HK$20 for both the permanent exhibition and the temporary exhibition.The temporary exhibition included a lot of exhibits depicting life in the early colonial days of Hong Kong (up to WWII), what the architecture was back then, how people dressed, what they ate, businesses that were in Hong Kong at the time. It is interesting (and surreal) to see what the streets that I go past every day now looked like back then. You can imagine many corners of Hong Kong then would be similar to places like... Singapore, Kolkata, Mumbai, or even, Vancouver.There are a number of sections in the permanent exhibition, including prehistoric, pre-colonial rule, colonial rule, and post WWII. A bit amazed that we even have archeological finds in the city (a number of pottery items on display from a number of different Chinese dynasties, all discovered in Hong Kong). There is a section depicting the different types of Chinese population that have settled in Hong Kong throughout the years and how we evolved from a fishing village to become a metropolis. And then there are some exhibits that would remind me of stories as told by my grandparents and my parents on what life was like in Hong Kong when they grew up.

Great place to get a feel for the history of Hong Kong. I wandered across this when I was having one of my sightseeing days around Kowloon.Lots to see and totally unhurried, even hordes of school kids visiting was tolerable - I would probably go more than once because there was a lot to see and do.

How to do it right.... This museum has two main exhibits, and we spent almost 3 hours on both. One was photos of the history of HK,with amazing old views of the packed city we were learning; the other was a long trip through the whole history of the small, intense corner of the world. Both were beautifully done and explained. They did a terrific job that shouldn't be missed (we ran out of time before seeing the Natural History next door, sadly).

Informative and beautifully displayed. We enjoyed special exhibition of old photos of Hong Kong and its people. What a contrast with the present day city. The museum section on folk culture is well worth a visit as it the Opium war section

Very Good. ....but be prepared to spend a large part of the day in there - plenty to see.The layout is rather peculiar at times but there was a huge variety of things to see. Very cheap entry fee also
wow what a place. amazing museum have been to Hong Kong so many times and finally got to see the museum wow what an amazing place so many things learned about HK

Huge exhibit about Hong Kong history. Worth seeing if only for this exhibition giving all the history of HK from rock formation, native peoples, cultural and social life etc. Free on Weds otherwise costs very reasonable. I rented the audio guide for $10 so cheap.

Quite impressive. The museum takes you thru the formation of Hong Kong (geologically) and then the various stages of the country's development. Walking thru the geological section it all seemed a little 'false' and not too promising. But then moved thru to the section about the peoples and their ways of life - and there were full size fishing boats and example temples etc etc. Suddenly it all became incredibly impressive.Each section/theme has a small theatre with short films continually running which provides a great intro and then wonderful exhibits i.e. a banking hall from the 1900s, shops from the same period, a tram etc etc.. I can only say again how impressive it was. The exhibits also interested the kids.Visited on a Wednesday = free. There was an extra exhibition of old photos of Hong Kong (for a small fee) but did not do. Ran out of time as museum was closing.

A fascinating look at the History of Hong Kong. There are many museums around Hong Kong and this one is really not to be missed, I though a couple of hours would suffice but exited after about 4 hours. The displays take you from pre-history Hong Kong through the colonial days and the Japanese occupation finally to the hand over in 1997.
Great experience. Very interesting exibition! Must see the visual materials in museum, especially in the begining. Good space organization

Whatever the weather visit the Museum of History. The weather was rainy and cold so visited the Museum of History. Discovered you should visit even if the weather is fine. A great morning out. Huge tableaus covering all aspects of Hong Kong from Pre Historic through to the present day.

Well worth visiting. Large airy modern museum. Plenty of large scale models and information in English. Comprehensive coverage of Hong Kong history. Temporary exhibition of vintage photographs was excellent and gave a different insight into Hong Kongs' development. Spent several hours there but could easily have spent longer.

fainting history of hong kong. A must visit if you have never been there before. Highly recommended for the tourist who is there for the first time. It is verbwell to naviget. The information is factual and not so polo
Iticlly biased one way or anther. It help to enrich your trip to this anmazingn city and understand its people and their soul.

Great for a couple of hours. Saw the current exhibition, photos of old hong kong. It was really interesting to see in pictures just how much the place has changed.
The Hong kong story is also worth spending time at.
Interesting history. Excellent overview over Hong Kong history, including Opium War and Japanese invasion and the new beginning of Hong Kong
Good history review. We enjoyed the displays. Excellent history of the city and region. On going image display worth seeing. Price for seniors is extremely low

Really interesting esp if you live in HK / have any sort of roots in HK. Learn about opium wars, life under the Japanese when they occupied HK in WWII, a bit of cultural information etc. Can spend a good 3-4 hours here. Nearest MTR is TST ior Jordan.

A must to understand the Hong Kong's history. The Hong Kong Story that is on display at the Museum of History is very well presented and all-encompassing for every aspect of the broad HK area: its geography, history, traditions, the ethnic composition of the islands, the political developments, the economic growth, the social challenges. This exhibition is a must for whoever wishes to learn more about this fascinating land.(Free on Wednesdays)
Old photographs exhibition. Happened to get lucky and saw an exhibition of 150 years of photographs of HK: totally mesmerizing and enchanting. Very well displayed and managed.

Outstanding. This is a must see. The history of Hong Kong is brilliantly, clearly and informatively set out with multiple video rooms and outstanding models whether bun towers or a junk. A very full half day that could last longer
Nice. Excellent museum. Spent several hours in it. Really gives one a good glimpse of the history of Hong Kong.

come here if you dont mind a bit of history. I found this museum tiring and me feet were hurting so much but the museum was set out very well and went from the begining on HK to the present. Its very interesting to read up about it. and if you are sick of reading, which you are bound to be there are movie theatres summerising basically each exhibit. we stayed about 3 hours and we were exhausted by the time we left. the museum isnt too expensive and is free on wednesday!

Huge Museum. Amazing show of the history and evolution of Southern China. About $6 USD for two to tour special exhibit and entire museum. Explains culture, society, major events, ethnic groups, traditions, etc.. Go early in your visit and it will open your eyes as you explore the city.

A must-see museum. I'm impressed with the great level of detail they have put into the museum. The visual and props bring you back in time and you get to experience history interactively. For the most part, the museum focuses on the colonial era, showcasing how Hong Kong evolves from two clashing cultures.

More interesting and fun than you might think. I really enjoyed this museum. It had lots of scenes in full size, and was interactive. Great for kids, as well as the young at heart. You could easily spend a few hours here and learn much about the history of Hong Kong.

History museum. The museum is free to visit on a Wednesday, very informative lots of good displays and several short films to watch to take you through the ages, a section on fashion through the ages, culture, also interactive exhibits, well worth spending a couple of hours and learn about the country your visiting

Time well spent. An excellent museum covering the extensive and colourful history of one of Asia's most fascinating cities. Exhibits range from HK's ancient history, its colonial period as part of the British empire as well as its modern history. I would recommend this attraction as one of the first places to visit in HK, to give you a better understanding of the history and culture this amazing city has to offer.

Learn something. Go there and learn something about Hong Kong history. We have wasted too much time on the first 2 floors, they are really interesting but not as much as the rest of the museum. It talks about the HK history much more. So if you have just lijmited amount of time, skip it and go directly to 3rd/4th floor/parts of the museum. It all started with Opium War ....
Fun little trip. Good to learn about some of the history of Hong Kong. There are also interactive exhibits (Chinese Opera) which are fun.

Don't Rush Through. The permanent exhibition, i.e. The Hong Kong Story consists of 8 galleries which would certainly be interesting with the help of audio guide. My personal favourite is Gallery 4 which is the Folk Culture in Hong Kong. This gallery particularly highlights the ethnic costumes, the people and their way of living. Oh yes, the payment of audio guide can be made at the point of purchasing the entrance ticket.

Brilliant education. This place is a must for any tourist who wants to get a bit of background of how Hong Kong got to where it is now. It really is advised as one of the first things to do on your visit HK, as it will give you a much better understanding of the place, but it also makes you appreciate things more when you are walking around afterwards.Very well set out and there are so many interesting things to see, read and take in.You will find yourself immersed in such a great history you will be glad you spent a couple of hours around this place.

Slightly Disappointing Museum. I think I was expecting more of a commercial history with what has happened after Hong Kong was first settled by English traders and how the space changed. I wanted to see about the war when Japan took over and then its fantastic transformation since the 1950s. I got more about the pre historic period and rice growing and fishing than I expected.The movies were OK.

Great starting point. This museum was excellent to visit. There is a free guide to take you around and give you some real inside information on Hong Kong and it's past which I would recommend doing. It would be great to do this early in your visit to give you some information to get you started.

Essencial for Visitors. What a lovely museum for any visitors to see the history of Hong Kong from its beginning to the present day. The museum offers a lot of memories for the elderly as they see some of the toys and places that disappear as Hong Kong redevelop itself. Overall its a must for visitors as well as the locals to develop an excellent knowledge of Hong Kong!!!!!

A must do. Plan to spend a few hours and take your time. Lots of little 'movie clips' in the different areas going into detail about each exhibit.Not 100% sure about the audio headset - its not expensive so take it just in case but I wouldn't do the thing in sequence as it would take too long.
Spend about 3 hour here. They take you from prehistoric times in sections to the present day. Well worth the time and nice and cool on a hot day.

Excellent information and presentation. The museum takes you from the prehistoric to present day Hong Kong. You walk through life size recreations of early houses, farming and tombs up to dockside HK a hundred years ago, HK under Japanise invasion in WWII, influx of refugees from mainland China to the unification time. Loved the display of 1950s industry where most of our toys had "Made in HK" on them. There was a school group there and the kids were having a great time playing in the HK tram.

Not enough time.. As soon as we arrived we realised we wouldn't have enough time to see it all so decided to concentrate on one gallery. We chose the section on Folk History which had stories of the people of many different cultures. Even then we were nearly running late to get to the airport.This is a huge museum which would require several hours to see everything. I hope it's all as good as the one section we saw.

Great place to spend a half day walking around. My teenage son and I decided to visit the museum and have a look around while the other family members went shopping! We got the better deal!! This place was amazing - the history on Hong Kong and nearby areas in China from prehistoric times to now was covered in detail. Everything you could image was covered and it was fascinating to see some of the artefacts on display. Ancient arrow heads, axes and fishing hooks to name a few items. The detail provided through the Chinese rule up to the British involvement was covered in detail. Around 4 hours was ample time to have a good look around. This was a great way to get some factual detail on the history of Hong Kong and the nearby areas. A great introduction to the place!

Loved this! The only way you can see HK's history..... Seeing as HK is what feels like the world-leader in constant re-invention, construction and commerce, much (all?) of its famous historical past is no longer visible, on the streets that have been reclaimed and rebuilt some time ago. As a result the Museum of History is well worth a visit if you want to see some visuals to go with the material you may have read about Hong Kong. This museum is large, detailed, and a lot of work has gone into explaining how the very islands were formed (I had no idea but was fascinated by the insight into the geology and carious climates the area had seen), the people and the artifacts, through to the much more political recent history. As well as the areas dedicated to the geological past and cultural heritage, I liked the recreated streets and shops of the colonial era, and the explanation of the handover from British to Chinese rule. It was especially interesting to analyse and read between the lines on the text which covers the handover of power. I don't think you can properly experience a destination without trying to form an understanding of where it has come from, so because of the absence of original buildings this museum forms a pretty important part of that in my opinion.

School trip to HK Museum of History. Great museum, with some excellent exhibits.The museum is so relevant to Hong Kong, with some really thoughtful exhibits. This is a must for anyone visiting HK and wanting to get a sense of the history and culture of this little corner of SE Asia.

Worth a visit for just $10. I have been a science buff and hence visiting the HongKong science Museum was a must for me on my trip to HongKong on a University assignment. The Hong Kong Museum of History is just besides the Hong Kong Science Museum and is a must for all visitors. The museum houses an amazing collection of artifacts which reflects Hong Kong’s rich heritage and culture. We brought tickets for ourselves ($10 each for me and my girlfriend) and gained access to all the floors of the museum. The ensemble of paintings obtained from renowned artists all over the world is a great gallery. The other things on display are related to archaeology, history, ethnography and natural histories of Hong Kong and South China. We spend around 2 hours walking through almost all rooms and segments the museum has to offer. Time worth spent.

Big and nice place to know the history. I just bought the ticket fot the HK history, but this "small" area of the museum took me more than 3 hours and I haven't seen all the things I had to. A "gotta go" place at HK.

Understand the culture. A visit to this museum will give you an insight into much of the history, customs and traditions that provides the vibrancy in Hong Kong. Set in a colourful landsacpe adjacent to a clean and safe park, well worth a trip for the first time visitor to Hong Kong.
Great way to learn about Hong Kong. The museography is excellent. From the first settlers to the handover, everything is very well explained and displayed. A definite must-see when in Hong Kong

thoughtful layout and detailed history lesson. This museum is huge and very well layed-out. It is artfully done and interesting. My wife and I spent over 4.5 hours there and we did not see everything. Not knowing the size, we spent way too long in the natural history and prehistoric sections and were a bit burned out before we got to the stuff we actually came to see. Details about the Opium Wars, Great Britain's control, and the reunification with China seemed accurate and fairly unbiased. We definitely learned a lot.

wonderful overview. Oops - we planned to visit on a Tuesday, but it was closed. Fortunately it was open on the day that we were leaving and we were able to explore all the different exhibits in the time. Some truly wonderful displays of day to day life.

Excellent for kids & adults. All the museums in Hong Kong ar great. The history museum is really good & is free on Wednesdays. Most of the displays are interactive & there is alot of replicas so kids aren't bored just walking around looking at Displays. I was very impressed

Excellent museum - allow a few hours!. This is a great museum - but to warn you - it's only about Hong Kong! The exhibits are really good - starting with the natural environment and working through the cultures of Hong Kong, the build up, the history. Very interesting. I didn't have much time, and I definitely needed more than an hour and a half. They also have a special exhibit on now - "Images through Time: Photos of Old Hong Kong" and it's well worth the extra 10 HKD. Really interesting exhibit to see Hong Kong over the years in photographs.

Do not miss. We visited this museum on the last day of our trip and did not allow enough time to cover every thing. A token HK$10 entrance fee was amazing value, I expected to see a lot of political propaganda but found the display generally unbiased and neutral.If your time is limited, skip the geology and prehistoric displays and spend time on the more recent history, especially British Colonial era and the Japanese occupation, there are fascinating short films played in various side rooms with rare and insightful footages.Don't bother with the gift store.
Nice. Excellent place to visit. If you're a person that must visit museums as u travel...this is a must go.

Good overview of history of HK. This museum is quite interactive with various displays and models bringing the history to life.I enjoyed the museum from the perspective of history and also what it tells you about the modern Chinese take on the place.In the latter category the comments on the Japanese and British were fascinating. Also I find from my father who was stationed in HK with the RAF in 1956 that certain things such as MIG pilots defecting to the west post war are not mentioned.
Great for visitors!. Exhibits were well put together. We spent three hours here and the tickets were peanuts! Great for kids to see " old hK" and lovely historical artefacts for adults too!

Cool place. I always go to museums to see how the local culture views themselves. I also wanted to go this time to see what effect the People's Republic of China (PRC) has on how the museum would portray Hong Kong and re-unification. I learned a lot and found it quite enjoyable.

Superb museum. This is the best history museum I have ever seen, and I have seen quite a few. I can only re-iterate what others have said: The exhibits are really informative and the English descriptions are excellent. They are laid out in an intelligent and informative way, so you really feel you get useful information about the past and evolution of Hong Kong. The peoples that make up the population, their lives and beliefs. This is the way a museum should be made. Go there.
Exhibition of old Hong Kong photographs. An excellent display of photos spanning the colonial era. really worth the entrance fee.Their toilets however were a disgrace.

a very interesting museum for all the family. Not expensive at all : only 100hkd! you can spend a day inside.It's really interesting ; it begins with a geological part, continues with ethnical explanations and finishes with the history until now.There are a lot of models and a lot films so children will pay attention.

A must see attraction. Put aside a day or two for this museum.. We visited the Hong Kong Museum of History on the afternoon before flying back to the UK. We barely scratched the surface, seeing only a small section of this most interesting museum. Let the pictures show the limit of our visit. We plan to return and estimate that we will need at one and a half to two days to wholly appreciated this fantastic museum. The Science Museum is adjacent to the Museum of History. To get there. If you are based on Hong Kong Island, take the star ferry to Kowloon. On exiting the ferry building you will see the bus station. Buses 5 and 5C go along Chatham Road and stop outside these museums.

Most interesting museum I've been. I'm not usually a museum sort of person and get bored really quickly even in the world-famous museums in Europe, but I enjoyed the HK Museum of History so much! It was extremely interesting and there's so much to see.The layout is neat and tidy and all the displays had English descriptions so that was great.If you really want to see and read everything, I would recommend an entire day here. We were here for about 3 hours and had to rush at the end because they were closing. Would have liked an hour extra here.A must see!

A visit to the museum. We did the hong kong story tour and found it very good - the displays were very well set up, unfortunately we had to rush through the displays as we were short of time and there were a lot to see,the ticket price was also very reasonable - in summary well worth a visit and spending a couple of hours
a must see. you can speed through the first few sections because there is a second floor with the really interesting content.
Very Interesting. Well worth a visit. Excellent displays through the ages. Be aware the museum is closed on Tuesdays and is free on Wednesdays, but not expensive on other days. Recommended.

Packs a lot of info into one place. Everything is laid out nicely, and the museum covers about 5,000 years of history pretty effectively. It starts with natural history, moves through ancient China, and explains Hong Kong's unique situation very well. I left with a much better understanding of Britain's role in Hong Kong and how the city has developed.

So Worth it. This was a great idea. Although my fiancé suggested we do the science museum instead on the "museum day" of our visit, we decided to check his spot out. It really puts you on educational mode and teaches you about the fascinating history of Hong Kong. Everything from the Japanese invasion to the British colonial period. You get a great sense of the roots of Hong Kong from a cultural perspective.

The best museum I have experienced yet. I have been to museums in Shanghai, Beijing, Suzhou, San Francisco, and many other places. Thus far, the Hong Kong Museum of History is my absolute favorite. Why? Because visiting this museum provides more than artifacts and factoids...it provides an experience. You can walk through recreations of the streets and shops of old Hong Kong, explore life-size models of cultural celebrations, and see the traditional ways of life for the distinct ethnic groups of the area. I loved walking on board a boat dweller's ship (called a junk), walking through a traditional Punti house, and seeing a life-size Bun Festival climbing tower.We enjoyed this museum so much that we visited it twice. I recommend the same, if you have the time. (With an entrance fee of only 20 HKD, you can go back as many times as you like!)
This is a 'must' if you are in Hong Kong. This is a very informative and fun place to visit. It is one of the best history museums in Southeast Asia.

Go. Wasn't sure about this.. I set out to go here and also the science museum which is right next door.. I ended up going here only cos of the long queues at the science museum.. Gives a very nice history of HK and they have videos in English which were very helpful too

A must for the trip to Hong Kong - the story of Hong Kong. For most people that visit Hong Kong, it is nothing more than a big shopping place, the women street, the temple street. This is just the surface. Hong Kong does have a history, the curator of the Hong Kong Museum of History has put a good story for you.Although it is probably better appreciated by those who have some knowledge or ties to Hong Kong. The museum does offer quite a bit for everyday tourists.If you are short of time, skip the first 2 areas at the lower level - the prehistory era, and go directly to the 3rd area where they start showing the history for the last 100 years, the culture of the four main groups of people that starts Hong Kong, etc.Be prepare to spend more time on the second floor with news clippings on quite a few interesting topics that made Hong Kong nowadays.Tours are offered on a regular basis. Daily in Cantonese and Mandarin. But there are English guide tours available, check the schedule. The knowledge and the stories of a lively tour guide will definitely make your visit that much more enjoyable. The admission is only HK$10, check the discount for senior 60 and over, and full time student

An excellent overview on the history of Hong Kong. This is a very well curated museum and is very much worth visiting if you are interested in any of a variety of historical aspects of Hong Kong.  The opening exhibition explains how the Islands came about over hundreds of millions of years, before providing details of the indigenous animals and plants of the region.  A section of jungle has been built complete with a stuffed, tiger, black bear, monkeys, a wild boar and a massive python amongst other jungle animals. The museum then moves onto the evidence of early human existence before fascinating exhibits the various cultures that have contributed to the city.  Life size replicas of traditional houses, boats, weddings and other cultural festivals are on display.  The section on the Opium Wars and the development of Hong Kong through e 18 th, 19 th and 20th centuries is very well presented and informative.  I learned a lot about the city and you coukd soend all day here. At the least I would recommend spending three hours at this excellent museum.
Very interesting. Takes about an hour to stroll around the various exhibits which show the history of Hong Kong. This bit added because TA requires 50 characters minimum for these reviews!

Brilliant, especially for history buffs like me. Originally I wasn't expecting much since HK has a rather short history but after looking at the many positive reviews here I decided to include it in my itinerary. We visited the Museum at 11am and the entrance fee was very cheap, only 10HKD per person. Ended up leaving the place only at 4pm, since there were simply too many things to see and understand that we were overwhelmed in a positive way. I was pleasantly surprised. The Museum includes portions of history ranging all the way from prehistoric times to modern Hong Kong. The history of Hong Kong is indeed rather short, but the positive thing is that they included many aspects of culture, politics and economy as well to make the whole experience much more detailed and in-depth. Many resurrections of buildings, infrastructure, models and items of various territories and local people from different provinces of China were available, small cinemas dispersed at various corners of the exhibition area provided tourists with an insight into early/colonial Hong Kong life, entertainment, food and street culture, which I found really interesting and informative. Before this visit I knew roughly the history outline of Hong Kong, but after the visit I gained more knowledge on what exactly happened in between and the certain minisule details that I would never have known. The Science Museum is located just right opposite of the History Museum which I'm sure is a place that kids will enjoy very much.

Not an exciting place. Huge building but nearly empty. As history of Hong Kong is realtively short, not too many thinghs to expose... Visitors used with European museums will be a bit disappointed... What I really missed is a bit of old Chinese history and culture...
not too much of history. the visit to museum of history was a bit of a disappointment.Though well maintained , the overall display was pathetic to say the least.
Good insight into the history of HK. A well spent hour and a half. Skip the initial sections on the prehistory of HK and go straight on the sections from the opium wars. Very well laid out.

Fun museum. If you are keen to know more about how Hong Kong came to be, then this is your one stop shop. The museum take you on a journey from the geological formation of HK, right through to today.The parts of particular interest are the Qing Dynasty area, the native groups area and the upper section that deals with the Opium Wars onwards. The recreation of the 19th and early 20th century streets is the real highlight and it takes you right into the scene. Very well done.Wednesday is free entry to all HK museums.

Informative and fascinating for both adults and children. Well worth a visit. Very informative and fascinating account of HK's history. Our little one of 7 asked loads of questions and found it fascinating as well. Directly across from the science museum therefore easy to do both museums on the same day.

The epitome to magnificence unfolded before my eyes. 'A country that doesn't remember its past has no future.' If these wise words from Winston Churchill meant anything, it's expressing to us that Hong Kong has a prosperous future ahead of her. This is also probably the closest thing to a time machine you can ever find in the 21st century.Greeted by the kind staff at the ticket counter who then proceeded to collect an entry fee of $10 per person, it is without doubt that the museum is suffering huge operational losses every year in the noble name of preserving the memorable yet, at the same time, arguably bitter records of the previous centuries of Hong Kong. This past colony of the British Empire has faced many ups and downs, with the latter occurring at a higher frequency; yet, it continues standing up high undauntedly.At the first level of the museum, you will walk down a pathway that brings you back to the Hong Kong of the Devonian Period (~approximately 400 million years ago). Admittedly, I am no fan of Geography, so I briskly walked past these rocks which meant no more than mere rubble to me. At the end of this path, there is a theater which plays a video to summarize everything you had just seen (the videos are first played in Cantonese, then English and finally Chinese). The duration of the video is about 10 minutes, and if you missed the English version of the video, fear not as there will be English subtitles for the Chinese and Cantonese versions. These 'mini theaters' can be found in almost every corner of the museum to explain the different exhibits you have enjoyed. The topics vary from the Opium war and Japanese Occupation that took place in the now established Special Administrative Region to the natural disasters and early entertainments of the widely acclaimed Pearl of the Orient.In conclusion, this was the best place I have visited during my trip to Hong Kong. If the ruler of time were merciful and the cacophonous rumble of my stomach would cease, I would have willingly spent more than the 4 hours I spent in the museum.
Worth a look. Worth a look, although we should have taken a guided tour.There isn't really a guided path through the place so without a tour guide you can wander around getting mixed up
interesting summary of HK. It's a lot of History (from 400,000,000 BC to around the late 1990s) in one building, but it was an interesting summary of HK's history.
Free entry every wednesday. If you want the kids to know more about the history of Hong Kong, visit this place on a Wednesday, it's free entry and free WiFi.

Feast for the mind. Fabuloys 3 hours at the museum, two of which were on the guided tour. If you can manage it would strongly recommend you go on the tour. The guide was very informative and personable, and presented the tour really well with interesting stories and personal connections. We have a much better understanding of the history and culture of Hong Kong now.

Setting a standard of Museums. Awesome.The details, information and especially the life in HK section through the 1900s is my favourite. Can easily spend your day here if the weather is bad outdoors.If you want to visit any museums in HK, do this one first and the rest is incomparable.Ensure your camera is fully charged !

Recommend a visit. My husband and I really enjoyed our visit to this museum and, if we are ever back in Hong Kong, we would certainly go again as there is so much to see. We went one afternoon when it was raining and wished we had found this gem earlier. My husband was posted to Hong Kong for nearly 2 years while doing his National Service so was extremely interested to see the film clips, pictures, etc, taken around the early 1950s when he was there. If you have some time available and are interested in the history of Hong Kong this is a must.
Hong Kong Museum of History. Very well displayed and informative museum - lots of space and nice clear displays taking you through the ages. Worthwhile

Best museum in Hong Kong. Hong Kong is known more for food and shopping than for museums and culture, but there are a couple gems that tourists will really appreciate. The Hong Kong Museum of History is one of those gems, hands down the best museum in Hong Kong, and among the best museums I've ever visited. Not only does it provide a cultural, historical context for what you see and experience in Hong Kong, it is also a fun and quite extraordinary place. You are transported to many time periods with the help of full-scale replicas of old pawn shops, HK cafes, and fishing boats, and very useful information and history lessons posted on walls. There were many photo opportunities within the exhibits even inside a full-scale tram. I have visited have the museum many times and with each visit, I learned more about the historical significance of this strategic city. For tourists, it is a very good way to start a trip, from the very beginning of the city's birth, as far back as the stone age surprisingly, all the way to modern civilization. And best of all, it's free admission once per week. Make sure you allocate at least a few hours here. I made the mistake of trying to see it all in 1 hour and ended up missing a lot, but came back and spent another 2 hours on my next visit.
Worth a vist. Large but informative museum charting Hong Kong's evolution. Good displays and material, can easily spend a couple of hours wandering through it.

Best way to start your visit toHong Kong. To get a real understanding of Hong Kong, this is the best place to start. From the geological beginnings 40 million years ago through early life and the early tribes upto present day, you follow a logical timeline of history. Delve as deep as you like or just breeze through. We took a walking tour (in English) with a great museum tour guide who gave highlights as well as personal insights into some of Hong Kong's history.Plan to spend as long as you want in this amazing place to get the best understanding of the people, culture and land of Hing Kong.

Information overload. This place is huge, the initial impression is that it might be a bit light on, but once inside the exhibits just go on and on. The commentary on the displays is informative, and you certainly need a large part of a day to get around fully
Historical visit. Rich cultural history shown from the displays and short movies. Free entries on Wednesdays.Not publicised enough.

Fascinating museum. A great and very interesting museum on Hong Kong;s dramatic history right up to the present day. It's in a spectacular building. It's also great to see lots of school groups visiting.

Don't miss the docent English tour on the Weekend. They offer a docent 1.5 hour tour on Saturday, Sunday and Holidays at 10:30 AM. We did it yesterday, and our guide Anders was fantastic. He took us through the highlights of the museum with great tidbits of history to make things come alive. Our tour started out with 4 people, but ended up with about 20. People kept joining because he was informative and entertaining. We didn't finish the tour in 1.5 hours, but he stayed longer to finish. It was a great museum experience.

Don't go looking for artifacts, but the narrative is done well. I am very interested in the history of Hong Kong, so perhaps know a bit more than most tourists. However I still found this museum interesting for the chronological narrative of its prehistory, geology, and more recent colonial and post colonial development. But don't go looking for important historical artifacts, This is not the place to find great porcelain. Children will likely be interested in the shops and ships that are re-created here.I went on a Monday. It was almost empty.
Worth a visit. I went on a rainy day. It was very informative and really gives you the history of Hong Kong. Some very cool life sized exhibits! I learned a lot.

Perfect for a wet afternoon. Normally I prefer to see the sights and experience the city I am visiting than spend the time in a museum but having read the glowing reviews we headed off there on a wet day. It was Sunday so quite crowded but once you brave the ticket queues (cost minimal) there is plenty of room inside and you don't feel on top of each other. We were lucky that an English speaking tour was just about to start (weekends only) and this lasted around 2 hours which flew by! It made the trip so interesting and our guide was fab. Recommended.

Living history for a living city. I'm not usually a 'museum guy' when I travel, but wanted to learn more about the quickly changing history of Hong Kong. We put the museum on our list a couple of trips ago, and finally made it there on our last visit. I wish we had done it earlier, as it put many of the places we has already visited into historical perspective.Hong Kong is a dynamic city. Very young by Asian standards, HK has been in a process of constant change for 200 years. the museum, through many interactive displays, documents those changes. From small fishing communities, through major shipping port, the British Empire and now Chinese nationalism, the museum is a living experience. The kids loved the dioramas and colorful clothing and I enjoyed the sense of optimism that was always present through a myriad of radical changes in HK over the past 100 years. Many of the stories recounted in the museum are personal and touching not stale and/or institutional.The Hong Kong Museum of History is a must see for everyone who wants to put the present city into perspective. It tells a fabulous story in an engrossing and interactive way. Give yourself a few hours, and you'll remember it for life.
Very well done!. My entire family (teens, adults and a young child) loved this museum. Very informative and engaging and all around fantastic. I highly recommend it for visitors to Hong Kong.

wednesday is free admission. ticket is 10 hkd , wednesday is free admission. science museum is also free on wednesday. thursday science museum is closed. i went on thursday so i missed the science museum and need to pay 10 hkd .. gggrrr

Good history of Hong Kong. Lots of good displays. Well laid out with short videos. There are times for each language, but the Cantonese ones had English subtitles so you don't have to wait for the English video. I got the audio guide, but I don't think it was worth it. Too much talking (while the displays had lots of good information).

History in a nutshell. The museum is dedicated to the history of the Hong Kong area from formation of the land mass to modern day. It is beautifully laid out with lots of interactive exhibits. It will leave adults and children with a clear picture of Hong Kong.

Amazing museum. My wife and I visited this on a recent trip to HK, overall an excellent museum. The early sections about the geology could be skipped, to make more time for the later more interesting parts. Very good value @ $10HK (approx 1 euro) and same cost for the audio guide. You could easily spend 4 hours in here if you can last that long. As with many indoor locations we found it a little too cold, although I'm sure thst is welcome in the middle of summer. Give it a try, you won't be dissapointed.

What an experience this was. What an experience this was, I would highly recommend a visit as it gives an overview of Hong Kong from prehistoric times to the present in a series of very well presented scenes.

Spectacular and a Must See in Hong Kong. We were drawn to this Museum by the reviews on Trip Advisor and were bowled over by the quality of the exhibits, the presentation, and the friendliness and helpfulness of the staff. The permanent exhibition is split over eight periods bringing the story from the Stone Age (Surprisingly Interesting ) right up to the present time. The displays are brought to life with film and strong use of colour plus many full scale reconstructions. Near to the Tsim-Sha-Tsui MTR station in Kowloon (Use Exit B2). A visit can easily take up most of the day and to preserve concentration we broke for lunch and then came back. The cafe is temporarily closed but we were give return passes for our afternoon continuation. GO you will not be disappointed

Hong Kong Museum - a pleasant surprise. We came across the museum while walking through the very pleasant Kowloon Park and decided to have a look.The amount of history was very good with examples of architecture and cultural exhibits over a long period of history.The museum is well laid out with plenty of light. It also has very good interactive exhibits.It is a contrast to what you normally find in Hong Kong, the hustle and bustle of the commercial activities (which we also love). It is a pleasant respite when to need a change of pace.We found it very informative and educational.

Walk with me. It is always good to visit a museum of history when you travelled to a place. You will get a chance to know the past of the place and how it shaped the present.. This is what this Hong Kong Museum of History presents to me. A very detailed and interesting presentation of the past history of Hong Kong, Now I know how a small fishing village can change into a cosmopolitan city. It is indeed a very enjoyable walk with the history of Hong Kong.

Great way to discover Hong Kong story. With just only 10HKD/adult, you can experience Hong Kong from the past till now (visit area in the lobby is FOC like in other cities). During your visit, you can see that Hong Kong authority already invested a lot on building and maintaining this museum. Huge space for each period exhibition with clear direction. If you don't have a guide (person or audio guide), should watch the general introduction movie in each area before seeing exhibits. English tour guide is available at 2h30PM.

Very interesting. Went here with my wife and my 8 year daughter and we enjoyed it very much. Whether you're passionate about the history of Hong Kong or just curious, this museum must visit. An entertaining program that will absolutely make you enjoy discovering this small territory. Comprehensive presentations and teaching of history but also of everyday life and traditional Hong Kong, from the beginning until the handover to China. This is not your typical boring museum, it’s quite an atmosphere created by the Life scenes, characters and costumes. A great place for kids and grownups as well, to learn about 6000 years of history history and get a glimpse of their way of life.

HK Museums. Get a week pass to get the most out of HK museums, it is not that expensive for a family of four and History museum is just next to the science museum which is also a must. Both museums seems very modern (recently built) and parents enjoyed absorbing some HK history whilst the kids loved the science museum where there were 4 floors and lots of interactive equipment. There is also space museum we went to which is a short taxi ride away (or you could walk it if you are planning to shop anyway).

Visit helps make sense of modern Hong Kong. I was really lucky and arrived just as the excellent guide started the morning tour, but even "self guided" the displays are interesting and informative. Hong Kong's history goes from Polynesian sailors, via Chinese warlords, colonial settlement, opium wars, japanese occupation - and now becoming part of China again. If you want to get a better idea of how and why it is the amazing city you see today, the HK Museum of History is a good place to start.
Well worth the visit. A great museum, well laid out and very interesting. If you want to stroll about unhurried then get there at opening to avoid the crowds.
Good overview. Great museum for HKG history, and the size of the museum is very well balanced. Good to get the history explained, especiallly the last 200 years exhibit was very good.

Excellent guided tour. With only a short time to spend in Hong Kong we decided that the Hong Kong Museum of History would be a good way to get a quick overall understanding of the history of this bustling city. We joined an English speaking tour guide and spent a pleasant and informative hour and a half with Cheung Wai-fung who clearly and simply lead us through the phases of Hong Kong’s history form ancient times, through colonial influence to the present time under China's leadership. He was informative, approachable, and could be easily understood. The exhibitions are clearly labelled (no need of the audio guide if you can see to read the panels) and presented in a visually stimulating way. Please note that there did not seem to be any form of cafe for refreshments. There was a minimal entrance cost

An excellent, good value museum.. We visited the museum early on in our stay with the plan of getting some historical context of Hong Kong before we explored further. The museum certainly provides that! Covering nearly 400 million years of HK history, it is a bold and comprehensive narrative of this fascinating city. Far too much to handle in detail in one visit, we moved quickly through some of the geological displays and focused more on the 'history' of the upper floors. We thought the information was presented really well. Many of the exhibits include full-size replicas of the places and things described which really add to the experience. Well worth a visit!

A treat of a museum. If you plan a visit to Hong Kong or Kowloon, do plan to visit this museum. It is well laid out and takes one back through the ancient history of the area to the present day. Travellers from the West will appreciate the English explanations used throughout the museum. An excellent display of Qing Dynasty Court Costumes was visiting when we toured and it added a truly special bonus. The entry fee is very low for the quality of the displays. This a good place to visit early in your stay if you haven't researched ahead of your arrival.

Three happy hours spent in the Hong Kong Museum of History - free on Wednesdays!. This new beautiful and well organized museum is worth a visit. Hong Kong is more than a city - it's a distinct geographic and historical place and this musuem is a great way to learn about what makes Hong Kong unique.We particularly enjoyed the clothing displays, the large space devoted to culture and festivals, and the modern history section.Unlike many musuems, this one is photography friendly.Go on Wednesdays, when it is free!

Comprehensive historical coverage, but getting a little long in the tooth. At HK$10 this has to be the best buy in HK (even better than the HK2.30 ~ 25c tram fare) but the sheer scale is daunting. If you are history buff then at least 2 visits will barely do justice. I have often wondered why museums (Las Vegas casinos?) don't pump oxygen into the public area to give tired museum feet a pick me up?Lots of content, but the presentation style is very wordy, with lots of videos and some not very convincing 'representations'. I was surprised at the relatively muted 'colonists-did-us-wrong' tone. In truth the British have a lot to answer, especially in the early years.This said, the sheer hardship of life in China does come across very clearly and reinforces the need for a good clan system.Some gaps ~ the Vietnamese boat people crisis and the economic shift (back) to trading and finance (the beginning) from consumption goods assembly, which has left less educated HKers stranded.Museum employees are amazing engaged and despite very limited English were 100% eager to help.Recommended for a hot summer's day or when sheltering from a typhoon, but not a must.

Fascinating museum, well presented. Very well presented museum, charting the history of Hong Kong. Unless you're particularly intersted in archeology and prehistoric matters, there is no harm in skipping the first sections. The later sections in particular were fascinating, especially re the occupation in WW2 and the city's development after . To do it justice, you really need at least 2 - 3 hours, if not longer. Very reasonable admission charges, especially if one is over 60 - HK$5 does not exactly break the bank!

I love museums. There's so much to see and look at here with history dating back thousands of years to the present day, with Hong Kong changing so rapidly this history museum keeps the past alive check whats changing in their display on a regular basis

Great exhibitions, very informative. We went to the museum on a Wednesday as it's free entry. It's a very well put together museum and covers a huge range of Hong Kong history. It's divided into four main sections: The Natural Environment, Prehistoric Hong Kong, The Dynasties: From the Han to the Qing and Folk Culture in Hong Kong. There are clear signs directing you to each section should you only want to see one in particular.There are large exhibitions in each section with lots of artifacts and includes very detailed signs in English. There are many historical building recreations and my favourite area was the reconstruction of an entire village with a bank, tea shop, sweet shop and much more. It brings history to life vividly and we were lucky to have a whole day free so we got to see all of the exhibitions.One of the best museums I've been to through all of my travels.

Learn where you are. A great place to see and understand how Hong Kong became what it is today. Also great to get out of the pollution.Interesting exhibits covering the early settlement right up to the current times.

Great Museum. One of the best and most interesting museums I ever visited.
Free entrance on Wednesdays.
Really loved it!

Lots to see. This was an interesting way to spend a few hours. There is alot to see, so if you are short on time, head straight for whichever section interests you most. I ran out of time and would have liked to spend more time in the WWII history section. This museum is very well put together and really does give you a good overview of HK history. I have friends whose younger kids were a bit freaked out by the wax cavemen, so if you have young kids who are frightened of that kinds of stuff, be aware - it's in the first section you walk into, but can be avoided by taking a different route.

If hunting for old Colonial Hong Kong, look here!. If you looking in ultra-modern Hong Kong for a glimpse at its colonial life, this is the place to go. Life-size displays, films and concise narratives. Unless you're a rock hound, skip past the initial geological displays and enter the story of the early trader contacts, the opium wars and then the colonial period. My top three display areas: (1) Explanations and displays of Chinese festivals. Amazing colors, sounds and life-like displays. HINT: go behind the opera scene to see a real backstage setup and read about unusual dressing-room traditions. (2) Films and displays on the lead-up to the Opium Wars. (3) A walk through colonial Hong Kong! Walk through the bank; visit the apothicary, go behind the teller window of a pawn shop, check out the shops. This is as close to 1900 as you can get in this city (until they finish the old government square restoration in 2014)!

A great, if overwhlemingly extensive display!. I was there for current The Splendours of Royal Costume: Qing Court Attire, which was absolutely fabulous, especially if you are interested in costume or dress at all. They also had a small exhibition of winners of a current fashion contest that was out of this world. The permanent display of the Story of Hong Kong is fascinating and well worth your time. It starts with natural history and then goes through all the stages of civilization to the hand back of HK to the Chinese in the 90s. The dioramas are fantastic and people of all ages will be thrilled by their detail. I only wish I had planned more time for the permanent collection, because it really is quite extensive... Do yourself a favor and take the day...really.

Very fascinating. We visited the Hong Kong Museum of History which was a very fascinating experience. We loved the various exhibits, displays and films that were present there. They showed the history of Hong Kong which was so interesting and wonderful. It was suggested to us that we go on a Wednesday as it was free and we did just that. So I would recommend the same. Besides that it is a very engaging experience and in my opinion not one to miss out.

It is a must for those who grew up in HK. I grew up in HK and had been living overseas for the last 12 years. There were many changes in HK in the last decade, and it is becoming a foreign place to me. After visiting the HK Museum of History, a lot of the childhood memory came back. The video I watched just before the exit to the museum, which is about the history of HK, was a very emotional experience for me. After the visit, somehow I have recollected my HK identity.

Brilliant. The Museum of History is huge, and it is not to be missed!There are a large number of brilliant exhibits - the highlight is no doubt the recreation of an old Hong Kong trading street, which has been brilliantly done.

Fascinating insight into Colonial Hong Kong. Takes you through the full history of the island, geological as well as anthropological. Floor by floor new surprises jump out at the visitor, with many reconstructions of temples and shops.

great museum. This is one of the best museums we have been to.I enjoyed visiting the museum. It was well-organized into sections based on the various dynasties. The facilities here are great, nice and clean. I liked the historical layout of the coinage and minting. They had a lot of rare footage and artifacts from this time which I had never seen before so the visit was worthwhile. The whole trip wasn't boring at all because of the many interactive potions of the trip.Nice way to escape the heat for a couple of hours!

Wonderful !. Such a positive surprise ! I planned to spend 30 minutes there and I was in for 2 hours. An absolute must ! My recommendation would be to skip (or accelerate) the visit on the 1st floor which is a bit disappointing. Though the second floor and the mezzanine classifies among the best musea I ever visited. The part from the Opium war until the reunion with China. All very well documented, explained and illustrated. Also, some of the videos are very well made.

History of Hong Kong brought to life. HK Story narrates the history of Hong Kong really well. The exhibits downstairs start with prehistoric times and provide an insight to the cultures of early inhabitants of the region. Upstairs focuses on the development of Hong Kong since the Opium wars all the way to current times.Exhibits are well built, streets lined with shops and teahouses really move you back in time. Multimedia is used as a nice support to provide deeper insights. Especially enjoyed the old British film about Hong Kong.Spent a couple of hours here and still felt like there was more to see for a further visit. Admission is only HK$10. Just hope that the gift shop would focus on all things Hong Kong, instead of generic Chinese merchandise.
A Worthwhile Visit. It is a walk around display of HK history back to pre-history. It covers all aspects including culture to present day. It will take about 2 hours and is well worthwhile.

Aussie tripper. What a great find this was. Went here because of reviews I read on trip advisor. Parts of the exhibitions were closed for updating when we were there but even without those sections there was more than enough for one visit the day we went admission was free.
Excellent. You want to know what hong Kong was ,, you should visit this museum ,, one of the best museums I have ever attend ,, so good and useful

Very interesting place. The museum is a must see place in Hong Kong. Starting from the pre-historic times to the development of new city, it captures all the phases that HK has gone through. The sections depicting British occupation, World War and Japanese occupation were full of details/ photographs/ movie clips etc. Definitely a great insight into the country's history.

The second half is fascinating. This is easily the best attraction we visited whilst in Hong Kong, and the entry fee is so cheap that it's hardly worth the bother of them charging! Don't bother with the audio guide, all it does is read out the text written on the displays. Hurry through the first section on geology, and devote some attention to the cultural history of HK. But spend hours upstairs on the Opium Wars and the colonial history of Hong Kong - absolutely fascinating! We had to be kicked out when the museum closed at 6pm, and could easily have spent another hour there.

Awesome. Definitely check out this place if your visiting the city, if you dont your missing out.Once you walk in its like walking back in time. Its so interesting to see how the city used to look like back in the colonial times. You really get a sense of how much things have changed around here over time. Once you walk out you notice the little things that haven't changed, and the obvious changes/development such has mega sky scrapers and globalization etc.
Good, not amazing.. There's a lot of interesting stuff here, but overall a little bit dated. Was under refurbishments when I was there.

Ok to fill in time. My family visited the museum of history on a Wednesday to take advantage of the free entry. The museum is very large, larger than we thought and as such we probably spent too long in the lower section and the kids (7 and 10) were therefore quite bored by the time we made up to the next section.I wouldn't recommend visiting unless you have a real interest in history or have a couple of hours spare with nothing else to do.
its historic. its amazing show of past of hk, its starts from stone age to till british left it. models arte v good. video show in each section is informative. you can go on reading and watching.

Free entry on Wednesdays. I'm not really big on museums but I wanted to find out about Hong Kong's history in the last few hundred years. This place answered every question I wanted to know. Awesome museum and it's right in town so easy to get to.
A must see. Informative and inexpensive. Even my teenage children enjoyed the visit very much. Give yourself 3-4 hours.

Very good. Interesting with plenty of things to do and see.- films to watch and well laid out.
In July, there was an excellent National Geographic photograph exhibition on, so that is worth checking to see what is on.
Lots of interactive bits and bobs on about 4 levels.
Great to see the original Cathay Pacific DC3 on the top floor.

Go on Wednesday, it's free!. The history of Hong Kong is well covered with a very well laid out set of exhibits and video stations. A must for anyone interested in the foundation of HK, the growth of a nation and subsequent hand over to China. I personally hadn't realised the involvement of HK during WW2. I spent 3 hours going around taking in all that I could, and with no admission fee on Wednesdays how could you go wrong.
Hong Kong Museum of History. Spent half a day with family - good to see the history. Rooms with displays were great - and realistic. Lots of photos as well to accompany the history.

Best HK museum. If you want to know about Hong Kong history, tradition, folklore and heritage, this museum is a must and you should visit this one before going to the other museums. The exhibition gives a detailed account of Hong Kong development from prehistoric to modern time. You also gets a glimpse of Hong Kong's British colonial heritage and legacy with many period artefacts and memorabilia, which can now be rarely seen elsewhere in Hong Kong. The museum is located in Tsim Sha Tsui East within 15 minute walk from Tsim Sha Tsui MTR station or Tsim Sha Tsui East station. Opposite the museum is the Hong Kong Science Museum. If you start your trip from Star Ferry and walk along the Avenue of Star, you can end your walk by going to these two museums.
Great!. This is fantastic museum! Go on a Wednesday - Wednesdays are free! :-) They have exhibits on archaeological history, culture/customs, and so much more. It's definitely worth visiting.
Must visit to understand Hong Kong. A must visit, to understand modern Hong Kong and its roots. The museum is very well organized and with good explanations

Go for the guided tour. To be fair, I was here mainly for the special exhibition on the Qing court attire (Splendours of the Royal Costume). That one was excellent, with detailed description of each display, as well as other interesting facts. I didn't catch the regular guided tour, but listened in on the tour given to visitors from an old folks' home. Fascinating. Spent more than 2 hours in there and was too tired to visit the Hong Kong Story. No photography allowed though. Came back another day for the Hong Kong Story (separate stubs on the same ticket). The guided tour was very informative, interesting and engaging (though I might have been lucky). It lasted about 1.5 hours and the area to be covered was quite big (2 floors). The front part was covering stuff that was a little too far back in time. Dinosaurs and stone age, and the first humans in the area. It got more interesting after that, talking about the early settlers, how they lived, and later folk culture and traditions. These were on the first floor, which you should complete before going to the second floor since you can't get back to the first floor within the exhibition (unless I missed some elevator somewhere). The second floor is more on the history, how HK came to be in such a special position. I didn't have time to catch the movies though. I felt that the information for reading was very dry, unlike the substantially more interesting and informative things that our guide told us. So check the timings and make it for the guided tour. Tips: freezing cold in there, so bring a nice thick jacket. There are resting areas and washrooms, even inside the Hong Kong Story exhibition. Bring a camera as there are lots to take (allowed in HK Story). Eat before going because you may end up spending quite some time in there.

Starting with the dinosaur,,,. It is all too and the information is quite bitty. The films We enjoyed, a lot of propaganda though. Great place to cool off for two hours...but otherwise not really worth it. Do not go there on Wednesday. It is free entry day. It is worth paying 10 hd for less people...

First day. Spent the day at the History museum. Quite interesting. The first floor was okay... But after that it was what I was really wanting to learn. How it became a British Colony, how Japan attacked and took over for 3 years and how Britain got it back after the US dropped an atomic bomb on Japan. Then gave it back to China after 100 years in 1997.

A bit of History. Very clean, air-conditioned and the artifacts were well displayed. Superb washrooms!Lots of information available, spent almost an afternoon here, just slowly admiring every piece on display. Cameras are allowed in certain halls, just don't use the flash.

How Museums used to be..... This Museum was interesting and there were some fun things to learn, but I actually found the feel of the place a bit stale, like being back in a history class in the early 90s where you were being hit with a pretty predicatable and stale way of being taught. Its not really very imaginative, or takes you coherently through the history and interesting times Hong Kong has been through. I also found some of the language emotive, which brought a few smiles to my face!

favourite museum. this place is absolutely amazing. Incredibly detailed exhibits paint a comprehensive picture of Hong Kong's history. There is so much to see, I spent 2.5 hours in here and a majority of the visit involved speed walking through the place and rapid picture taking for later enjoyment as I didn't have nearly enough time to see everything but I still managed to miss some of the displays. I'm definitely going to come back for a more lengthy visit the next time I'm in HK.

Great museum and VERY big!. Very well-presented museum. for me the highlight was the genuine shop interior which the museum had purchased and re-installed. The place is pretty big and it will take at least half a day to get around, but it is worth it.

A comprehensive history of Hong Kong not to be missed.. A great exhibit showcasing Hong Kong's history starting with ancient geology through prehistoric times and on to recent times. It can get overwhelming so take your time and don't try to absorb all of it at once.Museum is free on Wednesdays but also extremely crowded with local students and families.

Detailed history of HK. When you enter the museum it looks limited but once you are in the exhibition area you can witness the history of HK with art, videos and descriptions. The topics range form dynasties to the Japanese take over. Overall a good museum.
For the history nerds. Very nice exhibition of Hong Kong's history with lots of emphasis on ethnic culture and folk traditions.
Visit. Great hands on things to see especially for kids. Again be prepared to have to push and shove to get anywhere. Make sure you are there for when they switch on the ball race, it is fascinating.

Excellent. No trip is complete without a visit to the local History Museum and here was no exception. I enjoyed the Hong Kong Story and show how geographically and political it was established, well worth the visit

did not catch me. The History Museum was my first visit (I like this kind of museums to be introduced to the places I visit) and I was not impressed at all.I found the museum chaotic and I missed a path to visit it (the map is not a real path).I used also the audio guide to have the best support and this was even more disappointing: long and boring descriptions, mostly replicating the signs (my myth about HK as high tech place has been definitely destroyed).the deepest explanation of HK museum was about the Opium wars and the period of the new buildings. In the end not enough to catch my attention, especially when I compare this to many other museum I visited

Geological history in addition to Cultural and Political was very nice. The museum provides a good background on the cultural and political evolution of Hong Kong. Adding in a well done geological introduction was very nice. Nice explanation of the Opium wars. Good insight into how the people lived in early history

History Museum. If you have Young children take the kids to History and Science (both are side By Side) they will enjoy a half day with lot of learning and play options. Science has great options Energy, Transport, Agriculture Etc...The History Museum is great place for young children to understand the Basic history of Trade between Asia and West the importance of Hong Kong as Trade Centre

Surprise. A nice visit on a hot humid (rainy) HK day and close to the main shopping of TST and near MTR and bus, inexpensive and a good 1-2 hour visit - what more could you ask?This museum has 2 large floors. The first floor, for me, a tad boring covering the early history of Hong Kong. The 2nd floor covers the economic and trade development of Hong Kong and various impediments along the way.Overall it was a big surprise as to the quality of the exhibits, interesting narrative and audio/video cues.Is this a MUST SEE? Probably not but for those looking to escape summer heat, this is a nice pause to the day. Plenty of nearby restaurants to make a morning/lunch activity.

Most interesting museum. I visit this museum every time I go to Hong Kong. It is a fascinating place - very attractively and spaciously laid out and full of interesting and very varied displays. I always go with my children and as the years go by their interest is focussed on different aspects. Usually we would walk quickly through the geological history but this time we spent a long while there, as well as our favourites -the Chinese ethnic groups, festivals and celebration, Japanese occupation and post-war Hong Kong. The cafe is simple but a treat as is the little shop. It is a really lovely way to spend an afternoon.

One of best museums visited. Quite as recommended this is a real jewel and totally unexpected. Seeing this right after the disappointingly small maritime museum this was a better maritime museum with real boats!

Wonderful, attractive museum to learn about Hong Kong. Museum presentation has become so much better over the years and this museum sets the standard. The displays are extremely well done. The museum is laid out chronologically and if you have limited time and energy, most will want to pass beyond the first exhibits which deal with the geological formation of Hong Kong. It is interesting to see the Neolithic tools that have been unearthed, but Hong Kong's more recent history from the arrival of the first Europeans through the Opium trade and colonial period, the Japanese occupation and more recent history, are all more interesting.As noted, the museum fee, even on days other than Wednesday when it is free, is very modest HK$5.

Interesting display and films about Hong Kong. I was quite surprised to find the historical facts shown there. I was also pleasantly surprise to learn (or rediscover) my heritage for I was born in Hong Kong. I liked the recreation of old Hong Kong street. I appreciated the film of Japanese occupation because when we were a kid, the subject was never discussed in elementary school. I really enjoyed the museum. It brought back a lot of childhood memories.

Keep a good pace going. We visited this museum with our three girls, ages 12, 10 and 9. We each purchased the audio tour which I highly recommend. There is a lot to take in and we spent so much time on the beginning of the tour that we were worn out half way through. I loved how they had movies strung throughout the museum to correspond to the different galleries. If you can keep a good pace going, I think it is a great way to get an overview of Hong Kong's history.
Creative and Interesting Museum. The museum has interesting exhibitions, creative settings you might enjoy, moderate cafe, clean washrooms and a cheap ticket. Absolutely recommended
A way to grasp a brief history of Hong Kong. Both permanent exhibition and special exhibitions are worth for a visit. Do not miss the Qing Court Attire special exhibition.

Free on Wednesdays!. I visited this week and found the museum to be well worth a look and is FREE on Wednesdays. The museum itself is well laid out with plenty of clean toilets and resting areas on each floor. The exhibits are a combination of artifacts and film to support the experience. If you are not familiar with the history of HK, it really does help put everything in context, particularly the social history exhibits. There is no MTR station in the immediate area and due to traffic restrictions, taxis sometimes drop you at the rear of the building.

Best rainy day ever. I started at 10 AM and finished at 4 PM. This museum is extremely well done and very interesting. The videos and the displays are informative as well as beautiful. I rented the audio guide and I am so glad I did. The best HKD 10 that I have spent. The museum is free on Wednesday but is not expensive on any other day. I would say this is a must do in Hong Kong.

Hong Kong Does Have A History. My husband (Hong Kong born) brought our son (U.S. born) to the museum so that he can learn more about Hong Kong. Surprisingly, it was my husband who was moved by the exhibits and other displays about the city he grew up. The museum is very informative and presents an objective view of Hong Kong past. By the way, we didn't need to pay anything to get in. It is free on Wednesday.

Just for 10 HKD. Considered the price and everything else in Hong Kong, this is one of the cheapest activities you can find. Just for 10 HKD you can browse for an hour or dwell all day, depending on your interest. The first geological and natural chapter is a bit basic but later on, the dynasties, the English, the 2e WW period and the seventees are pretty interesting.
Well worth. The admission fee is HKD10 for adults, but I'm telling you is so worth it. The museum is kinda huge and there were lots of stuff to see, spent almost 3 hours here.

Spent more time here than I expected!. I like to go to cultural sites and art museums when I travel. This museum didn't fit the things that I normally do. I was very pleasantly surprised! I spent much longer time there than I expected and it was very interesting. The history of Hong Kong is laid out in an easy-on-the-mind approach. I probably would not go here if I had only 1 or 2 days, but it's worth seeing.

Great place to find out more about HK history. This is great value if you like museums..and even if you don't it gives you great insight into the history of Hong Kong. Also great place ona very hot, wet summer day.

Slow start but got really good.
