We followed the recommended route through the museum which takes you from the geologic formation of Hong Kong to the prehistoric settlers, this part of the museum was quite hard to take in and relate back to modern Hong Kong.We weregoing toleave butthought wemight as well have aquick lookthrough theto floor. The tour got much more interesting there as it covered more recent times, from Victorian Hong Kong to wsr times to the hand over to China. We didn't want to leave but we're just too tired to continue. Until we hit the museum shop which we spent a long time browsing through everything.The only let down was the cafe which was due be refurbished in the next few days and they practically had nothing left to eat.

Informative and excellent exhibits. I have visited this museum twice. The permanent exhibition are interesting and very engaging. It starts from the prehistoric period to reunification in 1997. A good place to start if you're interested in learning how this tiny fishing village came to be today's global financial hub

Size isn't everything - compact and excellent. Good size - very enjoyable. Excellent audio-visuals. So interesting to see vintage Hong Kong for real! Some of the displays were quite big compared to the overall size of the museum! Good value tip = visit on a Wednesday - free admission - though admission is not costly to be honest. BTW ... the Science Museum is just next door too!

Small, but worth a visit. I was told tourists usually do not visit museums when Honk Kong, but shopping insanely is not my kind of trip, so I found it interesting and had a good time. It is a small museum, but worth a visit. Had nice tour guide who showed me all around.
Decent history museum. It's a newer museum with main focus on showing pieces from the Hong Kong history. I didn't feel the history being shown that well nor interesting as in other museums though.
Learn a bit more about Hong Kong. Worth a visit if you have time while in Hong Kong. I went with someone who lives in Hong Kong - we both found it interesting

Good Way to Spend an Afternoon. We practically ran through the first floor, slowed down on the upper floors. The exhibits were very informative. The kids in my group enjoyed ducking in and sitting down and watching the various movies.

HK history well done. Went on Wed (free admission), otherwise it's $10hkd (still cheap). You need @ least 4 hours or more to see everything. The exhibits are well organized & very informative. There were lots of school children in attendance & they are cute & inquisitive; they have so much patience to learn about HK history.The cafe was being renovated; so you will need to grab refreshment outside. Well worth the visit.

Worth a visit. It was large with many attractions. Well worth the visit. Be prepared to spend a gd part of the day there, especially if you cover all displays thoroughly. Tip : go on a Wed if you can. Entry is free on that day.
Culture and History. I enjoyed visiting the museum. It was well-organized into sections based on the various dynasties. I liked the historical layout of the coinage and minting.

What a great museum!. This museum needs some of your time. We were constantly tugging each other into exhibits that were fascinating! They do a great job of creating exhibits addressing all aspects of history of Hong Kong. Big walk-through areas, all well done.
Great. Allow 4 hours in 1 or 2 sessions to visit galleries 1-8.I thought galleries 5&6 upstairs to do with opium wars & Japanese occupation especially good

Decent overview of Hong Kong's history. Good but it only really gets interesting later on, after the prehistory and primitive section. It covers the local cultures, the English opium wars, Japanese occupation and reunification with China.
I didn't find the audio guide to be much good. I wouldn't recommend the food either.

Good place to know about Hong Kong. C1 ( 2013.06.21 ) I always have visited museum in the country trip, because I want to know and understand that country. I traveled to Hong Kong and also visited Hong Kong Museum of History. I was very happy and exciting for understanding about Hong Kong's history. There was a many excellent exhibits from prehistoric to now about Hong Kong. If you visit Hong Kong, make sure to visit there. Recommand..

Excellent exhibits. The museum is split over several levels, is spacious, and includes a number of street recreations as well as original shop layouts from the Colonial era. If wanting to enjoy the museum to its full potential I’d recommend going later in the day.
Cool exhibits. Very cool and fascinating exhibits, I would go want to go again. :) Can be crowded at times because of school visits.

Wonderful. A very interesting and comprehensive overview of Hong Kong from the beginning of time to the present day. My only regret is that my wife's brain was full after four hours and we had to leave. Even so, she kept stopping to look at things on the way out, as it was all so well presented and fascinating.
Educational. Excellent exhibits, good value, a bit difficult to find for a western tourist. Learn about the history of Hong Kong at your own pace.

Surprisingly excellent... a must see. We went for a visit on recommendation from a friend. We were orginally from HK and we never knew this place had exisited during our previous return visits until this time. We went on a Wednesday and it is usually free admission on Wednesdays. We were surprised by quality and depth of the exhibtiions, including various videos (shown in English, Cantoense and Mandarin in turns) depicitng history such as the Japanese occupation, the HK handover, the history of the opimum war and the history of HK entertainment culture. Simply amazing and done to perfection. Not going to get into details as to what other stuff are in there (see other 5 star reviews) but this is definately a must see for both Chinese speaking and non-Chinese speaking people.

Don't miss the tomb. There are Junk boats, village houses, tombs, that you can walk through. Short films that explain the information. It is one of the few museums that you don't need an audio guide. Don't miss the tomb, and the info on the Han dynasty.

Excellent considering the low price. For such a cheap museum (HK$10) this was a great visit. It charts the history of Hong Kong from pre-historic times up until the hand over back to China in 1997. The lead up to the Hand Over was for me the most interesting part of the museum as it happened during my lifetime. They had a lot of rare footage and artifacts from this time which I had never seen before so the visit was worthwhile.
Great. Very well explained - good entertainment that does not last for hours and hours. very good option when it is rainning!

a bit ok. i always go to museums,its one of my favorite tourist spot,but this?not worth it at all..sorry guys
the staffs are not friendly at all,it felt like they dont want you to go inside

We went for a few hours and spent all day here. This is one of the best museums we have been to. We initially went to find out about the history of Hong Kong - thinking we would be there a couple of hours. How wrong that turned out to be we were there all day!The information and the way the displays were set out were fantastic, with information provided in both English and Chinese. We learnt a great deal - the museum covers the geological development right through the history of Hong Kong to the time when the British handed over rule to China. There is even information on what will happen in the future. Some of the displays/diaromas included celebrations for minority groups, resettlement estates in the 60's, made in Hong Kong toys and electrical items, street scenes etc.On one day a week there is free entry to the museum - but the entry fee on other days is cheap.The museum is good for adults and children. The museum is also closed on one day during the week so check before you go.It is easy to walk to the museum from Tsim Sha Tsui station and the Art Gallery is also well worth visiting ( located on the waterfront).
Very interesting. On a very hot and humid day, this provides a cool and informative place to learn the history of the city and area. Would like to see more about the history since 1997.

Interesting, engaging presentation of Hong Kong history. The museum was set up with many life size dioramas and displays with concise explanations in both English and Chinese which depicted both the geographical and social history of Hong Kong. There were short movies, recordings and touch screens which revealed more in depth information if desired.

Entertaining way to spend a couple of hours learning about HK. Spent a thoroughly enjoyable morning in the museum, learn't everything from pre-historic right up to the modern era. The rebuilt streets and exhibitions on life in colonial and hand over era are fascinating and give a real sense of what life was like. Well worth a visit, very easy to get to and very cheap entrance fee well laid out and clean.

HONG KONG MUSEUM OF HISTORY IS FOR EVERYONE. If you are flying out of Hong Kong in the evening, and just tired of shopping, I would advise that you visit the Hong Kong Museum of History. You can spend at least three hours there without knowing how fast time just flies! Very detailed, informative, spacious, clean, and with many helpful, English-speaking workers all around the museum. Very good for people who wants to know more about the South-Chinese history and culture. A must visit especially for those who have South-Chinese ancestors!

Smithsonian quality. Nothing to dislike. This museum was excellent in content and display. Took the visitor from 1000's of years ago to present using fabulous visual displays (think stage sets), short films, and interactive features. Truly a remarkable experience.

Interesting exhibit. We visited the history of Hong Kong exhibit. Was very interesting. We went on a Wednesday, so it was free, although that meant there was lots of school children! The facilities here are great, nice and clean. Nice way to escape the heat for a couple of hours.

History of Hong Kong in 2 hours. The musuem gives you a walkthrough of Hong Kong all the way back to when earth was formed. Taking you through the important points in Hong Kong history and the cultural traditions. The musuem can be easily reached by the MTR, get off at Tsim Sha Tsiu and there will be signs for this particular exit. The Musuem is right opposite the science museum and only 10 HKD for admission.

Great, if history stopped in 1997. This museum gives a panoramic view of Hong Kong history from four million years ago, but then stops at the high point, the handover to mainland China in 1997. That's the end of history, right? What more could you want?At some point, visitors may start to wonder why there is no more history.

Best place to know more of Hong Kong. Hi
Excellent Place to be, to learn the history of Hong Kong, the culture and the people.
Alot of historical things to see.
A definitive place to be when you are in Hong Kong.
Thanks

an insight to HONG kONG. A good place to visit on a rainy day. You need about a half day to enjoy it all. The exhibits are all interesting with lots to read and very colorful. It goes from the beginning to present day and also the occupation and the revert to China rule. As an english pensioner I really enjoyed it and learnt a lot of information. I would certainly go again
A great background on Hong Kong. This museum was very useful and provided some incite into Hong Kongs history. A great taster before hitting the sites. Free on Wednesdays

Been there twice, could go again.. This museum is just fantastic for getting to know about Hong Kong. It is organised into 8 parts and is huge. I didn't take everything in the first time so I have since revisited and I think I would go again. Could easily spend quite a few hours there. On Wednesdays it is free to enter and the rest of the time it is 10HKD for an adult, which is nothing really.The gift shop is pretty good too!

So much more to Hong Kong. One day a week is free, but I'd gladly pay t visit this museum. It is well planned, with Hong Kong's journey through history arranged chronologically. Many of the exhibits are interactive and life sized in realism. Loved the commercial street, bun festival and life of the fishermen. Can be crowded with school children but we last visited on 'free Wednesday' at opening time. Photos can be taken - without a flash. Hong Kong means so much more after a visit to the Museum of History - should be the first destination to inspire where you visit next in HK.

Worth Every Dollar. Going to museums has always been a part of our itinerary everytime we travel. I am especially addicted to history museums and I wasn't disappointed when I went to the HK Museum of History. I got to understand the locals and their culture through their history. The whole trip wasn't boring at all because of the many interactive potions of the trip. I will definitely come back!

We learned a lot!. Definitely worth the trip - especially on Wednesdays when entrance to museums are free! My traveling budding and I learned a lot about Hong Kong at this museum - it was very easy to navigate and organized well for tourists and locals alike - and would highly recommend it for anyone who wants to learn more about Hong Kong. Very glad we went!

A 'must do'. We were recommended to visit the Hong Kong Museum of History by a local who suggested that a tour to the Hong Kong story would help put Hong Kong in context. And 'wow' does it do that. The story starts 400million years ago and takes the visitor almost to the present day.The exhibit is very visual, interactive and expertly curated. The whole story is not a collection of artefacts but and exploration of ways of life and customs of the indigenous peoples of the area.We spent two hours viewing the exhibit and it was two hours very well invested.

Unmissable. Tells the history of Hong Kong brilliantly- you will need at least 3 hours to cover ALL the exhibits. Check out their special exhibitions too... when we were there they had the Mesopotamia exhibition which we had miseed in Melbourne. Avoid the coffee in the cafe- stick to tea.

quite interesting. we visited it in a week day cos once a week it's free of charge. good choice! we enjoyed it. this small country has so much to tell you. it was very impressive the video of the retirement of the british after their reign there. recomended it

Hong Kong Museum of History. Off the tourist track but well worth the walk to find it. Parking very difficult. Modern building that tracks the history of Hong Kong from the Jurassic times to the present day..Reasonable cafe and good toilets.
Lots of interesting HK art. Well laid out and presented place for history and art visitors. Good location to other features on waterfront.

Blasts from the past. On a very stimulating visit of the Island last autumn this place was heavily recommended to me by a long almost lost cousinOnce my wife returned to the coal face that is the big factory in Altona, i knuckled down for a week of climbing stairs, catching ferries and chasing tail (no erase the last bit from your minds)One quite saturday morning i hiked up to this cool museum in Kowloon from the stat ferryA nutritious way to spend half a day- NB. not Japanese friendly

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. Make sure you allow a couple of hours to visit this excellent compilation of the events that helped create Hong Kong as it is today.The museum can be a little tricky to navigate (even if you follow the signs that highlight the various stages in its history), but if you follow along, you leave with a good sense of the development and changes the city went through.If you go on a Wednesday, admission is free.

Quite extensive. Unlike most museums in Hong Kong,the museum of history is actually quite extensive and has adequate amount of visual aids in terms of the history and the cultural backgrounds of the different groups of people living in Hong Kong. It provides a better understanding of what makes the city diverse behind all the layers of concrete and skyscrapers. It is definitely recommended for people who want to understand more the background of Hong Kong and what makes it as it is today.

Better than expected. Another rainy day in HK so I decided to check out the history museum. I was pleasantly surprised! The displays were well done and I learned a great deal about HK. I would recommend going to anyone interested in learning more about HK.
Definitely worthwhile. This a great museum, well presented, lots to see and very educational. One and a half hours to see most of it, but you can spend a lot more time.

Interesting walk through HK history. A fantastic museum showcasing everything from the formation of the land in HK, right up until the present. All displays are informative but interesting for all and it is an enjoyable way to spend a few hours, to a full day easily. As with other museums in HK, the museum entry is free on Wednesday's. Although this doesn't permit entry to any special exhibits, there is more than enough in the main musuem to keep you entertained

Immersive and fun. Great way to spend a few hours. A lot of care and thought was put into this museum and it shows. Taking you through the pre-history of Hong Kong, right up to present day, the museum is interactive, colorful, and fun. Make sure to visit the opera house and take a walk through a house in a traditional fishing village.

Interesting. The exhibit starts out a little slow, I would skip the first floor section on the prehistoric age and geography section. The exhibit get very interesting when you get into the very early settlement days of Hong Kong. Well worth a visit.
Must see attraction. Must allow almost a full day to go through most of the display in this fine facility, very centrally located, friendly staff and best of all cost hardly anything to get in.
Interesting. This is well worth a visit. It takes about a half day out of your trip but is well worth it. Some fascinating exhibits and art. Very enjoyable.

Fascinating and fun for all the family. I love this museum. My only disappointment is that I have only ever visited it as part of an organised school group, accompanying various of my children. I must go back on my own! From the giant diorama of early HK, through the mock ups of life for various ethnic groups, the recreation of HK Iin the early 20th century and the newsreels of more recent HK history, this is a must see for anyone with an interest in how this vibrant city became what it is today.
well presented Mesopotamia exhibit. grabbed a quick hour between meetings and was well rewarded.I am in HK often on business and I always lcheck to see whats showing at this museum

interesting for both locals and tourists. My husband was born in HK (moved to Canada at 10y old) and I'm Canadian, but we both really enjoyed the museum on our last visit to Hong Kong. For both of us, we found the second floor more interesting, which spans from the Opium Wars onward, and in particular the sections on the last 50 years or so, when Hong Kong has changed so quickly. After visiting the museum, my husband spent the evening talking to his mom and aunts and uncles about everything he learned at the museum, despite being "dragged" there by his tourist wife.
great museum. Modern and informative museum. Provided history of Hong Kong in writing and displays with hands on tech too.
Spend some time to appreciate it all. Recreated streets and good exhibits make this a must see for all. i felt I really understood Honk Kong after visiting and what makes it such a unique place.

In Depth Look at Hong Kong's History. We had a couple of hours to kill before our flight and decided to check out the Museum of History. It is very in depth, and I recommend leaving a half day free, if this sort of thing interests you, to really do it justice. It starts with the geological formation of the Hong Kong area right through to the modern day skyscrapers and the handing back of Hong Kong to China in 1997.

Surprisingly good. Visited the museum on a rainy holiday day. The museum is so well thought out, presented and has extensive and interesting exhibits. There are numerous movies you can watch and it gives and excellent and easy to follow history of Hong Kong from geological creation to the treaty with the Commonwealth. We had a 6 year old child with us and she was not bored. On the day we attended it was free access but I think usually there is a nominal fee.Recommend for anyone.
great place to go with family. lots of interesting information about the history of Hong Kong, from how the land form to how hong kong become one of the most important city in the world

Very interesting. Very informative and well done. I learned quite a bit about Hong Kong from centuries ago until present time. I love history and this was quite good. I would recommend it especially on drizzly cloudy day!

A nice surpise. I'm not a big museum person, but was blown away by this museum and ended up spending about 3 hours there. It is about 10 minutes walk from the Hotel Panorama by Rhombus. It is a very well done museum, lots of displays and video presentations. I would definitely recommend fitting this into your schedule if you can - it was well worth it and a pleasant surprise.
excellent museum. Very interesting museum especially the later more recent history section on the upper floors. Allow a good few hours to visit we ran out of time towards the end
Very interesting. My 15 yo son and I visited. The older aged period was not that interesting, but the history of the last 200 years was very informative.

Very informative, comprehensive history of the region. Took advantage of the free Wednesday entry, was suprised it wasnt moe crowded. Spent 2 hours learning Hong Kong history fromprehiwtoric times to present, with highlights being background on the various peoples of the area, their architecture, customs and interaction, and the extremely interesting displays on WWII. ( known throughout China as " The War Against the Japanese. ". The occupation of Hong Kong information presented facts I had never heard of before. additional displays chronicle Hong Kong changes through the decades-- especially familiar was the Chinese entry into plastics and displays of well known childhood toys and icons , especially the Bob's Big Boy figure. There was also a photo pictorial of Chinese immigration to British Columbia in the 1930's that dealt with culture shock in that very different way of life. The museum also had a reataurant area, very clean restrooms on every floor, and a varied museum store.

Excellent Museum. This is one of the best museums I have ever visited. There is a great balance of displays, videos and written material. I stumbled onto the free Wednesday admission and spent a very enjoyable 3 hours there. The museum covers prehistoric times up to the present. Some aspects of Hong Kong's history I was aware of, but I knew very little about Japan's occupation of the city. The museum does a nice job of covering it all. The science museum is right next door.To get there, follow the signs at The MTR in TST and you will walk right to it.

Great Interactive Museum - Free on Wednesday!. This was a must-see for me on my visit to Hong Kong. The museum is very interactive and literally walks you through the history of the area. Every room has re-constructed buildings/displays from a time in HK history. I especially appreciated the complexity and curation of the imperial rule area as well as the buildings/boats(!) you could walk through from the original cultures who lived in the HK area. If you've been to the Museum of Civilizations in Ottawa it has a very similar feel. Also it's free on Wednesdays, although the regular fee is not high. While in the area take in the Science Museum, which is located on the same grounds.
Great value. $10 entry fee and an excellent travel through Hong Kong history. You need to allow 1 -2 hours as there is a lot covered and the exhibits are eye catching.
Engaging museum. Learned a lot about the history of Hong Kong and the people who live there. Beautiful displays showing cultural heritage and a lot of interesting videos too. Well worth visiting.

Very Informative. Museum is very organize and huge. You need around 2-3 hours if you want to see everything. There are small documentary movies/presentations on each section for about 10 min. in Three Languages. The lighting is dim through out the museum so you need to use your flash if you need to take good pictures. You are not allowed to use stands or tripods in the Museum. If you have kids, you may visit the Science Museum next door. They will have fun. Admission is free on Wednesdays!
Great place. I went there and had treasures of Babylon and entrance fee only HKD 10. Really enjoyed exhibition and the rest of the musuem is good. Dont forget nearby Science Museum.
Great overview of Hong Kong. I found that the time I spent in this museum allowed be to better put into context all that I experienced during my trip.

Best Museum in Hong Kong. They offer English language tours in both the mornings and afternoons, so check their website if you'd like a guided tour in English. We (two adults, one teen, one child) went through in about two and half hours (not enough time in my opinion) without the tour, but the displays were phenomenal. Everyone loved it, it was one of the real highlights of our trip.
Outstanding Museuem. I was ignorant of the Hong Kong history until I visited this. I want to squeeze in another visit on my next trip
Great for Children. The museums in HK are great for children they are very interactive and a great place to avoid rainy days.

Outstanding quality. It was comprehensive. Quality exhibits, engaging atmosphere. Something for everyone. We enjoyed it, our child enjoyed it. Free wi-fi was a nice touch. The staff outstanding. Restaurant served good tea and very good food. There were good activities for children and the shop was good too.What was there not to like. We happened to go on a Wednesday when the entry was free too. Would recommend as a great day out. It is well signposted and a short walk from number of metro stations.

Introduction to Hongkong. It' free on Wednesday.i took my children first day in hongkong so they can learn the history of HK. Walkable from Tsim sha tsui Mtr. I suggest one day tour include HK science museum ( in front ) , avenue of star, star fery and Victoria harbour
All you nee3d to know about HK in 1 hr. Great stories about HK in the 1950s to present day. Not interested in HK during its formative years during the Jurassic and Devonian eras.

a really inexpensive and educational treat for adults and kids. This museum is ridiculously inexpensive at about $11HK per adult. It has a good summary about Hong Kong's past, and is a good site to spend some time in case it rains, for both adults and kids.

Museum facilites are not up to the standard of the exhibits. A museum may well be a full day experience or at least an afternoon which may mean a trip to the washrooms and getting a bite to eat. Here is where the let down is as the restrooms are way to small for the demand. The cleanliness factor was OK. The food at the refreshment counter is limited, often sold out without a notice, slow and unappetizing. So bring your own lunch, skip drinking a lot of liquids before your visit, or plan to leave after a couple of hours and you will have a very interesting time, especially the permanent exhibition, "The Hong Kong Story" which gives a fascinating glimpse of what this area was like from ancient times, through prehistoric, to dynastic and folk cultures. Bravo for this! The visiting Mesopotamia exhibition was of high quality as was the earlier one on Terracotta Warriors.

A really good way to learn about the history of Hong Kong.. We had one half of a morning to spend in this Museum so we decided to concentrate on the exhibit which concentrates of the history of HK, and we were delighted with the choice! The exhibition starts at the prehistoric stage and ends at the handover of HK to China in 1997. The story is told with the help of some wonderful displays. Those that we particularly enjoyed were the cases of opium and the super depiction of the harbour at the height of its trading importance. The illustrations of the governors seemed to end before Governor Patten which was curious since the handover was dealt with in some detail. We combined this visit with one to the Heritage Museum in New Territories and they complemented one another well, albeit with some inevitable overlap. A great way to learn about HK, and not just for those who are dedicated history enthusiasts.

Surprisingly wonderful!. We ended up here after neglecting to read that the Science Museum is closed on Thursdays. What an absolute delight! Staff were welcoming, friendly and incredibly helpful. They had storage cubicles for backpacks, and a wheelchair for our tired child (with a broken foot in an aircast). The permanent exhibit "Hong Kong" was interactive and informative. We also purchased tickets to the "Mesopotamia" exhibit (a joint venture with the British Museum) and were impressed with the quality of the exhibit. It was great for kids and adults. And the cost of both exhibits for a family of 3? $55HKD. A steal for 4 hours entertainment! A visit we would holy recommend!
History of Hong Kong and Mesopotamia. Enjoyed the Mesopotamia exhibit but really enjoyed the history of Hong Kong. After spending a few days touring the island it answered a lot of questions.

Pick out things you like. The prehistoric until today's history and culture is explained and displayed in an excellent way. Pass by whst you're not so interested in. Learn a lot about the changing political cicumstances in 20th century. After that we went to the science museum; since I was with children aged 4 and 8.

Good museum that offer the history of H.K.. It was a great museum for the history buffs. All the H.K. museums are free on Wednesdays. It is located across the Science Museum and is worthwhile going to both.

Interesting exhibition. The story of Hong Kong is beautifully developed in this museum. It is interesting to be taken through its fishing village past to its present day status as an international city of importance. I particularly enjoyed the section on the British rule and the Japanese occupation.

Appreciating Hong Kong's culture and history. The permanent exhibition on the story of Hong Kong is excellent. I particularly enjoyed the sections relating to the geology of Hong Kong and the post-1800 era history (and the Opium War). I have been surprised by the level of detail provided and have visited this exhibition twice although ran out of time on both occasions. You need to set yourself a minimum of 3-4 hours just for this exhibition. It really is a great way to gain an appreciation of Hong Kong before touring the specific cultural sites.
too short visit. what I like HK's museum is its sooo huge! I was not able to check everything since its almost closing time when I went there. But will comeback for sure.

A Great Place To Learn About HK's Past History. I'm not usually a museum kind of guy, but thought that for a close in town excursion, it would be a good place to go. In the end, it was exactly that. The best thing was that it was only a short walk from my hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui on Nathan Road so that made for extra convenience as well. Anyways, the museum was set up very well and you can learn alot about the past history of HK, traditions, like weddings and festivals, food, and even the natural environs that HK was surrounded in many many years ago.  The displays are very well presented and one can easily spend a bit of time learning and gazing at all that is withheld in this museum.  Best of all, entrance to this museum for a single adult is only $10HK.

Visit for viewi the past to the present. Location - quite a distance from TST MTR so you will need to walk a fair distance. It is just opposite the science museum. We visited on a Thursday, the science museum is closed so we visited the history museum instead. Admission price is cheap (adult HKD10, kids HKD5) and well worth it for the kidsExhibits - there are 7 main exhibits area spread over two floors. From 400 million years ago to the present when HK is returned to China. My kids are specially interested in the animals replicas there. there is also a special exhibit for an additional feeShould you go? With kids - yes, other interests, look at rock exhibits, HK culture and modern history - yes, especially if you combine the visit with the science museum
A marriage of culture & history. This is a very good museum to visit with children, It is small enough to hold the children's interest and it is not too big to be intimidating.
A Glance of Yesterday Hong Kong. A starting point of learning Hong Kong history of past centuries, how a fishing village developed to an international city.
Well worth a visit. Great place to learn the history of Hong Kong.Visitors with children will find lot's of things for them to do.

some significant gaps. This is a large and modern museum which claims to be telling the history of hong Kong.however I saw very little about the development of the port under british rule.also there was no mention of the fact that many people fled to hong Kong after 1945 to flee from the communists.maybe I missed it because the upper galleries are so poorly laid out.there is no clear indication where to go next.it is though certainly worth a visit.

A Treat in Kowloon. This large, multi-faceted museum brings you close to understanding the geological and cultural underpinnings of what has become Hong Kong. It's many sections, together, require a stay of many hours, if you really want to gain a comprehenive sense of what this unique area is all about. It's a bit of a walk from the Nathan Road MTR train stations closest to it, but well worth it. There is a small restaurant, as I recall. It is clear that much effort, and expense, has gone into estabilsihg and filling this space with area artifacts. I don't know if it is high on the tourist list of things to see and do, but it should be.

Excellent Attraction for Anyone Wanting to Learn about Hong Kong. We originally went for a visit just intending it to be a short time filler in our itinerary (and it was on the free day as well) but ended up spending nearly most the day at this exhibit. It is wonderfully presented and gives you a wonderful overview of Hong Kong's past - from pre-historic days (and the weather and environment that led to the formation of Hong Kong) through to the Opium Wars and British sovereignty and finally to modern Hong Kong. The earlier parts, although informative, wern't as interesting as the latter parts (i.e. pre-Opium war).Considering that they allow free entry on certain days (check their website), I would highly recommend the Hong Kong Museum of History and their "Hong Kong Story" exhibit! Plan about 3-5 hours if you truely want to go slowly, otherwise you can probably get through it in an hour and half.

Skip the boring bits... Went here on the Wednesday (which is free) after it was closed on Tuesday. Bored with parts 1-4, but enjoyed 5 onwards, was mainly interested in the British and Japanese era's which I found interesting. They have an Egyptian exhibition on for a limited time for an extra fee, but I didn't go in having been to Egypt in '08.

Worth it. Excellent place to visit. If youre a person that must visit museums as u travel...this is a must go.The whole visit will take u approx 3 - 4 hours if u want to see everything. U can do this in 1hr if u are pressed for time
One of our usual pitstops. Discovered this on a previous trip. Made sure we visited this again so our kids can get a feel for our culture.Good fun for the kids

A Great Comprehensive Museum. I went for a few hours and spent the whole day. This is a well designed, interesting and beautiful museum. The exhibits show the history of the city from prehistoric time to the hand over to China. The exhibits are world class. I live near and frequent the Smithsonian and this is on a par. It was not crowded on a weekday. There is a variety of natural ethnic, religious and political history in colorful and fascinating vignettes, replicas, photos, all kinds of depictions of their subjects. It is an orderly and well cared for collection and facility. The restaurant is not so good. food was not that great service was rude.

Free entrance on wednesday!. A very thorough account on Hong Kong history. From 400 million years Bc till 1997 in film and display. Have to say that the displays of villages and shopping streets are legendary. Defenitly a must do when you're staying in Hong Kong!
The museum of science is nextdoor, but closed on thursdays...
Awesome.... Spent 2 and a half hours there... especially loved the second floor with the old HSBC bank notes, and the bus.. huge collection, and worth a visit.

A walk to remember. We visited this marvellous museum on a Wednesday and hence, we entered for free. Situated in the heart of the city and within walking distance from the MTR, this museum brought us back to the past of Hong Kong. I found the audio-visual particularly useful as the tourist were informed of life-changing events in Hong Kong. Also, we could see many local visitors indulging themselves in their own history. And today, I dare to announce to the world at large that I have known Hong Kong better, by merely spending an afternoon in this museum.
Science museum win. My 9yo and I visited this museum on a hot afternoon and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. The range of exhibits was impressive with many of them being interactive. We had a blast.

Hong Kong Museum of History. We were told by someone who lives in H k to visit this museum the history was great with lots of interesting sections the large displays .we spent 3 hours there in a busy city .
Fantastic!!!. We spent 4hrs in the museum it was brilliant, Such a great insight into the old Hong Kong, you must watch the film they show on how HK has changed over the years.

Must see if you like Hong Kong. I went to see it on Wednesday when it's free and I can tell it is a must see if you are a bit interested in the history of Hong Kong. From the first tectonic movements until the British hand over, you can get a real insight into the history of Hong Kong and the traditions of it's people.

HK Museum of History.. We were walking in the beautiful park and passed by the museum, and decided to have a look inside, we spend almost 2 hours and were very impressed about the history and the presentation. worth to pay a visit, free entrance!

Great Story of Hong Kong. The Story of Hong Kong is well told in photos and exhibits. The current exhibition in the foyer of the history of Chinese settlers in Barkerville (B.C.) is also interesting. The early settlers worked so hard and some of them were real entrepreneurs, unlike the current generation who get everything handed on a plate.

Very expensive set up. I was not expecting much, I paid about $2 US dollars to go in but it turns out the museum is very well set up. It has a Disney display like setting, all the "sets" are huge and life like. This would be a good history museum to bring a child, it really brings to life Hong Kong in every era. You can walk through the old life-size recreated shipyard, jail, bank, or neolithic site. They spent a lot of money on this museum no doubt.
a must in hk. wednesdays are free, but every day is worth it. take 1-2 hours to learn a bit about the place, from the geology to the WWII experience it is interactive and informative

History of Hong Kong very well done. We spent about 2-3 hours there and probably could have spent more. A great history of the city of Hong Kong. There was another exhibit there but we ran out of energy. Nominal price for all. Everything in Hong Kong is easy to get to either by metro, ferry , bus, tram or inexpensive taxis.

Fascinating. This is a really good way to get an overview of Hong Kong, not just its history but also it's geology, wildlife and culture. There are some excellent displays and enough material to fill half a day if you do it thoroughly. Highly recommended.

A must see. This was not in our expected plans, but was recommended by the hotel. The museum is full of facts all written in English and tells the fascinating story of how Hong Kong came to be as we know it today. Definitely worth a morning or afternoon visit.

Learning History. all is just fine , we need to learn other countries culture and history, thus visitng the museum teaches us the culture of one country or places and this is a big opportunity to see and be educated through these facility and i like it very much.more knowledge was added and learned.

Worth a visit. Gave a great history of hong kong and would recommend a visit for a couple of hours especially if first trip to hong kong. Gave me a much better understanding of the trials and tribulations of hong kong
History & culture appreciation . Worth a visit if you have an extra hour or two. However do not eat in te adjacent restaurant on the ground floor! We got a club sandwich that left much to be desired!

Get the full picture on HK's history. When the exhibit starts with a sign that says "400,000,000 years ago", you know it's going to be thorough. The prehistory is interesting, but I found the 19th and 20th Century rooms to be the best, with recreations of traditional tea rooms and market shops. A great rainy day option
So interesting.. The history of HK is currently showing. Wonderful dioramas, films, sets that you can walk into. Just go.

very well presented, entertaining, and informative. i'm not big on spending lots of time in museums and i'm not a history buff, but this exhibit is so well created i ended up spending hours in there without noticing time go by. i learned a LOT about HongKong in a very entertaining way

Must visit!. I have visited this place 4 times! I still don't mind to pay another visit. The place has a very large area showing you the geology of HK (HK has every kind of rock formation in the world!) It shows the natural history and exhibits local pre-historic findings. There is a large area of mock up showing the living condition in HK through its history. It gives me a feeling of traveling back into one of those old black-and-white movie. If you come to HK, take two hours and go through the museum. You will find the experience most worthy.
Actually Really Really Good. great insight into china history and in most languages - Would recommend and its a welcome break from the sometimes very hot close weather

Depends on how long you are in Hong Kong. The HK museum of history is interesting to go and visit but it really depends on how long you are in HK. If you have 1-2 weeks it is worth a look see but if you are only there for 2-3 days then it's not worth it as there are so many other better places to go in HK.Of course the history is interesting and I always love to know a little of history of place I visit so on that note - not bad to see... but it really depends on how much time you are staying in HK.

First rate history museum. I had time off and it was a rainy day- two things that point to a museum day. It was fairly easy to find, nice grounds, and the displays were amazing. A good timeline of HK and the different cultures that exist there. I recommend it anyone who is in HK.

Culture and History appreciation. The Hong Kong history museum shows you how Hong Kong was transformed from virtually nothing to the world city it is today. There are 6 areas spanning prehistoric to modern present times. Instead of reading each description in every exhibit, a tourist should just watch the videos in each area in order to save time in learning the history and culture.One lesson to be learned here is that Hong Kong was once a poor country. It took a lot of hard work and cooperation to make it what it is today. All the trials that Hong Kong underwent including drugs, typhoons, droughts, war, scandals, 1997 turnover were shown in this museum. After going to this museum, you will appreciate Hong Kong better.

interesting snapshot. It starts all the way from prehistoric times and is like said, pretty complete.The museum is easy to findIt provides a really interesting snapshot of what Hong Kong was like throughout time - from the ancient civilisations to modern times.

Worth a Visit. This museum has a lot of interesting information on the history of Hong kong, specially the different people who inhabited the region, the opium wars and japanese domination. Personally, I would recommend having a quick look at the first location (pre-history) and paying more attention to the others.

excellent way to learn about HK's history. I didn't have a clue about Hong Kong's history when we arrived in this fantastic city except from what I had read in my guide. So it was quite naturally that we decided to visit Hong Kong Museum of History. We did a one hour long guided tout with a friendly and witty guide who spoke english very well and who did such a great job that we decided to come back the following day so we could spend more time on particular chapters. The entry fee is cheap (10HK $), so we did not hesitate. There are many movies shown im multiple languages or with subtitle.The way the city's fascinating development is told is pedagogical and amusing. If you look this at is with critical (european) eyes, some propagandistic / chauvinistic insistances could be unveiled... But I guess this is a natural tendency in museums of history around the world. The props and the decor are really looking authentic!

Great for learning. We went here during our trip in HK last Nov. 2012. Admission fee is HK$ 10 for adults and HK$ 5 for kids. Our first plan was to visit the Science Museum because it is close to Hotel Benito where we stayed. Unfortunately it was closed during our visit so we opted for the Museum of History. At first we thought it as just so-so but when we explored the inside, we were fascinated by the vast collection of artifacts and displays. We learned the origin of HK and their culture plus their way of life during the old times. We didn't get to explore the whole place for we were not expecting it to be huge and we're already hungry come lunch time. Truly it was a wonderful way to learn more about Hong Kong.

Worth 2 hours of a trip to HK. Skip the first 4 rooms, which are the geology of the area, and get to the human history part of the museum. Wonderful pictures and recreations of street scenes from different historical periods. It is amazing to see how fast the city has changed. Entirely different place when comparing 1960 to 2013..

An immersive historical experience. I visited the museum on a Wednesday, when admission is free. There were a few school groups, but they mostly congregated towards the Museum of Science, on the other side of the complex. The main exhibition is called "The Hong Kong Story" and traces Hong Kong's history from prehistory all the way up to the transfer of Hong Kong from the British colonial rule to China. It's a well-curated experience that highlights a lot of the essential historial points, filling in the many holes a tourist or visitor might have in understanding the complex and colorful past that makes Hong Kong special.

A little bit of Culture. Amazing stuff in there. the civilization is so old!!! seeing the timeline going back several years BC was amazing and their craftmanship is aplaudable given that in those time they did not have modern day machinery to help them make those ceramics and jewelry. Calliograpy is also amazing to see. thousgh i didnt understand it at all. My interest in Japanese culture from earlier trips helps me appreciate this particular tradition though....truly mesmering

Nice museum. Went there to read up on Hong Kong's history as I had enough walking through the shopping streets and I wasn't disappointed. It starts all the way from prehistoric times and is like said, pretty complete. Had to rush my visit though as I went in with 90 minutes to go till closing time so if you want a real good look at the place, do plan more time for it.One thing: when walking from the Austin Road I couldn't see where the entrance was. An extra sign would be ideal. It would have saved me a walk around the back (or maybe I simply missed the sign)

Don't miss it!. If you have to choose only one museum in HK, go for this. The place has an excellent curator and is a lot of fun, showing from the geographic formation to folklore and contemporary days. Save at least two to three hours to this museum and make sure you don't miss the opium war section. You'll learn a lot about HK and China history.

Museum. For someone who's interested in getting to know the Countrys Culture this place is great You'll learn a lot from it. We went here together with a tour guide , it'll take you more than an hour or so to have a good look at the artifacts but since I was soo excited to go on shopping already it bored me right away (No offense!)It's just a walk away from Hotels and Boutiques and local restaurant It's in a very good location easy to find Been here June 2008

One of THE best history museums I've visited. I LOVED the Hong Kong Museum! I entered, not knowing what to expect or, for that matter, much about Chinese history. I left, hours later, informed, entertained, delighted. The museum takes you from the geographic formation of Hong Kong through each of the settling and original peoples [replete with life size dioramic room settings] through the Opium Wars and on to current times, inclusive of how Western culture influenced the Chinese. The exhibits were detailed, absorbing and vibrant. My only negative comment has to be about the snack bar. The food paled [literally and figuratively] to the museum. Don't bother to have more than tea. Also, the gift store was very unorganized, staffed by rather unfriendly women.

Great museum - especially the section on the recent colonial history.. I've been twice to this museum and could happily go back again. It's done out really well, with reconstructions of buildings, boats and even a tram. I found the upper floors most interesting which cover the colonial history of HK, through the Second World War and the Japanese invasion up to the handover to China. There are some good videos covering key parts of HK history.

This is brilliant - a good half day. The museum is easy to find - just off Chatham Road South - via a walk way and opposite the museum of Science. It works through the time line history of Hong Kong starting with the ice age and working through with loads of displays, artifacts, films, - in fact there is so much its amazing. All in English and chinese - very enjoyable - so much that we forgot how long we had been in there. Don't miss their own little cafe after your visit - excellent food at a very reasonable price

Great for history buffs. I had a ton of fun at this museum. My advice: go on a Wednesday when it's free. I'm Chinese but honestly know very little about my own culture so it was nice to walk around the room recreations and pour through the details. If you're into history, you could spend hours inside this museum and not get bored at all.
Brilliant introduction to the city. WELL worth a walk into Kowloon Park to visit - take the time to watch some of the videos as well as look at the artifacts and displays.

Worth a visit - give yourself plenty of time. Having enjoyed HK's food and shopping on a few different visits, I am glad we visited the museum this time around. It's built like a timeline, starting with prehistoric times and ending with the handover to China. The first few sections of the visit, complete with caveman exhibits have you worried about the quality of the experience. By the time your through these first sections, the quality picks up considerably and the experience is a good one. A great combination of traditional Chinese culture and an interesting look at the impact of the Opium Wars and the British occupation that followed. An enjoyable days rest from food and shopping!

Best part of our trip. We visited the Museum of History as an afterthought on our recent Hong Kong holiday, and actually ended up being the best part of it! It provides a really interesting snapshot of what Hong Kong was like throughout time - from the ancient civilisations to modern times. Perhaps not for small children, especially if you would like to take a bit more time reading and learning.
Excellent Museum. More of us should visit this more often. Well worth a visit - especially replica street and some of stories of hong kong's complex history - some of it contested!!!

Comprehensive and unbiased look at the history of HongKong. This superb museum is located a short walk away from the Tsim Sha Sui Metro station. Not too big, not too small and a great bargain for $10. Through 8 galleries, it covers the story of HK from prehistoric times to the current post-handover era. Each gallery is really well presented, with a very good mix of real artefacts, models and movies. There is a theatre in most galleries showing short movies. What I really liked is the unbiased view of history. Unlike museums in China, there is no Chinese propaganda here. In fact they have a very honest assessment of the shortcomings of the Chinese Imperial forces and the Imperial policies leading up to the Opium wars and the subsequent British takeover of HK. It deals even-handedly with the Japanese occupation during 1941-1945, and also with the handover to China in 1997. The handover ceremony is still fresh in many minds, and the displays with various invitation cards, newspaper reports etc are particularly poignant. The only topic that is not delved into is HK’s relationship with mainland China since the handover and the thorny political issues, but to be fair, these topics are perhaps current affairs rather than history. The shop has a useful collection of books, old HK postage stamps along with some of the usual tourist tat.

Extraordinary travel through time. This is a brilliant display of Hong Kong history from its geology and geography right through its various periods - with dioramas, movies, video clips, recreation of shops, houses, streets in various periods . it is divided into 6 different periods all well signposted and excellently curated. Allow at least half a day. Well worth a visit.

Very almost-comprehensive history of Hong Kong. Geology, ancient and medieval historical parts - fantastic. Very detailed, very interesting exhibits. Lots about the various Chinese peoples who came to live in this area. Then upstairs for the British 'occupation'.... oh dear. Very good exhibits, loads of mock-up interiors, but somehow... somehow the benefits for Hong Kong of being a British colony were... forgotten. Just not spoken of. One was given the strong impression that the British had done virtually nothing good for this place. I suppose it's to be expected, given that this is now part of China again, but the anti-British mood was quite uncomfortable. Hard to point at something and say 'See, here? THIS is propaganda, THIS is wrong', but the whole exhibit from the British period gave no positive information. It was rather sad.

Great exhibit and good location for Kowloon Business district. Good 1 hour tour and overview of old and new Hong Kong; special exhibit unique to Hong Kong. Special exhibits need additional ticket; but the permanent exhibit is very well done.

i enjoyed even if i went alone. I remember going here alone. My partner had a business meeting so I have free time to myself that I decided to check this out. It was within bearable walking from our hotel. Anyway, I enjoyed it seeing HOng Kong history unfolding through artifacts, pictures, etc.The place is not crowded when I went, so i had all time to check it out.

Very good and quite large. Very good content and well presented. The topics on the first floor did not interest me much but Upstairs has content from the Opium wars to today and was very interesting. Very well priced at @25HKD a head, but the best value is the 50HKD 6mth pass which gets you into pretty much every museum in HK for 6mths.

Take the guided tour....90 minutes well spent!. We visited the museum on a Saturday. It was not crowded and we arrived in time to take the guided tour in English at 10:30.The guide gave us an overview of what the museum had to offer. It was a very balanced view of Hong Kong history from ancient times until today. The museum has a very impressive collection laid out in a chronological pattern that flows very well. Definitely worth a visit!
fair. worth with the admission fee. they have some unique display. good toknow and add your experience while in there

Very good, everything about HK in one place. I like this place. It was filled with history and information on HK past. And it's pretty cheap. Think 20 HKD for the visit. On other days it would even be free. The museum is split into 2 main levels, and each level has many exhibitions and screen a number of films relating to the theme that they wish to illustrate on. I liked the exhibitions on the opium war and the world war. Definitely worth a visit. Very clean and everything is in English and Chinese. If you were to visit a museum in China, probably everything would be in Chinese.

Interesting place if you like to know HK history! Great service!. Like everything about. Lots of expositions and movies about HK history in both languages. Worth to visit. The price is cheap, the service is the best.

A Must See. I've been visiting HK for many years and only got to visit the Museum last year. There is a minimal entrance fee, about £1 I think. In short it's a great way to understand HK's history and culture, with some really good displays. Don't miss it.

Extensive review of HK history. The exhibition starts with geological history of the Hong Kong area which we found a bit boring. However, issues get very much more interesting towards the end of the exhibition when it starts covering more recent history of the area. Unfortunately, we ran short of time and had to rush through much of the interesting stuff. Reserve 3-4 hours for the visit!Highly recommended for a rainy day if you are interested in HK history!
Informative about the history of HK. Spent a rainy day at the museum and learned a lot about HK.No need to spend an entire day but it's worth a couple of hours.

A Fantastic Way to Spend a Day!. Especially if it is wet, or sweltering hot outside! For the HK$10 (US$1.25) admission price, you are treated to a comprehensive history of Hong Kong and the Pearl River Delta region. There are exhibits on habitat, geology, native peoples, culture, Chinese history, British/European History, Industry, Maritime History, and more. Like the signage, there are short video shows in Cantonese and in English. For the videos, just ask the door monitor at the theaters for the language of the next show. You can easily spend all day in the museum, and you might not see it all. On Wednesday's you can enter for free. If you will be in Hong Kong for more than 3 or 4 days, and wish to visit other museums, spend the HK$30 (US$3.75) for the week-long pass, good at most, but not all of the museums in Hong Kong.When I visited, July 2012, there was a separate, temporary exhibition featuring Terra Cotta Warriors, on loan from Xi'an in the PRC. In that exhibition, you got to participate in interactive displays, walk through a multimedia show that was spectacular, and view many different examples of the Terra Cotta Warriors. Entirely worth the extra HK$10 admission.

Excellent exhibition on first emperor. Interactive display was most interesting and at $10hk for entry unbelievable value. A lot of school students were there on the day we visited but still quite orderly.

Informative, classy and very thoughful. If you like history! this is one you must not miss! Very well organized. Excellent facilities, clean, peaceful. Pls ensure you have enough time on your side to patiently walk through history of hong kong right from its evolution! Thought provoking! Will visit again to see their innovative themes!

Very impressed with the knowledge present of Hong Kong. Pamphlet said to give it 2 hours and 4 hours later we were done. It covers the history of Hong Kong from prehistoric man to present. Very enlightening in a very entertaining way.

Very interesting. After having spent almost 4 months in HK, I decided to go to the Museum.The museum is really good! The exhibition is separated into 8 parts (from the early beginnings of the world ~4.5bn years ago until today).The first part is not really relevant for HK history in my eyes. The other parts are pretty good and many exhibits and photos with descriptions help you to get in touch with HK and its history and culture.The entrance fee is only 10 HKD (on Wed for free I think).Take your time to go there. We arrived at 5 pm and the museum closed at 7 pm. I think you need at least 3 or 4 hours to get a good overview!The museum shop is definitely overpriced. But it doesn't matter I think.My visit was really good and the museum is a must visit for people who spend more than 1 week in HK.

Great museum for a rainy day. We had great plans for the day until the heavens opened and I noticed we were close to the Hong Kong Museum of history. Although my daughter of 7 had gone in rather reluctantly she loved it. Beautiful museum, full of fascinating facts and displays.

Must see when u r in HK. Nice place and clean. Easy to get there. it is near the Hong Kong Public Library and Hong Kong Polytechnic University. It was worth the pay for $10 it has three floors of history in it, historic hong kong, the making of hong kong, current hong kong and other cultures in hong kong.It was great to see lots of colorful designs in the mini city street that they created in the museum. In short Hong Kong's history from ancient times to the present in all the details! Great job

Must see when in Hong Kong. If you in Hong Kong you must see this museum. It's about Hong Kong at the beginning. Nice place and clean. It is also easy to get there. MTR Tsim Sha Tsui Exit B2 walk along cameron road to Chatam Rd South turn to the left you will find the bridge beyond the road. You just walk on the bridge you will find it. After satisfied to look around you can get lunch at Guangdong Roasted Pork at Cameron Road. So yummy and tasty.

Guided tour + more time to explore. We did the Story guided tour in English, which was a whirlwind tour from pre-history to present. Good to have extra time afterwaard to go back and review some of the exhibits and see some of the video presentations. Excellent musem!

Wednesday is free. Not a great exhibit, not a bad one either. I was born & raised in HK, so I do relate to the history a little better than most foreigners. However, it will give most visitors a sense of how Hong Kong became a British Colony.
About HK history. Went there in the morning, around 10am. No crowd at all. All the staff in the museum are really friendly and proactive.

Awesome Museum. Well, we're not really familiar of the location, so we walked but the thing that I remembered is, it is near the Hong Kong Public Library and Hong Kong Polytechnic University. It was worth the pay for $10 it has three floors of history in it, historic hong kong, the making of hong kong, current hong kong and other cultures in hong kong. It was quite a lot of walking, but its really worth it. There was also short movies for additional info. It is also good that most of the personnel can speak and understand english, (because I cannot speak their native language hehe). It was great to see lots of colorful designs in the mini city street that they created in the museum.

Charming way to spend an afternoon. I've been to HK 7 times over the last 12 years and it's my first visit. Oh dear! I think I spent too much time in the malls. I had nothing to do one day and my hotel was a short 5min walk away. I walked into this gem of a place that cost hk$10 and spent the next 2 hours peacefully and enjoyably reading about HK's history and enjoying taking photos of the cute exhibits and sets. The videos are great too and I totally relived my childhood at the video on entertainment and drama. I loved seeing Chow Yun Fatt on screen in his Man in the Net days. So handsome. Totally my idea of the model HK man! Definitely a good way to spend a few hours away from the crowd and when you are tired of shopping. A great introduction for first time visitors and for frequent visitors like me, a re-introduction to HK history.

An interesting introduction to Hong Kong history. This museum covers the history of Hong Kong from the very beginning, from prehistoric to present. It has lots of interesting artefacts and displays and provided an engaging couple of hours out of the rain. The museum might not be great for young children as there is lots of writing but there are some more things to keep them interested like boats you can go into and reconstructed shops.It's free on Wednesday and inexpensive on other days 5-10 HKD

A lively exhibit of Hong Kong's History!. This is a well-executed museum that thoroughly documents HK's history; from the early days, to the British colonial era, the Japanese Occupation, the post-industrial era and up until the handover of 1997.Real life replicas and reproductions of an entire street during the early 20th century is exhibited; allowing visitors to really get a sense of what Hong Kong was like in the early days. Well documented photographs along with artifacts, recorded stories and short films all contribute towards an excellent museum.This museum is especially great for teaching young generations (especially those with Hong Kong ancestry, but born abroad), as I've noticed parents and grand parents take pride in telling their own stories to their children. I saw grandparents point at photographs, telling their children that's exactly what life was like, or some even recognized the street or store front!!This is probably one of the better museums in Hong Kong, and should not be missed for visitors or even locals who live in the area.This is suppose to be a 'sister' museum to the Heritage Museum located in Sha Tin (which documents the development of the New Territories). However, I found that museum quite lacking in the excitement and engagement. I would recommend this museum rather than the heritage museumThe museum is all in English and Chinese; and the films alternate between English, Cantonese and Mandarin, and is located in East Tsim Tsai Shui and next to the Science Museum.

Excellent museum, shouldn't be missed. Having been to Hong Kong several times over the last 2 years, I was wondering if there was anything worth seeing in the city that I had not yet visited. This time, as one of the perks offered on a recent conference trip, I took up the offer of a free visit (courtesy of a coupon from the Hong Kong tourism office).My initial impression was that the museum tried to include too much information. The exhibits started with the earth's creation and geological history, then moving on to its ecosystem (huh?)and neolithic man. But it started to liven up when the exhibits detailed the Yue people of southern China before going more in depth into the various Chinese dynasties. But where the museum really came into its own were the descriptions of the arrival of western civilisations that led to the Opium Wars and the creation of 'proper' Hong Kong. There were very good displays on the people that settled in the area (Punti, Hakka, Hoklo & the boat dwellers), their lifestyles and traditions. There was a terrific section on life in Hong Kong from the 1920s (including the Japanese occupation) and its modernisation, ending with its unification to China in 1997. Exhibits were varied, ranging from static displays to dioramas and mock-ups, as well as interactive walk-throughs and regular video shows.For me, this museum was proof that Hong Kong has a very good cultural attraction that is different from its usual set of distractions (shopping, eating, nightlife). It was well worth my time (about 4 hours) - Hong Kong should be proud of this museum.
better. I fine the museum much better now i went couple year ago but decide to go again with the child and is much better now it a niece place to lear about our culture.

Good to visit. The museum is about the local geography, culture and history of Hong Kong, which is quite different from mainland China. The museum doesn't have any new stuff (it is pretty much the same as the one in 2007), but it is well maintained and doesn't feel old or worn down at all. And for just $30 HKD ($4) you can visit 7 different museums in a week. Everything is available in Chinese and English. This one is certainly one of the best museum to visit.

Very insightful. This is a must for visitors to Hong Kong. From the Jurassic period to the present - it has an extremely comprehensive array of exhibits and you could easily spend the best part of a day here.

Good way to connect to Hong Kong. I'd been to Hong Kong once before, and for all its modernity, I was rather sad that much of its history had been lost beneath the skyscrapers. Visiting this excellent museum in November certainly helped connect to HK's past, and gave a context for present and future developments. Our cruise-ship visit was on a Wednesday when admission charges were free to both this museum and the science museum. The 'Terracotta soldiers' exhibition was next door and cost about one UK pound and was brilliant. I also visited a heritage centre in converted army barracks in the centre of Kowloon Park which was good, emphasising the importance of preserving both western and chinese historic buildings. For me the History Museum was the pick, and many of the displays quite beautiful. Well done to all involved.

Shouldn't miss this !. You can easily spend half a day in this museum. Highly enjoyable. You can combine the to the museum with strolling in jade market (they are not a real jade, btw), then go to ladies market/night market which open from 3 pm. Then on the way back, stroll at the Kowloon promenade and watch symphony of the light at 8 pm. You will then have a complete Kowloon experience.

Informative, interesting and engaging.. I'm normally bored silly in city museums - unless it's experiments, videos and computer. However, even though this museum details the history of Hong Kong, it's absolutely fascinating. The weather was atrocious back in April, so we actually spent 5 hours split over 2 afternoons in this museum - but I'm sure you could do it in 2 hours if you rushed.The English language displays are written really well, there's lots to see, huge statues, realistic boats, costumes - plus there's a number of theatres showing short films about a variety of topics - well worth seeing.My favourite part was the mock traditional street, complete with shops that you can go inside and a tram at the far end. Don't miss the huge theatre at the end before you take the escalator down, which has a brilliant film about the 'handing back' of Hong Kong.

If you only visit one museum, This is the one. Very well presented history of Hong Kong and details of the Japanese occupation. Hong Kong had a brillant education system until the occupation. Check opening hours as they may have changed.

Watch out for the school visit. We arrived at the museum just at the same time as coach loads of 5-7 years old school kids who had no interest in the museum, much more fun to run full belt shouting your heads off. Thus we had a very noisy visit, but still we took 2.5 hours to wonder through the exhibits. And we both enjoyed it.
wished we had more time. Should spend an entire day there! So much Hong Kong history to discovered - admission only HKD10... Next time we will spend more than an hour and half there.

One of the best museums.. Granted, it's not the archeological treasure trove that is the British museum or the size of the Smithsonian, but this museum is still massive! There is an entire neighborhood recreated in this museum, including wares from the original shops! My wife and I spent over five hours in this museum. It gives you the history of Hong Kong starting from pre-historic times all the way through how it became a British colony. Time here is well spent. It gave us much greater appreciation of the neighborhoods that we were walking through.
Get to know more about Hong Kong history. Get to know more about the history of Hong Kong from prehistory to handover. Huge museum, plan couple of hours.
Vist to the Museum. Good place to visit with kids as it has a lot of information that kisd will like to see and experience.
Well worth a few hours. Hong Kong Story exhibition is fascinating. Saw a fantastic exibition of some of the terracotta warriors for 10 HK$ (about 80p) but this ends November.

Wonderful visit. All exhibits are nicely presented and informative. Even if you are not interested in the old age HK, you can by pass them and go to the more 'modern' days from the 60s onwards.Absolutely enjoyable.
a must see museum. There is so much to see in this museum, all the exhibits are very well done. I would highly recommend it - definitely for visitors, even for locals.
Good to see. The only museum that I vivisted for my week-end trip but it worth it. I liked the different movies inside with english subtitles.

Friendly Staff and Excellent Museum. The staff was, without exception, very friendly and always willing to point you in the right direction. Such a change from the usual scowls in mainland museums. I went to the history of Hong Kong exhibit, which was really fantastic. The exhibits are well-marked in English and Chinese, and there was a great mix of audio and video in the exhibit galleries. On the day I went, there was a big school group, and the kids seemed very engaged. Highly recommended!
Great museum. I'm not a huge museum person but I LOVE this one. Very interesting and colorful displays to show HK's history!
Very informative!. Awesome! loved learning about their culture and the history of hong kong. Plenty of photos to be taken & a definate must see!

Good for children as well as for tourists. We have visited "China First Emperor" exhibition. I liked a lot interactive displays, 3D movie about Qin Shi Huang mausoleum and genuine terracotta warriors. It was well organized, well decorated and informative exhibition. Worth visiting.
The Art Speaks For Itself!!!. The museum is one of a kind and shows a variety in itself. A good place to visit if u like museums and art!!!

Great Place to Start Your Visit Nov 4 2012. I was re-visiting Hong Kong with a friend who did not have much time and had not been to Hong Kong before, so, after dropping our bags at the hotel, I took him straight to the History Museum. I lived in Hong Kong for many years and this was not my first visit to the museum but I still found it absorbing. The visit is low-key as you enter but picks up interest as you progress and, especially if you are a first-time visitor to China, you will love the highly visual and interactive nature of the many exhibits. You will become engrossed in examining what is on display as you wander into old shops, old houses, board a junk or stare at the Chinese use of colours, their architecture or costumes. It is not an overly large museum but is of high quality and highly recommended - my friend, a Kuwaiti, had not seen anything like it enjoyed it as well. Plenty for all ages to enjoy here and I would be happy to go back again.

Real insight into the history of HK. This museum is really interactive and 3D. Unlike many museums, it has so many old artifacts in situ which makes up old towns and streets. I really enjoyed this place and you could easily spend hours here. Go on a Wednesday when admission is free!

Great terracotta warrior exhibit. I booked our tickets over the phone which was a bit tricky.However, the exhibit was fantastic, enjoyable for my 6 year old too.We visited the science museum for kids ehich was opposite.We went on the free day for museums, they were not too crowded.However, there was a 10 hkd entrance fee for the exhibit.

An excellent exhibition. I went there more for time-killing, but instead, I was blown away by the excellently displayed and illustrated artifacts in the museum. I went to see the terra cotta exhibition on the first day. Even though I have been to Xian, but this exhibition in HK is really amazing. The digital re-creation of the Qin mountains is nicely made and you really felt like living in that era. The entrance fee is really cheap (~ £1). After the experience on the first day, I went back the next day visiting the routine exhibition about the HK history. It has a lot of big display introducing the history/culture of HK. This museum is a must-go if you are interested in HK history.

Great exhibition. We first went to the special exhibition (terracotta army) and were very much impressed by the modern and interactive presentation. As we liked it so much, we came back the next day to look at the permanent exhibition about the history of Hong Kong and were again quite impressed: one highlight was the scene at the harbor in the past with all the old houses you could walk into. Cannot be compared with some of the other "old style" museums in Asia. For 10HKD per person: def. worth a visit!

Lovely place to understand HK. An exccellent way to know HK in words and many exhibits of old HK. Very interesting and great space there... It doesn't get busy and it's free on Wednesday as well. Good to spend an afternoon there if your feet can cope with all the shopping and walking and walking !!

Went for the Terracotta Warriors but wish we had more time to explore. Ok I must admit my main reason for visiting the Museum was to see the Terracotta Warriors Exhibition, I always wanted to go and see them and when I heard that they were having an exhibition at the Museum of History I said we must go. We purchased our tickets online before we left Australia and the entry fee was very minimal, we were so lucky to be in Hong Kong when this exhibition was on, and wow what an amazing exhibition it was, we were blown away with all the old artifacts, and the size of all the terracotta statutes , I have two boys (13 and 6), and they were so amazed at what they were seeing, and asking so many questions. It was just a shame we were short on time that we couldn’t view the remainder of the museum.

Wednesdays Free, docents very helpful. This is an awesome place to spend the morning, and you will get a real sense of Hong Kong's colorful history. The docents are very helpful and will direct you to the exhibits you want to see, if you can't spend time to see it all. The interactive exhibits are very informative and they have alot of vintage film of WWII. The scope of their exhibits is pretty extensive and children as well as adults will find alot to see and do here. Alot of clear signage, directions and suggestions in English. First rate!

Excellent user-friendly museum. The Museum of History is well organised, user-friendly, great audio-visuals and interpretative displays. Provides walk through Hong Kong's history within each of its major time periods under Chinese, British, Japanese and Chinese ownership. Only addition would be more about Hong Kong in the current decade and the particular challenges it faces, including environmental, air quality, transport and housing challenges.
