There is a lot of information so one needs to allow at least 4-5 hours to do it justice.

Interesting well laid out museum. A great display of the history hong kong, with exhibits to interest everyone, young or old. The reconstructions of different eras give you a real insight to Hong Kong through the ages.

a great place to discover hong kong. go to this museum on a wednesday because entrance is free, and be prepared to be entertained, educated, and mesmerized by this exquisite place. the museum is topnotch and well-organized. this is a great place to start your discovery of a truly amazing hong kong.

Informative and Interesting (and free). Before going to any museum in Hong Kong check at one of the official tourism offices (like the one below the Star Ferry pier in Kowloon). They can tell you if there are free days. We happened to be there on a free day (think it was a Wednesday), so we combined a stop at this museum with a (free) stop at the science museum next door. Both are worth admission, of course, but if you're on a budget, "free" is always a great word!

World class museum. Buy the weekly museum pass and you can see all museums including the excellent history and science museums which are next to each other. You could even leave the kids in the science and spend more time in the history museum. Both museums are interesting for both adults and kids. There are movies and many huge exhibits like ships, a bun mountain, pharmacies, etc. One day per week closed.

HK has an interesting history - worth a visit. worth a visit - hong kong has an interesting history, particularly modern times, japanese occupation and opium wars etc. try to skip the prehistoric section as that didn't seem too unique to HK
HK History Museum. Great re-creations of HK artifacts - children particularly enjoyed the audio guides. A good day out for anyone interested in HK's past.

An amazing hi-tech museum of history. For less than £2.00 I was able to see the brilliant terracotta warriors and learn the about their history, and the excavation of them, through interactive display work that was second to none. The second part of the musuem - hard to find this entrance underneath! - was a treasure trove of passage ways housing relics and reconstructions from neolithic man to the present day. Well signposted and labelled, it was intriguing to learn about a part of history, only recently shared with the public, on early man and geo-HongKong. Wonderful for geographers and geologists alike! Well worth the trip to Tsim Sha Tsui East.

A museum for people who don't like museums!. This is WAY more exciting than you would think. There are Junk boats, village houses, tombs, that you can walk through. Short films that explain the information. It is one of the few museums that you don't need an audio guide. Don't miss the tomb, and the info on the Han dynasty, and the information about the Japanese takeover of Hong Kong, but if you have more time, start at the beginning, and go all the way through. I could have spent a day here. I go every time I am in HK. It costs 10 HKD about $1.30 usd, and worth 10 times that... The one negative is the museum food, it is just ok.  Both my husband and daughter who came begrudgingly, loved it...
Qin Show. First emperior in China, it's good to know what is going on in 246 BC to 221 BC at China, Save time no need to China

Great museum. Very well organised museum which gradually build your knowledge of the history of Hongkong. It is bigger than you think, take almost a day to observe it, but is so well organised you always want to continue. I will visit it again surely.

Terracota exhibit is the best. A break from the normal shopling routine of Hong kong. They had a very interesting presentation for the exhibit of the terrracota warriors. Very nicely done interactive attractions. Its a great trip down memory lane without having gone through a tour. If you want a history trip at your own pace, this is a must
Enjoyable , awesome museum. I had an extra day while on business and took a break from all the fabulous shopping. This is a must visit- so very interesting and well done.

Wonderful dioramas. The prehistory part was a little dull, but once you get into the dioramas depicting recent history things really start to pick up. This museum is well worth a visit.
Tip: there's an excellent little bakery called "pies and tarts" right at the bottom of the footbridge opposite the museum, if you want a quick snack.

Great visit. Spent an hour in the main museum looking at the History of Hong Kong exhibit (wished we had been able to spend more time on this) and then went onto the Teracotta Warriors exhibition. Although I'm not a massive fan of this sort of attraction normally, both exhibitions were superbly presented, making full use of interactive media and bringing exhibits to life.Amazingly cheap as well - the main museum is free on Wednesdays and the Teracotta Army exhibition was $HK10 (90p). Noe that the museum is closed on a Tuesday - never understand why they do this!

Excellent museum. Only went here because it was raining, but very pleasantly surprised at what a great museum this is. Much bigger than I expected and very, very well organised in logical sections.Unfortunately, I had only 90 minutes to spend here, but could easily have stayed for twice that time. Great variety of exhibits, so everybody must find something of interest here. Ultra friendly staff too.I live in Singapore and have been to the museums here. They are very good, but the Museum of History in Hong Kong is in a totally different league. Huge bargain at only ten dollars.

Worth Visiting!. Museum illustrates really well the history of this amazing city by very vivid exhibits. It is not boring and well presented. It will definitely interest everyone who would like to learn about English heritage in Hong Kong. It might be nice for children too as there not only reading involved which often kids find quite boring. You can spend good 3 hours there and slowly digest all the information. There are videos showed as well.

Interesting and worth visiting. It took 20 minutes to walk from Tsim Sha Tsui MRT but worth the visit. The history museum is on the left of the science museum and entry is on ground floor. There is variety in the presentation of Hong Kong’s history such as boats, statues and movies. There is plenty of themed seating for those with tired feet. Due to space limitations, the museum is two storeys and some would find this bothersome. Entry fee is extremely cheap.

Free on Wednesdays. Possibly the favourite part of my recent HK trip. We went on Wednesday to take advantage of the free admission to the permanent exhibits, which taught me a number of facts that I did not already know. The special exhibit (The Majesty of All Under Heaven: The Eternal Realm of China’s First Emperor) was very busy that day, so we went back on another day. For HKD$10 it was definitely worth seeing the terracotta warriors! The exhibit is on until November 26th and I would highly recommend it.

Glad I visited!. stopped by one morning, hoping to buy a ticket for the next day to see the Terracotta Warriors, but they had availability right away, so I took my opportunity.spent some time watching the introductory exhibits and then moved into the main hall where the warrior statues themsevles are, as well as horses, carriages, tools and implements, and numeorus interesting historical anecdotes as to their origin.money well spent!

Sotory of Hong Kong- really good. Very informative and interesting part of Chinese history. It's is in Kowloon. I realize how little we learn of this geographies history.It also describes how the islands were geologically formed.

The Secret Garden of Emperor Qianlong. This exhibition originally came from Beijing. It traced the life of Qianlong, 6th Qing emperor of China. A sophisticated exhibition, it showed pictures of the emperor's early life, his philosophy, love of art and pictures of family life. His name, taken when he was declared emperor, means 'lasting eminence'. There was a fascinating 3-D audio-visual display of his palace and garden that could be built up and deconstructed progressively through the use of various control buttons available for visitors. Also there were some very smart graphics that showed the emperor’s face as a young man progressing as a continuous graphic to old age as various key points in his life were explained. There was a very interesting letter from the Director of the Palace Museum in the Forbidden City in Beijing, expressing good wishes to the people of Hong Kong and delight at being able to share this important history with the people of this part of China. The museum is modern, cool in the heat, inexpensive to attend and there is a nice café that served a great lunch.

so much fun. if you get the week pass - it's so worth it. When i went, it was during a busy time so a lot of the things we wanted to do was booked - but if you get a week pass (30 hkd = 5 usd) you can go straight in and it lasts for a week. You can spend an entire day there because there are so many museums that you can use with the pass and it's all in the same area. Not enough places to eat though, but maybe I wasn't looking hard enough.

Exceptional presentation. Having a spare afternoon and having been recommended to a special exhibition currently running (Terra cotta warriors and other relics .) I visited this attraction . As with all museums in HK value is exceptional at HK$10. for entry and i have to say it was one of the best audiovisual displays I have ever seen . Perfectly pitched and beautifully animated it was suitable for all ages . The support given by the myriad (and very rare artifacts ) was perfectly presented . Whoever was in charge of this particular exhibition should be congratulated.The general secftion of the museum is also very precise and excellently presented giving a good insight into the history of hong Kong . You can find out what is on at any time in any HK tourist office and can book entry if required at any Urbtix outlet .

An unexpectedly good afternoon. Looking to fill half a day in Hong Kong we visited as a family and enjoyed the 2nd 2 thirds of the museum the most. It's a great way to learn more of the polical history and appreciate the rich cultural history Hong Kong has to offer. Inexpensive and well air conditioned :)

Very concise education on Hong Kong. The History museum was well laid out and very spacious . It was easy to follow and at the same time an exhibit on the Terracotta Warriors was on and we were able to go to this as well ( for extra cost) , which was great .
Really Interesting Museum. very reasonable to get in, enjoyed the displays and how it shows the birth of Hong Kong, the people and the current situation.

Terracotta Warriors. At the time I visited this museum of history they had some of the terracotta warriors there from China; which was very interesting and I highly recommend going there to see this exhibition!

Well worth a visit. The museum is a great respite from the hustle and bustle of life in Hong Kong. Well run and has good exhibits. Not only that, it has a couple of historically preserved buildings right across the street, the Rosary HIll Church. It's a little gem and not many left in Hong Kong that represents the architecture of that era. Neighbourhood is more open than most, reminder of what it was like decades ago, when that was a mostly Portuguese residential area. Museum is also close enough to other areas of interests to take a walk on a nice day, or catch a cab.

Double or triple the admission fee and I will still come again.. This is a big museum, and there is something for everyone here.The museum arrange your walk in archaeological order. Start from hundreds and thousands of years ago, with stones, fossils, then few thousands ago with Chinese, then few hundred years ago when there were interactions between east and west, then the last 200 hundred years.There are plenty of exhibits, both replicas and originals. They even have small set ups of farms, fishing boats, temples, Chinese opera, etc.There are videos in small theatres for more complex issues, like opium war. They rotate the videos in English, Mandarin, Cantonese; but you do not have to wait if you don't have the patience, as Chinese versions have English subtitle, and English videos have Chinese subtitle.I allowed myself half a day for the museum (as there are so many repetitions with museums all around the world), and I regretted it. I am sure that I will allow one whole day when I come next time.
Terracotta Warrior. We went to the terracotta Warrior exhibition at the Museum of History. Entrance fee only $10.00. Many pieces of exhibits - worth a visit!

Make time to visit this Museum. You could certainly spend a whole day in the museum. All the decription exhibts are in English so there is no need to rent an audio guide. Each section of the museum illustrates a different era and from the people, their lifestyle and politics. This museum is a great insight to the culture of the Chinese people.
Hidden Treasure. From the start of the world to present this place tells you everything you need to know about Hong Kong. Nice little resturant inside
Large and very interesting. It would be sad to leave Hong Kong without learning more about its history. The museum has many sections to explore and the displays really pull you in.

Great way to spend $10 HK dollars. We were visiting Hong Kong recently. I was with a friend from China. She enjoyed the museum as much as I did. There were was so much information to learn. We took our time and looked at all of the exhibits. We did not want to miss anything. I would definitely recommend.
Lucky enough to see Terracotta Warriors. Very well-kept museum, interesting. Lucky to have been in HK at the same time as the Terracotta Warriors exhibition.

The First Emperor Exhibition. The Honk Kong Museum of History featured an exhibition of the First Emperor and the terracotta army. This was a stunning production from start to finish with clever digital displays showing how the statues were made and painted. Then on to a stunning surround video experience of the archeological works before going into the exhibition proper. Very well laid out, very informative and detailed, the artifacts were amazing. What a wonderful exhibition. Now I want to go to the archeological site and see the real location.

Terra Cotta Warriors Exhibition - might be the best HK$10 (US$1.29) you will ever spend. As if the Hong Kong Museum of History wasn't good enough already, until the 26th of November 2012, there is a special exhibition featuring the Qin Terra Cotta Warriors from Xi'an, China called - "The Majesty of All Under Heaven: The Eternal Realm of China’s First Emperor." By all accounts, we found this special exhibition to be sublime, one of the very best HK$10 (US$1.29) we have ever spend. Tickets need be booked in advance, which can be done online at URBTIX. We really enjoyed everything that we saw at this special exhibition, particularly the multi-media contributions and the actual artifacts themselves. We spent just over 1.5 hours at this exhibition but the best parts could have been seen in perhaps just 45-60 minutes if you are in a hurry. The exhibition area is well laid out and easy to navigate. Displayed information is not overly wordy and artifacts are spaced out are all quite special to view. In all the exhibition felt very well planned, organized and executed. By comparison, this was a much better effort than the 'Dead Sea Scrolls' exhibition (US$25 per person) that we visited at the Discovery Times Square in NYC last year. Overall, this is a fantastic exhibition available for the small fee of HK$10 per person. If you are traveling to Hong Kong between now and the 26th of November, we'd strongly recommend that you take the time to visit this special exhibition at the Hong Kong Museum of History, especially if you are not planning to travel into mainland China to see the Terra Cotta Warriors in Xi'an. We are planning our second visit now, hoping to see it again before exhibition is finished.Hint: In addition to this visit, you should plan to see the Hong Kong Museum of History as well. This is an excellent museum that is child-friendly, informative with generally considered our very best in Hong Kong. Entry price is also HK$10 per adult, making this an equally excellent value for money experience.

History of Hong Kong concentrated in one place. If you ever go to Hong Kong for a visit, you must not miss this museum. The sections on indigenous cultures are particularly excellent. This museum provides a marvelous summary of Hong Kong's history.

Special exhibition of Terracotta Warriors. A special exhibition, naturally very popular and hard to get into, was the main reason for visiting this. There were about 20 Terracotta figures from the Xian, Shaanxi province. There is an interesting introduction to the exhibition with very impressive audio-visual and a few interactive displays. More information about the history and the warriors is available both in Chinese and in English. It is naturally not the same as visiting the real thing in Xian but it gives you an idea of what it is all about.

Well explained (in English), quiet, well done!. Loved the history museum - it's easy to think of Hong Kong as always having been the modern metropolis it is but the museum provides an excellent explanation of how people made it so. Especially now that the New Territories are being rapidly remade into suburbs, it's amazing to see what they were like just a few years ago. Enjoy!
Very interesting. A very good museum. Just beware it is closed on Mondays.Gives a very good picture of what Hong Kong used to look like. Particularly liked the junks.

Outstanding.. I was very impressed with this museun it was a long walk from the ferry but well worth it. It had 4 floors and every floor was hands on,There was a school party there when we were there it was a pleasure to watch them interacting with all the exhibits.

A well time spent to know Hong Kong's history. Having to read about the free entrance on Wednesday, we planned our visit to the science and museum of history with the family. What a delightful and educational time we had there. My 6 year old had such a good time trying and experimenting items. He asked many questions about the opium war, lion dance, ships as we watch the shorts videos. He loved the displays of the old buildings and opera house. The exhibition was worth visiting indeed. Prepare to walk. It is nice to see even the locals come visit this place.

Very informative. I really liked the part on the different Chinese ethnic group that made up what Hong Kong is today. There is also an excellent overview on the British influence in the region. Must do if you want to know more about the vibrant history of Hong Kong.

Very detailed museum. Well organized, with short videos. It's very easy to understand why and how HK has become the city we see nowadays.The details of the history are very easy to follow.Very interesting also the hall dedicated to the natural disasters (typhoons and scarcity of water).Despite 3-4 big groups were visiting at the same time (met at the entrance), the halls are so well organized that the museum didn't look crowded.Photos are allowed inside and the ticket costs only 10 HK$.
Lovely. The best way to learn about Hong Kong. It starts right from the bringing with the formation of the land. And finished with the hand back to China.

Interesting for an hour but skip the audio guide. This is a nice place to learn more about Hong Kong's history for an hour. Do not get the Audio guide it gives he longest most boring explanations of all the plaques. Everything in the signs is explained in English. Go on Wednesday when it's free.

Excellent insight into HK history for the tourist. One of the best museums I have been into as it is well laid out, interactive and good journey through the time line. It starts from geological formation through to the present day.Adults and children will find the exhibtion informative and interesting. The museum is a credit to the people of HK!

A must-see on Wednesdays!. Free admission on Wednesdays! The price is right! Liked the Story of Hong Kong - great history lessons, wonderful display of life-styles, artifacts etc.Paid nominal fee of HK$10 to see the First Emperor of China Exhibition. It was fantastic!! The 3D movie of the Terracota Army at the beginning of the show really set a high expectation for us! We enjoyed seeing the artifacts and reading the history notes and captions.
marvellous!. a good sample of all the time chinese history!all in a very nice atmosphere.the temporal exhibitions are great!

Great Exhibition. Exhibition of first emperor of China Terracotta Soldiers on show .Excellent value for money.You may have to book when you wish to visit . Don't forget to have a look of the painted steps and floor painting just by the museum .

Worth the visit. I was surprised at how much I enjoyed my visit. My knowledge of Hong Kong's history was greatly augmented by the time I got to the end of the displays. Good information provided in digest form and some amazing photos, film clips and static displays. A couple of hours sped by.

Enjoyable few hours. A lovely way to spend a few hours in Hong Kong to get a deeper understanding and respect for the place. Wasn't expecting much, but was really pleasantly surprised at the exhibits and information provided (just the right depth for me). Excellent on a steamy/ thunderstorm day!

A great summary of HK story. i love museum, and this was really great. This is the second time i was in HK, i would not have done it the first time but for a second visit is great. They have everything, from prehistoric times to the opium wars and the japanese invasion. The movie rooms are great, the chinese version has english subs and the english has chinese subs. There was a multimedia Terra-cota warrior exhibit. it was absolutely awsome, but you have if you can still catch it you have to buy tickets in advance, at least one day before. You won't regret it.

A Real Plus for A Visitor. If you are visiting Hong Kong on a tight schedule you might think you don't have time to go to a history museum. I recommend you reconsider when there is a museum of quality like the Hong Kong Museum of History. A two-hour visit here will provide significant context for the rest of your visit to this amazing city. You travel from the geological ancient history of the area through to present China. I particularly liked the recreated traditional Chinese pharmacy (the contents generously donated by a local family) and the recreation of Chinese home and wedding festivities. It is fine museum and will hold the interest of every member of the family.

Memory Lane. The museum was equipped with all the history from the past. There were exhibits of a Chinese Junk, Rickshaw, clothes that had been worn for many years and I was delighted that I was able to show my family what these things are. Also included was costumes from a Lion Dance, wedding ceremony and temples. Props were set up of businesses which had been created by the British e.g. an old post office. I would not have been able to show my family any of Hong Kong's heritage if it wasn't for the museum. Hong Kong has been modernised so much and unfortunately the old Hong Kong is disappearing.

Back to the roots. I always like to visit a history museum when I am new in town to understand its background and I appreciate if it also guides you through in an exciting and interactive way. Next to it are also other museums so you can plan a day for some education. On Wednesdays entrance was even free.

Edutainment at its best!. Educational entertainment at its best! Even non-museum lovers would end up enjoying it in spite of themselves. What's great about the museum is its gradual progression of Hong Kong history (I did away with prehistory and focused instead on folk festivals and the 60's). You pick and choose what interests you and still get a good context of Hong Kong.There's an ongoing special exhibition on the world-famous Terracota Warriors which you should not miss! For HKD 10, you get to see a slice of the terracota treasures in all their glory. Better get advance tickets as they are selling like hotcakes!If there's only one museum you should visit, it should be the Museum of History. It makes your walks around the streets of Hong Kong that much more special and intimate.
Very interesting. I love museums and this was a great one to see, it really has a complete history and is not politically 'edited' like the ones I have seen in mainland China. A great experience.

Teracotta Warriors. There is a brilliant exhibition on at the moment until Nov 12, HK$10, but you need to buy a ticket for an advance date because if you go there on any day all tickets are normally sold. The only let so many people in at a time. We went there on a Sunday and the earliest day we were able to get was the following Friday. I believe you can book online. Well worth a visit.

Perfect for a rainy day.. The Hong Kong Museum of History is fascinating, we learnt so much about the history of Hong Kong and the exhibits are very well presented. I highly recommend a visit if you are in Hong Kong wondering about what to do in the rain!

Wonderful walk through the history of Hong Kong. The Hong Kong Museum of History is well organized and interesting. Many of the workers spoke English and were very helpful. There is a nice cafe inside for lunch or a cup of tea. Allow at least four hours for a quick walk through. It is best to call ahead to reserve tickets for the special displays, because the display was booked solid until the evening for the Terra Cotta Warriors when we were there. We were still able to get into the main museum which was very interesting.
A bit of a schlep but worth it.. Very interesting museum at the beginning of the New Territories. Easy MTR ride but a fairly long trek through a mall and streets to get to. Go anyway. It's worth it.

Beautiful exhibition on terracota army of Emperor Qin. The entrance is very cheap (USD 10) and this exhibition was very interetsing, merging the true masterpieces from Xian city and the use of digital technology for a best understanding.
Interesting. Head there when one of the English language tours takes place or just wander about at your own pace. Interesting displays and a great place to escape the summer heat.

Great half day out of the rain. Really interesting exhibit that takes you all the way back to prehistoric times through to modern day. Gave me a good understanding of Hong Kong and how it sees itself. Exhibits are well done.Definitely worth a visit especially if you need something to do on a rainy day!

So much to learn and see!. You'll learn almost everything about HK there... It goes from ceology to archeology, pre-history, history, folk culture, modern history (Opium wars, British period, Japanese period, Chinese period,...), lifestyle,... And it's really well-presented. I can only recommend it.

Fascinating Museum. Easy to reach by 'bus for older travellers from T.S.T. 'bus no.5. Those disabled can use the pedestrian crossing first then the ramp up to the Museum with pleasant grounds. Inexpensive fascinating view of the history of Hong Kong in a beautifully well set out spacious surrounds. It starts off from pre historic times throughout the ages until more modern day, but the "time travel " is a truly spectacular journey depicting visually and auditory overwhelming precision of the background of this fascinating country of Hong Kong, enthralling visitors at every turn. You are transported back in time to the Big Bang, the development of the land, the water on the land, the rivers and lakes, miriad of islands, the geology, the history of it's first land dwellers, animals, reptiles, fish , bird life and insects. It has a real WOW factor, as it is all depicted so well. We particularly enjoyed the depiction of the buildings of yesteryear, transport, sea craft, trading, life of the boat dwellers and raised houses inhabitants.And currency and banks were explained, rulers and conquerors of the land, the Occupation of the area by the Japanese during the 2nd W.W., shops , festival displays, so many and varied amounts of history, all so fascinating, you could take many hours wandering around and still see more on a subsequent visit. I particularly loved the Opera Stage , costumes displayed, background of Chinese Music and other intruiging information. Special displays are held throughout the year, so you won't be disappointed to visit the H.K. Museum of history.

It's a must see. Every city has its non-negotiables for visitors. This should the first one. The museum is very informative, inexpensive, and fun to visit for children and adults alike. Although I didn't use it a lot, the self guided audio tours were helpful and extremely inexpensive. Helpful and friendly staff. I think three hours is about the right time needed to see everything at a relaxed pace. The only downside was that the bookstore at the end did not have their souvenir books organized in any recognizable form or manner, so there was no use looking for anything that had inspired me in the previous three hours, other than trinkets and postcards.

One of the best museums I've seen. This place is enormous. It's divided into 8 'scenes' or 'times'The first are about the creation of the world and Hong Kong. The prehistory, Fossils, nature, animals,...Then it goes to the beginning of mankind with artefacts from the bronze age and so on.The second floor is where it focusses more on Honk Kong, with the history of the place, the people, the different Chinese clans, Traditions, the opium war and WW2 until now.If you are interested in everything then leave plenty of time for the museum. You'll need over 4 hours to complete it. There are several video's playing in special rooms. They are certainly worth your time.The museum is unique for it's size and the way everything is built. It's not a boring place with some artefacts being displayed. They have built a whole town inside, There is a ship, nature, ...The place is way beyond expectation for only 10HKD!
Nice place to know more about HK. The ground floor might not be for everyone's taste. Upstairs is definitely very interesting with lots of interactive areas!

Nicely done !. Two good museum at the same spot ! Just great. This one and the Sciences Museum. I have appreciated all the way they have build all the scenes. It's simply visual and easy for your kids to understand what they are seeing.
Terracotta. It was in town and the exhibits are beautiful and well organized. They charged a reasonable price for entry.

very cool museum. brought my 8 and 10 yr old here and they really enjoyed the displays. Yes it's free on Wednesdays but if schedule doesn't work out no biggie because it's pretty cheap. Pretty strict with no food and drinks inside but if you happen to have dim sum leftovers (like we did) they will take it in front and you can pick it up afterwards. HK Science museum is conveniently next door.

A true step into HK's history.... As it comes to telling the story of a cities background, there is no better museum than the HK museum of History. It even moves back to the prehistoric ages when the HK landscape took place. With great settings and actual rebuild streets, trams and shops, it is great fun for even kids to learn more. The wide selection might spread a bit long at the beginning but when you reach the stages closer to our own current time, you can reflect more and really connect with HK's great history...A must see if you come to HK...!!!!

Hong Kong's history in one big package!. I knew before entering the museum that Hong Kong's history was rich and diverse. However, what I was not expecting was the amount of exhibits that reconstructed it's origins in precise detail. You will end up walking around the museum following the timeline of Hong Kong; from Prehistoric times, to the hand over from the UK to China. It's a fascinating learning experience and one that young children in particular will enjoy. The museum is free on Wednesday's and will take about 1-2 hours to walk around.
Good museum. Very nice, lots of informations about how hong kong has emerged, reconstitution of houses, shops etc...and free on wednesday!

Catch the Culture!. All the Museums in Hong Kong are fascinating and reflect local history and culture very well. The Museum of History is certainly no exception. You can see how Hong Kong developed from a small sea port to the wonderful city it is today. The section on the WW2 years is fascinating. Check which day is the "free entry" day.

Must start with this if you wanna understand HK's culture. This musuem is very well designed and provides great insight about the origins of HK, it's people and its specific culture. I loved it! a must see! althought not very well advertised.

very interesting couple of hours. A very reasonable experience which is good for a coule of hours on a wet day. The staff are very helpful and the museum itself I found gave a very interesting insight into the life and history of Hong Kong

a must go if you want a brief overview of HK's history. The permanent exhibit provides a good overview on Hong Kong's history. You may run into school tours if visiting the museum on a weekday. The gift shop features some interesting goods.
Museum in HK. One of the best museums I have ever visited. Even motivated our group of young English schoolkids. You need at least 2 hours to do it justice.

Interesting and perfect if it is raining or super hot. Great museum which has the history and is interactive with alot of movies in english as well. It had a great part of WW2 occupation which l certainely did not know. They loved the english failures during the merchant trading period too it had the english native speaking people in the audience in laughter as they showed us each failure. Great place to kill a couple of hours in air con.

very good museum.... We visted hong kong museum of history on our second day while travelling in hong kong. i had heard a lot about this museum. we really liked the way everything was kept and the monuments, cultural heritage.

Well designed museum. Certainly worth a visit - esp. if you want to get your head around the whole British/Chinese history aspects of Hong Kong. Beautifully presented - would love to have stayed longer, but with two young kids, museums always end up being done at Formula One pace

A very Entertaining and Diverse Museum!. I am not much of a museum type of person, but I really enjoyed this one. Taking pictures is a bit hard with a non-DSLR camera due to the difficult lighting conditions, but that shouldn't put you off. The visit itself is definitely worth it and I didn't think it was boring at all. It has so many different parts that if you don't like to read about the primeval origins of the area of Hong Kong, you can just skip it and turn to the next part. There is something in it for everyone, be it on the history geology, culture, public transport, festivities, or opera. I really enjoyed visiting and would recommend it to every traveler to Hong Kong.

natural history and all. Nice background to Hong Kong's history, from geographical point of view to cultural. Interesting, and learnt lots from my visit. Free admissions on Wednesdays (for this and many other museums), open from 10am till 6pm. Museum pass is also a good deal if planning to visit more than 3 museums, over the course of 7 days. Take MTR to Tsim Sha Shui East and walk North along Chatham - next to Science Museum.
Day Trip. Not just history that you learn but alot more. Art, culture, history etc. There are tours in English. Make sure you give yourself 3 hours to see everything.
Really interesting. Great exhibits and a great way to learn about Hong Kongs history.

Worth a visit. While there is much emphasis on China’s influence on Hong Kong (which is true), there is too little mentioning of the British influence on Hong Kong once it was ceded to Britain (which is very important in terms of shaping modern Hong Kong) – it’s as if the British rule was very minor in the whole course of its history. There also appears to be a lot of Chinese patriotism in this museum suggesting the great excitement of the return of Hong Kong to China…exemplified by the fact that the final videoclip about ‘the celebration of the return of Hong Kong to China’ was played simultaneously with an old song called ‘tomorrow will be better’ (sang in Chinese) in the background…and the museum information written ends with Chinese patriotism.Other than the slight personal disturbance descried above, I do think it is a great museum to visit especially for someone who doesn’t’ know much about Hong Kong history. The museum is cheap and definitely worth a look. You can spend a whole day here to look at everything properly; but if you don’t have time, 3 hours there is definitely worth it. Many audio-film/clips (with English subtitles) and visual displays are available. For those on tight-budget, I recommend visiting on Wednesdays for free.The great thing about this museum is that it is spacious with lots of seats around for you to sit if you’ve been standing and walking for too long – a good feet rest before getting up and moving onto the next area of displays. Like department stores, the air-conditioning inside also makes it a great place for heat-escape during summer with the additional benefit of getting some learning done.Walking to the museum isn’t difficult (around 15 minutes’ walk) especially when there are signs of direction once you leave Tsim Sha Tsui east station. If lost, ask the locals – they all know where the museum is.A visit to the museum does overall add to the fun of the whole Hong Kong trip.

A great way to understand the history of Hong Kong. Our family enjoyed this museum and were all engaged in learning about Hong Kong's amazing history. Unless you are particularly interested in geology I suggest that you fast forward the first section though.

A "must" visit upon arrival in Hong Kong. There are eight different galleries-something for everyone: 1. Natural Environment: "Landform and Climate", "Flora and Fauna"2. Prehistoric Hong Kong: Archaeology3. The Dynasties: From Han to the Qing4. Folk Culture in Hong Kong with life-size dioramas5. The Opium Wars and the Cessation of Hong Kong6. Birth and Early Growth of the City7. The Japanese Occupation8. Modern Metropolis and the Return to ChinaYes, it is a lot of ground to cover in one visit. (I was exhausted by the end of the day.) But there are lots of great educational and entertaining films, so you can rest a bit. Highlights of my visit included three traditional buildings showing how people lived; reconstructions of festivals; a street recreation with shops from the early 1900's; a film of life at that time; and the 1960's room displays. There is a restaurant for lunch and, yes, air-conditioning, which makes this a nice place to spend a leisurely humid Hong Kong day--even if you live here!

Excellent museum, but too much noise to really enjoy.. Hong Kong History MuseumWanting to have a "cultural" experience while in HK, we went to the History Museum, after reading the reviews on TA.Can recommend the museum if you want to know a bit more on HK, but beware of all the schools who visit. They had quite a few groups visiting when we were there, which meant a lot of shouting and running around of children.   Not exactly the right atmosphere for trying to concentrate on what you are seeing.Very nice displays though, very well done, except that it's not clear in which order you should walk through the displays.If not for the above remarks I would have rated it "excellent".
A must see. Learn about how people lived back in time, the four largest group of peoples before the colonization and a lot more. A must see if you want to learn more about Hong Kong.

A MUST STOP IF YOU HAVE TIME!. This was our first trip to Hong Kong and didn't know much about it! Our guide book recommended spending a couple hours in this museum to understand Hong Kong Better! Its incredible! Skip through the prehistoric stuff unless you care to know about Hong Kong 3 million years ago! Afterwards everything else is extremly informative and after 2 1/2 hours... you'll know everything about Hong Kong!

Worth a visit. For hk$10, it is good value. the museum of history is well equipped with many displays, artifacts, audio-visuals. History of hong kong from prehistoric times to the handover. Learn alot. Nice time spent there which is a good break from the the usual tourist places.
Interesting. A very interesting museum, setting out the whole history of Hong Kong, including its geography and geology to the handover to China!

A good modern museum, with a well-told story skilfully laid out.. Hong Kong’s fascinating history is very well set out in this modern building, with a visually very appealing use of the space. We were engrossed for the best part of two hours. Well worth a visit, but the history does not always make you proud to be British!
Not to be missed. Even if you know the history of Hong Kong, you are sure to learn something new in this museum. Definitely not boring!

Surprisingly great! Wonderful intro to HK . . .. I went in expecting an hour's max of cursory passing through. Ended up spending nearly 4 hours there. Beautifully put together; providing an extremely good introduction to HK history.
complete. nice history but a bit too much general stuff about rocks and such

Pride. Without knowledge of Hong Kong's history, you would have but a superficial visit with no appreciation of how it came to be, it's continued growth and the ingenuity and courage of those who live and work there.

Love It. HK Museum Of History offers a great and interesting set up where you can see and learn more about the history of the country: How it all started from prehistory to its rising while passing in details through how cavemen survived, different dynasties, the country's festivities, the World War and much more.Note that the museum is free on Wednesday :)

Must visit place for history lovers !!. Me and my wife decided to go to this place as we got a free ticket and moreover it was near to our hotel. Compared to other hong kong attractions, entry ticket here is dead cheap, just 10 HKD. Soon we realized that we made the right decision in visiting this awesome place. Unfortunately we didn't had much time to spend there as it was our last day in hong kong and we had some other things to be completed. This museum is having lot of real life structures and reserve at least 2-3 hrs to see around the museum. Museum tells the history of hong kong from stone age to current period. Overall, if you are a history lover, do visit this place.
Hong Kong History. A small museum but it offers an interesting perspective on the history of the area and its culture.

Museum of History was full of culture!. The Museums of History and Science are the ones to visit (Art and Space are significantly smaller and didn't hold any charm or history). I visited all 4 museums in one day. The history museum was huge and inside were multiple rooms that displayed different eras and were full of culture. They had vignettes dating WAY back to more current times. There was a LOT to see and it was well worth visiting. I could have stayed even longer!!!

Greta plac eto spend a few hours toget out of the heat and humidity. Nice museum, very interesting artifacts. I definitely learned many things I did not know before such as the cities involvement in WWII. Thoroughly enjoyed it.
Interesting. A great insight into Hong Kong's history. Most enjoyable.

Well worth a visit to find out more about Hong Kong. The HK Museum of History is well worth a visit - it starts off with the history of the geology of the Hong Kong area, the flora and fauna and then moves onto the different people who lived within the area. It then moves onto their culture and has exhibits of their clothes, pottery etc. as well as recreations of their houses. You then head upstairs to the more recent history, which shows the Opium Wars and colonial history of Hong Kong, right up the eventual handover to China.
Attractive. Used a quite interactive way to introduce Hong Kong History, there may have sound effect when you walk into some spots, but the exhibits and display mode seldom change.

Fun and Informative. My kids (4 and 11) and I really enjoyed the Hong Kong Museum of History. It begins with geologic history of the island and then moves to the present day. It's always fascinating to go to museums in foreign countries, but the presentations on the Opium Wars and history of the relationship with Great Britain were especially interesting. The museum is very colorful and has fantastic exhibits for kids, interspersed with short film vignettes. The staff were especially helpful, knowing when the English version was going to start and pointing us to the movies. The gift shop also had some inexpensive and fun finds. We walked there from the Star Ferry and it was a good hike. Maps don't provide you with adequate information regarding the entrance so we ended up walking around the building (the entrance is on the south). But the walk through the park and neighborhoods were also fun on the way.

Wonderful Museum. It was a hot and rainy day so we chose to come here. Well, let me tell you- do not wait for a rainy day to come here!!it is top notch and provides a vivid and colorful representation of the history of HK. The exhibits are top notch and layout is wonderful.You can see a junk boat, old trams, and a re-created old HK village amoung a whole lot more!There is a cafe here as well. Easy to get to from the subway!
Huge emphasis on british china history. Wwe like that it is not crowded, The exhibits were very information and it is easy to get to the museum.

a quick look of hong kong history. this is a must go if you are not an asian or have a passion in asia culture. this is a really fabulous museum of Hong Kong history. they have series of exhibition going on. However, I can ensure you will have really awesome journey here
Interesting. Visited the museum it was interesting to see how artistic Chinese can be and how they preserve their art

Multi-level Museum. My son had a great time here, he wanted to touch, see, read and try everything. A whole day should be spent here if you're going with an inquisitive child, specially one that loves Math as there is a Math section with lots of brain teaser interactive puzzles!

Professional and pleasant presentation of the history of Hong Kong. Grew up in HK and moved to the U.S. when I was 10, I have a limited knowledge of the city that I was born at. The museum gave me such a great snapshot of the city with emphasis on how the British acquired the colony and the war with Japan and finally the industrialization of the city. I was so impressed with the presentation of it all and it definitely meets right up there with museums in Europe and Washington D.C. and NYC in the U.S. I was so happy to finally learn so much about the city that I grew up in and love! P.S: Go on Wednesday, it's free admission!
History of Hong Kong. This is a wonderful museum and we went on a Wednesday when it is free. It has wonderful diaramas, photos and short movies and will interest all ages.

Free on Wednesday.. It's a well put together exhibition with fully built traditional house, temples and even a Opera stage. The exhibition works through the geological past of the Hong Kong region through the dynasty's wildlife and modern day history. There are videos in multiple languages and some interaction for younger kids.Tips: On Wednesdays its free. There's a nice cheap English audio guide. You need at least 4+ hours to go round it all.
Great place to visit. A good place to learn about Chinese history. Don't give it a miss when in Hong Kong

Allow plenty of time. The History museum is fantastic. Informative and very creatively displayed. My husband and I ran out of time and returned on Tuesday hoping to take a tour. Unfortunately it is closed on Tuesday. I recommend 4 hours.
interesting little museum. my son really like to go there (he is 3). On wednesdays its free.

Professionally laid out.. We were surprised at how interesting this museum is. Whole houses, temples. Everything laid out in an interesting and informative manner. Lots of info on the Japanese occupation. Very worthwhile going to.

The best HKD10 we've ever spent. It's very rich on history and there are a lot of things gong on! I love it and even if I saw everything, I wanna go back.From history to lifestyle, it's here. It's awesome!
This is a museum you will never forget. you will find so many hands on exhibits that you cannot get your children out there again.

It gets better as you go further in. At the begining was abit boring, it showed you about some geological stuff and the iron age. It gets better when it starts to talk about how HK fits in the previous empires and the change in culture, specially during the opium war and WWII. My favourite bit was the modern histroy of HK, it shows HK used to be industrial city and the stuff they used to make.

Informative. Enjoyed this museum. Felt well informed but this exhibit in not interactive. Felt that we were being watched at all times, so did not relax really. Lots of content. Easily located. Glad we went!

Great Museum and price!. There are some great things to see in this museum and the price is fantastic (only a couple of $CA/US). They have the full history of Hong Kong with some great exhibitions, well worth a visit if you have a couple of hours free.

You'll understand why Hongkongers always say they come from HK instead of China. In my local point of view, this is the museum you should visit if you want to visit a museum in HK.From pre-historic to 21st century, the museum summarise very neatly the history of HK. It depicts the moments of HK as a British Colony very clearly, with politically correct information about the return of HK to China. If you want to know what makes Hong Kong Hong Kong and why we insist we're from HK, not China. History is in our blood.

Fantastic price, great museum. You'll learn a lot about Hong Kong, its a typical museum, with a great layout and very good exhibits. Loved it. Perfect place to spend a rainy day in Hong KongTIP: Get the museum pass, cheapest way to see as many museums as you want and even if you just do the history and science museum its a good value

Excellent introduction to Hong Kong. If you can only visit one museum in Hong Kong it should be the HK Museum of History. Where to start--it has everything and anything you would want to know about the history of Hong Kong and its culture. I particularly liked the Chinese Opera display and the replicas of Colonial Hong Kong rooms and shops. It is a great place for photography as well--just point a camera in any direction and you'll come away with great photos.They also have a very nice museum shop and air-conditioning, which is a must in June.
Excellent history Of HK. Very good and interesting museum which gives you a real and instructive insight into the HK history and traditions.
Fantastic history and cheap admission!. Great way to spend a rainy afternoon or if you need to kill a few hours. Entrance fee is only a few dollars and well worth it!

The title explains all.. I think the title tells you everything you need to know about this destination. The Hong Kong Museum of History, well what else can I say, it's about Hong Kong's history, with some information about colonization and the struggles Hong Kong people have suffered / lived through in the past. There's also some old and new calligraphy, artefacts and paintings on show. Admission isn't expensive so I'd advise you to go see for yourself and then you can write a better review than me depending on what you think.

A Little History Lesson. Many people wonder if there is nothing but Shopping in Hong Kong, but after a visit to Hong Kong Museum of History, it will forever change your understanding.Hong Kong has a solid historical background, starting from a small fishing village, transforming into a pirate bay during the Dynasty times. Then being a British Colony forever changed it role into a business hub and Major world city. Surviving through Japanese Occupation during the World Wars. And finally returning to China ruling under one party two system.Hong Kong Museum of History is a great place to learn about Hong Kong, you will learn amazing facts and history that even most locals have never heard about.Our last visit lasted 2-3 hour and we still haven't finished, hopefully you will enjoy as much as we have.
Do not missed out!. If you have time please do not missed this brilliant museum. It was a great way to learn more about histories of Hong Kong or even China.

Wish I'd given myself more time. I tried to fit this into a couple of hours and this proved to be a mistake. If you're genuinely interested in the history of Hong Kong, you could spend hours here. If you must do it in an hour or two, I suggest you review the galleries ahead of time and skip straight to what you want to see. You could spend an hour in just one gallery. If you happen to have been to the Royal BC Museum in Victoria, Canada, that will give you and idea of what to expect here. The more information-oriented galleries are contrasted with others that recreate aspects of the island's history, including a life-size recreation of a street in 1920s Hong Kong.As someone else said, the first couple of galleries are about the natural history and habitat of Hong Kong. Not terribly interesting unless you're really into that sort of thing, but there's a 10-minute movie that sums it all up if you have time to watch it. The environmental gallery is built around a life-size faux forest habitat with information on all the birds and mammals in Hong Kong trough out the ages. There's a short, but fairly interesting gallery on prehistoric Hong Kong, complete with a life-size model of what it might have looked like -- prehistoric men building rafts and so on. From there, you enter the gallery that takes you through Hong Kong under the various Chinese dynasties.I was a bit disappointed in this gallery,because it seemed a bit heavy on artifacts and archeological information but short on context. That is to say, I would've liked to have read or seen more interpretation about what life was like in Hong Kong under the different rulers. Instead you get a lot of "we found pieces of this in this location, this location this location and this location," without much analysis. Also, even though I studied Chinese history in University, I found it hard to keep up with the references to the different dynasties, aside from the major ones (those ones where China is split into several kingdoms I can never remember). Unless you've got them all burned in your mind, you may need to consult Wikipedia on your smart phone as you're walking through. It would be nice if the museum had a nice big timeline or several maps of different eras to help visitors orient themselves a bit.On the other hand, the Folk traditions gallery is just lovely. It recreates aspects of the lives of different minorities who lived in Hong Kong.I rushed through most of the galleries concerning the British occupation, the Opium Wars and the Japanese occupation as I was running out of time, so I can't comment on those I'm afraid.But the modern Hong Kong gallery is just wonderful....I life-size recreation of a 1920s Hong Kong street. I just wish that there was more information about the squatter village and resettlement homes. I've been fascinated by my reading about them elsewhere and wanted to see more at the museum.All in all though, I thought this museum was very well-done and well worth a visit. If you want to learn more about Hong Kong, this is a must-see. And I suspect you could even keep the kids amused here for an hour or two.
Very Nice. Nice to see the history, from day one up until today..

Not a must see, but a very nice to do. A very nice depiction of the history of Hong Kong. Well laid out and definitely User friendly. I don't think I'd have it on a must see list for a one or two day visit, but anything longer I'd take the time to visit - a couple of hours would be fine.
Excellent history of HK. Professional displays and extent of subject covered

Rush through the downstairs. Downstairs is all about the the geography and formation of hong kong (rocks and animals that kind of stuff)... its interesting but quite generic. Rush through and go to sections 3+ as these are actually about the political, social and anthropological history of Hong Kong and are very interesting.
Worth a visit. Interesting and well worth the visit. Wednesday you can go for free.

This will give you perspective. Hong Kong looks so new but I figured there had to be some history and a backstory to tie it all together. We found the Museum of History on the hotel map (oops! it's moved). It was a very nice walk down to the Star Ferry and we discovered the Avenue of Stars which was cool. We asked and was told it actually was very near our hotel. We walked there and skipped the 40 million years ago part and went right to the folk and more modern portion. It was very informative and way underpriced. It was well worth the time. We had to cut it short as we had dinner reservations but I'll go back again if I get the chance.

Worth a visit. A wonderful museum which easily fills in half a day. Visually, an excellent display which helps explain Hong Kong's rich history, up to the present where it explains it's SAR connection with China in 1997.
HK in context. The museum sets the scene of modern HK. Visuals and audio are great, themes are authentic and the history a tapestry.
School kids everywhere. It was set up nice, but there were school children everywhere.It's free on Wednesday
Interesting exhibition on currency. A special exhibition on local currency is now on, and worth a visit.
A must visit. If you want to put Hong Kong in perspective go here. It is a world class museum. Just a bit off the beaten track.The restaurant/cafe is soulless
Interesting. I found it very interesting. I was there about 4 hours. If I'd known I was going to be there for 4 hours I would have eaten first.

Great Museum. Its near to the Tsim Sha Shui area.. can reach by walk around minutes.. A lot of things are displayed here.. Nice park with a green flowers.. Clean place... Beyond this museum, you can see a victoria harbour at avenue of stars.. Great placd to visited when you are in Hong Kong...

Very interesting museum with lots to see. There was plenty to see here and all the displays were modern and upto date. There are models of life in the past and fullsize replicas of fishing boats and old houses, which you could walk around. There are lots of videos to watch giving the opportunity to sit down. The museum has displays showing Hong Kong through the years as well as displays of local customs and the natural history of the area. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit and found it very interesting. It is good for all ages and provides a cool place to go when the heat outside is too much!

Modern, interesting and well located.. Excellent modern museum. Get the free tour. They run at fixed times both in English and Chinese, check their website. I would have wished to learn more about modern history and less about ancient history but that is - I suppose - a personal choice.Definitely recommended.
Hongkong Museum History. There's nothing much to see. Few displays by each era.

I <3 HK history. The history of Hong Kong is fascinating and entertaining. The ex colonial power has more history per square kilometer than most European countries. The HK Museum of History encapsulates the recent (200 years) of history and give a good outline of political as well as day-to-day history of its citizens.

Both Tourists and Locals Like It. It's a museum with fun. You can see how Hong Kong was like in the old days, let you understand Hong Kong traditional culture and changes over time. It perfect place to go if you are travelling with kids. A friendly reminder, make sure you have got battery for your camera, you will take lots of pictures here.
Very modern Museum. really good museum with wide range of exhibits which were well presented with informative labelling.

A must see if you have time. We went on a Wednesday and it was a free admission day, as it was the school holidays also in Hong Kong it was packed. We have visited on previous visits and would suggest visiting not in school holidays, too crowded. The Museum is excellent my grandson was very impressed Master 11yr old

Sooooooo interesting. This is not a stuffy experience. Once day was simply not enough time to really explore the museum of History. The sets are just amazing and the stories so interesting. I will certainly go back for more.

Chinese Art at its Best. Exhibition diverse and factual. Audio headphones provided, at a small charge, for further information in the language of your chice. At the time of our visit items from the British Museum were on display.
All staff particularly helpful and very polite.
Hong Kong Museum of History. Really worthwhile, especially the later exihibits that give the history from the British occupation on. Free on Wednesdays although the cost is minimal

Great displays. One of the most interesting museums I have been to. We were there 3 hours and it wasn't enough. Excellent displays and videos tell the history of Hong Kong. Also it's only $10 and free on Wednesdays.

One of the Best Museums I have ever visited.. This is wonderfully designed and is full of colorful displays and videos. If you love museums and absorbing information this is a full day! I went a total of 7 times and found something new each time.Not to be missed. If you can't make it on the free day of Wednesday it is cheap enough to visit on the other days it is open.
Very good. Very cool museum. Lots to see and well layed out. I'd go back.
Museum of History-worth it!. I didn't know much about Hong Kong's history. It was fascinating and beautifully displayed. You could send a 1/2 day in the museum.

Don't miss this!. Although not rated high on the "things to do" list, it it a wonderful museum which traces life in Hong Kong from the beginning until now. They have created a wonderful museum for both adults and children.
Good for a few hours. Visited the museum and spent about 2.5 hrs looking around. (only intended 1 hr) plenty of information films in English and large displays with English discription.Worth a Visit.

Brillant place, not to be missed!. Brilliant place, not to be missed. And at a mere HK$ 10 entrance fee, it's a steal.The many sections on two levels are very well laid out. You can probably rush through the geology and natural history sections, but you will really start to slow down from the ethnography section in gallery 4! The exhibit about folk culture in HK is worth is weight in 24ct solid gold. It's colourful, interesting, captivating, and attempts to show the culture and traditions of the various ethnic groups that HK is comprised of. The recreation of various processions, a Chinese temple and Chinese opera props will have you spellbound.Upstairs, the four sections on local history cover the Opium wars, birth and growth of the city, Japanese occupation and the modern city/ return to China. Recreations of a pawn shop, a post office, a bank (man, is that really what HSBC looked like?), a herbal tea shop and early tourist posters are priceless. And there is also a full sized tramcar preserved inside.Allow for at least three hours to do justice to the museum. There is a large cafe at the upper level if you fancy a coffee and snacks, but it is a little complicated to find.Don't miss the HK Museum of History if you are ever in HK.

Hong Kong's History on the way. A great way to learn more of Hong Kong is to visit this museum. Admission is inexpensive and free during Wednesday. To be able to appreciate all the exhibits, you need at least 2 hours. But to finish all the short films included, I don't think that is enough. You need to watch the short films to understand more the history of Hong Kong.

Good introduction. The information presented is a little basic, but well worth the time if this is your first trip to Hong Kong. Although not in depth, it made me curious to learn more and prompted me to do a little more research on my own to learn about different aspects of the history. I hadn't realized the incredible transformation Hong Kong has undergone in the past sixty years from a very rural to extremely modern society. Coming from San Francisco where museums are $12 - $20 a pop, it's amazing to me that this museum is so inexpensive. There's a small cafe and wifi.I'd recommend against taking the guided tour, however. Even though we were a small group, the guide seemed to have a set "spiel" which she didn't wish to vary from. I would have liked to have been able to have more dialogue with her, but she didn't seem to have a very extensive grasp of the information. We ended up rushing through the end of the exhibit, and because it was my first day I was too tired to go back through on my own. I think 2 - 2 1/2 hours would be a good amount of time to allot for a visit.
Excellent Museum. This museum is well worth a visit. We spent over 2 hours just in the area with life-sized panoramas & life-sized figures of early Hong Kong history

If you are a history buff don't miss this jewel!. The boldly colored displays of old Hong Kong culture are breathtaking. We couldn't take sufficient photographs to capture everything. You learn a great deal about 'old' China through the lens of Hong Kong. A marvel.

Utterly fascinating. This is in Kowloon and very cheap to enter (particularly so for seniors).The way in which the island's history is presented is very clear, sequenced and visually-demonstrated. I was totally fascinated. We went inabout 11.00 and my wife said later 'Do youn think we should get some lunch?' I thought it was maybe 12.45 but in fact it wa s nearly 3 pm. It really gripped me and made the rest of my stay more meaningful, to know the history of the place. Near to an ok science museum and 10 mins from very good park

Good if basic history of Hong Kong. Attended one of the guided tours today, well worth going if you're in HK, it's next to the Science museum so you can two in one hit if you so desire. You can kill the History museum in 2 hours if you so desire. I enjoyed it, but found it a little basic.

Interesting and cheap. This museum does a great job of telling the history of Hong Kong in an interesting manner with lots of well done attractive exhbits in both English and Chinese. The special exhibtion on the monetary history of Hong Kong was also quite interesting.
A Must See!. The history of Hong Kong is well shown is this wonderful museum.
Great place to know about HK History.. A must if its your first time in Hong Kong. 5 minute walk from the MTR East Tsim Sha Tsui Station
visit on Wed. Free entry on Wed. Great museum with so many interesting statues, re-creation, best museum i have ever been, dont miss it.

Can't miss if you're into history.. I am a big museum fan but I was going to skip out on this place because I thought, what could be so interesting about the history of Hong Kong? Boy, I am SO glad I didn't skip this place. The exhibits were excellent and very well done. It was huge museum and I really think you could spend a good part of the day here. From the prehistoric exhibits, the formation of the geology of Hong Kong, the mini-movie screenings, and insight into Chinese traditions, it really is a can't miss place to visit if you're in Hong Kong. Even if you're not a big museum fan, there are a lot of cool things to see. I regret not allotting more than a few hours to spend here and I would definitely go back.
Educational. A MUST see place at hong kong. well manage and also really educational.

Excellent. This reminded me of Singapore's museum of history and was its equal. It takes you from prehistoric Hong Kong through the different Chinese peoples, the British colonisation, Japanese Occupation, the British planned Economic boom of the post war years and finally the return to China in 1997.I think this museum captures the spirit of Hong Kong in that it is China but it has it's own identity which was heavily influenced by the 150 years of British rule.I would recommend a couple of hours here. Very interesting.
Great Value and Super Insights. Great insight into Hong Kong history. Fast forward through the dinosaurs and geology though.Super value at HK$10

Opium Wars and Japanese Occupation. This museum puts a particular emphasis on the two Opium Wars in the 19th century, the Fall of Hong Kong on Christmas Day 1941 and the subsequent Japanese Occupation period that lasted three years and nine months.

Informative and Fun. The Museum of History is located near the Museum of Science though the Museum of History opens at an earlier time (around 10AM) while the Museum of Science opens a bit later during weekdays (around 1PM).The Hong Kong Story provides a fun and informative tour of the history of HK, starting from the geologic processes that shaped the HK islands up to modern times. Interactive videos and films are available throughout the exhibit. English or Japanese speakers can avail the audio guide for just 10HKD though most of the panels and films do have English translations.I thoroughly enjoyed the presentation of artifacts from archaeological researches throughout the island. I also like the sense of continuity of the museum, giving you a feel that you are travelling through time. I spent more than 3 hours in this museum and I honestly didn't expect it to be that fun and informative. Tip: Best day to visit is Wednesday since admission is free.
A lot of history for a small piece of land. A real effort has been made to be exhaustive and to include environmental aspects.
Hong Kong Through the Ages. An excellent short history of HK from prehistoric times to unification.... very enjoyable

Very informative and very rich. Offers a lot of information and I like the way the museum presents itself using a timleine approach ranging from prehistoric times through Hongkong during the Emperors' era through to the British times, the Japanese Occupation and all the way to the present.
Could have spent hours here!. This is one of the best museums I've been to in a long time. Fantastic layout and great for kids too. A must for visitors!
Not Your Boring Silent Mausoleum. There was much to learn about Hong Kong. We stayed longer than our average for a museum.

Fantastic musuem that shows Hong Kong through the ages. Plan for at least 2 hours at this museum that shows Hong Kong's history. There are a few short films that are very informative also, broadcast in English, Mandarin, and Cantonese so you might have to wait or come back for your language, but they are very interesting.

Hong Kong 101, a must before embarking on vising other places in HK. The museum is a little gem hidden in all guide books about HKG. It has been dwarfed by attractions such as the world renowned Peak Trams; the new Sky100 on the Kowloon side, the Landmark shopping mall...etc. Little did i realize this little museum had so much to offer.The museum display is based on a one directional self guided tour, which you start with walking through the geological composition of Hong Kong dated to tertiary and Jurassic periods which explain why there are so many little islands in Hong Kong, then followed by a path to archaeological findings in Hong Kong and Kowloon islands, which then outlines the history of some of the earlier settlers. Slowly, you walk through the path along with the history of time on the early HKG, how The British won the opium war that forced China to give up this region to The Empire which has made HKG what HKG is now, then you will see from the early light industry of making plastic flowers to the renaissance in the late 60's, 70's and 80's with a lot of photos and display of Made in Hong Kong industrial products which you can be very well familiar with. I recommend that you fit the museum visit in your itinerary and make it the first visit, after which you can relate a lot better to some of the places that you will visit---literally everywhere you see in HKG and its British overtone but with the populace primarily Cantonese is all explained in this museum. I deeply believe that a visit to this museum will make your trip more enjoyable. Cheers.
cheap and excellent. The streets and shops are laid out to show just what old H/K was like - fascinating and entertaining.

History that will Appeal to All ages. The Hong Kong Museum of History is well worth a visit if you want a foundation of the history of the city. Starting with natural history, ancient and early cultures, the dynasties, colonial period, modern times, right up until the return to the Hong Kong to the Chinese, the exhibits, dioramas and audio-visual components are appealling and easy to follow. I especially enjoyed learning about the early inhabitiants, the major festivals, Cantonese opera, the opium wars and the Japanese occupation. Interesting for all ages!

Enjoyed it Thoroughly. We did two-hour tour on a Sunday morning. The tour guide, who worked for the museum, was named Yok or York and he did an excellent job.You can learn a lot of scintillating history of Hong Kong here in a few hours and the museum is also full of photo opps.

Fabulous overview of Hong Kong - Must see for all visitors who care about history.. This museum offers a great historical overview of Hong Kong from prehistoric to post-British times. The British influence over several hundred years truly makes Hong Kong the great city it is today. We have visited this fabulous city both before and after the "handover" and have to say that he influence of modern China is serving only to tear down those things which have made Hong Kong great. See it now - before it's too late.
Very well Presented. Really enjoyed an afternoon here and learnt so much!
Great Way to Learn about Hong Kong. Excellent museum if you want to know more about Hong Kong's history.
Great overview of HK. An in depth study of Hong Kong through the ages, as a museum should. Folk exhibit of HK makeup of people most interesting. Spacious, bright, modern and free on Wednesdays.

A Must See Hong Kong Attraction. A fantastic museum to visit whilst in Hong Kong. We went in the afternoon the first time but didn't see it all as they close about 6pm so we went back a second time to complete all the exhibits. HK$10 entry ( HK$5 over 60's) FREE for all visitors on Wednesday's.Everything was immaculately clean and well presented with an astounding amount of information, so much to see, too much to describe on here, go take a look for yourseff you won't regret it... plus the best / cleanest public toilet facilities in Hong Kong ( so my other half tells me )I would definately put this near the top of my list of things to do in Hong Kong
The best museum here. The best is that it takes up all sides of the history, not only the glamourous parts!

A lot of history for a small place. I visited this museum with low expectations but came away from it with much more than I ever knew about this city, where I have lived for many years. In my opinion, what they've done best is not focus only on politics or sociology, but also on geology, geography, culture, and even daily living as it was in the past. All this is organised in such a way that you walk through the museum following an actual timeline, from the earliest pre-habitation days up to the recent past. Many different reconstructions allow visitors to feel like they are in the middle of things. A good gift shop and coffee shop are there also, and the whole experience was really positive. It's not just for visitors to Hong Kong, but also for local and expatriate residents. Very highly recommended. Maybe go on a weekday, if possible, to avoid some of the crowds.

Revisited the museum with family. My family members enjoyed the museum thoroughly and we gained an in-depth understanding on the island of Hong Kong through interactive videos and displays. The admission is HK10 per adult and it's free entry on Wednesday. Hop over to the science museum which is just opposite the history museum if time permits! You can take a bus outside the museum to head to Avenue of Stars and other attractions around the area.
History of Hong Kong. Very interesting exhibits. Worth while to go & see. Free adminission every Wednesday.

very interesting. This is a very well presented museum about the origins of Hong Kong from the very beginings of time to the present day. It is free on Wednesdays but is well worth paying the small entrance fee.

Fascinating background to Hong Kong history and culture. We found this museum well laid out, interesting and enjoyable. After many business trips to HK we finally found the time to visiit this museum as tourists and loved it. The cultural life of the indiginous Chinese groups living there before mass expansion was fascinating, as was the story of the British development.

Stunning-don't miss it!. Wow! This museum is well worth one visit and I will go again next time I am in HK. An incredible amount of information of all sorts-geology, natural history, history and culture. A street of old Hong Kong has been reproduced inside the museum as has a sampan which you can climb on and see what kind of space sampan families occupied. Just too many experiences to list. Go see for yourself. Free admission on Wednesday but well worth the price on other days.

Best museum in HK. If you want to understand HK's history, from ancient times all the way up to the Chinese handover, run, don't walk, to the Hong Kong Museum of History. This very well curated museum has an absolute plethora of information and flows very well from exhibit to exhibit. Give yourself at least 3 hours to fully digest everything here.
Lovely break from the commercialism outside. Lovely museum, well done. It was nice to remember that HK has some natural history as well as the hustle and bustle of business outside

A very well presented history of Hk. The presentations in the museum are colourful and brilliant. Worth a visit at the beginning of a stay in HK as it provides of a good background for all further explorations of this great and vibrant city. It is not boring in any way. Easy to get to (frequent bus 5C from the Star Ferry terminal in TST).

Highly recommended. An interesting exhibition and well worth a visit. It was really close to our hotel (The Icon) so for us it worked well to do it on our last day. A good overview throughout the building of where what is, so you can see or skip as much as you like. And cheap, cheap, cheap. I think admission cost like only HK$10 !

Absolutely wonderful museum. This museum is probably is probably the best one I have ever been to. It takes you through the history of Hong Kong from pre-historic times to the modern day handover from Britain back to China passing the opium wars and slum regeneration on the way.Its really well put together with a range of stunning displays, artefacts and video displays.You can easily spend a whole day here.
"Fantastic". Well worth a visit. This is very well set out and explains the history of Hong Kong very well. Very colourful displays. Great for kids.
