Very informative and accurate. The area displaying the various ethnic groups of Hong Kong was very interesting. Being of Hakka descent, walking into the Hakka house was like stepping back into my Grandmothers house. The gift shop could do with being a little more relevant to the exhibitions but all in all a worth while afternoon.

Excellent Museum!. This museum is a wonderfully interesting and enjoyable way to spend a good part of the day. It's done very well and you really learn all about the different periods and aspects of Honk Kong! Good for the whole family

A Very Interesting Museum. This was a very interesting museum and I highly recommend making time to see it. It gave a great history of Hong Kong which were illustrated to great effect with the dioramas. Those were my favorite aspect of the museum.

A great Sunday afternoon. One the first places i visited when moved to HK, and although not a die hard museum fan I was impressed by the sheer size and set up taking you through from the archeological beginnings to life size replicas of villages, ect, through to the 50s/60s/70s. Definitely a must see.

Want to learn more about HK's history?. Very interesting, particularly the information about the opium wars and the beginning of HK. A lot there I was not aware of and the presentation was clear and absorbing. The section on WW2 and the Japanese occupation and then surrender was likewise exceptionally well done. We spent a whole afternoon there and still feel we did not do it justice.

Too short and superficial. Compared to the National Museum of Taipei, this museum is very small and pretty empty. Are there so many events in Hong Kong history that might hurt someone's feelings somewhere? Why is it so politically correct and dull? Isn't there something to show about the Opium War and claim loudly about the Japanese occupation? Not much to say about colonialism either huh? Everybody was nice, everybody was beautiful. C'mon, have some historians with guts to work on it, there are many things to say.
Good way to spend a couple of hours and not spend much!. Some great exhibits and ridiculously cheap $10HK! If you have some free time and like history check it out.
Worth a visit. The history of Hong Kong before, during & now after British colonial rule
great museum. very interesting -- planned to spend an hour and ended up spending four hours because it was so interesting
Great museum for overview on how HK came to be.. Lovely infomative displays a short walk across pedestrian bridge 2 blocks from hotel, free on Wednesdays.
OK when it is free entry.. Not as extensive as I had imagined but well signed and interesting.
Hong Kong's History. You must visit this Museum - it is well laid out and very interesting
Much more interesting that expected. Learned so much about the area and culture. Life-sized diagrams made it so much better. There were many video rooms to enhance the experience.
Great family activity. We enjoyed the Hong Kong Musuem of History, lots of interactive things for kids to enjoy.

Interesting for a peek back in historical Hong Kong. Unlike other museums where there are merely slideshows, pictures, there are mock ups of actual streets from the 1950s, a junk-boat and so forth. It makes for an interesting afternoon, even if one doesn't really care for history.I would recommend this to anyone who is in hong kong for a few days and want a break from endless shopping malls.

Great visuals accompany intersting history stories. I visited this museum because I saw it rated fairly high on TripAdvisor and I am glad I checked it out.The entrance fee is peanuts and the place is layed out in a smooth manner with short videos that are placed throughout the tour.The further you get throught the museum, the better is becomes. They really did such a great job with this place. I suggest visiting this museum after you have checked off the victoria peak and some market shopping.

Average museum, wouldn't rush to visit.. A good stop while around the TST area only after you've seen the other must-sees in HK. I think it came to a couple of US dollars for entrance so for that price, it's an easy go-to spot if you want to do something a little more low key ans slower.
Gateway to the 1960s!. The exhibits on life in the 60s was so cute. Typically Hong Kong.. in it's heyday! Get the museum pass and visit the different museums for a good look into Hong Kong!

Unbelievably interesting!!. We were pleasantly and more...surprised! And very glad we didn't miss it. Right from the word go, it was very uniquely interesting. And the excitement just went on increasing as we went from one section to another very creatively brought to life. An excellent insight into the history of this country and very well put together. A must do for everyone. Children too would love it.
Fascinating. A well organised walk through a museum. Seeing alot of the old hong kong/chinese artifacts and the new. Reasonably priced.
Well done. All you need to know, well laid out. Perfect for a rainy day.
Great museum!. Great museum to check out if the weather is bad. Very informative museum with beautiful displays.

Fasinating story of Hong Kong. This is a terrific museum -- the walk through history of Hong Kong tells its story with style. And by "walk thorugh" I mean that, you are literally immersed in its world(s), Aim to spend a couple of visits here, as it is a lot for one. Not expensive -- and free on Wednesday (but school children then become a hazard).

great focus on british and chinese handover. i think it's the best museum in hong kong, considering how young the country has been. what's interesting and iconic about hk is the handover, and the muesum does it pretty well. The only inadequacy is how little the rest of hk covered - i would have hope to know something more than the handover.
impressed. go on wednesday and it is free nice old historical film which I likeand refresh my childhood memory
Good fun. i thought this was actually really great fun. Was at a bit of a loose end on the last day and did the odd museum - thoroughly enjoyable!

Very Good Museum Especially the 2nd Floor. This museum is one of the seven museums included in the weekly pass that costs less than four US dollars (can you say bargain). I gave them a very good rating based on admission price, allowing photography in all areas, and providing a free English speaking tour. Went on a Sunday and walked around before the start of the tour.Especially enjoyed the exhibits (opium wars, birth and growth of the city, Japanese occupation, modern Hong Kong and its return to China) on the second floor and the folk culture exhibit on the ground floor.
Fabulous - best afternoon spent in years.. Don't miss it, worth every HK$ of the entrance fee. Not your average stuffy boring museum.

A definite must-visit!! Fun and informative. The staff is very nice, the gift shop has a nice selection of gifts. The entrance fee is so reasonable. Plan on staying for several hours - one of my friends stayed 5 hours!! It is a wonderful place, sharing the history of Hong Kong. You will be happy to have placed this museum on your itinerary. Although it nice if it rains out your other plans, it is certainly one of the better history museums I have visited.

Good displays. This is a good way to get an overview of the region and its culture. It might be ok young kids - there are some interactive things to do but it is also a place where you look but dont touch so some may find that frustrating.

A wonderful find. The museum is one of the best we've been to in Asia. We weren't planning on visiting a museum but glad that we stumbled upon this one as it had lots of interesting displays and plenty of photo opportunities.

Well Done!. I love history, so knew I wanted to check this place out, but my boss is more into shopping, food, and wine. He also loved this museum. It's very well done: Great exhibits and explanations. There is a good flow to the museum and you leave feeling you understand quite a bit more about all that has taken place here. If you like history, I'd also recommend the Hong Kong Heritage Centre in Kowloon Park--the 13 3-minute videos on life in old HK were great!

Amazing museum!. If you are going to only visit museum. The Hong Kong Museum of History is the one to see. Its usually $10 admission but it is free on Wednesdays but still well worth the money. . This museum covers everything from the physical creation of Hong Kong 400 million years ago during the Devonian Period right up to the present day. Covering everything from Hong Kongs customs, lifestyle, entertainment and people. I really enjoyed the pottery section and information on the Opium Wars. I would recommend around half a day to see everything here. This is a must see!

An Incredible Museum, outstanding in every way!. Last week while on hoilday in Hong Kong I decided to visit the Museum of History.I was so amazed by this museum.The entry fee of 10 HK dollars was worth every cent.Entering the museum you enconter amazing exhibits depicting prehistoric life in Asia.The exhibits are beautifully presented and walking through the Museum you see amazing artefacts and exhibits from different periods in Hong Kong's amazing history.Most of the exhibits are really clearly labelled and photography in the Museum is permitted which is a great bonusParticularly interesting is the section on the opium trade with Britain from the 18th century.A wonderful feature of this Museum is the number of movie theatres in the museum which show really interesting historical documentaries at regular intervals showing various interesting aspects of Hong Kong's amazing history.The museum gift shop has some beautiful souvenirs which make your visit to the Museum ma really memorable and special, indeed an experience to cherish This Museum is truly incredible and a great place to visit in Hong Kong!Don't miss it!! It;s too good!! Andrew

Great place to get a better idea of Hong Kong history.... It's quite a good collection, particularly the section from the arrival of the British to present... If you are interested in Hong Kong history and have some time to spare is definitely worth it, also because tickets are quite affordable.

What a great place to visit. This was well worth the entry fee, it gave a chronological view of Hong Kong from the very beginning through to the handback to China. Very well laid out and easy to skip the bits you dont like. Had trouble finding it but that was partly our fault in that we missed the stop on the bus and walked around in circles! The cafe did great snack food. Found the obligatory gift shop OK good mix of things and great variety of price but found the staff a little bit terse!

One of the best history museums in East Asia. Hong Kong Museum of History offers a range of approaches to the topic, from natural history and archaeology to cultural and popular aspects of social history. While Hong Kong has done a poor job of preserving its historic fabric, the memory is kept alive by informative and resonant displays. Be forewarned, however, that it blends real artifacts with reconstructions and simulacra, which may be problematic to some.

Great Museum. I have been to a lot of museums and work in the field of history. This museum is incredible. The sheer scale of the museum is staggering, with ceilings over three stories tall and entire buildings reconstructed inside. The interpretation is also interesting, particularly if one knows anything about Hong Kong history or public history. There is certainly a pro-Chinese take, and some anti-British and anti-Japanese interpretations. For instance, an eighth of the museum is dedicated to the little over three years of Japanese occupation. The section on the Japanese occupation is brilliantly done, with the entire architecture of the space changing from the rest of the museum to create a feeling of oppression. The museum costs only $10 HKD and is free on Wednesday. It would be easy to spend at least a couple of hours there. This is among the better history museums in the world.
Confusing...but worth it. The paths are not laid out properly, i.e. you can get easily lost in the exhibitions....but the stuff they have on display is pretty educational. Recommended.

A little kiddish. Found out a few interesting things about Hong Kong and it's history, but was hoping for something more impressive. Seemed like a very nice elementary tutorial on Hong Kong, which will be excellent if that is what you are looking for.

a fantastic place for all ages. like all HK's museums, it's cheap (free on Wednesdays), with discounts for children and elderly. It's one of the best museums I've ever visited anywhere. Not huge (which is good) but full of amazing displays of HK, past and present.........a great introduction to visitors to the city and a place to revisit over and over again for HOng Kongers.
Kinda boring. I love HKG history but the curators there are just so uninventive that it makes you hate your hobby.

The absolutely most engaging museum I've been to!. I am a high school teacher, and I know how difficult it is to engage students whose first reaction to anything is hormonal. Given that, even if you have no interest in Hong Kong, the interactive props and simulation of Hong Kong's history simply sweeps you off your feet for an adventure you weren't expecting. It isn't just the recreated fishing boats, tea shops, streets, documentation, or the concise shows that draw you in, but just the grandness of the place that is so out of character for space-conscious Hong Kong. They have something to appeal to every kind of learner, from sensory perceptions to artwork to historical details to geology. They spared nothing in giving you the most complete story I have ever discovered about a place. For about $1.20, this is one of the best bargains in a town full of them!

Start your visit to Hong Kong here. This is the place to start your first visit to Hong Kong. The museum's permanent exhibit "The Story of Hong Kong" explains the history of Hong Kong with amazing walk-thru dioramas. The exhibit is a little like a Michener novel: it starts with the very formation of the land millions of years ago and takes you to the (almost) present day. If I had it to do over, I would probably skip the pre-historic portions of the exhibit in order to spend more time on the later portions. The section that explains the four ethnic groups that settled in and around Hong Kong is simply amazing. The exhibit covers the history of Hong Kong well - examining colonial history, Japanese occupation, and the reversion to Chinese control. Oddly, the exhibit ends with the 1997 transfer from British to Chinese control. I would like to see some coverage of life since 1997. But a definite must-see for first time visitors. And museums are feee on Wednesdays.

If you want to learn a lot about HK in a short amount of time. This is a great museum, which gives a tremendous snap shot of the events which created modern-day Hong Kong. From the Stone Age to the present day, this museum does a great job of highlighting the key components of the HK story. There's a great exhibit on the Japanese occupation during WWII, and a wonderful turn-of-the-century Hong Kong village scene that all will enjoy. Some great artifacts on Sun Yat Sen, as well. And the large, open exhibit on the ground floor depicting Chinese Opera and neighborhood scenes is terrific. I could have stayed all day!

Not a must-see, but worth a short look. I like museums in general, but found the layout at the HK Museum of History to a bit too open. It's not very clear how you should proceed within each section (it's split into about 7-8 time periods) and I found myself looking at displays out of order. Having said that, there are very nice and simple displays all around, and I enjoyed the short video clips, which are nicely timed and informative. The sections on the Opium Wars and the Japanese Occupation were the most interesting.I rented the audio guide ($10 HKD) which you can do without...the displays all have enough information on them and I hardly used the guide (not enough prompts throughout the museum to actually make use of it). I'm glad I went through the museum, but if you're short on time, you can give this one a pass.

Very thorough. A must-see for any culture buffs out there, and this place is likely to take you a few hours to get through all the exhibits. Was great for my elderly mother-in-law who had never been to Asia before and wanted to know more.
amazing. everything was good and a great history lesson, very informative and a must see place
Exactly as the name says!. Gives a great overview of the history of Hong Kong. However, depending on the amount of time you have not necessarily going to be at the top of the list!
Interesting visit. We visited this on our final day in HK. Found it very informative. Clever displays and interesting short films screened at various stages.Well worth a visit if you have time.
Interesting Venue. There is a good exhibit on the history of HK, and good mock ups of HK in the past and some of the festivals in HK.

Wonderful museum. I loved the hong Kong story and learnt so much about China, the Opium wars, the 2nd World War and the Japanese occupation. It was a really well put together exhibition with lots to see and experience. And excellent value at $10 HKD

really interesting. I really enjoyed the museum, although there is so much to take in I got a bit tired towards the end at the stuff I found most interesting - think I would skip the first floor if I went again!

Worth a short visit. We are not museum people but this museum had some great displays and short movies that kept our interest. We watched a movie on HK culture and history and another on the Opium Wars.

fun. good to learn history of hk
tho it's a little museum
great fun
worth going if you visit tsim sha tsui

Don't Miss Out. This is highly ranked for good reason - it's an excellent all-weather way to learn everything you need to know about this fascinating place throughout the ages, including its geology, inhabitants, culture and much more besides. With its well laid out and clearly labelled exibits, many other museums throughout the world could learn much from the HKHM's example. And it's virtually free to get in (HK$10). Allow at least 3 hours to do it any justice at all.We were in HK for a 24-hour stopover and do not in any way regret spending many of our waking hours during that period at the museum. It opens at 10am and bear in mind that it's closed on Tuesdays.

Good experience. Needs 3 to 4 hours to see everything. Excellent way to understand Hong Kong's interesting past. Well laid out, high quality, and interactive exhibits from prehistoric times through to present day. Looks from Chinese and European perspectives. If you get hungry half way through you need a re-entry pass from a security guard to get to the cafe which is external to he exhibits. Cafe menu looked good but not impressed with the quality of the food or the service.

Fun for everyone!. HKHM is a fun way to learn about the history and culture of hong kong in an interactive way. The attractions themselves are very fun- you feel almost part of the history. My personal favourite is the little comic stall which is based on a famous hong kong photograph. It is suitable for all ages, and has history from all perspectives (such as war, the market and even toys)! and i would recommend this to anyone (it's even free on wednesday).
Very interesting. This museaum gives the tourist a good introduction to the history, culture, and political environment that characterizes Hong Kong.

Love this museum!. Not the most coherent story of Hong Kong, but GREAT fun -- interactive, walk-through exhibits, good short films, friendly staff... we have been to this museum many times and always enjoy it enormously.
Very Good. Opposite Science Museum. History information from Pre-historical era. Very impressive replica items.

A worty place to see and visit. something new to a visitor and worth to visit, a good place to access and convinent location, its just nearby everything, an addition to local programme, snap taking area a must for everyone, some benches are theere so if you wanna rest go rite ahead & visit the Hk museum of History
MUST SEE ON YOUR ITINERARY. But if you have limited time, skip through the first rooms unless you are a geologist
Special Exhibition. Saw special exhibition on the history of the Chinese examination system and enjoyed it very much.

Fantastic for visitors!. What a great history museum! The Story of Hong Kong literally begins in prehistoric times (fascinating for the kids), moves into ancient China and local ethnic tribes, then the arrival of the British, the Japanese Occupation, and into modern times. We spent between 2 to 3 hours there and found it very worthwhile. Since the grandparents are from HK, my kids found the Japanese Occupation period especially moving . They have a wonderful kids' activity room about two thirds of the way through where the kids can rest there feet and do some educational crafts.

Away from crowd. It's only HK$10 for admission and you can easily spend 2-3 hrs educating yourself. Big place. The admission fee includes any special exhibition that is currently on. Worth it. If you are from Hong Kong island, take any bus that cross the tunnel and get out at stop immediately after tunnel crossing. It's nearer than going thru TST MTR.

A great little history museum in Hong Kong.. The Hong Kong Museum of History is an excellent little history museum. It chronicles the history of Hong Kong from the earliest inhabitants through to the present day. The exhibits are authentic and incredible.

Free English tour at weekends - well worth it. The museum covered a long period of history very competently, and the mock-ups of boat homes and traditional courtyard houses were interesting. There is a free tour in English at weekends and our guide was brilliant. She had total, genuine enthusiasm for her subject, spoke better English than I do, and was thoroughly engaging. Hearing stories from a Hong Kong native really made this museum accessible on a human level.

What everyone should know about HK.. Although we have visited HK many times, this was our first visit to this museum. A pleasant surprise. HK's history seen from many angles...Opium Wars, Chinese dynasties, WWII, Japanese occupation, 60s-70s, shipbuilding, ethnic folk culture, prehistoric, climate hazards. Modern exhibit design & enjoyable.
Wow. I recommend this to all visitors it is superb. Very well set out.

One of the best museums I have ever visited. We found the museum pretty much by accident while wandering around the area.Expected a 'typical' town history museum but were staggered by this one. starting with the geology - wonderfully done - it ges through the whole history of the area up to the handover from the UK to the present time. My wife was brought up in Hong Kong and was amazed by what she learnt about a city she thought she knew well!We were there for almost four hours, if we had not been pretty tired after a 12 hour flight the previous day we would have stayed longer. I would not want to try to cover the whole place with children in tow. But it is so cheap (about 50 pence sterling, free some days) that you could easily take them a couple of times if necesary. It is so big that although there were a lot of people around it was never crowded.The cafe seemed to only cater for chinese style so we did not eat there so can not comment. It appeared rather disapointing in comparison to the rest of the museum.This museum is VERY well done and highly recommended.

Good place to kill some extra time on your itinerary. The HK Museum of History was great! We thoroughly enjoyed the early periods of the exhibits, including the culture section (number 4). We went on a damp and rainy day, and surprisingly, the museum was rather empty! (how lucky for us) I wouldn't suggest this place for someone who isn't really into culture or history, there are no "touch" exhibits, and it requires alot of reading like most history museums. My partner isn't big on history, but she loved seeing the traditions, culture and ways of life of many different decades of Hong Kong inhabitants. I would absolutely recommend this place to anyone who asks.

Fun Place. This is pretty interactive and although my kids complained, they did enjoy the visit.The complaints came mainly from my very timid second born - she dislikes cinemas for the darkness, gets upset and cries when the villians appear on TV, etc. May want to pre-empt a child of similar character before the trip as some spots in the museum can get really dark.

Good option on a rainy day. We went to this museum to pass some time on a rainy day. We spent about 3 hours here in the end! The museum is carefully laid out, and the exhibitions are clear and informative. As this is located in the same area as the Science Museum you can combine your visits.

A great overview of the history of Hong Kong. The musuem of history in Hong Kong has an outstanding display of the history of Hong Kong. Easy to spend 2 hours here. Make sure you get the earphones is the language you prefer. I found the story about the British Occupation to be fascinating. There are a number of opportunities to watch short films about the history of Hong Kong was well
If you're into Museums, this is good.. Decent amount of Chinese and Hong Kong flavour and history. Several sections, good gift shop.
Very informative. An excellent museum giving the background, geologically, geographically, and historically, of the area. Well worthwhile if you have a couple of hours to spend.

A Great Way to Learn about Hong Kong!. One of my favorite museums, it's a great way to learn about the history of Hong Kong from prehistoric to modern times. I especially love the life size recreations of boat and village lives, folk customs and festivals. I was able to spend only 3 hrs, but I needed an entire day. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to return on this trip, but I will be back on my next trip. Also, as others noted, this museum is a great value.
Must go, and only $10!. Got to allow at least 2 hours, a trip down memory lane if you used to live in HK.
Free entrance on Wednesdays.. Fantastic day out, when it was grey & raining outside. Great history about the handover.
Nice introduction to the history of HK. Great museum. Entrance on certain days is free, but it will be crowded.

An excellent rainy day past time!. First of all, on Wednesdays, the museums in Kowloon are all free. TA doesn't give you a choice, so I have checked "fee" because more often than not, you do have to pay a tiny price to enter!  I also checked that you should allow for more than three hours in this venue. I come from a city, that I believe,  to have the best museums in the world: New York City. I was raised on going to museums and so I am a bit of a museum snob. The Museum of History in Hong Kong is wonderful. It doesn't try to do too much and it is clear that they offer an overview of the history of Hong Kong. I agree that you can probably skip the prehistoric level, but they have films for the major history parts, so I recommend at least viewing the film in the prehistoric section as watching the animation of the land forming is fascinating. I appreciate that the museum has these films available in four languages, running continuously throughout the day. For the Japanese Occupation section, I stayed and watched that film in English and with English subtitles. This section was particularly interesting and well done!  There are plenty of WC facilities and they are clean. There are four floors accessible via escalators and ramps. Some of the lighting is not camera friendly, but photos are perfectly fine and you will want to take them! If you are tired, just catch one of the movies. There are also places to rest in between exhibits. The souvenir shop was well stocked and the proprietors spoke English; they also accept credit cards. Hong Kong's history is long and varied and this museums helps to condense most of it into an easily digestible history "lesson" including the two devastating typhoons that destroyed homes and started deadly fires. I spent 4.5 hours here and only left because hunger called. I would go back and I would bring my attention-deficit husband with me, as I know he wouldn't get bored here! It is also a worthwhile stop if you have already hit the touristy high points already. It is child-friendly as well, especially if you go on a Wednesday! I am tough to impress and I really enjoyed this museum. Please note: I think you have to walk the two flights of stairs to the main entrance. When I went, all other street-level doors were locked, thus forcing me to walk around the entire building. Some German tourists I met later, said they encountered the same issue.

Excellent value at this museum. My husband and I recently visited the HKG Museum of History - the entry fee was really inexpensive (from memory it was less than 5 Euros each). Great value here. The time line stretches from pre-history to modern day and although the museum was really crowded on the day we visited (it felt like there were 3 million school children there with us!) - the place is so spacious and so well-laid out, it was easy to get around despite the crowds. We spent a full morning there and could easily have stayed longer. Definitely worth a visit if you are even marginally interested in history.
Don’t miss it!. You would regret if you didn’t visit it! Admission is cheap, but loads of interesting things to see! My favourite was the City History. Fantastic work of HK people!

Fascinating exhibits, you will definitely learn something new. I spent my time exploring The Hong Kong Story, and a temporary exhibition "Examinations in the Qing Dynasty". Both were well laid-out with information panels in Chinese and English. There were some fun interactive exhibits such as lifting a replica broadsword used for military examinations, and sitting in an imperial examination booth. There are plenty of places to sit down and catch your breath, or watch a video while waiting for other members of your party. Everyone can browse at their own pace. I like its promixity to other museums, you can go around to all of them in a single day.

Best US$1 museum ever!. Not sure why this museum isn't busier. And I thought I didn't hear it correctly when the gentleman at the front said it would be HK$35 for our family of four! It was a fantastic overview of the history of Hong Kong, complete with walk through dioramas and at least a dozen small movie theaters with English subtitles. Even our kids loved it.

Well worth the nominal $10 entry.. Comprehensively covering Hong Kong’s history from its pre-historic beginnings to present day. The museum is split over several levels, is spacious, and includes a number of street recreations as well as original shop layouts from the Colonial era.Tip, when we were there (Friday AM) there were a number of school groups, largely unsupervised and quite unruly. If wanting to enjoy the museum to its full potential I’d recommend going later in the day.
seeing the past in the present. The permanent display is a good introduction to the history of Hong Kong. I found the Japanese Occupation period had been well presented
Bored?. If you have done Hong Kong before and are looking for something different, this will fill half a day easily. It was great!

Captivating and Informative. The Hong Kong Museum of History is definitely worth a visit. It held the interest of my 4 and 10 year olds, each of whom came away with some strong and age-appropriate messages and I learned quite a bit as well. There are short movies throughout and the docents were helpful in steering you towards them when they were about to start in English. The exhibits were fantastic and very colorful and while there may be different interpretations of various historical events the treatment seemed reasonably fair. The museum was filled with tons of school kids (who had a great interest in my kids which also made a nice cultural experience), which was a little louder and more crowded than I would have liked but not a big deal. If you have some time and want to do something other than shopping check it out. We walked there from the star ferry through Kowloon Park which was quite a good walk but also interesting and worthwhile.
you can easily spend half a day in there. most interesting exhibits about history from early settlers to modern SAR Hongkong.Excellent audio-visual information.Cleanest toilets.

One of the best HK museum. Just skip the prehistoric thing and directly jump into the city history(this are some more letters in order to fullfill the tripadvisor 300 letter policy. this are some more letters in order to fullfill the tripadvisor 300 letter policy. this are some more letters in order to fullfill the tripadvisor 300 letter policy. this are some more letters in order to fullfill the tripadvisor 300 letter policy)

"The Hong Kong Story" A Must Visit for HK Cultural Experience. The Hong Kong Museum of History is a cheap (10 HKD or free on Wed) and fun look at HK history. It's a great place to visit in the afternoon, followed by dinner and the 8pm light show from Avenue of Stars.There aren't many "hands on" exhibits for kids (try the Science Museum next door instead), but the 2nd floor replicas of traditional HK shops and a sailing junk should keep them occupied for a little while.The museum is surprisingly large, and can take a long time to visit if you carefully wander through the whole "Hong Kong Story" permanent exhibits and watch all of the videos on Hong Kong culture. The ground floor talks about prehistoric history and the geology, which wasn't too interesting, but the 1st floor was eye-popping with a large number of carefully replicated traditional HK establishments (bank, shops, etc), a replica houseboat, replica houses, etc. If you're a photographer, you could probably spend all day snapping away (photos allowed but no tripods). Then there are various videos talking about the numerous customs and traditional celebrations when you want to sit down and take a break.The museum appears to be poorly marketed, as there were only a handful of visitors on a Saturday afternoon. Great value and a great experience!

An interesting museum for rainy days (free on Wednesday).. Not far from the Hung Hom train station and several bus lines (check the HKTB map for nearby bus routes). Kids will enjoy the exhibits, and parents will apreciate the videos.

Very informative. Very interesting place. And very informative about the culture and history of Hong Kong, I really liked it. Come on a Wednesday, entrance fee is free. Though it can bore a small child after a while, but there's a nice little tram for them to play inside.
Something else other than shopping!. Really nice and informative place to spend the afternoon, learning about th history of HK. My family really enjoyed this gem of a place
Not to be missed!. Excellently designed and very informative about the history of Hong Kong.
Interesting and Informative. Great way to learn about the history of HK. Really good, well set out displays. Free on Wednesdays.

Interesting but sterile. I spent a free afternoon wandering the HK Museum of History. Lots to see and I especially enjoyed the centuries old pottery and other artwork. The place had a distinctly sterile feel to it though and there were many employees keeping tabs on the visitors. I got myself into a little trouble taking pictures as apparently no pictures are allowed. Likely it posted in Cantonese, but that certainly doesn't help me. The gift shop had some expensive, but higher quality items than I had been seeing at other venues in HK.

Don't miss this museum! Great sights and sounds of old Hong Kong. Be sure to visit the Hong Kong Museum of History. It is very educational with very colorful exhibits of old Hong Kong. You can stay here looking at the exhibit for hours! I have been here once before and made sure I came back with my family this summer. You get to see what the storefronts look like in the 50's and 60's, old post office, old furniture from by gone era. There is even a replica of Cantonese Opera.It's a nice change from the hustle/bustle of the present day Hong Kong that is just outside.
Great for some insight in Hongkong history. If you want to learn about Hongkong history go visit this museum! You might want to skip the prehistoric parts. Free admission on Wednesdays.

Time well spent...... I will recommend Museum for those who has extra time to visit HKG. You need a good four hrs. It introduces HKG from pre-historic era to present day HKG and also the cultures of HKG. Of course to skip sections that doesn't interest you. A replica 'c-store'(present day known as convenience store) with bottles of Vitasoy and Green Spot.... I just 'WOW'... that's really reminds me of my childhood. A job very well done by the folks who designed & implemented them. Definitely worth the time.

If you think this is another dusty museum... How wrong you are!. I have been here before with my friend, but because we came in quite late, we only managed to do one section and then, they shooed us out. So coming back to Hong Kong, I really wanted to see this again! This time I had to drag my aunt with me, who really really is not a museum person because she thinks it's boring. For 10 HK Dollar, you can see how Hong Kong evolved into the current booming awesome city it is now! Even my aunt was excited and tucked me to go ahead. especially the part that reminded her of her own childhood was something she really enjoyed, like the cinema, the stores, ... All of the replica's there are so nicely put together. It really does make you feel like you made a journey through time. For all the non-Chinese people, this museum is a very nice one to get in touch with the Chinese culture. From wedding ceremonies to British occupation, etc... it's like getting a crash course. There's also a special exhibit every now and then. When I came there, it was about daily life during the Mao Zedong regime. Last time with my friend, they were talking about the Revolution in 1911. So definetly a must see! We spent 3 hours in that musuem!!! And I wouldn't get tired of it! Next time I go back with my family, I will take them there again!!!You can reach this museum by subway, but it's quite far away, so for those who don't wanna walk. Just take a cab. And for those who don't mind like me... Just follow the signs. It's REALLY obvious.Have fun!!!

Very interesting and free on Wednesday!. I loved this museum, it was very interesting and complete and explains so much about Hong Kong. It is very engaging and also definitely one I recommend for children, as those I saw all around me, seemed to be very entertained.And it is worth paying for too.

Wonderful introduction to HK!. This museum is a great introduction to HK - go there on Wed (I think) where there is free admission!It is quite a big museum so one needs to allocate some time to appreciate the exhibits - what I liked very much is that it also features the geophysical aspects of HK which is pretty dramatic! And of course, the history of HK!A MUST VISIT!

Fascinating museum. I have visited this museum twice - on this occasion I skipped all the pre-historic and archaelogical stuff and went straight for the social and folk history. An interesting display of costumes and displays related to Chinese culture. There is also a very interesting seciton about the Opium Wars and the Japanese Occupation. Well worth a visit - also, if you go on a Wednesday then it is free to get in.

Amazing Hong Kong Museum. I have been visiting some Museums in Malaysia, Singapore, Australia and recently was Hong Kong. Hong Kong Museum is the wonderful tour I never had before, the location is just opposite of science museum and is free-of-charge every Wednesday. I was there on Wednesday, so no need to pay ....haha.I had spent about 2hrs in the Museum. Basically, If you really want to know about Hong Kong's history and other aspect, visitors should spend about 2-3 hours in the Museum. I left Museum after 2hrs as I was rushing to other places, by the way, I was not finished the everything in Museum.I really like the presentation here, they present very full picture of Hong Kong's development from ancientry to current. We can easily know the history clearly. Also, there are not only the things presented on the table, but they present films to attract the visitors, interesting films.However, you will feel boring if you are not interested on learning the history. All depend on your interest.Regards,Heroes19http://newzealand-paradise.blogspot.com/
A very educational visit. Entry is free on a Wednesday and make sure you have at least a couple of hours to spare so that you can see all the exhibits and some short films

Clever museum. We went to this museum with kids 11 & 14 the day after a typhoon as the weather was still a bit dodgy. Ridiculously cheap, $10hk adult, and even free on Wednesdays.A good bad weather day thing to do, or if you're really sick of markets, but otherwise I would think there are more fun outside things to do.I found the museum clever in the way it was set out, via epochs and eras, and you start back in the primordial ooze of Hong Kong, and make your way forward in time to Modern Hong Kong. It covers 9 eras, ie 9 sections. I enjoyed the fossils, and geology, the stoneage and archaology the most. Probably the modern stuff the least. But maybe would have liked it more if kids were more interested. They liked it but didn't love it. It was enough after 2 hours. Expensive gift shop.Overall great museum, just the right kind of info, presented cleverly with great displays and 'real' landscapes etc. (real ancient street, 'real' bamboo jungle, etc.)

If you are interested in geology and other historical subjects this is an excellent choice. Excellent museum to get info about all the history of Hong Kong, from geology to opium war. Informative audio tour in good English; nice movies about different subjects. Good lay- out.
Not to be missed. Great museum. I went there twice and enjoyed it both times! Go when it's free admission.

WOW!. A friend of a friend recommended this museum, and I was definitely uncertain when I ventured through the doors. This museum, however, is designed to be informative and entertaining. I had planned to only stay an hour, and ended up staying for at least 3. The layout of the exhibitions takes you through the history from the rocks of HK through the end of the departure of the British in 1997. All of the displays are interactive and there is a heavy emphasis on different types of media. I learned so much during my visit to this museum and loved the installations as they gave a genuine feel to every time period of HK. I highly recommend visiting this museum, especially if you aren't a museum person. Not only does it give context to so much of Hong Kong's culture, but it builds your understanding of what makes Hong Kong exceptional.

Worth A Visit. The Museum has interesting sections. There is a geological survey of the city of Hong Kong.While we were there the Museum had an exhibit on life in Hong Kong during the 20th Century up thru World War II. It was well-done and informative. It is worth a visit of a few hours.

Must see if you're interested in HK. Not on the main tourist trail but a true gem for info on HK. I grew in HK back in the 80's but learnt a lot from the museum on a trip back with the family last year.Very well laid out. Price is a bargain. And so much to see. I'd forgotten all about the bun towers from the Bun Festival but the display brought it all back.HK through the ages!
Very impressive. A very good museum. The best history museum we've ever been to. Very cheap entrance (and free on Wednesdays).

Excellent Museum - Must see if interested in Hong Kong. After reading other glowing reviews, I expected to spend up to 3 hours at the museum. I actually spent 6 hours. Rent the audio guide for 20 HKD which is well worth the cost. Be warned, that if you listen to all the stops, you will spend a lot of time at the museum. The museum goes through 4 major periods of Hong Kong. One of the more fascinating sections describes the 4 different groups that settled in Hong Kong - Boat Dewellers, Hoklo, Hakka, Punti.It is amazing to realize how far Hong Kong has progressed. From basically a 3rd world country after World War 2 to today's modern society's that is a hub for business/finance. I find it fascinating to learn why some countries/societies are able to develop so quickly, while other do not.I went on Wednesday, when all the "major" Hong Kong museum have free admission. Thus the museam was very crowded.
I loved it will be back. Excellant museum 5 floors of Chinese treasures I found very educationalI haveno hesitation in recommending this museum especially for children.Go on Wednesday free entry.

Informative and Hi tech Museum. Hongkong Historical MuseumThis is another worthwhile to visit in HK. It’s walking distance from TST. From Prat Avenue, walked through Granville Rd. Cross over an overhead bridge to HK Historical museum. The museum was located side by side with HK Science Museum. Entree fees of HK10 (Rm4) was a worth for money, it was a well designed and structured museum. Where it started with the early age of HK existent, in Palaeolithic age to the recent of handing over HK to China ( HK to be run by HK people). Inside the museum, you can be educated with a theatre show of HK folks shows , HK histories etc. In a well seated comfy chair, you’ll enjoy an educational and informative show. We spent around 2 hours in the museum and just before exit, there was a souvenir shop, where we can buy HK souvenirs.

Very informative, interesting, and affordable museum. This is a huge museum the details the history of Hong Kong from prehistoric times to present. There are exhibits about the different peoples native to HK and the area, and it has an extensive section on the time period of occupation by the Japanese, which I didnt' know anything about before visiting this museum. The building is huge with numerous exhibits--we only made it through the first floor before having to leave. Would have loved to stay, but we needed to eat lunch and the museum restaurant isn't very good.Best part: this museum is incredibly cheap! We got the student discount, so our total admission was the equivalent of about USD 1.25. Even w/o the discount, it's that much per person. Definitely worth a visit, and very easy on your wallet!

MUST GO!. This is the highlight of my HK trip.LOVED the musuem of history. It was so fascinating and informative. I enjoyed all the mini shows that explained the exhibits around the museums and it was truly fun and meaningful. I came out of the museum, gaining a deeper understanding of Hong Kong. I think we went on Wednesday, which offered free admission! A plus point is that the science museum is just beside the history museum! The science museum is another MUST GO place!

Fantastic, one of the best museums I have ever visited. We came to the Hong Kong Museum of History expecting to fill in an hour or so, and not really knowing a great deal about the history of Hong Kong. We were greatly rewarded. What an impressive museum- a visual feast. This is a must-see in Hong Kong to obtain a real understanding of how this city has evolved. It puts everything you have already seen and experienced in Hong Kong in to perspective.

Excellent. The Museum was fantastic.. It takes you right through the history of time for the reigon and was just beautifully presented. All the displays were so interesting. They had an English bank set up,also shops, boats, and amazing clothing and costumes that actors wore in plays. It is well worth spending at least half a day there. so much to see. If you go on a Wednesday it is free entry.

One of the best museums, anywhere. The Hong Kong Museum of History is fantastic. I have been to so many museums, all around the world, and this is one of the best. The exhibits are gorgeous and interesting. One thing lacking is hands-on stuff for the kids, which other HK museums do a good job with and would be so easy to do. Kids will still like it though. It's free on Wednesday's but even the regular price is cheap. It makes a great combination visit with the Science Museum just next door.

Absolutely great!. We had no expectations when we entered this museum. We where suprised by the low entrence fee of 8 HKD. Soon we realized that this is a high quality museum. It all starts how the rocks and nature of the Hong Kong area was millions of years ago. Then u walk forward in time untill the first humans setteled here. It keeps going untill modern time and history of the opium wars and english colony. Then ww2 history, japanese occupation and how modern Hong Kong grew untill what it is today. U can easily spend a day here!

Well worth a visit. I popped in here one afternoon thinking we could just have a quick look through the museum, although ended up spending about 3 hours here, and had to speed up our second half due to the museum nearly shutting. Was a very interesting experience!

An interesting musuem to visit. It is definitely worth visiting this museum to better inderstand this fascinating city. I attended the free guided tour in English at 2.30pm, which gives a quick sum-up of the highlights of the exhibition. However, this is quite limiting as it lasts 1.5 hours and the museum is far reacher. I went back to see the few films which complements a few section. Very educational but entertaining too. To visit during the first trip to Hong Kong!

Its really good! You should add this to your must-do/must-see when in HK. Excellent value for money museum. At HK$10, there is an incredible amount on display at the HK Museum of History for you to see. The place is huge with 7 galleries full of interesting historical displays and information. Gallery 1 -The Natural Environment: This is ok, a bit like a natural science museum, showing how the geology of what is now called Hong Kong has changed over the life span of the Earth. Its interesting but not as great as later galleries. The reconstructed forests and jungles are ok. Gallery 2 - Prehistoric Hong Kong: This is a pretty good gallery showing the life of pre-historic humans and their lives in Hong Kong. Its interesting and helps build up context for the next Dynasty gallery. Gallery 3 - The Dynasties: This is where Chinese history starts to mingle with Hong Kong and there are some nice artifacts, antiquities and even a tomb display helping to build context around China, Hong Kong and how they fit together, historically. Gallery 4 - Folk Culture in Hong Kong:This is a FIVE STAR display section with a Sampan (junk boat), salt fields, fish salting, Hakka style house, Punti (ancient locals) house, temples, Opera House, Dragon Dance, Bun Festival, the list seems to go on and on. This is the highlight Gallery of the downstairs area. The displays are well presented and enjoyable. The kids running around are evidence that even they can find joy in this museum. Gallery 5 (upstairs) - The Opium Wars: This area is very interesting if you want to learn about western (European) powers becoming involved in China. There is a very good theatre show (10 minutes) about the period leading up to the first opium war. The miniature figure model of the destroying of opium by the Chinese is really nice. This is the second or third best gallery 4. Gallery 6 (upstairs): Birth and Early Growth of the City: There is a wonderful display of many early Hong Kong shops, it looks like a village as you walk in and out of an old HSBC bank, post office, tea dealer, pawn shop, Chinese medicine shop, upstairs teahouse. You get a real sense for Hong Kong's early 20th century modernization and development, pre-Japanese occupation. This is the second or third best Gallery in the museum, along with Gallery 5.Gallery 7(upstairs)- Japanese Occupation: This is a small section but quite interesting if you want to know more about the short period of time Hong Kong was under Japanese rule. Few displays, mostly information you can read. Gallery 8: Modern Metropolis and the Return of China This is the last Gallery and covers the periods of Hong Kong's explosive period of economic growth, through the British hand-over to China in 1997. The gallery sort of stops after the hand over in 1997 but that is fine as you're going to be quite tired from seeing 8 comprehensive galleries. Overall, we strongly recommend a visit to the Hong Kong Museum for visitors, unless you are here on a 1 day layover and prefer to see a theme park or HK island sights only. We'd advise you to make time for this museum, especially if you're here for a week or so. There will most likely be at least one bad weather day, perfect for spending a few hours indoors. For HK$10 per person, this is likely one of the best value for money museums you'll find anywhere.

What a museum..... I read a lot of reviews about this museum and went there with high expectations and was not let down. This is a museum which is really not a museum - its more like listening to story of Hong Kong. The museum is laid out in the way that it starts the story from pre-historic HK to the current times. The pleasant surprise was a free guided tour in english @ 2:30 pm which is for 90 mins. The guide was wonderful and runs you to everything about HK, the people, the culture, daily lives, major events, etcThis place is a must go and not to be missed in HK.

Awesome family museum!. We almost didn't go.... had intended to go to the Science Museum which was closed and the Museum of History, across the courtyard was open. We intended to stay for an hour with our 2 kids (aged 6 and 9) but ended up staying for 4 hours! The kids kept going ahead and running back to us saying "Hurry! You have to see this!" The displays were excellent and easy to understand for us Canadians who don't speak any Chinese. Videos in each section helped capture alot of the information relating to the displays (and gave us a break from the walking!). Interesting to see the different perspectives on historical events!I would HIGHLY recommend this museum to other families whether or not they are from Hong Kong.
The Best HKD 10 I ever spent in HK. This is a must do if you have the time. It is conveniently located very near to TST.The museum is very well layout and surprisingly informative.

Take a tour!. I'm not the museum-type, but this one is clearly outstanding! There are free guided tours on weekends and public holidays at 10:30 and 14:30...If you are in Hong Kong for longer maybe spare it for a rainy day... Otherwise: Do it on day 1! You will learn a lot of things that make walking around on the city more interesting.

Great for non-museumy people. To be honest my wife and I aren't museum-type people. Our kids are 8 and 10 years of age and at THAT age where museums are cool. So along we went.Although my wife wasn't overly enthused I have to say I loved it there. I had a great time for 2-3 hours and in the end it was the kids moaning "where's dad nooooowwwww?"It's not too heavy and covers all the interesting things about HK from it's geology through to it's 1997 handover in concise detail.All up, excellent value and great for a half-day out in HK.

Surprisingly fun and informative. I visited this museum on a whim with my wife's 20-something cousin (who is a local). We both expected to spend an hour and ended up spending over four hours touring the museum. The layout is clever--starting with prehistory and the geology of Hong Kong and then proceeding through time in different sections. I particularly enjoyed the mid-20th century street, complete with shops (apothecary, grocer, post office) that have been moved in their entirety into the museum. As expected for Hong Kong the English explanations were virtually perfect. Interestingly, the English and Chinese texts were not always word-for-word translations so if you read both it is entertaining to compare them. The differences were benign: in some case the Chinese text mentions historical figures or additional details that Hong Kongers would know about from school but that would simply be confusing detail for non-locals. Also, the videos, and in particular those dealing with the opium wars and with the British colonial period (I'm not a Brit) are factually correct and critical but thankfully lack the over-the-top anti-foreigner hagiography that is typical of museum exhibits on the mainland. I highly recommend this museum, and suggest you visit it early during your holiday in HK as it will inform the rest of your visit. Tip: the museum gets a lot of school groups (all ages), who are there from about 10-2. If you enjoy their enthusiasm (as I did) visit in the morning. If kids aren't your thing visit in the afternoon--the kids thin out after lunch and are all gone by 2 pm.

Learn What Makes Hong Kong What It Is and Why. An excellent museum covering Hong Kong from Pre-History through today. Well done bilingual exhibits with multi-media give a good understanding of the geographic, commercial, colonial, and historic influences that caused Hong Kong to evolve into the fascinating place of today. Allow at least half a day. No admission charge on Wednesday. A scant 10 minute walk east of Nathan Road in Tsim Sha Tsui (TST) in Kowloon.

Worth a visit. The museum is a ten-minute walk from the Tsim Sha Tsui Metro Station and is well signposted. There’s a path to follow through eight Galleries that charts Hong Kong’s history from its geology and early inhabitants through its maritime and cultural heritage into modern times. There’s also a café and a special exhibition area. There are ten short videos showing in the different Galleries. Allow about two hours to walk around.

Hong Kong Museum of History: Wayyyyy more than you will expect!. “The Hong Kong Story” is the permanent exhibition for the Hong Kong Museum of History. Made up of 8 different sections, you essentially start at the beginning of Earth's creation through the turnover of Hong Kong. WOW! Hints: - Allow WAY more than the recommended 90 minutes- Don't miss the assorted videos throughoutFor more detail, see my blog posting: http://kmcoyle.wordpress.com/2010/10/11/hong-kong-museum-of-history-what-a-great-place-for-a-rainy-day/

Excellent place to visit, but allow yourself plenty of time.... I hear they have spent over 20,000,000 HK$ on this place and it shows. The whole presentation of the history and culture of China is done in such an interesting and visually pleasing way that you wish you had arrived at opening time in order to see it all before closing time.There are a lot of video presentation theatres in English or Chinese, wonderful exhibits of costume and even a full size "junk" in authentic setting, I particularly liked the Chinese Opera stage and costumes. Amazing! I am not really a "museum" type of person but I found this totally absorbing and interesting because of the way everything is presented. I just wish I had allowed a whole day to see it instead of 4 hours. Allow 6 hours if you want to read what its all about rather than just look at exhibits, and if you want to see all the video presentations, which are excellent.We both wanted to go back again when we return to Hong Kong, to go over the sections that we rushed through. The admission price is around £1 each, not bad for a great afternoon out!If you are limited for time, then cut out the beginning part, which is the formation of the earth and hong kong area as there is much more interesting things to see later, it gets better and better the more you progress through the museum. Dont miss it.
Highly Recommend. Brilliant presentation of Hong Kong's history. Very interesting and suitable for kids.

an insight into Hong Kong. We visited the Hong Kong Museum of History hoping to get a good overview of the origins and history of how the city had developed..The museum is excellent, taking one back through to the geographic and anthropological origins then through the development of Hong Kong through early Chinese History, to the Opium Wars and the British 'occupation', World War 2 and the hand-over to China. Brilliant use of contemporary photography as part of the exhibitions.

Good Place, don't miss it. This is a very educational place to visit. You will learn about the history of HK and a lot of the materials also apply to the mainland Chinese culture!! highly recommended. And its free on Wednesday ^_^!!

Probably my favourite part about Hong Kong. If you find yourself bored at the beginning of your tour, or if you don't have much time to spend there, you might want to skip the first 2 galleries, which centered on the geological evolution of the area (basically, lots of rocks), and prehistoric Hong Kong (a bit more interesting than the first, but I guess very similar to other exhibitions depicting the period) respectively, and move on to the rest. The exhibits were really detailed and provided lots of insight as to the locals' ways of life in the olden days and how Hong Kong progressed to the bustling city it is today. some of which you can still vaguely see around Hong Kong (especially in the Kowloon areas). There are artifacts on display as well as mock-ups of various "scenes" e.g. typical family home, sundry shop, school/classroom, café/tea room, holiday celebrations, and loads more. I spent roughly 3 hours walking around in the museum and it got very tiring (I am young and able-bodied, just to get it out there), and sadly had to speed up a bit towards the last gallery. If you are a genuine history buff and want to truly take in everything you see, consider making two trips down to the museum(or have a lunch break at the museum's café), although you probably won't be able to tear yourself away the first time round. There are guided tours and audio aids available but I found the write-ups accompanying each display to be sufficiently informative.

Hong Kong Story - excellent exhibition. Our family (including 3 children aged 9, 8 and 6) all spent a few hours ot the HK Museum of History to see part of the Hong Kong Story exhibition - more time would have been needed to see all of it. It is an amazingly well designed exhibit covering HK from its geological background (the least interesting part), right through to the current day.Our children particularly liked the cultural parts of the exhibit eg. Cantonese Opera, Cheung Chau Bun Festival and the sections about the main groups of Chinese people that settled in Hong Kong (where you could see the clothes, farms, boats, etc).The size of the exhition - and the time we spent on the first half - meant that we saw very little of the second half. Our children were ready to go elsewhere after the 3 hours we spent in the first half. If we had realised how big it was we would have moved a little faster in the first half (and skipped the geological section) to enable us to see more about the British and Japanese in HK.The exhibition is one of the best we have been to - no expense has been spared in putting it together.It is well worth a visit - if no kids you could spend a full day there - with kids a half day (could do the full exhibition by spreading it out over two visits). At just $10 HK entry for an adult it is amazing value.

Informative and Interesting. A real gem. Historical events were clearly explained; exhibitions were beautifully displayed. A must-do for visitors to Hong Kong who is interested in learning about the history of the city. Admission is unbelievably low, only $10 HKD.

The Hong Kong Story Exhibit: From creation to handover. This exhibit requires a few hours to complete so wear good walking shoes. It begins with the geological formation of HK to the 1997 handover to China. Both adults and children will enjoy the vast displays and admission is free on Wednesdays. Don’t’ forget to bring your camera!

There is always more to see.. My wife and I lived in Hong Kong for over two years from 1960. The museum was more than interesting, it was brilliant. We have been back to Hong Kong on a further seven occasions and each time we have visited the museum when it has been possible, the most recent time was in March 2009 and each time we have found something to add to our knowledge of Hong Kong. It takes you back to a more gentle time before the 'money-hungry' touts that prey on the tourists.The staff at the museum are very helpful and well informed and open to questions about Hong Kong.It is a 'Must See' place which entails a pleasant walk through a great shopping area out of the main stream shopping in Kowloon.

one of the best museum. On our first visit we took the free 90 minute English language tour (available on weekends). Our guide enriched our experience by his enthusiasm and knowledge. We returned later that same day because we wanted to visit some of the exhibit again, but found that a third trip was necessary to take in all of the movies (either in English or with English subtitles) that animated the exhibit.I would highly recommend a visit to the Hong Kong Museum of History for anyone visiting Hong Kong - whether interested in history, or not. At the very least, it's an air-conditioned, colorful, well-designed space. At its best, it instills one with a sense of the fortitude of the people who lived through some wonderful and terribletimes.To adequately appreciate the Story of Hong Kong exhibit, allot at least four hours for your visit. Because of the depth and breadth of information, I would advise multiple short visits. If the HK$10 entrance fee is a deterrent, consider visiting the museum on Wednesday when it is free. The museum is closed on Tuesdays.

Not to be missed!. This is one of the best museums I have ever visited. Come here for the remarkable range of historical and cultural information covered, for the outstanding presentation of exhibits and accompanying explanations, for the extraordinary intelligence that has gone into crafting an easy-flowing learning experience for you. I spent substantial parts of 2 days here (until my old legs gave out), and could easily have spent more. If you visit only one museum in Hong Kong, make this the one.

As advertised!. Yes - it's everything the other TA reviewers have said - stunningly good! We were there when there was also a "100 years of China" exhibition, so allow another hour for that - the old news bulletins on crackly old cinefilm and the many information panels with copious pictures were fascinating. It reminded me how terrible my modern history was taught at school. If you can leave without shedding a tear at the final video of the handover in 1999 you are indeed a hard man!! (sorry, person). 110% !! Waysidemen.ps - worth every penny - and we went on Wednesday and it was free!!!!

Go on Wednesday when its free!. We ended up with a free half day to fill in that just happened to be a Wednesday when entry is free! Covers the details and history of Hong Kong, including archeological finds. If you decide to visit the museum make sure you leave around three hours free.

set aside half a day. This is one of the best and most thorough museums I've been to - the exhibits are facinating and spectacular (inc life-sized houses, boats and fesitival sculptures) and the place is huge!

Go on Wednesday when it's FREE. This is an excellent museum. Make sure to see it in order because they arranged it in order from prehistoric times in the actual formation of the island, to the historic dynasties, to modern times covering Japanese occupation of Hong Kong during WWII, to the television revolution in the 70's, and finally to modern Hong Kong.You will learn many things you might not have already known about Hong Kong as well as a few things about the world from Hong Kong's eyes. Bring your camera, empty your memory card, and recharge your batteries. You will find yourself taking plenty of photos. There are movies in every section of the museum with a short 7-10 minute film relating to the section it is in. The films play in Cantonese, Mandarin, then in English. There is a clock on the wall by the auditoriums that tell you how long until the next showtime in the language you prefer.Make sure to go on Wednesday when it's free, but even if you can't make it on Wednesday, it is pretty cheap to get in. It's worth it, make sure you check it out.

Excellent lesson in the history of HK. If you have 3 hours to spare, this is a very educational place to visit. You will learn about the history of HK from some 300m years ago until today. A lot of the materials also apply to the mainland Chinese culture, which is an added bonus. Highly recommended.

It's an Brilliant Work of Love!. I would never have imagined that the government of Hong Kong could create an awe-inspiring museum such as this. It covers everything from archeology, anthropology, architecture, sociology, popular culture to animal and plant life! They have real artifacts from centuries and millenniums past, life-size mock stores and houses from decades ago, even a retired tram that you can walk in, and numerous movie rooms narrated in three languages elaborating on every aspects of the topics they cover.It was so well designed that all the life-sized models, the computer terminals, the displays, the short video rooms, and detail descriptions are always right there if you want them. Anywhere you stand there's a sight to behold.Yet you will not feel overwhelmed. You can just as happily spend a whole day there reading every fine print or briskly stroll through the main show pieces in 30 minutes -- but you will be impressed.

Excellent attraction - amazing value, and so much to see. The Hong Kong Museum of History is excellent. It’s a huge museum, and gives a ‘timeline’ of Hong Kong, through various tableaux, exhibits, recreations and films.I think it would appeal to all ages, and English was used everywhere. It was astonishingly cheap to enter (HK$10), and we spent almost three hours there. It would have been longer, but it was closing time.We did pay an extra HK$10 for an audio headset, but found that we didn’t really need this since the written information provided next to all the exhibits were generally sufficient.We highly recommend this museum to all visitors to Hong Kong.

The Best Museum in Hong Kong. This museum takes you for a walk through time. It starts at the very beginning when Hakka settlers from China came to Hong Kong on their live-aborad Junk boats. As you walk through the museum, there are various movie rooms, displays and recreations of old pawn shops or post offices which were typical in the colonial days. There are also many photos of old Hong Kong.Walking though this museum is truly an education in Hong Kong history. At the end of the tour, there was a film about the handover day back to China in 1997. I was in Hong Kong on this date partying in Lang Kwai Fong. The film about the handover day literally evoked so much emotion in me, that I almost cried.This is by far the most worthwhile museum to see while you are in Hong Kong. You will learn so much about the rich culture and history of this vibrant city.

Highly recommended. We had read about the Hong Kong Museum of History in the Hong Kong Lonely Planet Guide. We were especially interested in visiting the permanent exhibit "The Story of Hong Kong". We were so impressed withthe museum that during our 2-week trip we visited it three times (which was not difficult to do given the entrance fee is HK$10). On our first visit we took the free 90 minute English language tour (available on weekends). Our guide enriched our experience by his enthusiasm and knowledge. We returned later that same day because we wanted to visit some of the exhibit again, but found that a third trip was necessary to take in all of the movies (either in English or with English subtitles) that animated the exhibit. In "The Story of Hong Kong" entire streets are built into the museum to give a feeling of what it was like to live in pre-WWII Hong Kong. In the wing on Traditional Cultures a parade of statues recreates the Bun Festival on Cheung Chau Island. Cymbals, drums and Cantonese opera are heard in the hall.The Hong Kong Museum of History was impressive in the scale of its exhibits and in the depth of the information given. School groups of children were engaged by the interesting artifacts that they could touch and play on (like the sampan boat rebuilt in one gallery), and adults paused to read documents like the Treaty of Nanking. I would highly recommend a visit to the Hong Kong Museum of History for anyone visiting Hong Kong - whether interested in history, or not. At the very least, it's an air-conditioned, colorful, well-designed space. At its best, it instills one with a sense of the fortitude of the people who lived through some wonderful and terribletimes.To adequately appreciate the Story of Hong Kong exhibit, allot at least four hours for your visit. Because of the depth and breadth of information, I would advise multiple short visits. If the HK$10 entrance fee is a deterrent, consider visiting the museum on Wednesday when it is free. The museum is closed on Tuesdays.
